104. Be QUIET!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 11:09:21 -0000

Last night I noticed that when I try to cube quietly (because someone
is sleeping nearby) I automatically slow down and become quite
fluent/smooth during F2L and generally lock up much less. It works
much better than explicitly telling myself "boy go slow". Maybe that's
also a reason we hurry too much in competitions: because the sound
level is generally higher there and we have a tendency to match the
sound level around us (at least that's the case for talking).

Cheers!
Stefan





105. Re: 5x5 supercube parity
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 15:08:45 -0000

Hello !! So u mean in actual we have only 3 parity scenarios : 1,2 and 1+2 For 7x7x7 cube we would then have following scenarios : 1,2,3,1+2,1+3,2+3,1+2+3 (7 scenarios). That's exactly how i think also. No real need to look at cycle decompositions to prove this, thought that can be interesting in itself ;-) This extends easily to larger cubes of course :-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > > > That's why switching two outer edges requires also switching two "+" > > centers. > > I somewhat disagree, but that comes mostly because I don't understand > your desire to not change the corners. > > Summary: You have two causes that change the parity of several groups > of pieces. > > Outer layer: corners, Xcenters, +centers, middle edges > Inner slice: +centers, outer edges > > So there are four different parity situations because those two causes > can be combined 2*2 ways. Combining both you have a parity for the > outer edges but not the +centers. > > Cheers! > Stefan

From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 19:10:27 -0000

Hello all, May be this will help you solve it: http://www.puzzle.jp/keys/sudoku_keys-e.html This is not a solver but some explanations how to solve sodoku's Greets Alexander --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > Hi all, > > > > > > Last week, this Sudoku was posted in this group: > > It is difficult - I take it you've already put in a 6 (that part is > easy). To give you more idea of the difficulty, I gave a friend who > also does Sudoku another grid with the numbers 1,2,... on which > order to fill the squares in! (That was a while ago and he still > hasn't got the second one in yet.) > I don't know where you are in the puzzle, so I'll tell you this - > the second number to put in goes in the square below that I've > labelled with "@". The third one goes where the # is. > (If you get really stuck, I can post a complete solution that > explains how to get each step without trial and error.) > > > > > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 @ > > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > > 5 # . * . . 9 * . . . > > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. Can anyone give me some > tactical > > > advise on how to solve it? Seems I can't solve it without > > > trial-and-error... > > > > > > -Bram > > > > > > > > ================================================ > > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken > en > > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > > ================================================ > > The information contained in this message may be confidential > > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you > > receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the > contents > > herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. > > ================================================

Ron

113. Here's a start (Re: Solving Sudoku)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 20:41:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > Hi all, > > > > Last week, this Sudoku was posted in this group: > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 . > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > 5 . . * . . 9 * . . . > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. Can anyone give me some tactical > > advise on how to solve it? Seems I can't solve it without > > trial-and-error... > > > > -Bram This is a bit OT for cubing but anyway, here's the first few steps (to get the first 7 cells in). It's still difficult after this so there's still a challenge left but it still doesn't need any trial & error. Initial Grid: (above) For convenience label rows R1 to R9 (downwards), columns C1-C9 (left to right), boxes B1-B9 (right then down). 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a 6). *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ ***|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*1* 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 5**|**9|*** ***|***|*4* 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must contain 7. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ ***|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 5**|**9|*** ***|***|*4* 3. In B5, 1 and 8 must appear on the leading diagonal as they are already present in C5 and R5. Thus since 7 is in R5, 7 must occur in the intersection of B5 and C5. In particular in C5, 4,7 and 8 appear before B8. Thus in R8 4,7,8 must occur in C2-C4 and hence 4 lies in the intersection of C2 and R8. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ ***|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 54*|**9|*** ***|***|*4* 4. Thus in B4, 4 goes in the intersection of R4 and C1. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 4**|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 54*|**9|*** ***|***|*4* 5. Thus in C1, 7 must go in R9. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 4**|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 54*|**9|*** 7**|***|*4* 6. Recalling that in R8, C2-C4 contain 4,7 and 8, 8 must go in C3 (because B7 contains 4,7) and so 7 in C4. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 4**|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7**|***|*4*
114. Re: New record category: F2L (Average of 10)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 20:47:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Hi friends, > > > > I created a new record category: Solving F2L (Average of 10). > > http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_f2l_av10.html > > Great, I wanted to do that anyway, obviously Francois was faster ;-) > I'm gonna submit one soon and I'd really love to see the times of the > top guys... Hmm, actually I wanted to do an average-of-100, will do that soon (did an ave10 a few moments ago). One more rule suggestion: The cube should always be scrambled just like a normal full 3x3. And I'd like to ask everyone to not make exceptions. If I get a superb F2L I might feel the urge to complete the full 3x3 in order to improve my record in that category. But it would make the F2L average unrealistic if I throw out fast times this way. Cheers! Stefan
115. Re: Be QUIET!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 20:56:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@y...> wrote: > I've kinda noticed this too...that going slower actually will > eventually make your times faster...kinda a paradox, huh? (: Yeah but that was already well-known. What I tried to point out was that going quietly makes me go slowly, and it's much easier to tell myself to go quietly than to go slowly. Stefan
116. Re: New record category: F2L (Average of 10)
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 21:31:45 -0000

I was thinking about this category recently, so I think it's graet you started it. By the way; what's a good aaverage for F2L? I've done 12,18. Is 10 seconds as average reasonable? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friends, > > I created a new record category: Solving F2L (Average of 10). > http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_f2l_av10.html > > Would love to see some people post in this category. > > Have fun, > > Ron
117. Re: New record category: F2L (Average of 10)
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 24 Jul 2005 21:35:27 -0000

I have to admit that I'm tempted to solve LL with a really great F2L but I did stop once when I did F2L in 8,67. My record for the whole cube is 15,10 so I was a little angry with myself. /Gunnar Krig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> > wrote: > > > Hi friends, > > > > > > I created a new record category: Solving F2L (Average of 10). > > > http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_misc_f2l_av10.html > > > > Great, I wanted to do that anyway, obviously Francois was faster ;-) > > I'm gonna submit one soon and I'd really love to see the times of > the > > top guys... > > Hmm, actually I wanted to do an average-of-100, will do that soon (did > an ave10 a few moments ago). > > One more rule suggestion: The cube should always be scrambled just > like a normal full 3x3. > > And I'd like to ask everyone to not make exceptions. If I get a superb > F2L I might feel the urge to complete the full 3x3 in order to improve > my record in that category. But it would make the F2L average > unrealistic if I throw out fast times this way. > > Cheers! > Stefan

121. advanced LL edge control for CFOP
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 06:41:50 -0000

Hey everyone,

I know a very small minority of people are interested in learning
ZBF2L algs, but I'm trying to put together the ones that I think would
benefit CFOP solvers the most without having to learn too many algs.

I've come up with a proposal for an advanced partial edge control
method for the LL edges while doing the 4th c/e pair.

Macky already has all the algs to one of the cases I have too, so I'm
only adding one more F2L case (7 more algs). The total to learn would
be 13 algorithms, but they would help you to get all oriented edges
where most people would just use partial edge control.

I added a section at the top of my zbf2l page that describes what I
propose.
http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbf2l.html

Again, I find these algs to be incredibly useful, and I'd like to
bring to light the most useful ones that I think could benefit a CFOP
solver.

I also want to compile a list of all the shortest/fastest to execute
zbf2l algs. This would mean that instead of the regular f2l case for
a few rare cases, you could use an alg that takes the same amount of
time and get all oriented edges (and the best part is you would *know*
you will get all oriented edges before starting the alg).

Again, I'm just trying to make this stuff seem a little more
accessible and show the pros of what I'm really starting to believe
will be very useful algs to know.

Let me know what you think about my proposed advanced edge control idea.
Chris




122. 6x6x6 proto
From: "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 06:42:59 -0000

It was a prototype. It got stuck very often, and it had weird color
scheme. It took me 1 hour to solve centers, except 2 pieces.
My dad solved them. Then I started doing pairing, but I sadly messed
up centers. The inventor, Mr. Verdes, sends me one when it's ready.
Maybe 6x6x6 was so hard for me, because I have never tried 5x5x5!




123. UK TV Appearances
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 07:59:22 +0100

Probably those of you who actually get UK TV will already know but Tuesday
26th July morning there are some cube TV things going on.

Dan Harris and Jasmine Lee are going to be on ITV during the breakfast show
and I (Duncan Dicks) and my kids are going to be on BBC Breakfast (at around
8 am I believe).

We are all going to be at Hamley's toy shop later in the day for their
Rubik's Cube 25th Anniversary.

We are hoping to to get both TV slots videoed and maybe posted sometime.
Wish us luck!

Duncan

125. Re: [Speed cubing group] advanced LL edge control for CFOP
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 02:12:37 -0500

Hi Chris.

I think extending partial edge control to cases where the c/e pair isn't yet together is a fantastic idea and something I've been planning to learn. You've finally given me an excuse to get around to it.

It's helpful because 75+% of the time, my c/e pairs are inserted from one of those cases. This will make my partial edge solving much more efficient, and will probably eliminate my need for CLL+ELL for all cases except the final pair being solved before I orient edges.

Because of these last few posts, I'm starting to believe in the ZBF2L cause a little more. After I finish learning COLL and perhaps some CLL+ELL, I'll probably wind up learning ZBF2L now. Thanks. ; P

-Mike Bennett


----- Original Message -----
From: cmhardw
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 25, 2005 1:41 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] advanced LL edge control for CFOP


Hey everyone,

I know a very small minority of people are interested in learning
ZBF2L algs, but I'm trying to put together the ones that I think would
benefit CFOP solvers the most without having to learn too many algs.

I've come up with a proposal for an advanced partial edge control
method for the LL edges while doing the 4th c/e pair.

Macky already has all the algs to one of the cases I have too, so I'm
only adding one more F2L case (7 more algs). The total to learn would
be 13 algorithms, but they would help you to get all oriented edges
where most people would just use partial edge control.

I added a section at the top of my zbf2l page that describes what I
propose.
http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/zbf2l.html

Again, I find these algs to be incredibly useful, and I'd like to
bring to light the most useful ones that I think could benefit a CFOP
solver.

I also want to compile a list of all the shortest/fastest to execute
zbf2l algs. This would mean that instead of the regular f2l case for
a few rare cases, you could use an alg that takes the same amount of
time and get all oriented edges (and the best part is you would *know*
you will get all oriented edges before starting the alg).

Again, I'm just trying to make this stuff seem a little more
accessible and show the pros of what I'm really starting to believe
will be very useful algs to know.

Let me know what you think about my proposed advanced edge control idea.
Chris

128. EOCross
From: "thawk_pl" <tomahawk@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 14:41:25 -0000

Have someone ever tried to solve the cross and simultaneously orient
all edges?? This would make rest of F2l much simpler and faster,
also only ZBLL would be needed to solve the cube after F2L.




129. Re: EOCross
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 14:48:41 -0000

Yeah, Ron tried something like this a while ago. With practice, it gets easier. Not sure if it will beat pure CFOP, though :). - Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "thawk_pl" <tomahawk@l...> wrote: > Have someone ever tried to solve the cross and simultaneously orient > all edges?? This would make rest of F2l much simpler and faster, > also only ZBLL would be needed to solve the cube after F2L.

139. Re: [Speed cubing group] UK TV Appearances

141. looking for a little 5x5x5 help
From: "Jeff" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 18:35:17 -0000

All --

I just got my 5x and promptly set to solving it. I'm using the
standard "reduce to 3x" algorithm (centers, match edges, solve like
3x).

However, I'm stuck on the final edge match. Do you know any good 5x
solution resources on the web? Chris Hardwick has a great 4x
solutions resource which I use for the few things unique to 4x, but
no 5x.

Here's where I'm stuck, in case you know of a move for it. What's
left is the Red-Green and the Red-Blue edge. I have them on the same
layer (front) , opposite each other (FR and FL), with the following
setup (the inner colors of the pair (in caps) are on the Front face)

Blue-RED RED-Green
Red-GREEN RED-Blue
Red-GREEN BLUE-Red

Feel free to reply in email (to yeff@...) and say "check out
*this* website" to avoid group clutter.

Thanks in advance for any help,

yeff





142. Re: looking for a little 5x5x5 help
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 18:47:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff" <yeff@y...> wrote: > > Here's where I'm stuck, in case you know of a move for it. What's > left is the Red-Green and the Red-Blue edge. I have them on the same > layer (front) , opposite each other (FR and FL), with the following > setup (the inner colors of the pair (in caps) are on the Front face) > > Blue-RED RED-Green > Red-GREEN RED-Blue > Red-GREEN BLUE-Red That's the easy case, not parity problem. Think about how you'd match the last two edge pairs of the 4x4. Cheers! Stefan

145. F2L CATEGORY
From: Jason Kovacic <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 12:31:17 -0700 (PDT)

AWHILE AGO I MADE A CUBE WITHOUT LL STICKERS, FOR THE
SPECIFIC PURPOSE OF DOING THE F2L. CAN I USE THIS
CUBE FOR THE F2L CATEGORY?


ALSO, I KNOW THAT NO ONE USES CORNERS FIRST SOLUTIONS
ANY MORE, BUT IT WOULD BE INTERESTING TO ME IF THERE
WERE A CATEGORY FOR SOLVING THE CORNERS/CENTERS OF A
3X3. KIND OF LIKE A 2X2, BUT EASIER TO HOLD, AND WITH
CENTERS.
MY RECORD IS 7.XX SEC

JASON KOVACIC

146. Re: Cool new COLL alg!
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 21:07:12 -0000

Hi Chris, You might try mine: B R2 B2 R F2 R' B2 R F2 R B' Left thumb on Up center, left middle finger on Down center, left index and ring fingers help to keep Front and Back side aligned. David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I've posted this case on here two times I think, but didn't really get > a response the last time. > > I really used to hate this COLL case, but now it's just mildly > annoying :-D > > My usual alg for the case is this > B L' U2 L B' L' B U2 B' L > > which is fast if you have a perfect execution, but almost always lockup. > > Here's an RUL move I found with Acube that is 4 moves longer, but for > me noticeably faster on average. > > R' U' R U' R' U2 R L' U R U' L U R' > > which is just a sune and then an Alan (?) can't remember the name of > the other, but it's one of the stand fast corner switchers. > > Let me know what you guys think, I've already switched to this alg > since my other one is so terrible for my hands. > > Chris

ago and they are amazing. I absolutely LOVE the bright orange. Ah...I
am so happy now. :)

I'm glad I ordered 4 complete sets and 10 bright orange sets :)

149. Re: [Speed cubing group] UK TV Appearances
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 25 Jul 2005 22:10:07 -0700

My experience is that people are just as impressed by a 20 seconds
solve as a 40 seconds one. Either way it's just faster than is
imaginable for most people.

So don't worry about 20% difference. Take your time.

/Lars

152. Re: 6 months of ZB
From: nviennefr <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 09:03:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I'm not going to take up the space here, but read my journal > [http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/myzb.html (July 25, 2005)] if you > want my opinion of ZB after 6 months. > > Chris Hi Chris Congratulation for your hard motivation to learn ZB System !! I read your note on your web page about your progress and I am surprise why you want to persever in this system because you say it could'nt be faster than fridrich if his system is use by excellents cubers like those who average 15' or sub 15 ? isn't more "easy" to persever in F2L cases to decrease your time? . I say that because I think ZBF2L is not the problem of This system. For example you can easily decrease the number of configurations if you connect the pair on LL etc... or other example . The Big Problem of this system IS THE LL PERMUTATIONS (493 algos) and particulary The case: S (72 config.) and case: As (72 config) according to Dan Harris ' Page at : http://www.cubestation.co.uk/ So, 144 config in total on which you surely stuck because there are very similar ! I don't know if you have always a list of them with the color pattern, that will frighten you! good luck nevertheless Nicolas

158. Re: F2L CATEGORY
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 12:13:30 -0000

Alrite ;-) I gonna try avoid the shift key for the most part :-P I don't have a good 2x2x2 cube :-( I do believe that 7-8 secs is possible even with a "no-method" approach: - first layer corners , 3-4 secs (should see how to do those moves during preinspection time) - position LL corners, 2- secs - orient LL corner, 2+ secs So total : 7-8 secs I guess for those who practice the 2x2x2 they will prefer do it on a real 2x2x2 cube. Those who don't practice much might well prefer to do it on a 3x3x3. Even w keeping stickers on the edges left intact :D Also, is noone using LBL method anymore? Hehehe ... Well i'm in fact still using that and i just did a new pb average of 21.49 secs with it, and a new pb single solve of 13.20 also. Not too bad of a 39 yr old to still improve his 20 yr old speedcubing method :-)) Cheers! -Per PS! As a rough guess i'd say about 50% use pure fridrich method, 30% use some slight variation of it and the rest of us are using corners first, label by label or whatever ... > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jason Kovacic > <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > > > > ALSO, I KNOW THAT NO ONE USES CORNERS FIRST SOLUTIONS > > ANY MORE > > ISN'T IT ALWAYS FUNNY WHAT PEOPLE "KNOW" ? ... > > > BUT IT WOULD BE INTERESTING TO ME IF THERE > > WERE A CATEGORY FOR SOLVING THE CORNERS/CENTERS OF A > > 3X3. KIND OF LIKE A 2X2, BUT EASIER TO HOLD, AND WITH > > CENTERS. > > MY RECORD IS 7.XX SEC > > I'M QUITE SURE I'VE SEEN A "3X3 CORNERS" CATEGORY AND SOMEONE GOT A 4. > 5 AVERAGE OR SO. CAN'T FIND IT ANYMORE, THOUGH. > > BTW, SORRY I TRIED TO SCREAM EVEN LOUDER THAN YOU BUT PRESSING SHIFT > TWICE DIDN'T HELP AT ALL :-( > > STEFAN
159. Re: 6 months of ZB
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 12:20:58 -0000

Hi :-) What he means by "lazy" is not that u are lazy to learn that enormous high number of special cases. But once you know all that u have reduced ur decison-making/intuition or whatever u call it to just be "applying cases". At that stage u are "lazy" i guess ;-) Relatively "easy" as the 3x3x3 cube is, this is the cube where it takes the most time to become a specialist. It's taking a lot less time and effort to make it to the top in 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 cubing. Oh well, 4x4x4 is becoming tougher but there still aren't all that many sub 3:00 guys around for the 5x5x5 cube. -Per --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > I'm not going to take up the space here, but read my journal > > [http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/myzb.html (July 25, 2005)] if you > > want my opinion of ZB after 6 months. > > Haha, my favourite part is when you say "ZB is the lazy way out" ;-) > > Cheers! > Stefan

161. Want to improve? ...
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 15:30:59 -0000


... Stop cubing!

For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I recorded an
(rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all sub-16.2).
I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying that
stopping for some time helped him getting faster too.

Gilles.

163. Re: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 09:37:48 -0600

Hi Gilles,

I think it's true for many things. Personally, these last few days
have been absolutely miserable on the blindfold solving for me. I
think I failed six solves in the row. My hands were just slipping and
I was forgetting pieces, transposing pieces... quite the nightmare.
This was just yesterday so I haven't had the chance to take a break,
but I'm confident it'll help.

It definitely applied when I was speed cubing and I was averaging
around 27 seconds. I got busy in school and so I took some time off,
about three weeks, and then I came back. The first two averages were
about 28 but then after I started getting a feel for things, I hit
about 25's.

And in music, generally the best preparation of a major concerto, at
least I did this back in high school, was I learned a piece my
sophomore year, and then put it off and learned some other things, and
then brought it back up again for the competition when I was a senior.
Taking time off can give a new perspective to things that you weren't
able to see before.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jul 26, 2005, at 9:30 AM, Gilles Roux wrote:

164. Re: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ...
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 08:39:21 -0700

I hear ya!

I had a 23 second average for months and then I had an insane finals
week and couldn't touch a cube for 10 days. When I picked it back up,
I could consistantly average 19-20 seconds. I have no idea what the
heck happened, but I like it :)

-Chris


165. What's multislotting??
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 15:55:36 -0000

Hi!

Can someone please explain what multislotting means. I can't find any
information about it.

/Gunnar Krig




166. Re: [Speed cubing group] What's multislotting??
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 12:39:46 -0400

Where did you hear the term? It sounds like someone is inventing new terms. Here's my best guess. A slot is the destination of an unsolved corner-edge pair in the F2L system. Multislotting could refer to using an open slot (not the one you are working on) to enable a shorter solution to a corner-edge pair. On 7/26/05, Gunnar Krig <gunkr520@...> wrote: > Hi! > > Can someone please explain what multislotting means. I can't find any > information about it. > > /Gunnar Krig
167. Re: [Speed cubing group] What's multislotting??
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 16:45:06 -0000

Multislotting is when you solve more than one F2L piece. Such that when you make one F2L, the other one is already set-up or in the slot. There is a website that has a few examples of multislotting http://homepage.ntlworld.com/family.hayden/cube/cube_frontpage.html but it doesn't work. Multislotting saves times and uses fewer moves than making two F2L pieces. Also I think you could use Multislotting for more than two pieces. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > Where did you hear the term? It sounds like someone is inventing new > terms. Here's my best guess. A slot is the destination of an > unsolved corner-edge pair in the F2L system. Multislotting could > refer to using an open slot (not the one you are working on) to enable > a shorter solution to a corner-edge pair. > > On 7/26/05, Gunnar Krig <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Hi! > > > > Can someone please explain what multislotting means. I can't find any > > information about it. > > > > /Gunnar Krig
168. Re: [Speed cubing group] What's multislotting??
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 16:46:38 -0000

Multislotting is: after pairing up the pair, working on the next pair while inserting that pair. I don't really use it, but I know Sebastean Felix knows a lot about this. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > Where did you hear the term? It sounds like someone is inventing new > terms. Here's my best guess. A slot is the destination of an > unsolved corner-edge pair in the F2L system. Multislotting could > refer to using an open slot (not the one you are working on) to enable > a shorter solution to a corner-edge pair. > > On 7/26/05, Gunnar Krig <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > Hi! > > > > Can someone please explain what multislotting means. I can't find any > > information about it. > > > > /Gunnar Krig
169. Re: What's multislotting??
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 17:58:45 -0000

In fact multisloting is very easy, but it is hard to do at very high
speed because you may anticipate 4 F2L pieces, Joel was right but not
complete, in fact i try to work with another pair while inserting the
first one. Sometimes it doesnt solve direclty the 2nd pair but offers
an easier case which allow me to always have easy cases or at least
not have worst cases.

Some people think thats is better to use it for 2 first slots, but I
think it is easier to do that with 2-3 lasts slots because there is
less freedom, and for the 1st slot you need to anticipate quickly what
you'll do after cross.

I did an average of 50 cubes one month ago and average about 31 moves
for solving F2L.

Sbastien




170. New file
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 26 Jul 2005 18:03:39 -0000

I added a file concerning multisloting in the file section. Thanks to
ron for the global page.

sbastien

From: Gilles Roux

Sent: Tuesday, July 26, 2005 10:30 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ...



... Stop cubing!

For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I recorded an
(rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all sub-16.2).
I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying that
stopping for some time helped him getting faster too.

Gilles.

177. Re: 6 months of ZB (learning algs)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 04:30:37 -0000

Hey Gunnar, When learning a new alg I usually am trying 3-4 different ones out for the case I am looking at to see which I will like. I basically just read the alg off while timing myself to see which one I think will be faster. I don't memorize each one, I just stare at the notation while solving to get an idea of how the alg will work. Once I do decide on an alg, I have already timed myself doing it 10-20 times, so I have a fairly loose idea of how the alg goes. I usually have them broken down into 3-5 groups of triggers so I just memorize those trigger groups. Once I've done that I time myself again and try to get the alg to sub-4 (you can substitute whatever time contraint you want here). I basically just do averages with that same alg until I get a sub-4 one, or if sub-4 is easy I try for sub-3 etc.. By that point you've probably done 50-60 repetitions of the alg and if you put the cube down and came back a day or two later you would still recall it. I did some research on memory and a lot of sources say that once something is in your short term memory, you will lose it (forget it) in 2-3 days. However, if at the end of those 2-3 days you rehearse that same thing (basically rememorize it, or think about it a lot), then you will remember it for maybe 3-6 more days. Then at the end of those 6 days rehearse again and you will remember it for a week or more. Then at the end of that week rehearse again and you will remember for a month, etc.. Of course at some point that information enters your procedural memory and you won't forget it unless you don't think about it for years (and sometimes not even then). So just rehearse it at the end of each memorization period. I mean that sounds kind of hoky and weird, but it really does work for me. Since I'm learning algs all the time, I'm always in the "rehearsal" stage for some cases at the same time that I'm in the "just learning for the first time" for others. So I sort of always am rehearsing something I learned 3 days, 6 days, 2 weeks, 1 month, a few months ago, etc. as well as learning new algs. I hope that makes some sense. I find this technique to work for learning quickly, meaning always learning new algs, and not forgetting what you've learned before. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > Hi Chris! > > I usually check your journal everyday and think its quite > interesting. Is amazing tha you are really going for learning al > those algs. Whats the procedure you use when learn new algs. Im kind > of a "slow-learner" myself, but at least I know all OLL-cases now. > > /Gunnar
178. Re: New Member!!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 04:32:50 -0000

lol, ok so I put my foot in my mouth :-D I did mean what Per wrote a few messages back. I called ZB the "lazy way out" meaning that it doesn't take as much skill as Fridrich during the solve. There is less art and more clunky applying of memorized sequences. So whereas solving with Fridrich is really an art form, ZB is just brute force solving and not much art. Didn't mean to sound arrogant if it came across that way, I meant to compliment the Fridrich method quite a bit actually :-D Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > > i haven't read all the previous messages yet, but i like to know all > > your solving techniques > > My, are you an ambitious one! > > Ok, the first one will probably take you the remainder of your > vacation, and the last one, well, I suggest you take the very lazy > route and follow Chris Hardwick's advice. Try learning ZBLL, I think > you should be done in a year or two, three tops. ;) > > Michiel

180. 5x5x5 move found, lubing a 5x? (was Re: looking for a little 5x5x5 help)
From: "Jeff" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 05:51:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff" <yeff@y...> > wrote: > > > > Here's where I'm stuck, in case you know of a move for it. What's > > left is the Red-Green and the Red-Blue edge. I have them on the same > > layer (front) , opposite each other (FR and FL), with the following > > setup (the inner colors of the pair (in caps) are on the Front face) > > > > Blue-RED RED-Green > > Red-GREEN RED-Blue > > Red-GREEN BLUE-Red > > That's the easy case, not parity problem. Think about how you'd match > the last two edge pairs of the 4x4. > > Cheers! > Stefan You're going to make me work for it, aren't you Stefan! :-) If I had a 4x4 with the two edges like: Blue-RED RED-Blue Red-GREEN GREEN-Red I'd use d R F' U R' F d'. So, I played around with that sequence and variants on the 5x5x5, not quite getting there. A kind soul (David Barr) then sent me the answer for the above 5x5x5 situation: L2 d2 R F' U R' F d2 As one can see, very very similar. So, I didn't get it on my own, but I did successfully do the 5x5x5 for the first time after this one fix! Now, to do it again. As a random question, it looks like the 5x5x5 doesn't come apart as easy as the 4x or 3x. Any suggestions from folks on best way to lube a 5x5x5? It's pretty stiff right now and while it's good to build up strength, I don't need to look like Popeye. thanks, yeff
181. Calendar cube games
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 05:59:45 -0000

Hey everyone,

So yeah, I'm a self admitted calendar cube addict. I use my calendar
cube everyday, and always change it with the day :-D It actually is a
lot of fun!

I thought of an interesting challenge for it. Trying to minimize the
number of turns required to change each day (average for each month).
You can take longer to solve the next day and also do some moves to
prepare the day after that, but then again you can't do too much since
you have to solve today in as few moves as possible.

I also wonder if there is a distinct cube configuration for the
beginning of each month such that every time you solve a day, the next
day is setup very easily. It seems with some thought you could plan
out this entire solution and just setup the cube that way at the
beginning of each month with a regular Fridrich solve. So the first
day of that month is say 50-55 moves (or you could FMC the solution on
a regular cube and get it in even less) then each day after that is
maybe 5 or so.

Not sure which the best way would be, but it's fun to try to turn
something that seems at first to be simple into a more complicated puzzle.

Does anyone else use the calendar cube, or try to minimize the moves
required for each day change?

Chris

183. Re: New Member!!
From: kirk83616 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 06:29:20 -0000

Hey Rinie, you'll get overwhelmed very quickly if you try to go too fast learning all the stuff out there. Take it one step at a time. If you do a layer by layer approach, maybe start with learning/improving on the OLL and PLL algorithms that affect edges only or corners only. [sorry if you don't know what OLL or PLL is yet, but lots of sites can get you caught up on the terminology]. Basically, if you can flip the edges, then flip the corners, then re- arrange the edges, then the corners, you can do the last layer with confidence no matter what you get. After that feels fairly comfortable, then move on to some more last layer algorithms. Alternatively, if you're comfortable with how you're doing the last layer [assuming you do it that way], there's been a lot of talk here lately about the first 2 layers [F2L] and there's a lot of great tips on that out there. good luck, and welcome. I'd say the cube gets more fun the faster you get, and definitely a way to wow your friends [unless they're already in here], so it's worth putting in some time practicing. best, Kirk --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rinie" <pine_nimba@y...> wrote: > hello! > > i was just looking around when i bumped into this e-group! great, it's > completely my thing! > i'm a 19 year old girl from the netherlands, and my english isn't the > best... so if anything is unclear, pleaz tell me! > > i haven't read all the previous messages yet, but i like to know all > your solving techniques > > myselve i can solve it in 3 minutes or so, not very quick, but hee, i > havn't had your tips ;-) > > grtz > Rinie
184. Re: Cool new COLL alg!
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 06:57:25 -0000

I've actively used this alg for about 5yrs now. Just checked LarsP's site, thought it might already have a name or something but guess not. The one that doesn't touch edge perm I can average 2.20s on. Just took 22.04 for 10 executions. I preform it like this: LL on F, oriented corner on UFR (RU')F2(UR'U'R)F2(R'U) In full detail: (RU') F2[with right thumb downward twice] (UR'U'R)[start with right index; both R',R done with right thumb passively resting, U' done wiht left index] (F2)[same way] (R'U)[quick flick] Somewhere during the middle of this alg I do a rapid flick of my left wrist to guide the turns and angle the grip temporarily. It's truly a feelgood alg! :) Back from NY and there are a bit over 100 posts to catch up on.... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey again Masayuki, > > Yeah my execution is very poor for B L' U2 L B' L' B U2 B' L > (02.50), 03.20, 03.28, 02.88, 04.20, 03.95, 03.06, 04.13, (04.53), > 04.37, 03.26, 04.18 = 3.65 > > But for R' U' R U' R' U2 R - L' U R U' L U R' is better > 02.72, (02.28), 02.45, (03.65), 03.38, 02.63, 02.34, 02.97, 02.72, > 03.22, 03.26, 02.78 = 2.85 > > I always seem to lockup with the first B turn transition into the x' > (L U' L' U). > > Also I have a question for you, can you recognize the CLL cases from > different angles? I've been meaning to learn the sune cases from the > 180 degree rotation of where I currently recognize. Since I use your > method of same and opposite colored stickers I can do the 4 corner > flipped cases from multiple angles, but the two corners flipped cases > and the sunes I have to do from the same angle. > > Do you use multiple angles for recognition, and if so does it help? > > Thanks again, > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > Hey Masayuki! > > > > I have a question? How do you perform B L' U2 L B' L' B U2 B' L ? > > > > I do it as (B) (L' U2) x' (L U' L' U) y' R2 (U') (F) > > > > Maybe I just need to practice this alg more, of do it differently. I > > can get very fast times with it if I have a flawless execution, but if > > I lockup my time for it is about 4 seconds :-( > > > > I can do the RUL sune/alan one in about 2.75 on average, so I guess > > I'm just debating whether I am just doing a good alg poorly, or if > > that alg is slow for my hands. > > > > I'd be curious in how you execute that case, or if you have any other > > cool algs for it. > > > > Thanks for the help and the comments! > > Chris > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, makimoto2000us > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > >I've posted this case on here two times I think, but didn't really > > > get > > > >a response the last time. > > > > > > > >I really used to hate this COLL case, but now it's just mildly > > > >annoying :-D > > > > > > > >My usual alg for the case is this > > > >B L' U2 L B' L' B U2 B' L > > > > > > > >which is fast if you have a perfect execution, but almost always > > > lockup. > > > > > > > >Here's an RUL move I found with Acube that is 4 moves longer, but for > > > >me noticeably faster on average. > > > > > > > >R' U' R U' R' U2 R L' U R U' L U R' > > > > > > > >which is just a sune and then an Alan (?) can't remember the name of > > > >the other, but it's one of the stand fast corner switchers. > > > > > > > >Let me know what you guys think, I've already switched to this alg > > > >since my other one is so terrible for my hands. > > > Hi Chris, > > > > > > It is always interesting to see your posts about COLLs. > > > Since there are not many CLL (COLL) > ELL cubers, it is good chance > > > for me to think my algs. > > > > > > Sorry, I missed your old posts. > > > I used to use B L' U2 L B' L' B U2 B' L. > > > > > > Probably one year ago, I changed this as similar to yours, but I do > > > Alan (?) then anti-Sune(?). > > > It is because of my recogition. > > > I have to distinguish two cases. > > > 1: L' U R U' L U R' > > > 2: L' U R U' L U R' - L U2 L' U' L U' L' > > > > > > If the recognition system is different, you may not be interested in. > > > In regard to permution speed, I think I still can do faster with old > > > alg. > > > > > > Masayuki Akimoto

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff" <yeff@y...> wrote: > > You're going to make me work for it, aren't you Stefan! :-) Yes, I am. I don't like to steal your opportunity to find a solution yourself and feel good, successful and satisfied with yourself. That's why I always try to just give minimal hints, not a solution. > If I had a 4x4 with the two edges like: > > Blue-RED RED-Blue > Red-GREEN GREEN-Red > > I'd use d R F' U R' F d'. Do you understand *why* that algorithm works? If you do, I'm sure you could've found a solution to the 5x5 case yourself as well. Now try to find a different one than David gave you, more similar to your 4x4 alg :-) > As a random question, it looks like the 5x5x5 doesn't come apart as > easy as the 4x or 3x. Any suggestions from folks on best way to lube > a 5x5x5? It's pretty stiff right now and while it's good to build up > strength, I don't need to look like Popeye. Which type? Rubik or Eastsheen? How old? Cheers! Stefan
186. Re: [Speed cubing group] Calendar cube games
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>

I use a calendar cube, only reason I ever know the date is becuase I change it every morning. I don't concentrate too much on changing the date, but I have gotten it in 5 moves a couple times, none less yet becuase I haven't set it up. But maybe I'll think about this one. -E On 7/26/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > So yeah, I'm a self admitted calendar cube addict. I use my calendar > cube everyday, and always change it with the day :-D It actually is a > lot of fun! > > I thought of an interesting challenge for it. Trying to minimize the > number of turns required to change each day (average for each month). > You can take longer to solve the next day and also do some moves to > prepare the day after that, but then again you can't do too much since > you have to solve today in as few moves as possible. > > I also wonder if there is a distinct cube configuration for the > beginning of each month such that every time you solve a day, the next > day is setup very easily. It seems with some thought you could plan > out this entire solution and just setup the cube that way at the > beginning of each month with a regular Fridrich solve. So the first > day of that month is say 50-55 moves (or you could FMC the solution on > a regular cube and get it in even less) then each day after that is > maybe 5 or so. > > Not sure which the best way would be, but it's fun to try to turn > something that seems at first to be simple into a more complicated puzzle. > > Does anyone else use the calendar cube, or try to minimize the moves > required for each day change? > > Chris > > > > ________________________________ > YAHOO! 189. Re: New Member!!
From: "Rinie" <pine_nimba@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 11:35:08 -0000

Hi! thnak you for this welcome :-) and you're right that it is veryvery much that's coming at me now, esspecially the terms. I have my cube not here (that's a bad thing, isn't it? :-P) but when i see it again i will give it a big hug and then will try this method! kiss! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, kirk83616 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey Rinie, > > you'll get overwhelmed very quickly if you try to go too fast > learning all the stuff out there. Take it one step at a time. If > you do a layer by layer approach, maybe start with > learning/improving on the OLL and PLL algorithms that affect edges > only or corners only. [sorry if you don't know what OLL or PLL is > yet, but lots of sites can get you caught up on the terminology]. > Basically, if you can flip the edges, then flip the corners, then re- > arrange the edges, then the corners, you can do the last layer with > confidence no matter what you get. After that feels fairly > comfortable, then move on to some more last layer algorithms. > > Alternatively, if you're comfortable with how you're doing the last > layer [assuming you do it that way], there's been a lot of talk here > lately about the first 2 layers [F2L] and there's a lot of great > tips on that out there. > > good luck, and welcome. I'd say the cube gets more fun the faster > you get, and definitely a way to wow your friends [unless they're > already in here], so it's worth putting in some time practicing. > best, > Kirk > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Rinie" > <pine_nimba@y...> wrote: > > hello! > > > > i was just looking around when i bumped into this e-group! great, > it's > > completely my thing! > > i'm a 19 year old girl from the netherlands, and my english isn't > the > > best... so if anything is unclear, pleaz tell me! > > > > i haven't read all the previous messages yet, but i like to know > all > > your solving techniques > > > > myselve i can solve it in 3 minutes or so, not very quick, but > hee, i > > havn't had your tips ;-) > > > > grtz > > Rinie

And that average came out pretty easy too, even though I was shaking, and didn't have my normal 'fluency' back yet. - Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > ... Stop cubing! > > For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I recorded an > (rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all sub-16.2). > I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying that > stopping for some time helped him getting faster too. > > Gilles.

192. Re: Want to improve? ...
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 12:15:57 -0000

mmhh.. maybe.. maybe not.. I was not that slow :-) When I have a bad day (neurons not working together, acting like brakes), slowing down helps preventing disasters or bad times, I agree. But when I feel great, I don't have to take care about solving slowly, because turn speed is automatically regulated, driven by the anticipation possibilities. I often heard people telling you have to slow down if you want to be consistent, but it never really worked for me, when I was a beginner or now. What about you? 198. Re: [Speed cubing group] Calendar cube games
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 09:59:56 -0600

I usually use about 3 or 4 moves for changing the last digit so it
takes a few more moves if it's going from the 29th to the 30th. For
the day of the week, I usually just use an A-permutation because I
don't want to deal with screwing up the orientation of anything.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Jul 26, 2005, at 11:59 PM, cmhardw wrote:

> Hey everyone,
>
> So yeah, I'm a self admitted calendar cube addict. I use my calendar
> cube everyday, and always change it with the day :-D It actually is a
> lot of fun!
>
> I thought of an interesting challenge for it. Trying to minimize the
> number of turns required to change each day (average for each month).
> You can take longer to solve the next day and also do some moves to
> prepare the day after that, but then again you can't do too much since
> you have to solve today in as few moves as possible.
>
> I also wonder if there is a distinct cube configuration for the
> beginning of each month such that every time you solve a day, the next
> day is setup very easily. It seems with some thought you could plan
> out this entire solution and just setup the cube that way at the
> beginning of each month with a regular Fridrich solve. So the first
> day of that month is say 50-55 moves (or you could FMC the solution on
> a regular cube and get it in even less) then each day after that is
> maybe 5 or so.
>
> Not sure which the best way would be, but it's fun to try to turn
> something that seems at first to be simple into a more complicated
> puzzle.
>
> Does anyone else use the calendar cube, or try to minimize the moves
> required for each day change?
>

199. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ...
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 11:02:36 -0500

I've always had trouble going slowly on the F2L or steps 1 and 2 of your method. Even if I try to go slowly on purpose, or cube quietly, it doesn't work. I've just trained myself to see the pieces at the slightly faster speed, and it's helped my F2L times a bunch. When I see the pieces, even while going quickly, my times are very good. With a good F2L, I can manage sub-20, no matter how difficult my last layer is. For most solves, I use F2L, orient edges, orient corners, PLL. However, there are 4 PLL cases I've never bothered to learn. The cases which cycle 3 edges and 3 corners each I do in two steps. Even so, because of good F2L's, I've gotten several 18.xx's on these cases. I read about all of these people averaging 45+ on the groups who already know all of the OLL's and PLL's. It seems like a waste of effort to me. The F2L is really where to get faster, at least initially. And I don't think anyone needs necessarily to go slowly, just learn to recognize pieces at your comfortable speed. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Gilles Roux To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 7:15 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ... mmhh.. maybe.. maybe not.. I was not that slow :-) When I have a bad day (neurons not working together, acting like brakes), slowing down helps preventing disasters or bad times, I agree. But when I feel great, I don't have to take care about solving slowly, because turn speed is automatically regulated, driven by the anticipation possibilities. I often heard people telling you have to slow down if you want to be consistent, but it never really worked for me, when I was a beginner or now. What about you? Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Perhaps a part of this is the fact that because you haven't touched the cube in two weeks, you're forced to go slightly slower at the beginning. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Gilles Roux > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Tuesday, July 26, 2005 10:30 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ... > > > > ... 200. [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ...
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 16:07:24 -0000

Ok.. Now people are giving their opinions about going slow or fast during F2L. Of course, speed is the ultimate goal, but you can't reach that goal by telling a newbie to try to go as fast as possible. In that case, it will be counter productive. I'd like to quote my site on this subject: ----------QUOTE------------ Speedcubing videos might give you the impression that speedcubing is all about speed. But that's not true. In my opinion, speedcubing is all about finding a balance between fluency and speed. You should not focus on speed to much. It's more important to work on your technique. The speed will come naturally. When I am having a bad cubing day, one of the things that helps me to get better times is telling myself to slow down. The idea is not to solve the cube at full speed (especially the F2L), but to go a little slower instead. This will enable you to watch the pieces, and it gives you time to look ahead. When you are solving a 'sub-problem', you can try to figure out what your next step is going to be. For people that use Fridrich, this means that when you are inserting a corner edge pair, you should have already spotted the next pair. Also, after finishing the cross, you should at least have a general idea about where your first corner edge pair is. The goal of looking ahead this way is that you can solve the cube without, or with only very small delays between algorithms. If you don't believe me, just time yourself, while aiming at your normal average plus 5 or 10 seconds (this will probably work for most people who average around 17-30 seconds). You will see it's not that hard to do that. Do about 10 of those very slow solves, and try to look ahead while doing this. Now, slowly accelerate to your normal times. I hope you'll find that rushing through a solve like a mad man it completely unnecessary, and that you can have the same (or even better) results by slowing down just a little bit. One last thing: It's a good idea to solve the last layer at full speeds, because when solving the Last Layer, it's almost impossible to look ahead. It's also a good idea to practice solving all different steps at full speed, because you should be able to do them without thinking. Of course, I am not telling you to go slow, just go as fast as you can without making mistakes, and without big delays between algorithms. ----------QUOTE------------ --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I've always had trouble going slowly on the F2L or steps 1 and 2 of your method. Even if I try to go slowly on purpose, or cube quietly, it doesn't work. I've just trained myself to see the pieces at the slightly faster speed, and it's helped my F2L times a bunch. When I see the pieces, even while going quickly, my times are very good. > > With a good F2L, I can manage sub-20, no matter how difficult my last layer is. For most solves, I use F2L, orient edges, orient corners, PLL. However, there are 4 PLL cases I've never bothered to learn. The cases which cycle 3 edges and 3 corners each I do in two steps. Even so, because of good F2L's, I've gotten several 18.xx's on these cases. > > I read about all of these people averaging 45+ on the groups who already know all of the OLL's and PLL's. It seems like a waste of effort to me. The F2L is really where to get faster, at least initially. And I don't think anyone needs necessarily to go slowly, just learn to recognize pieces at your comfortable speed. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Gilles Roux > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 7:15 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ... > > > > mmhh.. maybe.. maybe not.. I was not that slow :-) > > When I have a bad day (neurons not working together, acting like > brakes), slowing down helps preventing disasters or bad times, I > agree. > But when I feel great, I don't have to take care about solving > slowly, because turn speed is automatically regulated, driven by the > anticipation possibilities. > > I often heard people telling you have to slow down if you want to be > consistent, but it never really worked for me, when I was a beginner > or now. > What about you? > > Gilles. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Perhaps a part of this is the fact that because you haven't touched > the cube in two weeks, you're forced to go slightly slower at the > beginning. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: Gilles Roux > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Sent: Tuesday, July 26, 2005 10:30 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ... > > > > > > > > ... Stop cubing! > > > > For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I > recorded an > > (rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all sub- 16.2). > > I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying > that > > stopping for some time helped him getting faster too. > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Online puzzle games Puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle > game > > Free puzzle games Computer puzzle game Free puzzle inlay > games > > > > > > --------------------------------------------------------------- ----- > ---------- > > YAHOO! 201. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 10:10:23 -0600

"It's all about F2L." - Shotaro Makisumi Really, all cubers should learn F2L first in my opinion. The reason is that OLL and PLL algorithms don't take time to "master". There's not nearly as much finesse and decision making in the LL as there is in the F2L. The LL is all about just execution of the algorithm, and to a smaller extent, recognizing which case it is. In the F2L, you have to deal with execution, but also being able to find the next pair. Also, sometimes knowing to do one pair first will set you up nicely for the next pair, or sometimes you'll know that for a certain algorithm if the 3 of the last layer edges are yellow, then you can get all the edges oriented, just things like that. Learn the F2L. Remember, there's no way to average sub-20 if your F2L takes 18 seconds. Focus on getting F2L down because that's really what accounts for your times. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Jul 27, 2005, at 10:02 AM, Mike Bennett wrote: > I've always had trouble going slowly on the F2L or steps 1 and 2 of > your method. Even if I try to go slowly on purpose, or cube quietly, > it doesn't work. I've just trained myself to see the pieces at the > slightly faster speed, and it's helped my F2L times a bunch. When I > see the pieces, even while going quickly, my times are very good. > > With a good F2L, I can manage sub-20, no matter how difficult my last > layer is. For most solves, I use F2L, orient edges, orient corners, > PLL. However, there are 4 PLL cases I've never bothered to learn. > The cases which cycle 3 edges and 3 corners each I do in two steps. > Even so, because of good F2L's, I've gotten several 18.xx's on these > cases. > > I read about all of these people averaging 45+ on the groups who > already know all of the OLL's and PLL's. It seems like a waste of > effort to me. The F2L is really where to get faster, at least > initially. And I don't think anyone needs necessarily to go slowly, > just learn to recognize pieces at your comfortable speed. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Gilles Roux > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 7:15 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ... > > > > mmhh.. maybe.. maybe not.. I was not that slow :-) > > When I have a bad day (neurons not working together, acting like > brakes), slowing down helps preventing disasters or bad times, I > agree. > But when I feel great, I don't have to take care about solving > slowly, because turn speed is automatically regulated, driven by the > anticipation possibilities. > > I often heard people telling you have to slow down if you want to be > consistent, but it never really worked for me, when I was a beginner > or now. > What about you? > > Gilles. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: >> Perhaps a part of this is the fact that because you haven't touched > the cube in two weeks, you're forced to go slightly slower at the > beginning. >> >> -Mike Bennett >> >> >> ----- Original Message ----- >> From: Gilles Roux >> To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >> Sent: Tuesday, July 26, 2005 10:30 AM >> Subject: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ... >> >> >> >> ... 203. Re: [Speed cubing group] Calendar cube games
From: Evan Gates <evan.gates@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 09:48:48 -0700

Why don't you just solve it like a first layer corner? -E On 7/27/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > I usually use about 3 or 4 moves for changing the last digit so it > takes a few more moves if it's going from the 29th to the 30th. For > the day of the week, I usually just use an A-permutation because I > don't want to deal with screwing up the orientation of anything. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jul 26, 2005, at 11:59 PM, cmhardw wrote: > > > Hey everyone, > > > > So yeah, I'm a self admitted calendar cube addict. I use my calendar > > cube everyday, and always change it with the day :-D It actually is a > > lot of fun! > > > > I thought of an interesting challenge for it. Trying to minimize the > > number of turns required to change each day (average for each month). > > You can take longer to solve the next day and also do some moves to > > prepare the day after that, but then again you can't do too much since > > you have to solve today in as few moves as possible. > > > > I also wonder if there is a distinct cube configuration for the > > beginning of each month such that every time you solve a day, the next > > day is setup very easily. It seems with some thought you could plan > > out this entire solution and just setup the cube that way at the > > beginning of each month with a regular Fridrich solve. So the first > > day of that month is say 50-55 moves (or you could FMC the solution on > > a regular cube and get it in even less) then each day after that is > > maybe 5 or so. > > > > Not sure which the best way would be, but it's fun to try to turn > > something that seems at first to be simple into a more complicated > > puzzle. > > > > Does anyone else use the calendar cube, or try to minimize the moves > > required for each day change? > > > > Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ________________________________ > YAHOO! 204. [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ...
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 18:03:36 -0000

I also use F2L, orient edges, orient corners, PLL. And I also use a combination of two PLL algs for the PLL cases which cycle 3 edges and 3 corners. Actually, only for 2 of the 4, I have learnt the alg + mirror for one of the pairs. I think of these four PLL cases as two pairs of cases. Anyway, my point in saying this is that this makes me feel really slow! ;) I use pretty much the same method as Mike and I average ~36-37 seconds. I've never done a sub-20s solve and I only occasionally get sub-30s times! I feel like I must be missing something fundamental. All the 3-LL solvers are faster than me!! Even on what felt like my most perfectly executed non-lucky solve, it was 23s. I just can't imagine ever getting sub-20s!! I've been on this group for several years now, so I think I've read just about every tip that anyone's ever offered, so in theory I know how I should be able to get faster, but I'm just not there. Maybe I just don't practice enough?? Having said all this, I guess I should keep in mind that my average was well over a minute when I first joined this group, so I have made *some* progress. :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I've always had trouble going slowly on the F2L or steps 1 and 2 of your method. Even if I try to go slowly on purpose, or cube quietly, it doesn't work. I've just trained myself to see the pieces at the slightly faster speed, and it's helped my F2L times a bunch. When I see the pieces, even while going quickly, my times are very good. > > With a good F2L, I can manage sub-20, no matter how difficult my last layer is. For most solves, I use F2L, orient edges, orient corners, PLL. However, there are 4 PLL cases I've never bothered to learn. The cases which cycle 3 edges and 3 corners each I do in two steps. Even so, because of good F2L's, I've gotten several 18.xx's on these cases. > > I read about all of these people averaging 45+ on the groups who already know all of the OLL's and PLL's. It seems like a waste of effort to me. The F2L is really where to get faster, at least initially. And I don't think anyone needs necessarily to go slowly, just learn to recognize pieces at your comfortable speed. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Gilles Roux > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 7:15 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ... > > > > mmhh.. maybe.. maybe not.. I was not that slow :-) > > When I have a bad day (neurons not working together, acting like > brakes), slowing down helps preventing disasters or bad times, I > agree. > But when I feel great, I don't have to take care about solving > slowly, because turn speed is automatically regulated, driven by the > anticipation possibilities. > > I often heard people telling you have to slow down if you want to be > consistent, but it never really worked for me, when I was a beginner > or now. > What about you? > > Gilles. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Perhaps a part of this is the fact that because you haven't touched > the cube in two weeks, you're forced to go slightly slower at the > beginning. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: Gilles Roux > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Sent: Tuesday, July 26, 2005 10:30 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ... > > > > > > > > ... Stop cubing! > > > > For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I > recorded an > > (rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all sub-16.2). > > I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying > that > > stopping for some time helped him getting faster too. > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Online puzzle games Puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle > game > > Free puzzle games Computer puzzle game Free puzzle inlay > games > > > > > > -------------------------------------------------------------------- > ---------- > > YAHOO! 205. 5x5x5 move found, lubing a 5x? (was Re: looking for a little 5x5x5 help)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 18:44:34 -0000

Hi :-) There's no need to take apart a puzzle in order to lube it. I bet as good as 100% of all sprays these days come with a narrow long tube for spraying. If so u only need a little gap (which u make easily) to get the silicone inside. Spray into the puzzle from various locations around the cube. Then work it in by playing about with the cube a little. If it's first time u lube it u can repeat this a few times more. After working it in for the last time u can leave the puzzle couple of hrs before testing it again. (U might need a tissue to wipe off silicone on the outside of the puzzle.) But actually i recommend for the rubiks.com 5x5x5 that u wait quite a while before lubing it first time. It will "wear down" faster i guess without the lube inside. I normally wait at least a few weeks before lubing those 5x5x5 cubes. With eastsheen (mini) cubes u can lube straight away. But only a very little amount will be needed. I recommend never to take apart those eastsheen cubes. They become loose easily. The only real good reason to take apart rubiks.com 4x4x4 and 5x5x5 is to check cubies for irregularities that u can remove with a sharp knife or other sharp tool. Good luck :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff" <yeff@y...> > wrote: > > > > You're going to make me work for it, aren't you Stefan! :-) > > > Yes, I am. I don't like to steal your opportunity to find a solution > yourself and feel good, successful and satisfied with yourself. That's > why I always try to just give minimal hints, not a solution. > > > > If I had a 4x4 with the two edges like: > > > > Blue-RED RED-Blue > > Red-GREEN GREEN-Red > > > > I'd use d R F' U R' F d'. > > > Do you understand *why* that algorithm works? If you do, I'm sure you > could've found a solution to the 5x5 case yourself as well. Now try to > find a different one than David gave you, more similar to your 4x4 alg > :-) > > > > As a random question, it looks like the 5x5x5 doesn't come apart as > > easy as the 4x or 3x. Any suggestions from folks on best way to lube > > a 5x5x5? It's pretty stiff right now and while it's good to build up > > strength, I don't need to look like Popeye. > > > Which type? Rubik or Eastsheen? How old? > > > Cheers! > Stefan

208. Re: Want to improve? ...
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 20:08:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" < grrroux@f...> wrote: > > ... Stop cubing! > > For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I recorded an > (rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all sub-16.2). > I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying that > stopping for some time helped him getting faster too. > > Gilles. I don't know about that - I hardly cube at all but after I saw your message I did a bit of cubing. I got a 47 and a 27 and some 30s. 47 was worse than useless, 27 was pretty good but lucky (amazingly I didn't have to PLL which happens maybe once in a year so that's me done for 2005). I'd have to say it was generally well below that level for which I might have hoped. I found that some of the strings in my mind like LU2F'L'U'LUF2U2F'L' didn't come to mind too easily either and RU2R2FRF'U2R'FRF' (in fact, I think I might have had that in the 47s one and I was thinking FR'F' and having to undo it. My fingers tripped over each other a lot too. I did get a 30 a bit later which was the best non-lucky time but I don't know about that abstinence resulting in faster times hypothesis. I'm sure once a long time ago I could have hit 29s or maybe even 28s at least once and may have got into the 32-34s with some regularity.
209. Telling the difference between a cuber and a non-cuber...
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 20:39:29 -0000

Thought of these while walking home from the train station today...

*Stickers
Non-cuber: I peel the stickers off because I can't solve it.
Cuber: I peel the stickers off because I wore them out.

*Methods
Non-cuber: Is there a method?
Cuber: What's your method?

*Solve times
Non-cuber: What's your fastest time?
Cuber: What's your average (regular and best)?

*Lube
Non-cuber: *snicker*
Cuber: What brand, how often and where can I get some?

Any others?? :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

Non-cuber: Blindfold and handcuffs.
Cubers: Blindfolded while handcuffed.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
