214. New F2L idea/approach (well, maybe new)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 22:19:16 -0000

Hey everyone,

I've been really doing some thinking about my F2L lately, and came up
with a cool new technique that I really like, and that I think has
very general applications.

Obviously for ZBF2L I really have to focus on the LL edges while
solving the 4th pair, but I find it to be very hard to be thrust into
this F2L case + LL edges case right after the 3rd pair.

So what I've started doing is to mentally focus only on the LL edges
while solving F2L. This is kinda cool, since it means I have an idea
the whole time what the LL edges are doing, sometimes I get most of
them oriented for one pair, only to flip them later, etc.. I'm
starting to get a feel for which F2L algs flip the LL edges a lot, and
which ones are more preserving.

Anyway this makes the F2L itself a little easier. I know that sounds
weird, but since you are mentally focusing on your LL color only, the
F2L pieces really stand out as "wrong" or "weird" since they don't
have the LL color.

It's weird, but my F2L is actually pretty smooth this way, plus the
transition from 3rd pair to 4th pair ZBF2L is easier since I have been
thinking about the LL edges the whole time and am not suddenly thrust
into this hard case.

So anyway I don't know if anyone has ever tried F2L while focusing on
LL edges, it's sort of an inverted way of thinking, but it really
makes the F2L pieces stand out.

Just wanted to post, it seems to be helping me specifically for ZBF2L,
but I also am getting some nice standard F2L solves when I try it.

Try it and see what you think!
Chris




215. Re: Cubing influence
From: "Rinie" <pine_nimba@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 22:27:04 -0000

Many years ago i teached it to my little brother, but then in my own terms, so he could understand it. there were whole stories in in, like travelling around the world and sneaking back in through the backdoor and so on... and now i still do it myself with this stories in my imagination :) but i will learn your terms, then i can understand what the conversaton here is about.. ause till now it's still very confusing... :-S --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" <mahti- anssi@l...> wrote: > My dad, two cousins and one classmate can solve the cube. > Everybody in under 3 minutes. How about you others?
216. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ...
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 19:09:29 -0400

I am a 3-look LL solver too, I average around 32s - and I agree it's all about the F2L. I am constantly trying to make mine faster. Anyway, another good thing that might help is to time each part of your solution, ie cross, finishing F2L, edges, corners, PLL. When I was averaging in the 40's, it helped me realize my cross should be faster, and I worked on that a little bit more. As far as F2L goes, I still haven't seen how slowing down helps but there are other things to look at such as using empty slots, inserting pairs from any angle, finding the next pair before the one youre working on is finished, etc I'm sure if you work at it you can get your average down to around 30s rather quickly, cuz I've only been cubing for 5-6 months - and you seem to have more experience :) Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Jul 27, 2005, at 2:03 PM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > I also use F2L, orient edges, orient corners, PLL. And I also use a > combination of two PLL algs for the PLL cases which cycle 3 edges and > 3 corners. Actually, only for 2 of the 4, I have learnt the alg + > mirror for one of the pairs. I think of these four PLL cases as two > pairs of cases. > > Anyway, my point in saying this is that this makes me feel really > slow! ;) I use pretty much the same method as Mike and I average > ~36-37 seconds. I've never done a sub-20s solve and I only > occasionally get sub-30s times! > > I feel like I must be missing something fundamental. All the 3-LL > solvers are faster than me!! Even on what felt like my most perfectly > executed non-lucky solve, it was 23s. I just can't imagine ever > getting sub-20s!! > > I've been on this group for several years now, so I think I've read > just about every tip that anyone's ever offered, so in theory I know > how I should be able to get faster, but I'm just not there. Maybe I > just don't practice enough?? > > Having said all this, I guess I should keep in mind that my average > was well over a minute when I first joined this group, so I have made > *some* progress. :) > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > I've always had trouble going slowly on the F2L or steps 1 and 2 of > your method. Even if I try to go slowly on purpose, or cube quietly, > it doesn't work. I've just trained myself to see the pieces at the > slightly faster speed, and it's helped my F2L times a bunch. When I > see the pieces, even while going quickly, my times are very good. > > > > With a good F2L, I can manage sub-20, no matter how difficult my > last layer is. For most solves, I use F2L, orient edges, orient > corners, PLL. However, there are 4 PLL cases I've never bothered to > learn. The cases which cycle 3 edges and 3 corners each I do in two > steps. Even so, because of good F2L's, I've gotten several 18.xx's on > these cases. > > > > I read about all of these people averaging 45+ on the groups who > already know all of the OLL's and PLL's. It seems like a waste of > effort to me. The F2L is really where to get faster, at least > initially. And I don't think anyone needs necessarily to go slowly, > just learn to recognize pieces at your comfortable speed. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: Gilles Roux > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 7:15 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ... > > > > > > > > mmhh.. maybe.. maybe not.. I was not that slow :-) > > > > When I have a bad day (neurons not working together, acting like > > brakes), slowing down helps preventing disasters or bad times, I > > agree. > > But when I feel great, I don't have to take care about solving > > slowly, because turn speed is automatically regulated, driven > by the > > anticipation possibilities. > > > > I often heard people telling you have to slow down if you want > to be > > consistent, but it never really worked for me, when I was a > beginner > > or now. > > What about you? > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" > > <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > > Perhaps a part of this is the fact that because you haven't > touched > > the cube in two weeks, you're forced to go slightly slower at the > > beginning. > > > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: Gilles Roux > > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > > Sent: Tuesday, July 26, 2005 10:30 AM > > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Want to improve? ... > > > > > > > > > > > > ... Stop cubing! > > > > > > For the last 2 weeks, I hardly touched a cube. Yesterday, I > > recorded an > > > (rolling) average, and it looked so easy! 14.32s (all > sub-16.2). > > > I don't remember who it was, Dan Knights maybe, who was saying > > that > > > stopping for some time helped him getting faster too. > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Online puzzle games Puzzle games Jigsaw > puzzle > > game > > > Free puzzle games Computer puzzle game Free puzzle > inlay > > games > > > > > > > > > > -------------------------------------------------------------------- > > ---------- > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > > > > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! 217. Square-1 Method
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 23:37:02 -0000

I have a method that's been strictly in the planning stages. I'd
like to share it with everyone, in hopes of refining it further, and
getting useful feedback. It goes as follows:

1. Cube Shape


2. Solve D corners (forcing U-D corner seperation)


3. Seperate Edges+Permute U corners

www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia/sq1step3

**Still working on this page, I don't have algs yet**


4. Permute edges

>From what I can tell, this method has a manageable number of cases
if learned completely. I estimate possible average for this at
sub20. Let me know what you think.




218. Re: [Speed cubing group] Telling the difference between a cuber and a non-cuber...
From: "tsbischof" <tom@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 23:48:13 -0000

*Mechanism Non-cuber: It comes apart?! Cuber: How many pieces have you popped? *Solving Non-cuber: I need to move this sticker here... Cuber: Left Sune and a T-perm and you're done. *Upon solving Non-cuber: Gah! That was so fast! Like under a minute or something! Cuber: Not bad, but I saw that it took you a while to recognize OLL there... Hopefully I'm not the only one who gets these (both the jokes and in actual experiences). -Thomas Bischof --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Non-cuber: Blindfold and handcuffs. > Cubers: Blindfolded while handcuffed. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Jul 27, 2005, at 2:39 PM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > Thought of these while walking home from the train station today... > > > > *Stickers > > Non-cuber: I peel the stickers off because I can't solve it. > > Cuber: I peel the stickers off because I wore them out. > > > > *Methods > > Non-cuber: Is there a method? > > Cuber: What's your method? > > > > *Solve times > > Non-cuber: What's your fastest time? > > Cuber: What's your average (regular and best)? > > > > *Lube > > Non-cuber: *snicker* > > Cuber: What brand, how often and where can I get some? > > > > Any others?? :) > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 220. Re: Square-1 Method
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 00:53:19 -0000

I think that square-1 still has a long way to go until we approach an
optimal solution. But this does look to me like it might be able to
contend (I don't know what Lars V's method is, though.)

> 1. Cube Shape

Obviously, the best way to do this step is to memorize how to solve
from any shape, but I don't know what you're going to do about this.
I only know two good methods for returning to a cube. One is to
gather 6 corners on one side, then you only have about 5 or 6 cases
to memorize. The other is to gather exactly 4 corners on the top
side. This leaves 4 edges on the top and the same on the bottom.
Limits the number of cases you have to know.

> 2. Solve D corners (forcing U-D corner seperation)

Both getting corners on their right layer and permuting them take
very few twists, so this should be fast.

> 3. Seperate Edges+Permute U corners

I'm not sure what the actual move counts would be for this, but it
seems like it would be more efficient to solve all corners at once.
50%, I think, of the time you can do it with 3 twists.

> 4. Permute edges

Lots of cases for this, but I think it could get pretty fast. I'm
wondering what you plan to do about parity? Doubles the number of
algorithms if you include algorithms for all parities. But pushes
the time way up if you don't.

> From what I can tell, this method has a manageable number of cases
> if learned completely. I estimate possible average for this at
> sub20. Let me know what you think.

I'm actually planning my own square-1 method right now. Mine would
go like this:

1. Cube shape.

Either learning all cases or using one of the methods I described
above.

2. Get colors on the correct layers

Initially I may split this up into corners then edges (that's what i
do right now). I'm thinking (I haven't looked into it seriously,
but) probably less than 30 algorithms for this step when combined.

3. Solve corners.

Really easy step. Only about 8 algorithms for this. And like I said
above, half the time, it's really really fast.

4. Solve edges.

Maybe someday, all in one step, but initially, find the fastest edge
parity swap and use it when there is a parity issue. Since there are
algorithms for all the even parity cases, this should add very little
time. I don't know how many cases there would be, but I think if we
add parity into the algorithms, this may be comparable to the LL on
the 3-cube.

Sorry about the long post. I have strong opinions about speedsolving
the square-1. I think if I knew as many algorithms for square1 as I
did for the cube, I'd be faster than Lars. I am glad to see that
lately, a lot more people are learning the square-1 and pushing the
limits, hopefully past what has been done by Lars.

By the way, I think we need to get some three letter acronyms for
these steps like they have for the cube. (PLL, CLL, F2L, etc...)

-Ben.

225. Re: [Speed cubing group] New F2L idea/approach (well, maybe new)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 22:35:39 -0500

I've wondered about this since starting partial edge control a while ago. Recently, I've taken to using COLL as often as possible, so having properly oriented edges when I get to the LL helps quite a bit. It's often the difference between sub-20 and not sub-20 for me.

Lately, I've been focusing on the LL edge pieces during the entire F2L, preserving them when possible, but generally keeping an eye on them. At very least, it helps me to know how many and which I'll need to flip come 4th corner/edge pair or beginning of LL. Generally, I don't know very many alternate algorithms for edge preserving, but it still helps to know where I'll end up a bit earlier.

Hopefully, in the relatively near future, I'll learn the rest of the case 2 for the ZBF2L algs you've compiled. That ought to help me out immensely. We'll soon see.

-Mike Bennett


----- Original Message -----
From: cmhardw
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 5:19 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] New F2L idea/approach (well, maybe new)


Hey everyone,

I've been really doing some thinking about my F2L lately, and came up
with a cool new technique that I really like, and that I think has
very general applications.

Obviously for ZBF2L I really have to focus on the LL edges while
solving the 4th pair, but I find it to be very hard to be thrust into
this F2L case + LL edges case right after the 3rd pair.

So what I've started doing is to mentally focus only on the LL edges
while solving F2L. This is kinda cool, since it means I have an idea
the whole time what the LL edges are doing, sometimes I get most of
them oriented for one pair, only to flip them later, etc.. I'm
starting to get a feel for which F2L algs flip the LL edges a lot, and
which ones are more preserving.

Anyway this makes the F2L itself a little easier. I know that sounds
weird, but since you are mentally focusing on your LL color only, the
F2L pieces really stand out as "wrong" or "weird" since they don't
have the LL color.

It's weird, but my F2L is actually pretty smooth this way, plus the
transition from 3rd pair to 4th pair ZBF2L is easier since I have been
thinking about the LL edges the whole time and am not suddenly thrust
into this hard case.

So anyway I don't know if anyone has ever tried F2L while focusing on
LL edges, it's sort of an inverted way of thinking, but it really
makes the F2L pieces stand out.

Just wanted to post, it seems to be helping me specifically for ZBF2L,
but I also am getting some nice standard F2L solves when I try it.

Try it and see what you think!
Chris

Jigsaw puzzle game Puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games

228. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Square-1 Method
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 27 Jul 2005 23:35:57 -0700 (PDT)

nice guys. its cool to think of solving the bottom first so that your eyes are on the top layer when you finally permute. as for me im doing the opposite lol i solve the top first. 1.top corners. 2. top edges 3. permute everything at once on the bottom / fix odd parity if needed. my best time for the square-1 is 20.81 sec. done at the orange county fair. i guess it was kinda lucky the top layer was done pretty quick :-D mostly i range in the 40s --- Ben King <grsbmd@...> wrote: > I think that square-1 still has a long way to go > until we approach an > optimal solution. But this does look to me like it > might be able to > contend (I don't know what Lars V's method is, > though.) > > > 1. Cube Shape > > Obviously, the best way to do this step is to > memorize how to solve > from any shape, but I don't know what you're going > to do about this. > I only know two good methods for returning to a > cube. One is to > gather 6 corners on one side, then you only have > about 5 or 6 cases > to memorize. The other is to gather exactly 4 > corners on the top > side. This leaves 4 edges on the top and the same > on the bottom. > Limits the number of cases you have to know. > > > 2. Solve D corners (forcing U-D corner > seperation) > > Both getting corners on their right layer and > permuting them take > very few twists, so this should be fast. > > > 3. Seperate Edges+Permute U corners > > I'm not sure what the actual move counts would be > for this, but it > seems like it would be more efficient to solve all > corners at once. > 50%, I think, of the time you can do it with 3 > twists. > > > 4. Permute edges > > Lots of cases for this, but I think it could get > pretty fast. I'm > wondering what you plan to do about parity? Doubles > the number of > algorithms if you include algorithms for all > parities. But pushes > the time way up if you don't. > > > From what I can tell, this method has a manageable > number of cases > > if learned completely. I estimate possible > average for this at > > sub20. Let me know what you think. > > I'm actually planning my own square-1 method right > now. Mine would > go like this: > > 1. Cube shape. > > Either learning all cases or using one of the > methods I described > above. > > 2. Get colors on the correct layers > > Initially I may split this up into corners then > edges (that's what i > do right now). I'm thinking (I haven't looked into > it seriously, > but) probably less than 30 algorithms for this step > when combined. > > 3. Solve corners. > > Really easy step. Only about 8 algorithms for this. > And like I said > above, half the time, it's really really fast. > > 4. Solve edges. > > Maybe someday, all in one step, but initially, find > the fastest edge > parity swap and use it when there is a parity issue. > Since there are > algorithms for all the even parity cases, this > should add very little > time. I don't know how many cases there would be, > but I think if we > add parity into the algorithms, this may be > comparable to the LL on > the 3-cube. > > Sorry about the long post. I have strong opinions > about speedsolving > the square-1. I think if I knew as many algorithms > for square1 as I > did for the cube, I'd be faster than Lars. I am > glad to see that > lately, a lot more people are learning the square-1 > and pushing the > limits, hopefully past what has been done by Lars. > > By the way, I think we need to get some three letter > acronyms for > these steps like they have for the cube. (PLL, CLL, > F2L, etc...) > > -Ben. > > > ____________________________________________________ Start your day with Yahoo! - make it your home page http://www.yahoo.com/r/hs
229. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 12:19:31 +0530

I have also taught two of my friends and they ave around 2:30. but i wanted to ask what method u all use to teaach large audiences and how much time didi it take? Sachin On 7/27/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...m> wrote: > Currently teaching three people at work and one younger brother. In the past year, have taught just over a dozen how to solve. A friend and my girlfriend both average under 30. > > Rock. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Andreas Renberg > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 10:28 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence > > > I am currently teaching 3 people, and I also tried teaching my 9 year > old little brother, but he was to impatient. > > Andreas > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > The worst influence at a summer camp you'll ever meet: taught about > 500 > > students over a couple of years. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Jul 27, 2005, at 6:36 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" > > > <mahti-anssi@l...> wrote: > > >> My dad, two cousins and one classmate can solve the cube. > > >> Everybody in under 3 minutes. How about you others? > > > > > > President of the Rutgers Rubik's Cube Club...taught dozens to > solve. ;) > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 230. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 01:59:28 -0500

I teach either a very simple corners first method or a very simple layer by layer method, depending on whether they see corners or edges easier at first. For the corners, I teach them how to solve four on a side intuitively, and then one corner permuter and the Sune/antisune. Then I teach them simple commutators to solve the pieces on one side, followed by two different 3 cycles and some edge flippers to orient. It's probably 7 easy algorithms total. Takes a couple of hours, though. For people who can see edges easier, I teach them how to solve the cross on top, generally using the 'put the piece directly below where it needs to be' approach. Two cases. Then come the U layer corners. Three cases. Then I teach them how to solve middle layer edges (cross side is now on bottom). Two algorithms that are very simple and only a single ' different. Then comes working corners, if they are doing well. This is followed by two cases for edge orienting. Then comes the corner permuter, same as above. Next is the Sune/antisune. Then, I teach a simple 3 cycle and its reverse. Including working corners, I taught the latter method to someone in just over an hour, and she was watching a movie at the time. She has since moved on to a 3 look LL and the F2L, and averages under 30, with very little effort. I've also taught it to a couple of people that have taken several hour or longer sessions and are still very beginner. It all depends on the student and how much they want to improve. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: Sachin Shirwalkar To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Thursday, July 28, 2005 1:49 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence I have also taught two of my friends and they ave around 2:30. but i wanted to ask what method u all use to teaach large audiences and how much time didi it take? Sachin On 7/27/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: > Currently teaching three people at work and one younger brother. In the past year, have taught just over a dozen how to solve. A friend and my girlfriend both average under 30. > > Rock. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Andreas Renberg > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 10:28 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence > > > I am currently teaching 3 people, and I also tried teaching my 9 year > old little brother, but he was to impatient. > > Andreas > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > The worst influence at a summer camp you'll ever meet: taught about > 500 > > students over a couple of years. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Jul 27, 2005, at 6:36 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" > > > <mahti-anssi@l...> wrote: > > >> My dad, two cousins and one classmate can solve the cube. > > >> Everybody in under 3 minutes. How about you others? > > > > > > President of the Rutgers Rubik's Cube Club...taught dozens to > solve. ;) > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > Yahoo! 234. Re: possibilities for an nxnxn cube
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 08:02:29 -0000

Yes. Look under my files section in cubewhiz.com. It is written in Java, however, there is no user interface. You must run it in DOS and have Java installed on your computer. Cube1 gives the number in scientific notation and Cube2 gives the number written out in expanded form. The program will give the number of combinations for any cube of size n=2 to n=100. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, klcandyman <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was wondering if there was a program somewhere to tell you the > possibilities for an nxnxn rubiks cube
235. [Speed cubing group] Re: Cool new COLL alg!
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 10:58:11 -0000

Wow, good memory. Hem, since not many people like it, it would go under your Step 5+6 list, I seem to have the fastest execution of it, and have been using it for so long... maybe you can name it the "Doug" after me :) on your site. I've really grown a liking to your naming scheme. This week I started calling the "Buffy" by that name. I take a bit longer on the mirror (not sure why, but I never do the inverse), and do it like this: L'UF2U'LUL'F2LU', the L's I do with my left hand (lots of supporting fingers), U with right index, U' with right thumb, and F2 with right thumb downward twice. Nowhere is there a genuine trigger, each move is pretty much individual, so it's suprising how I can still be fairly fast with it. Though in actuality I might be using r and r' instead of the L turns... hard to tell, depends on my mood. I just tried the inverse a few times (of the original) and I really like it, I think I can go much faster with it than this mirror I just listed. It solves the same case. Looks like it's time to change a 5yr old habit and covert... come to think of it, the only reason I can do the trigger-less mirror (I'm not as dexterous with my Left hand as most cubers out there) so fast is probably only due to necessity over the yrs. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > > On Jul 26, 2005, at 23:57, d_funny007 wrote: > > > I've actively used this alg for about 5yrs now. Just checked LarsP's > > site, thought it might already have a name or something but guess > > not. > > You showed me that one, and I recognize it when I see it, but I've > never gotten around to practicing it much. > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." > --- Frank Zappa > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com

238. Re: New F2L idea/approach (well, maybe new)
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 12:56:25 -0000

Hi Chris, This is a bit like how I think for the F2L. When working on F2L pairs, my focus is actually on looking for pieces that don't have yellow (yellow is always my LL face). I find this much easier than trying to focus on five different F2L colours. It also makes it less difficult switching between a White/Yellow cube (my usual colour scheme) and a White/Blue cube. If someone hands me a White/Blue cube, then during the F2L I just think to myself 'focus on non-blue'. What I'm not doing, which you have obviously started to do, is pay attention to what is actually happening to the LL edges during the F2L. I might try giving this a go sometimes, although I imagine you'd only get the full benefit of it if learning ZB or VH, both of which are too advanced for me at the moment!! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I've been really doing some thinking about my F2L lately, and came up > with a cool new technique that I really like, and that I think has > very general applications. > > Obviously for ZBF2L I really have to focus on the LL edges while > solving the 4th pair, but I find it to be very hard to be thrust into > this F2L case + LL edges case right after the 3rd pair. > > So what I've started doing is to mentally focus only on the LL edges > while solving F2L. This is kinda cool, since it means I have an idea > the whole time what the LL edges are doing, sometimes I get most of > them oriented for one pair, only to flip them later, etc.. I'm > starting to get a feel for which F2L algs flip the LL edges a lot, and > which ones are more preserving. > > Anyway this makes the F2L itself a little easier. I know that sounds > weird, but since you are mentally focusing on your LL color only, the > F2L pieces really stand out as "wrong" or "weird" since they don't > have the LL color. > > It's weird, but my F2L is actually pretty smooth this way, plus the > transition from 3rd pair to 4th pair ZBF2L is easier since I have been > thinking about the LL edges the whole time and am not suddenly thrust > into this hard case. > > So anyway I don't know if anyone has ever tried F2L while focusing on > LL edges, it's sort of an inverted way of thinking, but it really > makes the F2L pieces stand out. > > Just wanted to post, it seems to be helping me specifically for ZBF2L, > but I also am getting some nice standard F2L solves when I try it. > > Try it and see what you think! > Chris

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 09:27:03 -0600

Everyone wants to see a co-worker or friend of mine scrambling the
cube. The reason I didn't do that before is because I wasn't as fast
as I am today, and my camera has a 3 minute limit so pretty much I had
to use every second I could solving the cube. I can average about 2:20
to 2:30 now, so I think that gives a co-worker 15 seconds to scramble a
cube for me.

Does any one have an idea of how to do it so I can prove that I'm not
looking?

247. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New F2L idea/approach (well, maybe new)
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 11:51:03 -0500

I'm curious how much work it would take to learn a few simple algs that help with corner positioning. I managed to insert my final edge pair on a solve last night in such a way that it correctly oriented my corners, and I did it on purpose. It was entirely accidental that it happened to permute them correctly, too. But getting the Z perm after a fantastic F2L+LL edges just felt great. The fact that it was a 16.45 didn't hurt, either. If anyone knows more about this, please let me know. It's something I'd like to look into. -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: jasmine_ellen To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Thursday, July 28, 2005 7:56 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: New F2L idea/approach (well, maybe new) Hi Chris, This is a bit like how I think for the F2L. When working on F2L pairs, my focus is actually on looking for pieces that don't have yellow (yellow is always my LL face). I find this much easier than trying to focus on five different F2L colours. It also makes it less difficult switching between a White/Yellow cube (my usual colour scheme) and a White/Blue cube. If someone hands me a White/Blue cube, then during the F2L I just think to myself 'focus on non-blue'. What I'm not doing, which you have obviously started to do, is pay attention to what is actually happening to the LL edges during the F2L. I might try giving this a go sometimes, although I imagine you'd only get the full benefit of it if learning ZB or VH, both of which are too advanced for me at the moment!! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I've been really doing some thinking about my F2L lately, and came up > with a cool new technique that I really like, and that I think has > very general applications. > > Obviously for ZBF2L I really have to focus on the LL edges while > solving the 4th pair, but I find it to be very hard to be thrust into > this F2L case + LL edges case right after the 3rd pair. > > So what I've started doing is to mentally focus only on the LL edges > while solving F2L. This is kinda cool, since it means I have an idea > the whole time what the LL edges are doing, sometimes I get most of > them oriented for one pair, only to flip them later, etc.. I'm > starting to get a feel for which F2L algs flip the LL edges a lot, and > which ones are more preserving. > > Anyway this makes the F2L itself a little easier. I know that sounds > weird, but since you are mentally focusing on your LL color only, the > F2L pieces really stand out as "wrong" or "weird" since they don't > have the LL color. > > It's weird, but my F2L is actually pretty smooth this way, plus the > transition from 3rd pair to 4th pair ZBF2L is easier since I have been > thinking about the LL edges the whole time and am not suddenly thrust > into this hard case. > > So anyway I don't know if anyone has ever tried F2L while focusing on > LL edges, it's sort of an inverted way of thinking, but it really > makes the F2L pieces stand out. > > Just wanted to post, it seems to be helping me specifically for ZBF2L, > but I also am getting some nice standard F2L solves when I try it. > > Try it and see what you think! > Chris ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! 249. Re: [Speed cubing group] Telling the difference between a cuber and a non-cuber...
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 28 Jul 2005 18:11:41 -0000

*stickers
Non-Cuber: He's not actually solving it. He's just peeling off the
stickers really fast.
Cuber: When I get going really fast, the stickers start to peel off.

*bluffing
Non-Cuber: I can always get five sides but I can't ever get the sixth.
Cuber: (No Comment)


These are both true stories.

-Ben.

265. Here's a start (Re: Solving Sudoku) (Spoiler)
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 02:35:12 -0000

That's all well and good, I was able to figure that much the first try. It seemed that after an hr on it I had only placed one number (the 6). But I eventrually got two boxes/regions. But then I got to the following point and haven't been able to proceed for over a week. . 2 6 * . . 7 * . . 8 8 9 5 * 6 2 . * . 7 3 . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . * * * * * * * * * * * 4 5 7 * 1 9 3 * 8 6 2 9 8 3 * 2 4 6 * 5 1 7 6 1 2 * 5 7 8 * . . 4 * * * * * * * * * * * 2 . 9 * . 1 . * 7 8 . 5 4 8 * 7 . 9 * . . . 7 . 1 * 8 . 2 * . 4 . Kinda wierd one can still get stuck after getting two boxes, one column, and two rows... Well I've been staring at this for a rather long time. I do know that (3,7) is one of 1,2,6,9; that (3,8) is one of 2,5,9; and that (3,9) is one of 1,6,9. (1,7) can be one of 1,4,9. Well anyways I'm lost. Also I'm what is known as a "logical-purist" so I won't be satisfied with trial-error and stuff like that... (though in my math classes I do proof-by-contratdicton all the time). Well I found the solution using trial/error, but I'm very much displeased by it, since I was able to convince myself of uniqueness in addition to existance, there much be a better way. Probably a method I don't know about. I started tring out ways of symutaneously placing all of a certain number. I noted that 5 had two different possiblities (placing one (in 1 of 2 spots in a row/col/box) would place force all others). -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > Hi all, > > > > > > Last week, this Sudoku was posted in this group: > > > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 . > > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > > 5 . . * . . 9 * . . . > > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. Can anyone give me some tactical > > > advise on how to solve it? Seems I can't solve it without > > > trial-and-error... > > > > > > -Bram > > This is a bit OT for cubing but anyway, here's the first few steps (to get the first 7 cells in). > It's still difficult after this so there's still a challenge left but it still doesn't need any trial & > error. > Initial Grid: (above) > For convenience label rows R1 to R9 (downwards), columns C1-C9 (left to right), boxes > B1-B9 (right then down). > > 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a > 6). > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > ***|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*1* > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 5**|**9|*** > ***|***|*4* > > 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and > R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must > contain 7. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > ***|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 5**|**9|*** > ***|***|*4* > > 3. In B5, 1 and 8 must appear on the leading diagonal as they are already present in C5 > and R5. Thus since 7 is in R5, 7 must occur in the intersection of B5 and C5. In particular > in C5, 4,7 and 8 appear before B8. Thus in R8 4,7,8 must occur in C2-C4 and hence 4 lies > in the intersection of C2 and R8. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > ***|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 54*|**9|*** > ***|***|*4* > > 4. Thus in B4, 4 goes in the intersection of R4 and C1. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 4**|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 54*|**9|*** > ***|***|*4* > > 5. Thus in C1, 7 must go in R9. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 4**|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 54*|**9|*** > 7**|***|*4* > > 6. Recalling that in R8, C2-C4 contain 4,7 and 8, 8 must go in C3 (because B7 contains > 4,7) and so 7 in C4. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 4**|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7**|***|*4*
266. [Speed cubing group] Re: Want to improve? ...
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 03:01:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > "It's all about F2L." - Shotaro Makisumi That's a great quote! I need to put it on a huge banner in my new apartment, and get a shirt or mug with it on. It one of those things only uber geeks would understand :). I've been learning so much ZBLL, specialized CLL, doing ELLs from different angles... I've neglected F2L too much. All the ZBLL I know is so useless without a good number of ZBF2L to support them. My times have grown increasingly inconsistant once again. I switched to a 25th anniversary cube about a month ago and notcied that my standard deviation dropped like a rock (to like 1.5), my mean dropped slightly too. But with the special cases I've started actively using my SD has risen again. A few days ago I got a 10.32 solve and these sub-15s are becomming more frequent. However I now get a bunch of >30s solves as well. I take a long time during recognition... there's a lot to see between steps. Dispite having plenty of experience doing COLL recognition... Recalling those ZBF2L cases is pretty painful and gives at least a 2s pause. >From my best RA of 22.16 this summer, my times avarage 25s again. But I'm not particularly sad about it. I really enjoy taking these weeks to (re)learn F2L. A few of my algs have changed too. I caught a new COLL alg from BobB, and I'm getting an all time high on the percentage of getting good LL edges. It's kinda cool how my internal alg set/repitoure changes a little bit every week (when I'm active), swapped out three COLL algs this week. And even this slight change requires a lot of effort to practice for me. I think I fear change too much. I keep piling on more algs. This is bad... Lots of my previous algs need to be re-examined FIRST. I used to think this was hard to do, but I heard ppl like DanH saying they change algs they don't like all the time. With 100% on ZBF2L, the chances of an OLL skip is 1/27... for the COLL to solve it is 1/12. I like those odds :). -Doug

274. Re: I am awesome
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 11:47:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> > wrote: > > Watch me solve a Pyraminx, a Rubik's Cube and a Megaminx ultimately > > fast: > > > > http://www.stefan-pochmann. > > de/spocc/other_stuff/videos/PyraminxRubinxMegaminx.wmv > > (672 KB) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > Quite impressive but I only see 3 sides of the cube solved (could be unsolved edges in the > unseen side - I'd be really impressed if you turned it over so we could see the other solved > sides! 275. Re: Square-1 Method
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 11:56:28 -0000

> --- "sinac_be" wrote:
> > I forgot to mention that after being back cube form, I use this
> > kind of method: corners orientation, edges orientation, corners
> > permutation and edges permutation

--- "Stefan Pochmann" wrote:
> You *orient* pieces of the Square-1 ???

I'm sure Joel means separation (i.e. bring to the correct layer).

As for recognising parity, it is not practical to try to recognise it
early. When it is not in the cube shape, there is no well defined
meaning to the parity of the position. It only has a definite meaning
when you get to the cube shape.

When it is in the cube shape, it is hard to recognise until you have
separated all the pieces into their layers, otherwise the time needed
for recognition is horrendous.





276. Re: Square-1 Method
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 12:09:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > As for recognising parity, it is not practical to try to recognise it > early. When it is not in the cube shape, there is no well defined > meaning to the parity of the position. It only has a definite meaning > when you get to the cube shape. Well if you know for each shape not only how to bring it to cube shape but also where each piece belongs (in the scrambled state, so that when you make the cube, the puzzle is completely solved), then you could see it right away. And you have 15 seconds preinspection, that could be enough for following 16 pieces :-) And you could know two ways for each shape to make it into a cube, one for each parity situation, so that you make the cube and fix parity at the same time. Another negative aspect though is that you'd probably want to preserve the parity until the end, which would mean the algorithms you use for the other steps might become longer (though I wouldn't be surprised if most optimal algorithms preserve parity). Cheers! Stefan
277. Re: [Speed cubing group] Calendar cube games
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 10:55:28 -0400

My calendar cube is on my desk at work, so I don't solve it on weekends. I'm trying to arrange my cube today (Friday, July 29th) so that I'll have as few turns as possible to solve it when I come in on Monday, August 1st. So far I've got it down to 11 turns. Can anyone do better? I have my stickers applied like cubesmith.com suggests. Here's my solution: Friday JUL 29 on F G at (U)R Tues at (R)UB C at (B)L 1 at (L)DB Wednes at (D)FL R' L' D B' L' B L' B' U B U' On 7/27/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > So yeah, I'm a self admitted calendar cube addict. I use my calendar > cube everyday, and always change it with the day :-D It actually is a > lot of fun! > > I thought of an interesting challenge for it. Trying to minimize the > number of turns required to change each day (average for each month). > You can take longer to solve the next day and also do some moves to > prepare the day after that, but then again you can't do too much since > you have to solve today in as few moves as possible. > > I also wonder if there is a distinct cube configuration for the > beginning of each month such that every time you solve a day, the next > day is setup very easily. It seems with some thought you could plan > out this entire solution and just setup the cube that way at the > beginning of each month with a regular Fridrich solve. So the first > day of that month is say 50-55 moves (or you could FMC the solution on > a regular cube and get it in even less) then each day after that is > maybe 5 or so. > > Not sure which the best way would be, but it's fun to try to turn > something that seems at first to be simple into a more complicated puzzle. > > Does anyone else use the calendar cube, or try to minimize the moves > required for each day change? > > Chris

Yeah, it's cool being a girl. Much more variety when it comes to fashion and accessories! :) I saw a sparkly Rubik's Cube necklace in a trendy store a few months ago. I was going to buy it until I found out how much it cost 80 pounds!! This is ~$USD140!! Then I looked closer and saw that it was basically just a keychain cube with fake gems stuck to it. What a rip-off. BTW, Doug did you just make up that thing about the fingernails? If so, that's a huge coincidence because I said the same thing in an interview the other day. I have actually done this before, but it was a long long time ago. 280. Messy generating function
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 20:30:56 -0000

Hey everyone,

I need to find the coefficient of x^7 in this generating function, and
I don't have any math software. Is there a place I can do this online?

(1+x)^5*(1+x+x^2)^9*(1+x+x^2+x^3)*(1+x+...+x^4)^4*(1+x+...+x^6)^3*(1+x+...+x^8)*(1+x+...+x^9)^2*(1+x+...+x^12)

And yes the function relates to scrabble odds :-D

Chris

P.S. Is there an easier way to find 1) the odds for drawing a certain
7 letter word at the start of the game, including using blanks and 2)
the total number of unique draws out of the bag at the start of the
game?

All I could really figure out for this was to use generating
functions, but I don't have any math softward to go further.

P.P.S. without googling it? :-D

284. Re: [Speed cubing group] Messy generating function
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 21:12:12 -0000

Wait is this right? So by the expansion the term is 16007560800*x^7 which is what I set it up as the number of distinct opening draws from the bag of 100 tiles. So this would count eeeeeez as the same draw as zeeeeee and eezeee. Also this doesn't acount for the ordering of the tiles on your rack, it's just the number of groupings of tiles out of the bag. Is this right? 296. Re: [Speed cubing group] Dallas, here I come...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 21:47:42 -0600

Hey Chris,

That's great to hear! Want to come on Dallas news with me at 5:30 AM
on Friday?

301. Easy PLL-case :-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 05:23:34 -0000

Hi!

Which algorithm for the _+_ solely edge PLL case is everyone's
favorite?

(M2 u M2 u2 M2 u M2) or( M2 D2 M2 U M2 D2 M2 U')?

Or are there other ones just as easy?

Cheers!

-Per

PS! Of course with u is meant the fingertrick u.
u=(UE') and u2=(U2E2)




302. Re: Easy PLL-case :-)
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 05:43:11 -0000

(M2' U) (M2' U2) (M2' U) M2') http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05slow.avi http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05fast.avi I average sub-1.5 for this algorithm and can achieve sub-1.3 on perfect execution. :-) Watch the videos to see exactly how I perform it. ;-) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > Which algorithm for the _+_ solely edge PLL case is everyone's > favorite? > > (M2 u M2 u2 M2 u M2) or( M2 D2 M2 U M2 D2 M2 U')? > > Or are there other ones just as easy? > > Cheers! > > -Per > > PS! Of course with u is meant the fingertrick u. > u=(UE') and u2=(U2E2)
303. Re: Easy PLL-case :-)
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 05:52:27 -0000

Sorry to post again. I actually just remade my fast video. The new one shows a near-perfect execution in 1.133 seconds. Maybe sub-1 is possible? ;-) It was only my second try, too. :-D ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > Which algorithm for the _+_ solely edge PLL case is everyone's > favorite? > > (M2 u M2 u2 M2 u M2) or( M2 D2 M2 U M2 D2 M2 U')? > > Or are there other ones just as easy? > > Cheers! > > -Per > > PS! Of course with u is meant the fingertrick u. > u=(UE') and u2=(U2E2)

Oh how I wish you could pick the hotel first then attach a flight (instead of flight then hotel). Ahhhh.... I want to scream. I need to find something from Detroit to Dallas staying at Hearthside Suites from the 11th till the 14th (preferably an evening flight back) with no limit of connectors (though a layover in Omaha would be amazing). I need phone numbers (or just Tyson's cell) too in case I need help: need a ride, or get lost... Some of the deals I select don't even have Hearthside as an option... are the differnt airports in Dallas located very far from each other? Which is Hearthside closest to? Man I'd just google and find out all this stuff myself and had been done with it if I wasn't so lazy... or if I wasn't on dial-up this week. On broadband and a fast computer I tend to book flihgts by opening upwards of 30 browser windows... lol. I mean I could chance it and try for a last minute deal... :). Ok it's 5:15AM, I'm going to keep looking. The concensus seesm to be at $439 on all these sites... but I know I can find something under $400... oh dear god please! Last minute deals with hotel can even dip below $275... How about those cubers with cars help out with shuttle service from the hotel to the venue??? Or maybe even airport, that'd be marvelous! I keep asking myself... "Do I really need to come???" Thus I'm probably going to chance it last minute... I can't really do much with my current finances. p.s. 308. Re: Easy PLL-case :-)
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 10:54:20 -0000

I love this PLL case! This one and the 3-cycle of edges are my favourites.. :) I use basically the same alg as you, Bob, except I do U' for the second and second last moves and I execute it differently (and not as fast as you!). I don't use my left hand fingers for the M2 moves, and I have my right thumb on the FRU cubie and use it to flick the U' and U2 moves. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > (M2' U) (M2' U2) (M2' U) M2') > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05slow.avi > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll05fast.avi > > I average sub-1.5 for this algorithm and can achieve sub-1.3 on > perfect execution. :-) Watch the videos to see exactly how I perform > it. ;-) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi! > > > > Which algorithm for the _+_ solely edge PLL case is everyone's > > favorite? > > > > (M2 u M2 u2 M2 u M2) or( M2 D2 M2 U M2 D2 M2 U')? > > > > Or are there other ones just as easy? > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > PS! because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward.

311. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 11:56:04 -0000

My least favourite PLL-case is for sre #16 on Dan Harris site. Its the only case where my average is over 3 seconds. If someone have a good algoritm for that case the feel free to share it. :-) http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/permutations/permutationslist .php#pll16 My favourite case is #11 on Dan Harris site. I love my algoritm on that case. My best average is 1,72 and my best time 1,34. http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/permutations/permutationslist .php#pll16 --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > My least favourite PLL case is this one: > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/v1.gif > If anyone loves this PLL case, please tell me which alg you are using > because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward. > > What is everyone elses least favourite PLL case? > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

313. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 12:42:44 -0000

Hey Jasmine! That's actually one of my better cases :). I do it like this: (R' U R' U') x2 y' (R' U R' U')(l R U')(R' U R U) But when I first learned this algorithms, I did the cube rotation the wrong way.. There is a nice way to 'combine' that x2 y' with the surrounding moves. This is well illustrated on this movie:" http://www.planet-puzzle.com/pll_video/n9.html (Only Katsu does the last few moves slightly different, it shows the cube rotation. LarsV also has a different algorithm that's not used by a lot of cubers, see www.cubezone.be. My worst case has to be (ULF URB) (UL UR). Cyou Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > My least favourite PLL case is this one: > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/v1.gif > If anyone loves this PLL case, please tell me which alg you are using > because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward. > > What is everyone elses least favourite PLL case? > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

planning of where/when to take vacations

that city/county

315. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 13:15:33 -0000

#16 used to be one of my least favourites because I hadn't learnt a PLL for it. I used a combination of 2 PLLs instead :/ A couple of weeks ago at the UK speedcubers gathering, Duncan taught me an easy to remember alg for this case: L U' R D2 R' U L' U2 L U' R D2 R' U L' I find this easy to remember because it's just the same sequence (L U' R D2 R' U L') repeated with a U2 in between. I also quite like #11. :) I use the second alg list on Dan's site for this, although I hold the cube differently when I execute it. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > My least favourite PLL-case is for sre #16 on Dan Harris site. Its > the only case where my average is over 3 seconds. If someone have a > good algoritm for that case the feel free to share it. :-) > http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/permutations/permutationslist > .php#pll16 > > My favourite case is #11 on Dan Harris site. I love my algoritm on > that case. My best average is 1,72 and my best time 1,34. > > http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/permutations/permutationslist > .php#pll16 > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > My least favourite PLL case is this one: > > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/v1.gif > > If anyone loves this PLL case, please tell me which alg you are using > > because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward. > > > > What is everyone elses least favourite PLL case? > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com
316. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 14:02:47 -0000

--- G'day Jasmine! This one was always awkward for me too but I picked a better alg from somewhere (can't remember where now). Try: L'U R U' L U L'U R'U' L U2 R U2 R' and see what ya reckon. It sets up the case as well so just keep doin the same alg to set it up and to solve it. Hope that helps. BTW, did ya get my last email? Keith. In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > My least favourite PLL case is this one: > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/v1.gif > If anyone loves this PLL case, please tell me which alg you are using > because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward. > > What is everyone elses least favourite PLL case? > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com
317. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 14:30:48 -0000

That alg is heaps better than the one I've been using. I'm going to re-learn that PLL case with that alg. For (ULF URB) (UL UR) and the mirror I use: L U' R d2 R' U L' U2 L U' R d2 R' U L' (+ the mirror alg) Duncan also taught me this one. Actually, I think Duncan's alg was a little different, I just made a slight modification which made it easier for me to remember. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jol van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey Jasmine! > > That's actually one of my better cases :). I do it like this: > > (R' U R' U') x2 y' (R' U R' U')(l R U')(R' U R U) > > But when I first learned this algorithms, I did the cube rotation the > wrong way.. There is a nice way to 'combine' that x2 y' with the > surrounding moves. This is well illustrated on this movie:" > > http://www.planet-puzzle.com/pll_video/n9.html > > (Only Katsu does the last few moves slightly different, it shows the > cube rotation. > > LarsV also has a different algorithm that's not used by a lot of > cubers, see www.cubezone.be. > > My worst case has to be (ULF URB) (UL UR). > > Cyou > > Jol. > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > My least favourite PLL case is this one: > > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/v1.gif > > If anyone loves this PLL case, please tell me which alg you are using > > because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward. > > > > What is everyone elses least favourite PLL case? > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

320. Re: Group running out of space ... ??
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 15:15:30 -0000

We are running out of space, but this is the first time that's ever happened. The files section has 20 MB allocated and we are using 96% of that. So you can only upload about 800kb right now. The photos section has 30MB allocated and we are using 82% of that so only 5.14 MB remain. This isn't really that much of a problem, since photos are usually small. We can put the videos on a time limit, so the oldest videos will be removed and then the space freed up until it fills up again, at which point the oldest videos will be removed. Since this is the first time this has happened I have no plan for what to do. So what do you guys suggest? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > I just tried to upload a file about 2.3 MB. And i got message there is > not enough space. Since there already is a file uploaded almost 5MB i > reckon this is total allocated space for files. Or in worst case it's > the total space for all the files, photos, messages and so on of the > group. Im not sure ... :-( > > Should we do some cleaning in the files and photos sections. Or maybe > move to some other site ?? > > Cheers :-) > > -Per

323. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 17:04:45 -0000

That case isn't too bad...that one is about 2.5 for me...one of my slower cases, still, though. I don't like the cases that swap diagonal corners and opposite edges: [(L U' R) U2' (L' U R')] [(L U' R) U2 (L' U R')] U' and its mirror. They are the only PLL cases for me that are over 3 seconds. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > My least favourite PLL-case is for sre #16 on Dan Harris site. Its > the only case where my average is over 3 seconds. If someone have a > good algoritm for that case the feel free to share it. :-) > http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/permutations/permutationslist > .php#pll16 > > My favourite case is #11 on Dan Harris site. I love my algoritm on > that case. My best average is 1,72 and my best time 1,34. > > http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/permutations/permutationslist > .php#pll16 > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > My least favourite PLL case is this one: > > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/v1.gif > > If anyone loves this PLL case, please tell me which alg you are using > > because the ones I've tried feel kinda awkward. > > > > What is everyone elses least favourite PLL case? > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

326. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 18:25:45 -0000

How about these algs for the case that we all seem to hate? R U' R' U l' U F U' R' F' R U' R U R' F R' R' F' R U R' U F' U' R' F R d R U2 l U z U R' U' R U F R F' U' R' U F' U F U' R U' I found these with ACube (only allowing <U,R,F> and optimizing for quarter turns) and then edited the best results to make them more finger-friendly. In particularly like the first algorithm a lot, I think that one can be quite fast, what do you think? Cheers! Stefan

328. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 19:53:36 -0000

I hate (UFR UBR) (UFL UBL). My alg is [(l U') (R' D)] (R U R') z
((L')2 U') (R U) (L U') (R' U)

It's 15 moves of "oh man why did *this* case have to come up?"

Chris

340. DIY cubes
From: "kovacic81" <kovacic81@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 18:15:20 -0000

I recently bought a few diy cubes. I have some questions if anyone can
help me out.

Do all DIY cubes have those weird center caps? the ones with the tabs..
Is Glue the only way to get the caps to stick?
If so, what type of glue is the best?
DO all DIy cubes have crowned centers?
My Cubes came with those rivets AND the screws, are everyones like that?

Thank You,

Jason Kovacic




341. Re: DIY cubes
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 18:40:28 -0000

Hi :-) Yes, you are supposed to have the choice between screw and rivets for attaching the centers to the core. I'm quiye sure 99% do prefer screws and not the rivets though. This is because it makes the cube tension adjustable :-) Cut away that "excess" inner material from the centercaps so thay actually fit into the centers then you can sand down the edges of the caps as well since they tend to be a little too wide. Now you either glue the centercap along one edge only or use thin paper to make a better fit. If you use glue make sure you have already adjusted the cube to your liking. Not that it's too hard to break the glue and reglue :-) The best glue to use is superglue. make sure it's _real_ superglue w ONLY cyanoacrylat as its content. Get it in a plastic tube with a pipette. This glue is useful for repairing broken cubies also :-) Cheers! -Per PS! All black diy-kits have arched centers yes. The white ones don't have it. Most prefer black diy beacuse w the arched centers u hardly get any popping. However, without the arched centers the cube might lock a little less. The locking on my diy cube is negligible :-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kovacic81" <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > I recently bought a few diy cubes. I have some questions if anyone can > help me out. > > Do all DIY cubes have those weird center caps? the ones with the tabs.. > Is Glue the only way to get the caps to stick? > If so, what type of glue is the best? > DO all DIy cubes have crowned centers? > My Cubes came with those rivets AND the screws, are everyones like that? > > Thank You, > > Jason Kovacic
342. WC2005 regulations about cubes
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 20:41:34 +0200

Hello,

I just have a question about the regulations about the fact that it
has to be a brand Rubik's cube :

# THE ONLY CUBES ALLOWED FOR COMPETITION ROUNDS MUST BE AUTHENTIC
RUBIK'S BRAND CUBES. COUNTERFEIT CUBES OR ALTERNATIVE CUBES WILL NOT
BE ACCEPTED.

Does that also include the stickers ?
For example if I want to take part to the championship with a Rubik's
Cube but with CubeSmith stickers, will I be allowed to compete with
that cube ?

Thx,
Gilles.

COUNTERFEIT CUBES OR ALTERNATIVE CUBES WILL NOT > BE ACCEPTED. > > Does that also include the stickers ? > For example if I want to take part to the championship with a Rubik's > Cube but with CubeSmith stickers, will I be allowed to compete with > that cube ? > > Thx, > Gilles.

345. Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 21:58:05 +0200

Hi Chris,

First of all, I think it is amazing what you already have achieved. I wish I had the spare time and guts to do this too.

Even though you have the most experience with ZB (maybe???), I still think that you are too negative about ZB.
Remember when you started F2L? It felt so awkward. Actually I have a 1981 book that describes the F2L technique, and in 1981 I made an annotation on that page: "too hard to apply". My opinion has changed completely now. :-)
What I am trying to say is that after looooooooots of practice ZB MUST be faster than basic CFOP. Fewer steps, fewer moves.
Recognition and the huge number of algorithms are an issue now, but won't be an issue when you have 3 years of practice at this.

Anyway, keep up the good work. I like your ZB pages a lot.

Have fun,

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: cmhardw
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, July 31, 2005 9:40 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method


I think I've finally found the future role that ZB will play in my
solving.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/myzb.html

Chris

346. Re: future of the ZB method
From: zorin_r <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
