And se how "spike" your times will be with Fridrich. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I think I've finally found the future role that ZB will play in my > solving. > > http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/myzb.html > > Chris
347. Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 20:08:18 -0000

Aaah I feel bad now, I don't mean to sound negative about ZB at all! I really do still see myself spending the time learn all of ZBLL, which I wouldn't do unless I REALLY liked it :-) I agree that maybe with a lot of practice, that ZB could potentially be faster than CFOP (it doesn't seem impossible). However, after seeing Sebastien and Jean on the 3x3 this seems like it would take a lot of practice indeed (at the very least 3 years or so). Maybe then this strategy of using it as a "first two rounds" method is a way to use it when you are in the intermediate stages of learning it? I think I will write something about that in my next entry. I do feel bad though, I really, really, really like the idea of ZB method (in fact that's why I want to learn it so badly!) but I have had some doubts lately about how fast it can get. This could of course be the fact that I have only used it for 6 months, which in the context of ZB is really not very long. I agree that perhaps this strategy would be a good idea for "intermediate/beginner" ZB users such as myself rather than for an expert (someone who knows all of it and has for at least a year). Hopefully my opinion will change in 3 years! I really hope it does, but I guess for now this is the strategy I want to pursue! Please don't think I feel negatively about ZB, quite the opposite! I will try to be more careful with my wording in the future, please no hard feelings! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi Chris, > > First of all, I think it is amazing what you already have achieved. I wish I had the spare time and guts to do this too. > > Even though you have the most experience with ZB (maybe???), I still think that you are too negative about ZB. > Remember when you started F2L? It felt so awkward. Actually I have a 1981 book that describes the F2L technique, and in 1981 I made an annotation on that page: "too hard to apply". My opinion has changed completely now. :-) > What I am trying to say is that after looooooooots of practice ZB MUST be faster than basic CFOP. Fewer steps, fewer moves. > Recognition and the huge number of algorithms are an issue now, but won't be an issue when you have 3 years of practice at this. > > Anyway, keep up the good work. I like your ZB pages a lot. > > Have fun, > > Ron
348. Re: future of the ZB method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 20:22:09 -0000

Exerpt from May 2, 2005: (I apoloize for the wording when comparing ZBF2L to F2L, looking at it now I think it's pretty harsh. I just mean to say that it was "very easy"). ------------------------------------------------------------ May 2, 2005: 18.95 18.42 15.12 16.07 17.60 (20.35) 17.00 15.82 17.09 (13.66) 16.22 16.94 = 16.92 This was my first pure Fridrich average since January 27, for almost 13 weeks. Recognizing the last F2L pair is pathetically easy after being used to trying to recognize the ZBF2L case. I think I'll use ZBF2L as my method of practicing for May, but at the actual competition I'll honestly probably end up doing pure Fridrich. I can't wait until I know ZBF2L well enough to use it in competition. :-( ------------------------------------------------------------ Exerpt from May 7, 2005: ------------------------------------------------------------ May 7, 2005: This next average was a mix of ZBF2L/COLL/PLL and F2L/OLL/PLL. I did 4 F2L/OLL/PLL solves, mostly near the end. I wanted to try to find a good balance of Fridrich and ZBF2L that I might use at the New York tournament. The 12.52 below was a ZBLL solve. 16.40 18.17 15.85 15.11 (12.52) 17.80 17.74 18.32 16.74 17.38 (19.65) 16.26 = 16.98 ------------------------------------------------------------- May 2nd shows that the transistion from ZB to Fridrich feels easy (when I am still in practice with Fridrich, 13 weeks is not as much time as 13 weeks plus basicaly 2 more months), and makes the steps feel easy. May 7th shows the spike times of ZBLL (the 12.52) and also that Fridrich helped me to stay consistent with the average when I got amnesia with ZBF2L. Right now I'm fairly rusty with Fridrich, I amnesia OLL cases a lot, and I'm at least 2-3 seconds slower on average than when I was practicing all the time. I hope with the 2 weeks of practice before Dallas that I can chip off some of that rustiness, but I imagine not having worked on Fridrich for a long time will really take its toll on my times. That doesn't mean I don't think this will be a bad strategy. Once I've had time to practice both ZB _and_ Fridrich together (switching between the two like I will in competition), I think it's possible that I'll be able to repeat May 2, as well as use a combination of ZB and Fridrich like on May 7 if I am screwing up with ZB in competition (amnesia and the like). Chris P.S. I can do a few averages and post them if you still want (ZB, then Fridrich, done in that order) but I can almost guarantee that the Fridrich will be nothing special, and perhaps slower than ZB since I haven't practiced Fridrich to the point of starting to amnesia OLL cases. Again, that entry was my theory for the future, once I've practiced in that mindset for a while. I don't expect immediate results with this at all. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, zorin_r <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Can you take some average with Fridrich so we can compare them with > average from your ZB? And se how "spike" your times will be with > Fridrich. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > I think I've finally found the future role that ZB will play in my > > solving. > > > > http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/myzb.html > > > > Chris
349. Re: future of the ZB method
From: zorin_r <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 21:18:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Exerpt from May 2, 2005: (I apoloize for the wording when comparing > ZBF2L to F2L, looking at it now I think it's pretty harsh. I just > mean to say that it was "very easy"). > ------------------------------------------------------------ > May 2, 2005: > > 18.95 18.42 15.12 16.07 17.60 (20.35) 17.00 15.82 17.09 (13.66) 16.22 > 16.94 = 16.92 > > This was my first pure Fridrich average since January 27, for almost > 13 weeks. Recognizing the last F2L pair is pathetically easy after > being used to trying to recognize the ZBF2L case. I think I'll use > ZBF2L as my method of practicing for May, but at the actual > competition I'll honestly probably end up doing pure Fridrich. I can't > wait until I know ZBF2L well enough to use it in competition. :-( > ------------------------------------------------------------ > > Exerpt from May 7, 2005: > ------------------------------------------------------------ > May 7, 2005: > This next average was a mix of ZBF2L/COLL/PLL and F2L/OLL/PLL. I did 4 > F2L/OLL/PLL solves, mostly near the end. I wanted to try to find a > good balance of Fridrich and ZBF2L that I might use at the New York > tournament. The 12.52 below was a ZBLL solve. > > 16.40 18.17 15.85 15.11 (12.52) 17.80 17.74 18.32 16.74 17.38 (19.65) > 16.26 = 16.98 > ------------------------------------------------------------- > > > May 2nd shows that the transistion from ZB to Fridrich feels easy > (when I am still in practice with Fridrich, 13 weeks is not as much > time as 13 weeks plus basicaly 2 more months), and makes the steps > feel easy. > > May 7th shows the spike times of ZBLL (the 12.52) and also that > Fridrich helped me to stay consistent with the average when I got > amnesia with ZBF2L. > > Right now I'm fairly rusty with Fridrich, I amnesia OLL cases a lot, > and I'm at least 2-3 seconds slower on average than when I was > practicing all the time. > > I hope with the 2 weeks of practice before Dallas that I can chip off > some of that rustiness, but I imagine not having worked on Fridrich > for a long time will really take its toll on my times. > > That doesn't mean I don't think this will be a bad strategy. Once > I've had time to practice both ZB _and_ Fridrich together (switching > between the two like I will in competition), I think it's possible > that I'll be able to repeat May 2, as well as use a combination of ZB > and Fridrich like on May 7 if I am screwing up with ZB in competition > (amnesia and the like). > > Chris > > P.S. I can do a few averages and post them if you still want (ZB, > then Fridrich, done in that order) but I can almost guarantee that the > Fridrich will be nothing special, and perhaps slower than ZB since I > haven't practiced Fridrich to the point of starting to amnesia OLL > cases. Again, that entry was my theory for the future, once I've > practiced in that mindset for a while. I don't expect immediate > results with this at all. Its not necessary, if you think you are rusty with Fridrich it wont be so good to compare with anyway. And now i see that your zb-site is longer then i first saw :)
350. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 19:10:20 -0500

at least 12-15 people.. but they don't care enough to seriously solve it :( except my brother who is the only one ive taught who's under a minute On 7/28/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: > I teach either a very simple corners first method or a very simple layer by layer method, depending on whether they see corners or edges easier at first. > > For the corners, I teach them how to solve four on a side intuitively, and then one corner permuter and the Sune/antisune. Then I teach them simple commutators to solve the pieces on one side, followed by two different 3 cycles and some edge flippers to orient. It's probably 7 easy algorithms total. Takes a couple of hours, though. > > For people who can see edges easier, I teach them how to solve the cross on top, generally using the 'put the piece directly below where it needs to be' approach. Two cases. Then come the U layer corners. Three cases. Then I teach them how to solve middle layer edges (cross side is now on bottom). Two algorithms that are very simple and only a single ' different. Then comes working corners, if they are doing well. This is followed by two cases for edge orienting. Then comes the corner permuter, same as above. Next is the Sune/antisune. Then, I teach a simple 3 cycle and its reverse. > > Including working corners, I taught the latter method to someone in just over an hour, and she was watching a movie at the time. She has since moved on to a 3 look LL and the F2L, and averages under 30, with very little effort. > > I've also taught it to a couple of people that have taken several hour or longer sessions and are still very beginner. It all depends on the student and how much they want to improve. > > -Mike Bennett > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Sachin Shirwalkar > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Thursday, July 28, 2005 1:49 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence > > > I have also taught two of my friends and they ave around 2:30. > > but i wanted to ask what method u all use to teaach large audiences > and how much time didi it take? > > Sachin > > On 7/27/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: > > Currently teaching three people at work and one younger brother. In the past year, have taught just over a dozen how to solve. A friend and my girlfriend both average under 30. > > > > Rock. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: Andreas Renberg > > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 10:28 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing influence > > > > > > I am currently teaching 3 people, and I also tried teaching my 9 year > > old little brother, but he was to impatient. > > > > Andreas > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > wrote: > > > The worst influence at a summer camp you'll ever meet: taught about > > 500 > > > students over a couple of years. > > > > > > Tyson Mao > > > MSC #631 > > > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > On Jul 27, 2005, at 6:36 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" > > > > <mahti-anssi@l...> wrote: > > > >> My dad, two cousins and one classmate can solve the cube. > > > >> Everybody in under 3 minutes. How about you others? > > > > > > > > President of the Rutgers Rubik's Cube Club...taught dozens to > > solve. ;) > > > > > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 352. Videos - Team Blindfold Solve
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 02:18:09 -0000

Chris Hardwick and I recently got together and did lots of team
blindfold solves. We're definitely better when he calls. We took a
couple of videos of us in action.

In the first one, we went through the solve pausing at each step
just to show what we've done. If you listen carefully, you'll hear
me catch a mistake Chris made.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/videos/ianchristeambldtutorial.wmv

In the other video, we got a very good time of 36.77:

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/videos/ianchristeambld3677.wmv

Here is the scramble from that solve and then our solution:

Note that "spin right" means the cube rotation y'

Scramble: F' B' D' R2 B F D' L' F' B L F R' U' F' B' L U2 D L' B' F
R2 B' R

Solution:

Extended Cross: y' L U2 L' U2 R' F2 L'

Chris wasting time: U U'

2nd F2L pair - Case "C1": U F' U' F U' R U R'

Set-up for 3rd pair: y2 U'

3rd F2L pair - Case "Split 1 2": R U2 R' U R U' R'

Set-up for 4th pair: y' U2

4th F2L pair - Case "R1": U' R U R' U R U R'

Without prompting, Ian moving what he thought was the remaining F2L
slot to be done to the front right: y2

Orientation - Case "Stool on the right 1": L U' L' U2 L d R U' R'
U' F'

Set-up for Permutation: U y'

Permutation - Case "Edges clockwise": R2 U R U R' U' R' U' R' U R'

Chris should be posting our F2L codes by Thursday. OLL and PLL
codes can be posted if anyone is interested.

Ian





353. One more thing...
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 02:28:41 -0000

If clicking on the links to the videos in my last post doesn't work,
copy each link and paste in a new browser.

Ian




354. Re: [Speed cubing group] Videos - Team Blindfold Solve

355. Re: future of the ZB method
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 03:19:29 -0000

> Its not necessary, if you think you are rusty with Fridrich it wont
> be so good to compare with anyway. And now i see that your zb-site is
> longer then i first saw :)

Hey,

in response to your question I went through and practiced my OLL cases
to cover the ones I was amnesia'ing and then did a few warmup Fridrich
averages.

When I felt good I did a ZB average, followed immediately by a
Fridrich average.

First off I want to say that the two methods compliment eachother
well. The pacing for ZBF2L is much slower than F2L, since you have to
track the LL edges, and for Fridrich is obviously much faster and more
fluid. So switching between the two helps me to try to apply some of
the F2L pace of one to the other, speeding up ZBF2L a bit and making
F2L nice and slowfast.

Well here were the averages:

ZB (every solve was ZBF2L / (21%ZBLL) or (COLL/PLL) :
16.63, 17.73, 17.93, 16.00, 17.58, (15.54), 19.52, 18.90, 18.02,
16.97, (21.40), 19.52 = 17.88

followed immediately by Fridrich (every solve was F2L (with basic
partial edge control / (OLL/PLL) or (1/7 COLL/PLL) :
18.23, 17.86, 17.32, 15.56, 17.98, 14.55, (14.08), 15.49, 15.67,
(20.02), 17.34, 17.26 = 16.73

I did do COLL during the Fridrich average when it came up, but other
than that I only did basic partial edge control (making sure to not
end up with all flipped edges).

16.73 beats my fastest ever offical rules average by 0.02 seconds!
And I haven't practiced Fridrich seriously since Horace Mann (2 months
ago)!

I am really set on using ZB as my "first two rounds" method and then
Fridrich as my "final round" method. If I do get to the point where I
am consistently faster for ZB stuff than Fridrich, then I will of
course try to use that for all rounds.

These averages makes me really happy! I think these methods
compliment eachother well! ZB solving makes me slow down and be
slowfast for F2L when doing Fridrich. Fridrich solving makes me try
to speed up my ZBF2L pace a little bit.

I can't wait till I've had the time to practice and really get fluid
with Fridrich again!

I really do think ZB and Fridrich can be used together, and you can
easily switch between the two without any interference or problems.
In fact practicing one way seems to help me for the other way.

Chris




356. Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 20:43:36 -0700

On Jul 31, 2005, at 12:58, Ron van Bruchem wrote:

> What I am trying to say is that after looooooooots of practice ZB MUST
> be faster than basic CFOP. Fewer steps, fewer moves.

The case against that MUST is that for a given amount of practice time
Fridrich will always allow for X times more training per alg than ZB,
where X is the ratio of algs in ZB vs Fridrich, which I think is around
10 or 20 (?). So each alg you encounter you will have X times more
practice with. If it's true that the more you practice an alg, the
faster you get, we're not talking about a MUST here as much as weighing
different factors.

Inherent in a method with fewer algs is that you'll always be better
practiced on those algs than one with more.

Another possibility it is that you need a certain amount of practice to
reach your top speed, and once you're there it can't really be
improved. In that case, you only need to spend X times as much time to
reach your top speed with ZB, and then your MUST will be true by
logical necessity. That disregarding the need to maintain your skills,
which may be ignorable.

Anyway. My point is that for a fair comparison between methods, you
need to compare them with a similar amount of practice put in. I
suspect that while it's probably *possible* to become faster with ZB
than any other method using that measure, it would require *enormous*
amounts of practice to reach the breakeven point.

- - - - - - - - - - - -
"He who refuses to do arithmetic is doomed to talk nonsense."
--- John McCarthy

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com



357. Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 2005 06:38:05 +0200

Hi Lars,

Yes, you are right.

I think ZB is crazy and even a bit intimidating. :-)
There will be guys learning this system. For me it is impossible to do that within 2.5 years: family, busy job, other hobbies, website, competitions...
And if you finally master every little algorithm, you have to work hard each day to not forget anything and be able to execute them very fast.
Actually, I think that if there would be someone fully mastering ZB (and most importantly: be exceptional on F2L!!!!!!), then it would force a few other cubers to use it too. And that makes me feel sad... I don't want to work that hard. :-)

There must be easier ways to achieve the times you could reach with ZB.
Especially corners first systems look promising, because of the fewer moves.
At the moment I am investigating CF approaches and I found some promising ones. CF systems where you solve several edges at once.
After WC2005 I will give up CFOP for a while and see what these systems can bring.
It would be great to not do this alone.

Have fun,

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: Lars Petrus
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, August 01, 2005 5:43 AM
Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method


On Jul 31, 2005, at 12:58, Ron van Bruchem wrote:

> What I am trying to say is that after looooooooots of practice ZB MUST
> be faster than basic CFOP. Fewer steps, fewer moves.

The case against that MUST is that for a given amount of practice time
Fridrich will always allow for X times more training per alg than ZB,
where X is the ratio of algs in ZB vs Fridrich, which I think is around
10 or 20 (?). So each alg you encounter you will have X times more
practice with. If it's true that the more you practice an alg, the
faster you get, we're not talking about a MUST here as much as weighing
different factors.

Inherent in a method with fewer algs is that you'll always be better
practiced on those algs than one with more.

Another possibility it is that you need a certain amount of practice to
reach your top speed, and once you're there it can't really be
improved. In that case, you only need to spend X times as much time to
reach your top speed with ZB, and then your MUST will be true by
logical necessity. That disregarding the need to maintain your skills,
which may be ignorable.

Anyway. My point is that for a fair comparison between methods, you
need to compare them with a similar amount of practice put in. I
suspect that while it's probably *possible* to become faster with ZB
than any other method using that measure, it would require *enormous*
amounts of practice to reach the breakeven point.

360. Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 08:23:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I agree that maybe with a lot of practice, that ZB could potentially > be faster than CFOP (it doesn't seem impossible). However, after > seeing Sebastien and Jean on the 3x3 this seems like it would take a > lot of practice indeed (at the very least 3 years or so). Maybe then > this strategy of using it as a "first two rounds" method is a way to > use it when you are in the intermediate stages of learning it? I > think I will write something about that in my next entry. It almost seems unfair to compare ZB to Fridrich via Sebastien and Jean. If you look at the SCC UWR list, their average times for F2L are sub-9. Since Fridrich and ZB "share" the first few steps--cross, and first three pairs--I would think you could only compare the remainder of their solves, instead of comparing entire times. For example, I remember seeing that you would like to be within one second of the 1st place on the F2L fastest average list. Therefore, would you feel a bit more confident in ZB if your ZBF2L was sub-10 seconds? Even with a 6-second ZBLL, that would give you a sub-16 average. I think that since there is an overlap between the two methods, it would give you a better idea of comparison by comparing your speed for the ZBF2L alg + ZBLL alg to the speed of a Fridrich 4th pair + OLL + PLL. :-) Whaddya think? ~ Bob
361. Special Magic Puzzles at competition
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 2005 11:46:49 +0200

Hello,

I just have another question :
usually people compete with a magic whith rings (red or black), but
what about other magic "special edition" ?
For example, would it be possible to compete with a Harry Potter Magic ?

Thx,
GIlles.


362. Gallery of 25th Anniversary Rubik's Media
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <jasmine_ellen@...>, "'Duncan Dicks'" <duncan@...>, "'Paul Nixon'" <Paul@...>, "'Sean Connolly'" <sean@...>, <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>

363. Re: Special Magic Puzzles at competition
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 12:40:00 -0000

--- Gilles van den Peereboom wrote:
> For example, would it be possible to compete with a Harry
> Potter Magic ?

As far as I know, all official magics use exactly the same solution
as
the original magics (I only know for sure on the Harry Potter magic).
Given that is true, I don't see why not.

If however you had a magic that had an intrinsically different
solution
(i.e. one that would not work on an original magic in some form), I'd
say no.

366. The hardest puzzle ever...
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 2005 10:16:24 -0700

Ok, so I was practicing with my 4x4x4 and the thing exploded. This
happens a lot, but I still have trouble putting it back together. Does
anyone have any secrets for putting the center pieces in? It takes me
hours to get the last center piece on and I still haven't done it. It
seems to fall apart quite easily but takes days to fix.

Any help on getting those center pieces in would be greatly appreciated! :)

-Chris


367. Re: The hardest puzzle ever...
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 17:24:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > Ok, so I was practicing with my 4x4x4 and the thing exploded. This > happens a lot, but I still have trouble putting it back together. Does > anyone have any secrets for putting the center pieces in? It takes me > hours to get the last center piece on and I still haven't done it. It > seems to fall apart quite easily but takes days to fix. > > Any help on getting those center pieces in would be greatly appreciated! :) > > -Chris I assume you're using a rubik's 4x4x4. I have that problem a lot too except when mine falls apart, it's usually due to a center snapping. But the way I do it is to build it layer by layer on a table. For example, start with white. Should be easy to get all the centers in. Then put in the rest of the pieces. Build the side centers. Should still be easy because the top isn't done. Then when you do the top, Just try to get as many centers out of the way when you put in the last one. I think two of the centers should be able to move out of the way. Hope that helps, Ben.
368. Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method
From: "Wayne" <mylib_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 17:57:32 -0000

Ron, It would be great to have another corners guy on here. I currently use an incomplete Waterman system and avg 21-23sec. I say incomplete because I don't position two edges while orienting the middle edges. Too many algs ! Also, I solve with the middle slice being "E" instead of "M" becuase I can execute the algs faster. I wish I knew some details of the method that Dave Allen used. Wayne --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi Lars, > > Yes, you are right. > > I think ZB is crazy and even a bit intimidating. :-) > There will be guys learning this system. For me it is impossible to do that within 2.5 years: family, busy job, other hobbies, website, competitions... > And if you finally master every little algorithm, you have to work hard each day to not forget anything and be able to execute them very fast. > Actually, I think that if there would be someone fully mastering ZB (and most importantly: be exceptional on F2L!!!!!!), then it would force a few other cubers to use it too. And that makes me feel sad... I don't want to work that hard. :-) > > There must be easier ways to achieve the times you could reach with ZB. > Especially corners first systems look promising, because of the fewer moves. > At the moment I am investigating CF approaches and I found some promising ones. CF systems where you solve several edges at once. > After WC2005 I will give up CFOP for a while and see what these systems can bring. > It would be great to not do this alone. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Lars Petrus > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Monday, August 01, 2005 5:43 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] future of the ZB method > > > On Jul 31, 2005, at 12:58, Ron van Bruchem wrote: > > > What I am trying to say is that after looooooooots of practice ZB MUST > > be faster than basic CFOP. Fewer steps, fewer moves. > > The case against that MUST is that for a given amount of practice time > Fridrich will always allow for X times more training per alg than ZB, > where X is the ratio of algs in ZB vs Fridrich, which I think is around > 10 or 20 (?). So each alg you encounter you will have X times more > practice with. If it's true that the more you practice an alg, the > faster you get, we're not talking about a MUST here as much as weighing > different factors. > > Inherent in a method with fewer algs is that you'll always be better > practiced on those algs than one with more. > > Another possibility it is that you need a certain amount of practice to > reach your top speed, and once you're there it can't really be > improved. In that case, you only need to spend X times as much time to > reach your top speed with ZB, and then your MUST will be true by > logical necessity. That disregarding the need to maintain your skills, > which may be ignorable. > > Anyway. My point is that for a fair comparison between methods, you > need to compare them with a similar amount of practice put in. I > suspect that while it's probably *possible* to become faster with ZB > than any other method using that measure, it would require *enormous* > amounts of practice to reach the breakeven point. > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "He who refuses to do arithmetic is doomed to talk nonsense." > --- John McCarthy > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Free puzzle games Puzzle games Computer puzzle game > Online puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games > > > -------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > -------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------- > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

373. Question: what does (U3) etc. mean to Fridrich?
From: ssrc@...
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 2005 22:27:34 +0000 (GMT)

I have a question about Fridrich's PLL notation. I'm referring to
this page:

http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html

Several places on the page, there are notations in parentheses about
(U), (U1), (U2), and (U3). What do these mean?

I'm confused. First, there is U meaning "Upper side" and then there
is Fridrich's and Goljan's "constellation" notation where U permutes
three edges. Neither one of these seem to mean the same thing as the
U-with-or-without-a-numeral-in-parentheses.

Thanks,
Larry


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

376. 5x5x5 Parity errors
From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 00:07:19 -0000

Hey everyone,

I've recently picked up my 5x5 and decided trying to solve it on my own
with no hints or anything. It all went well, except for the fact that I
don't know how to solve the parity errors (such as two same
colored "wedges" are flipped or one normal edge flipped). Can someone
give me any alg.s to solve this? It would be most helpful, thanks alot
=]

~Joseph





377. Re: 5x5x5 Parity errors
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>

Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 02:21:11 -0000

378. Re: [Speed cubing group] Question: what does (U3) etc. mean to Fridrich?
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 1 Aug 2005 22:30:16 -0400

U1 = U U2 = U2 U3 = U' I'm not sure why the standard notation wasn't used for these turns. They are in parentheses because they don't really count toward the length of the algorithm. They are just there to let you know (a) which direction the upper face is pointing when starting the algorithm and (b) if there is a turn required at the end to align the face. On 8/1/05, ssrc@... <ssrc@...> wrote: > I have a question about Fridrich's PLL notation. I'm referring to > this page: > > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html > > Several places on the page, there are notations in parentheses about > (U), (U1), (U2), and (U3). What do these mean?

well this site was kinda supposed to be under wraps until i completed but since i know a lot of people have issues with the last set of edges, i will post the page containing the last 2 sets of edges, it will give you a guys taste of whats to come, i plan on making this the main site for 4x4 and 5x5 information and possibly contests in the future. here is the page address for those final steps, thanks to frank morris for the algs on this page and all the other help on the site, and thanks to the makers of the professor player applet, since i'm way too lazy to write my own.....i promise it will be fully functional asap :) www.bigcubes.com/temp/lastedges.html any other cases should be mirrors of these, but please take a picture or write it down and mail me if u see have one we missed (even if it is a mirror) --- azinj05ieipih <azinj05ieipih@...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I've recently picked up my 5x5 and decided trying to > solve it on my own > with no hints or anything. 381. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity errors - some hints
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 08:32:33 +0100

Hi Joseph, I got a 5x5x5 last week and it took me a few hours thinking to work out the parity things. It might not help but if you are just looking for hints and not actual algorithms then I would suggest as hints: 1. To my mind there is only one issue and that is two edges apparently swapped - the other cases you mention can be reduced to this case. 2. It really IS impossible to swap two edges. 3. It might help to solve the edges before you solve all the centres. 4. Its easier to see whats going on if you have the two edges in the same slice (rather than in the same layer for example). Oh and I guess 5. You can solve anything with conjugates! Maybe thats all too cryptic or maybe it makes it too easy I don't know :) These hints amount to the rational thinking process I went through anyway and I'm not very fast (about 13 minutes!) but at least I understand whats going on now. Hope that helps. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "azinj05ieipih" <azinj05ieipih@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Tuesday, August 02, 2005 1:07 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity errors > Hey everyone, > > I've recently picked up my 5x5 and decided trying to solve it on my own > with no hints or anything. It all went well, except for the fact that I > don't know how to solve the parity errors (such as two same > colored "wedges" are flipped or one normal edge flipped). Can someone > give me any alg.s to solve this? It would be most helpful, thanks alot > =] > > ~Joseph > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >
382. [Speed cubing group] Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "goodxy2002" <goodxy2002@...>

383. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity errors
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 09:42:22 +0200

I also decided to solve the 5x5x5 without specific algorithms, but I
managed to do it because my method avoids that parity problem :

1. Solve the centers
2. Pair up the edges with one wing (so that you have on one edge 2
blocks : one wing and on wing/edge paired)
3. Finish the edges (pair up the blocks together)
4. Solve the 3x3x3 cube

And you can't have that parity proble ;-)


384. [Speed cubing group] Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 07:46:52 -0000

Stickers? They're plastic tiles, maybe 1mm thick :-) And hey, last night I was able to solve that PLL using my new alg once in 2.44 and four times in a row in 10.02 seconds, both on the stackmat (i.e. including picking up the cube). I'm usually around 11.50, though. Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Marco Garbelini <garbelini@g...> wrote: > That's one fancy cube. 386. Re: [Speed cubing group] 5x5x5 Parity errors
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 09:59:19 +0200

With my solution, you can't have two wings swapped, they are just in
the good orientation.

Now you might have to use the (R1R2 U)*5 if you only have 2 or 4
edges to solve at the end, but you don't have to swap to wings.
I don't know which way is the best. :s

Cheers! Stefan

My new alg > > > > > > Both are below 3 seconds (2.8 for the old alg including regrip at > > > start, and only 2.27 for my new alg). > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 392. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 12:01:55 +0200

I use this algo for this PLL : RUR'U(L'U)(RU')(LU'L'UR'U'r)

if it helps...


393. Fwd: My 5*5 algs
From: Frdrick BADIE <f_badie@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 10:53:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Frdrick BADIE <f_badie@y...> wrote: My 555's algs are in two categories. First one corresponds with a parity correct, second with an uncorrect parity Algs with no parity error : (Ll) (Rr) F2 D2 (Ll) (Rr) B2 D2 (Ll)2 (F2) (Rr) D2 (Rr)' F2 U2 F2 (Ll) B2 (Ll)' F2 Algs with parity error : (Rr)' U2 (Ll) F2 (Ll)' F2 (Rr)2 U2 (Rr) U2 (Rr)' U2 F2 (Rr)2 (F2) Useful for 444 ( flip one edge ) (Ll)' U2 (Ll)' U2 F2 (Ll)' F2 (Rr) U2 (Rr)' U2 (Ll)2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr)2 U2 (Rr) U2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr) U2 (Rr)2 U2 (Rr)' (Rr)2 B2 (Rr)' U2 (Rr)' U2 B2 (Rr)' B2 (Rr) B2 (Rr)' B2 (Rr)2 B2 Useful for 444 (flip one edge and permute two edges) Have fun, Frederick --- End forwarded message ---
394. Re: WC2005 regulations about cubes
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 13:07:14 -0000

COUNTERFEIT CUBES OR ALTERNATIVE CUBES WILL NOT > > BE ACCEPTED. > > > > Does that also include the stickers ? > > For example if I want to take part to the championship with a Rubik's > > Cube but with CubeSmith stickers, will I be allowed to compete with > > that cube ? > > > > Thx, > > Gilles.
395. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 14:06:51 -0000

Ok, let me know then :-). What's your time for your current alg? I think you might easily get faster than me. The U and F at the end give me a bit of trouble. I'm trying two ways to fix it, one is to do the F with the middle finger. And I know you can do RUR'U fast like that, which I can't. The other way is to push the U with my left index finger... Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jol van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey Stefan.. That's a new alg for my worst case!! 405. Re: 4x4x4 speed solve
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 20:53:15 -0000

Hey! Thats indeed what most top 4x4x4'ers do. With various little tricks along the way. Like pairing up many edges at a time or avoiding parity etc etc ... Other ways of solving the 4x4x4 is the Akimoto columns method. Or my own cage method, which incidentally is VERY similar to Courtney mcFarrens method. By searching around a little u should find info on those methods easily. Umm another potentially good method i'dl ike to listen is to do 2 opposite faces completely then the remaining edges (avoiding parity ... at least a trivial fix) then rest of the centers. There are others that may be good too. Like solving blocks-style like Petrus for the 3x3x3. Richard Patterson has looked into this. Not sure how far he got with it. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goodxy2002" <goodxy2002@y...> wrote: > What are your methods for doing it fast? Can i hit a fast time by > solving the centers/edges, then 3x3x3? Or do all of you fast 4x4x4ers > do another method?
406. BLD description
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 16:01:17 -0600

In case anything is interested in what goes on in my head:

The following is a full description of both the memorization and
solving of a cube scrambled with the following algorithm:

U' R B F' R' L' U' B F' R' U2 D' F' D L2 B2 R' U' R L B L2 R' U F2

The first thing I memorize is the edge permutation. I start with 1,
and then go to 11. Then I think that the cycle sweeps across the
bottom to 9, and continues right, but goes diagonally up to 5 and then
further across and back to 7. From 7, I have to remember that it jumps
to 3, but then I think that it sweeps across to the right to 2 and
further down right to 10. At 10, I have to remember that it jumps to
6. I glance at the timer and see that it reads 23 seconds.

Then I see 4 and I see it plunges down to 12 and I realize it cycles to
8. I make a very quick mental note that it's a clockwise cycle.

For the corners, I see 1 going to 8 and 5. I see the 8-corner in the
one place so I make a quick note that I will start off with a D2 setup
move for that cycle. I then see 2 sweeping to 3 and I see that it
continues down to 7. I am relieved to see 4 and 8 in the right place.

I notice the edge orientation that three edges are wrong on the top. I
see the front right edge in the middle layer is oriented wrong and I
tell myself "U2" and then I picture very quickly that I will flip that
edge in the middle layer for a four-edge flip. I then flip the cube
over with z2, tap the two adjacent edges that are wrong, and say to
myself "back left".

I look at the corners, and think "easy" on the two corners which form a
pair on the top layer in the left. I flip the cube over with z2, and
see three corners wanting to be clockwise twisted. I make the mental
note that no U-turns are necessary and that I will correct the corners
starting with that first one, which happens to be on the URF after I
flip the cube over with z2.

I return the cube back to its position, and see that the timer reads 53
seconds.

I immediately perform a right handed Sune and a left handed Sune. Then
I do z2 and cycle three corners clockwise. Since the cube is already
flipped over, I recall to myself "back left", perform (L F), and do a
two-edge flipper and then undo that setup move. I then flip the cube
back upright and do U2, F' and do the four-edge flipper that I
visualized before. I undo those setup moves.

I recall the D2 setup move for (1 8 5) I told myself earlier so without
thinking, I do D2 + (R' F R F')x3 + D2 + (R' F R F'). I remember that
2 sweeps to 3 and continues down to 7. I think that 7 wants to go to 2
so the setup move is U2 and I do U2 + (R B' R' B)x3 + U2 + (R B' R'
B)x3.

I turn my attention to the edges and I do L2 to put 11 next to 1. I
realize 9 is already in the bottom layer so I do D but do not do R2 to
flip it up. Instead, I begin my 3-cycle with just U. I reverse the
setup moves and then do U' and flip up the 5 and 7 and perform another
counterclockwise U-permutation. I reverse that and I immediately do
another counterclockwise U-permutation because (1 3 2) is the nicest
edge-cycle in the world. I then do D' to put 10 next to 6 on the
F-face and I do the counterclockwise U-permutation with the cube
rotated but I do not do R' because I would have had to redo that for
the setup move anyway.

I then recall the clockwise U-permutation that awaits. The clock reads
1:53.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



407. Re: BLD description
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 02 Aug 2005 23:13:33 -0000

Hey Tyson this is really interesting but when you say "1 goes to 6" or something similar, what places are those? I just look at where the pieces go so I don't know the standard numbering scheme. This seems really interesting, only I don't know what pieces go where for you! This is a cool idea though, thanks for posting! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > In case anything is interested in what goes on in my head: > > The following is a full description of both the memorization and > solving of a cube scrambled with the following algorithm: > > U' R B F' R' L' U' B F' R' U2 D' F' D L2 B2 R' U' R L B L2 R' U F2 > > The first thing I memorize is the edge permutation. I start with 1, > and then go to 11. Then I think that the cycle sweeps across the > bottom to 9, and continues right, but goes diagonally up to 5 and then > further across and back to 7. From 7, I have to remember that it jumps > to 3, but then I think that it sweeps across to the right to 2 and > further down right to 10. At 10, I have to remember that it jumps to > 6. I glance at the timer and see that it reads 23 seconds. > > Then I see 4 and I see it plunges down to 12 and I realize it cycles to > 8. I make a very quick mental note that it's a clockwise cycle. > > For the corners, I see 1 going to 8 and 5. I see the 8-corner in the > one place so I make a quick note that I will start off with a D2 setup > move for that cycle. I then see 2 sweeping to 3 and I see that it > continues down to 7. I am relieved to see 4 and 8 in the right place. > > I notice the edge orientation that three edges are wrong on the top. I > see the front right edge in the middle layer is oriented wrong and I > tell myself "U2" and then I picture very quickly that I will flip that > edge in the middle layer for a four-edge flip. I then flip the cube > over with z2, tap the two adjacent edges that are wrong, and say to > myself "back left". > > I look at the corners, and think "easy" on the two corners which form a > pair on the top layer in the left. I flip the cube over with z2, and > see three corners wanting to be clockwise twisted. I make the mental > note that no U-turns are necessary and that I will correct the corners > starting with that first one, which happens to be on the URF after I > flip the cube over with z2. > > I return the cube back to its position, and see that the timer reads 53 > seconds. > > I immediately perform a right handed Sune and a left handed Sune. Then > I do z2 and cycle three corners clockwise. Since the cube is already > flipped over, I recall to myself "back left", perform (L F), and do a > two-edge flipper and then undo that setup move. I then flip the cube > back upright and do U2, F' and do the four-edge flipper that I > visualized before. I undo those setup moves. > > I recall the D2 setup move for (1 8 5) I told myself earlier so without > thinking, I do D2 + (R' F R F')x3 + D2 + (R' F R F'). I remember that > 2 sweeps to 3 and continues down to 7. I think that 7 wants to go to 2 > so the setup move is U2 and I do U2 + (R B' R' B)x3 + U2 + (R B' R' > B)x3. > > I turn my attention to the edges and I do L2 to put 11 next to 1. I > realize 9 is already in the bottom layer so I do D but do not do R2 to > flip it up. Instead, I begin my 3-cycle with just U. I reverse the > setup moves and then do U' and flip up the 5 and 7 and perform another > counterclockwise U-permutation. I reverse that and I immediately do > another counterclockwise U-permutation because (1 3 2) is the nicest > edge-cycle in the world. I then do D' to put 10 next to 6 on the > F-face and I do the counterclockwise U-permutation with the cube > rotated but I do not do R' because I would have had to redo that for > the setup move anyway. > > I then recall the clockwise U-permutation that awaits. The clock reads > 1:53. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
408. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: BLD description
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 17:14:44 -0600

Yeah, everyone's numbering scheme is different. You should be able to
figure out my number scheme with the scramble and the description
though, right?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 2, 2005, at 5:13 PM, cmhardw wrote:

> Hey Tyson this is really interesting but when you say "1 goes to 6"
> or something similar, what places are those? I just look at where
> the pieces go so I don't know the standard numbering scheme.
>
> This seems really interesting, only I don't know what pieces go where
> for you!

> This is a cool idea though, thanks for posting!

409. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: BLD description
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 17:52:14 -0700

I had my first blindfold success! Thanks Tyson! I solved the scramble:

U F' U' D' F2 U' L' R D' B' D F2 U F B2 U2 B D2 L B2 U2 F2 U2 B' L2

It was a pretty good case and I did it in about 15 minutes. Hopefully
this will get easier :)

-Chris


410. How do scrambles work?
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 03 Aug 2005 02:20:47 -0000

I've always pondered this but when you perform a scramble for 3x3x3,
for example Jnet Cube, which side are you supposed to do it on? Like
which colour is supposed to be the top face and front face? And how
are the WCA scambles done?




411. Re: [Speed cubing group] How do scrambles work?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 2 Aug 2005 21:02:34 -0600

Hi Darereck, (is that your name)?

For JNetCube, the default sets white as the front and green as the top.
That's because Chris Hunt solves it that way. You can change the
settings yourself in the options though.

WCA scrambles are done two ways. In certain tournaments, the
organizers won't say anything and they'll just choose a color scheme.
The color scheme can be chosen at random. Generally, if you request a
certain color, the tournament organizers will honor that request. In
most tournaments in the United States, during registration, you have
the opportunity to state what front and top color you would like for
your puzzle for the different events.

Color choosing is usually requested in the blindfold solves.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 2, 2005, at 8:20 PM, darereck wrote:

> I've always pondered this but when you perform a scramble for 3x3x3,
> for example Jnet Cube, which side are you supposed to do it on? Like
> which colour is supposed to be the top face and front face? And how
> are the WCA scambles done?
>
>
>
>

412. COLL page
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 03 Aug 2005 04:16:38 -0000

Hey all,

I made a COLL page with all the COLL algorithms that I use now. I
added a short description of how I recognize each individual case, and
I added slow videos demonstrating exactly how I perform each
algorithm. Fast videos will be up eventually with execution times,
but almost all cases are very fast (I believe all are sub-3 and most
are sub-2).

~ Bob

414. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 speed solve
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 3 Aug 2005 08:44:12 +0200

I developped a layer by layer method for the 4x4x4, but I don't
recommend it for speedsolving the 4x4x4.
(still incomplete, if anyone wants to help me for basics OLL et PLL on
the 4x4x4...thx :-))


415. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 speed solve
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 03 Aug 2005 06:52:37 -0000

Hi :-) Just out of curiosity. Why would u do OLL and PLL for the edges of the last layer? Or u really mean OLL and PLL for edges and corners combined? I guess that will be far too many cases to be practical. I do corners on LL separately and then edges with 3-cycles pluss parity fix. I don't have any need to orient edges then permute them. It's unnecessary work. Using 3-cycles u for the most part solve 2 edges at a time. It takes a while to get used to the various kinds of 3-cycles u will need. But it's not extremely hard either :-) Umm .. doing centers also strictly layer by layer seems not like a good idea. Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > I developped a layer by layer method for the 4x4x4, but I don't > recommend it for speedsolving the 4x4x4. > (still incomplete, if anyone wants to help me for basics OLL et PLL on > the 4x4x4...thx :-))
416. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 speed solve
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 3 Aug 2005 09:12:01 +0200

Well, I developped that method on a long boring train ride :p

Solve the 3 first layers is quite easy.
Then the last center is already solved.

What I need to find is an OLL which enables me to orientate two
opposite "half-edges" at a time (which the very basic case that can
solve anything) and then instead of pairing up the edges then solve it
like a 3x3x3, i was hoping to find some more specific PLL algorithms
which can permute only hald-edges and not only the full edges (which
are the basic 3x3x3 PLL).

But that method is looooooooong.......


417. [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 speed solve
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 03 Aug 2005 10:20:13 -0000

Okie! Now i follow. More details about doing first 3 layers pls. Do u do fully first layer then 3-cycles to solve middle 2-layer edges? I can solve all of last layer corners/edges in about 20-25 secs on the 4x4x4. Sorting out the edges doesn't have to be so long-winded really :-) Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > Well, I developped that method on a long boring train ride :p > > Solve the 3 first layers is quite easy. > Then the last center is already solved. > > What I need to find is an OLL which enables me to orientate two > opposite "half-edges" at a time (which the very basic case that can > solve anything) and then instead of pairing up the edges then solve it > like a 3x3x3, i was hoping to find some more specific PLL algorithms > which can permute only hald-edges and not only the full edges (which > are the basic 3x3x3 PLL). > > But that method is looooooooong.......

424. BLD Move Counting
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 3 Aug 2005 11:37:50 -0600

F' L' D L' F2 U2 R' L F U2 R U B R' D' L U' R D F L2 F2 D F2 B2

Leyan and I decided to count the number of moves (in HTM) for a
blindfold solve. He did the above solve in 59 second memorization + 60
second solve and I did the above solve in 43 seconds memorization + 85
seconds solve. We're trying to figure out if there is a trade off
between memorization and solve time. The number of moves for my solve
are as follows:

Corner Orientation

8*4 = 32

Edge Orientation

D2 F2 B + 4-Flip + B' F2 D2

3 + 24 + 3 = 30

Corner Permutation

F2 U' + (A-Perm) + U F2

2 + 9 + 2 = 13

B2 F2 + (R A-Perm) U (Left A-Perm) U' + F2 B2

2 + 9 + 1 + 9 + 1 + 2 = 24

Edge Permutation

2 + 11 + 2
3 + 13 + 3
2 + 11 + 2
3 + 11 + 3

Total = 165 moves

Leyan on the other hand did: CO 28 + EO 32 + CP 26 + EP 49 = 135 moves.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

432. Re: [Speed cubing group] BLD Move Counting
From: Anthony Hsu <erwaman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 03 Aug 2005 16:44:53 -0400

I tried blindfolding the same scramble, and this is what I got:

Edge Orientation
D2 + F2 + B + 4-edge flipper + B' + F2 + D2 = 3 + 24 + 3 = 30

Corner Orientation
Bruno + Allan (U-permutation) + D2 = 9 + 9 + 1 = 19

Corner Permutation
F2 + A-permutation + F2 = 1 + 9 + 1 = 11
R2 + T-permutation + R2 = 1 + 14 + 1 = 16
L2 + R2 + T-permutation + R2 + L2 = 2 + 14 + 2 = 18

Edge Permutation
B' + D + Allan + D' + B = 2 + 9 + 2 = 13
F2 + U' + B' + Z-permutation + B + U + F2 = 3 + 13 + 3 = 19
D + B + U2 + Z-permutation + U2 + B' + D' = 3 + 13 + 3 = 19

Total Moves: 30 (EO) + 19 (CO) + 45 (CP) + 51 (EP) = 145 turns
Total Time (memorization and solve): 4:06.78
This was my second best blindfold solve ever! Only two seconds slower than my best.

I'm not nearly as fast as you guys though...

Anthony
----- Original Message -----
From: Tyson Mao
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, August 03, 2005 1:37 PM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] BLD Move Counting


F' L' D L' F2 U2 R' L F U2 R U B R' D' L U' R D F L2 F2 D F2 B2


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

But you did it in fewer turns than me! I spoke to Leyan. I think we
agree that memorization a trade off with solve time if you think ahead.
Our solve times are accounted for by the fact that he owns me.

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology

439. Re: COLL page
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 06:04:03 -0000

Hey Dan, I made a printable page tonight. It is linked from the COLL page, but I will give the link here, also. http://www.cubewhiz.com/collprint.html I think eventually I will change the layout of my printable alg pages, but it will do for now. Eventually I want to have the algs all print on one page and group the cases by orientation. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hi Bob, > > Good stuff, would you also make a printable page? > > Cheers, > > Dan :) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> wrote: > > Duh... I forgot to give the link. > > > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/coll.html > > > > Enjoy! > > > > ~ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> > > wrote: > > > Hey all, > > > > > > I made a COLL page with all the COLL algorithms that I use now. > I > > > added a short description of how I recognize each individual > case, and > > > I added slow videos demonstrating exactly how I perform each > > > algorithm. Fast videos will be up eventually with execution > times, > > > but almost all cases are very fast (I believe all are sub-3 and > most > > > are sub-2). > > > > > > ~ Bob

Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 16:11:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > > This is how I used to do it: > > Put the Up side on the right and do D' F2 R U2 R' U' R U2 L' U R' U' > L > > F2 D. > > > > If you don't like that one I've one more. > > Hi David, > > thanks, I do like the middle part a lot, but the D and F moves are > killing me and I'd rather not have a cube rotation or regrip at start. > What's the other alg? > > Cheers! > Stefan Well you could try R' L' U2 L R but that changes the F2L. Seriously though try L D' L B L2 D2 R F R' D2 L B' D L' I don't know whether or not it would suit your style. Regards, David J

447. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 17:42:45 -0000

Haha, thanks for your efforts, guys, but they both don't fit my hands very well. Both D and d aren't good for me and F/F' only when flowing well with the other turns. I'll practice this one now, it feels very promising: R' U R U' R' F' U' F R U R' F R' F' R U' R Cheers! 452. Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 19:52:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I'll practice this one now, it feels very promising: > R' U R U' R' F' U' F R U R' F R' F' R U' R I'm stopping four times in a row with a stopwatch now, record so far is 10.75 seconds. Already much faster than the alg I used previously and there's no cube rotation at the start, so this is definitely my new alg for this case. It also uses the same setup rule as its mirror, i.e. bring the correct pair to front, then apply the alg. Any times from somebody else for this case? Cheers! Stefan

454. Another cubing reference
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 21:39:01 -0000

I'm just watching House M.D. on TV at the moment and noticed a cube
reference. One of the other doctors says to Dr House (something along
the lines of): "Some doctors have the messiah complex they want to
save the world. You have the Rubik's complex you want to want to
solve the puzzle."

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com





455. My point of view about fridrich...
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 21:42:51 -0000

For people qho don't know i'm sebastien felix, I averaged 13.00s (
13.55 12.87 12.62 12.56 13.90 13.67 (14.15) 12.59 13.17 12.28 12.83
(12.13) SD=0.66 average 13.004(so close to sub13:D))with the fridrich
method and think we can get sub12.

Here are all the tips I use to speed my fridrich solves.

CROSS:
1.end your cross at D, L or R and try to find the 1st pair during the
D, D' or D2 move. If you can anticipate the 1st pair during 15s of
preinspection do it!

2.try to build extended cross or a cross and a piece of the first
pair, then before doing the D, D' or D2 to end the cross, insert the
2nd piece of the 1st pair and you'll get an extended cross

3.be able to do the cross BLD almost everytime.

F2L:


1.Of course look ahead and have NO DELAYS

2.use empty slots to less turn your cube during F2L.

3.use multisloting to reduce your number of moves for solving F2L(try
to do every F2L solve with less than 32 moves)

4.have a look on LL edges from the 3rd slot to the 4rth slot, and try
to orient as many as possible(it avoid 0 edges oriented OLL, and you
have more than 1 chances out 27 to skip OLL if you master it since the
3rd slot)

5.of course know how to solve every case for every slots

6.learn zbf2l algs for the cases where the last pair is incorrect but
in its own slot.


THE GOAL IS TO AVERAGE 7-8S FOR F2L

LL:

1.Have the best recognition system you can, the goal is to recognize
and execute LL algs as fast as possible. For example when you got a
thunder for OLL, place the 2 cases with the same orientation of the
thunder, do the same thing for square cases...etcetcetc

2.be able to achieve all OLL sub1.5 and all PLL sub2.

3.avoid cube rotations during algs.

THE GOAL IS TO AVERAGE 4-5S FOR LL




THE GOAL OF FRIDRICH METHOD IS TO AVERAGE 11-13S...

I hope this topic will help some cubers.

[Absolut teaM member]






456. Re: [Speed cubing group] My point of view about fridrich...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 4 Aug 2005 15:48:51 -0600

How long did it take you to improve to this speed? You must have
worked a lot as I recall in April you averaged over 20 in France. Good
work!

Tyson Mao

California Institute of Technology

457. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 21:52:45 -0000

I use F2L for about a year now and work my LL algs since 2 years.
I average 20s at the CdF but was about 17s of best avg and about
18-19s of global avg, now i'm about 13s and between 15-16s fr global
avg...

459. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 and 5x5 parts for sale
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 22:44:44 -0000

Hi! Professor (5x5x5) x-centers break rather too easily also. More easily than 4x4x4 centers i would say. Unless you use the original arxon which seems to have weaker centers than newer 4x4x4. And anyway it seems to me the prices are a tad too high. Those who break cubies easily may be better off simply get a cheap cube off eBay for spare pieces. That said it's great that people now have a place to easily get single spare pieces. Myself, i have many "retired" cubes ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > It looks like you have the wrong picture on "Rubik's 5x5x5 Middle Edge". > > I understand the request for 4x4x4 center as they break easily, but > why are you getting other requests? > > On 8/3/05, jello33 <chris@c...> wrote: > > I've been getting alot of requests for parts for the 4x4 and 5x5 so I > > now have them for sale on my site. > > > > The pieces come unstickered. > > > > Thanks > > Chris > > www.cubesmith.com > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 460. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 and 5x5 parts for sale
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 00:21:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > It looks like you have the wrong picture on "Rubik's 5x5x5 Middle Edge". I fixed the picture, thanks for pointing it out. As to the point of the parts being a little too pricey, these are brand new peices and I'd have to sell all the centers from each cube to make a profit, and since I probably won't sell many of the other pieces, (edges & corners) I'll be lucky to break even on the parts, and that's before I pay for shipping. ;) Anyway, thanks to everyone for supporting cubesmith, I see a lot of kind words about my stuff around this board. Chris

From which website? zemalinou <l_f_l_x@...> escreveu: For people qho don't know i'm sebastien felix, I averaged 13.00s ( 13.55 12.87 12.62 12.56 13.90 13.67 (14.15) 12.59 13.17 12.28 12.83 (12.13) SD=0.66 average 13.004(so close to sub13:D))with the fridrich method and think we can get sub12. Here are all the tips I use to speed my fridrich solves. CROSS: 1.end your cross at D, L or R and try to find the 1st pair during the D, D' or D2 move. If you can anticipate the 1st pair during 15s of preinspection do it! 2.try to build extended cross or a cross and a piece of the first pair, then before doing the D, D' or D2 to end the cross, insert the 2nd piece of the 1st pair and you'll get an extended cross 3.be able to do the cross BLD almost everytime. F2L: 1.Of course look ahead and have NO DELAYS 2.use empty slots to less turn your cube during F2L. 3.use multisloting to reduce your number of moves for solving F2L(try to do every F2L solve with less than 32 moves) 4.have a look on LL edges from the 3rd slot to the 4rth slot, and try to orient as many as possible(it avoid 0 edges oriented OLL, and you have more than 1 chances out 27 to skip OLL if you master it since the 3rd slot) 5.of course know how to solve every case for every slots 6.learn zbf2l algs for the cases where the last pair is incorrect but in its own slot. THE GOAL IS TO AVERAGE 7-8S FOR F2L LL: 1.Have the best recognition system you can, the goal is to recognize and execute LL algs as fast as possible. For example when you got a thunder for OLL, place the 2 cases with the same orientation of the thunder, do the same thing for square cases...etcetcetc 2.be able to achieve all OLL sub1.5 and all PLL sub2. 3.avoid cube rotations during algs. THE GOAL IS TO AVERAGE 4-5S FOR LL THE GOAL OF FRIDRICH METHOD IS TO AVERAGE 11-13S... I hope this topic will help some cubers. [Absolut teaM member] --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! Acesso Grtis: Internet rpida e grtis. Instale o discador agora! [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
463. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 00:47:49 -0000

Hey Sebastien! Congratulations on your new average that is absolutely amazing! Also thanks for your tips, I'm sure I speak for a number of people when I say that I think they'll be useful. I've already started trying to prepare the next c/e pair while working on the current one (multislotting) and so far I like it! However since I just started I really don't know many cases and I have a hard time doing it quickly. But I assume this comes with practice. Thanks again for the tips, I for one will be reading over and trying to implement them in my own solving. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@h...> wrote: > For people qho don't know i'm sebastien felix, I averaged 13.00s ( > 13.55 12.87 12.62 12.56 13.90 13.67 (14.15) 12.59 13.17 12.28 12.83 > (12.13) SD=0.66 average 13.004(so close to sub13:D))with the fridrich > method and think we can get sub12. > > Here are all the tips I use to speed my fridrich solves. > > CROSS: > 1.end your cross at D, L or R and try to find the 1st pair during the > D, D' or D2 move. For example when you got a > thunder for OLL, place the 2 cases with the same orientation of the > thunder, do the same thing for square cases...etcetcetc > > 2.be able to achieve all OLL sub1.5 and all PLL sub2. > > 3.avoid cube rotations during algs. > > THE GOAL IS TO AVERAGE 4-5S FOR LL > > > > > THE GOAL OF FRIDRICH METHOD IS TO AVERAGE 11-13S... > > I hope this topic will help some cubers. > > [Absolut teaM member]
464. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 03:49:49 -0000

For LL i use my own algs, I advice everybody bernard helmstetter
database:Very usefull to find THE alg which fits well with your hands...

I fogot some things...

F2L:

7.Use non adjacent pairing, if one piece of a pair is already solve?
do D or D' or D2 then put the 2nd piece and realign F2L...

LL:

3.Use your own algs, I think finding your own algs helps you to
increase your dexterity and makes you better

466. Program to analyze the "speed" of an alg
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 14:16:21 -0000

Hey everyone,

I remember this topic came up a long time ago, and it was decided that
it would probably take a lot of work.

Is there a way that we can build some sort of testing program to
analyze this? Maybe we could fabricate lots of similar scrambles with
only a small portion of the algs different (say two or three turns in
the middle) and have the users rate which one feels "faster".

This way we could have it rate two types of regrips, or two ways to
insert an uncomfortable B move into a fast RUL alg or something like that.

I've noticed with ZBLL algs that I almost exclusively look for RUL
algs now. I usually also end up liking RULM moves too, but they just
don't come up that often for the algs I need.

Even when I get a weird alg like L D R U' R E R2 F D2 B' D2 F2 which
has D,E,F, and B turns I still turn it into an RUL alg. My trigger
for this one is almost exclusively RrULlM except for one easy to
execute F turn in the middle: L z' (R U) [L' (U)] [(M') (U2)] (F) [R
l] [U' (l')2] U2

What other turn groups are good? I think ULD and URD and URF and ULF
are also very fast! What others do you guys use?

Also do we think that together we could try to work on such a program,
or would it not be very practical/accurate? I was recently reminded
of this old topic, but I don't remember what we concluded.

I think it would be very interesting if it existed, but I wonder about
how good it would be at actually identifying which algs are good.

What do you programmers think?

Chris

469. sub-17 with ZB!!!!!!!!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 15:30:45 -0000

I finally made it to sub-17 with ZB!!!! It took me 6 months, all of
ZBF2L, and 60 ZBLL algs to do it, but I finally got there!

18.29, 17.56, 15.47, 17.06, 17.67, 14.80, 14.58, 18.37, 19.31,
(12.70), (24.56), 16.66 = 16.98 (this was not a rolling average
either, and done on a stackmat)

:-D Can't wait for sub-16! I predict that it will take 144 ZBLL algs
(2 full orientation cases) to do it, but I hope it will happen sooner.

Chris

472. edge permutation for square-1
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 17:13:03 -0000

Lately I've been working on trying to find algorithms that I like for
all the edge permuations on the square-1.

To find these I've been using Jaap's sq1optim.exe program. It's
really fast, but it doesn't pause between algorithms and it doesn't
have enough options for me.

Plus the algorithms that I get are sometimes pretty ugly like: (1,0)/
(5,-4)/(-2,-5)/(3,-3)/(-3,0)/(5,2)/(0,-3)/(4,-2)/(5,-3)

So I'm wondering, has anyone already compiled a list of good edge
permutation algorithms?

Or does anyone have a square-1 solver with more options like no turns
of 4 or 5, or ignoring the side-colors?

Thanks for your help,
Ben.

476. Re: [Speed cubing group] edge permutation for square-1
From: lwin kyawkyaw <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 5 Aug 2005 11:46:02 -0700 (PDT)

hi there ben. ive come up with some simple but pretty fast permutation for three cycle edge permutation and i believe we can also derive other forms of permutations from it. its pretty hard to describe but ill see if i can get a video of it onto this forum. it involves. (doing moves set A, my discovery :P)-(moving bottom by 1,2,5 etc.)-(reversing moves set A') its pretty fast from what i think. --- Ben King <grsbmd@...> wrote: > Lately I've been working on trying to find > algorithms that I like for > all the edge permuations on the square-1. > > To find these I've been using Jaap's sq1optim.exe > program. 478. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 20:02:04 -0000

merci gilles mais tu es trop flatteur;)

...I think that multisloting is not fast to master but quite easy,
that is just intuitive algs, the hardest thing is to anticipate the 4
pieces! but doing that force you to develop you're anticipation, it
allow you to see how pieces will change during F2L and have a better
fridrich F2L solve.

I advice everybody to work a lot on his LL algs because thats one of
the key to low averages(have an efficient LL with an avg of 4-5s at
everytime), the other is to have an efficient F2L,)

but i got one question for your gilles, why don't you use ZBF2L for
the last pair of your 2nd 1*2*3 blok and then use COLL to skip the
orientation stage for your 6 last edges?

Keep cubing

sebastien



[Absolut teaM member]
