482. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: thylakoid125 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 05 Aug 2005 22:36:27 -0000

Hey sebastien, I'm sure I'm not the only one, but I have very high
doubts about your incredible records. Maybe show us some proof...
perhaps an uncut vidoe like katsu's? Even a sub 15 average would be
sufficient because honestly, with your reputation, I don't think you
can even hit that. But its ok, you'll probably have an excuse for not
making a video so I don't expect one. Unlike macky, you have no proof
of your accomplishments. I'm sorry if this sounds offensive, but I
think you should expect some doubt with those kind of achievements and
no form of credibility.




483. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: isolvecubes <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 03:56:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thylakoid125 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey sebastien, I'm sure I'm not the only one, but I have very high > doubts about your incredible records. Maybe show us some proof... > perhaps an uncut vidoe like katsu's? Even a sub 15 average would be > sufficient because honestly, with your reputation, I don't think you > can even hit that. But its ok, you'll probably have an excuse for not > making a video so I don't expect one. Unlike macky, you have no proof > of your accomplishments. I'm sorry if this sounds offensive, but I > think you should expect some doubt with those kind of achievements and > no form of credibility. You know, I hate to say this, but I have to agree here. Now, I don't know Sebastian, so I am not one to judge on his character. However, the tournament in France where he set a 20.02 average was in April. Do you really expect us to believe that you cut 7 seconds off of your average in 3 months? People spend years trying to shave off seconds especially in the 15 and 16 second range. A 13 second average is amazingly fast, and I do not believe it is possible to achieve that from 20.02 in 3 months, especially since Rubik's Cubing is not a job. If you would provide some sort of video evidence that you can indeed accomplish this, then perhaps we would have more reason to believe. However, as it stands, no one asked you for your advice and you simply put out an e-mail with "your view about fridrich". I get the feeling that you claim to be a master at Fridrich and a foremost authority simply because you occupy the number 1 slot on the unofficial rankings list. There's news. You can say whatever you want! But no one has to believe you. In all honesty, you are not the number 1 cuber. There are 24 cubers who are faster than you. You are 25th. This is based on official competitions where we know you cannot cheat or lie. And yeah, thanks a lot for presenting your views on Fridrich. You have done nothing but spit out the mantra of every sub-25 cuber out there in the world. Find algorithms that fit your hands? Look ahead? We know all of this already! I do not see a single novel idea in anything that you have presented. Thylakoid is right. You cannot expect any respect from any of us unless you provide us with a little bit of evidence. Just a little. Macky has time and time again in competition showed that he can achieve low 15 and sub-15 averages in pressure situations. For a 13.00 second cuber, I would expect you to solve a cube, on a bad day, in about 15 seconds. Just show us a 15.5 second average and it will quell the doubts of everyone. You gain nothing from bragging here. No one believes you, and when it comes time for the competition, you will be beaten by 19 second cubers, and you'll be searching for excuses, and we'll all turn away, and turn our attention to those who have honest characters. -Jonathan
484. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 07:18:38 +0200

Hi Jonathan, I would like to keep this a club of friends. So please find friendlier wordings for your opinion next time. Keep on cubing, and have fun, (moderator) Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: isolvecubes To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Saturday, August 06, 2005 5:56 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thylakoid125 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey sebastien, I'm sure I'm not the only one, but I have very high > doubts about your incredible records. Maybe show us some proof... > perhaps an uncut vidoe like katsu's? Even a sub 15 average would be > sufficient because honestly, with your reputation, I don't think you > can even hit that. But its ok, you'll probably have an excuse for not > making a video so I don't expect one. Unlike macky, you have no proof > of your accomplishments. I'm sorry if this sounds offensive, but I > think you should expect some doubt with those kind of achievements and > no form of credibility. You know, I hate to say this, but I have to agree here. Now, I don't know Sebastian, so I am not one to judge on his character. However, the tournament in France where he set a 20.02 average was in April. Do you really expect us to believe that you cut 7 seconds off of your average in 3 months? People spend years trying to shave off seconds especially in the 15 and 16 second range. A 13 second average is amazingly fast, and I do not believe it is possible to achieve that from 20.02 in 3 months, especially since Rubik's Cubing is not a job. If you would provide some sort of video evidence that you can indeed accomplish this, then perhaps we would have more reason to believe. However, as it stands, no one asked you for your advice and you simply put out an e-mail with "your view about fridrich". I get the feeling that you claim to be a master at Fridrich and a foremost authority simply because you occupy the number 1 slot on the unofficial rankings list. There's news. You can say whatever you want! But no one has to believe you. In all honesty, you are not the number 1 cuber. There are 24 cubers who are faster than you. You are 25th. This is based on official competitions where we know you cannot cheat or lie. And yeah, thanks a lot for presenting your views on Fridrich. You have done nothing but spit out the mantra of every sub-25 cuber out there in the world. Find algorithms that fit your hands? Look ahead? We know all of this already! I do not see a single novel idea in anything that you have presented. Thylakoid is right. You cannot expect any respect from any of us unless you provide us with a little bit of evidence. Just a little. Macky has time and time again in competition showed that he can achieve low 15 and sub-15 averages in pressure situations. For a 13.00 second cuber, I would expect you to solve a cube, on a bad day, in about 15 seconds. Just show us a 15.5 second average and it will quell the doubts of everyone. You gain nothing from bragging here. No one believes you, and when it comes time for the competition, you will be beaten by 19 second cubers, and you'll be searching for excuses, and we'll all turn away, and turn our attention to those who have honest characters. -Jonathan ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
485. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 08:30:34 +0200

Hello,

I don't know much about fast progress, but what I know by my own
experience is that you can always improve yourself, and sometimes it
doens't take that long if you have done many mistakes all along, and
then one day you say "oh ! I can do that instead !"

Ron can tell you that 2 or 3 days ago I sent him 2 differents emails
about a new best average : 22.16 in the morning, and the evening I did
a 20.97.

What happened ? I changed something in the way I was solving the
cross, and the result is there.

Now I can agree that there is a slight difference between 1.19 seconds
(from 22.16 to 20.97) and 7 seconds (from 20 to 13).
That's why I agree that it's possible to have a doubt, but you can't
judge the person directly without letting him proving himself.
I see 2 possibilities here :
1. One video would be a very good way to prove yourself to the people
(and have your average accepted in the UWC list)
2. Wait until the next tournament to see if you can solve it so fast

You can choose :-)
Anyway, keep up the good work :-)


486. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: thylakoid125 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 06:39:37 -0000

There's a huge difference between 22-20 and 20-13. Anyways... yes a
video would be extremely good proof, but as I said before, I highly
doubt he'll be able to produce one. But if he miraculously does, I'll
gladly eat my words because sub 14 would be an incredible feat.





487. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 00:28:50 -0700

1. Competitions are hard. Most people are several seconds slower than
their at home average, especially on the first one.

2. A video proves nothing. Anyone averaging 20 seconds can do sub 15 on
rehearsed cubes.

This is a pointless argument since there is no way to find out. If you
don't believe someone until they've proven their skills in
competitions, then don't. But speculating about it is a waste of time.
Not that that will stop 50 more posts on this over the weekend...

- - - - - - - - - - - -
"The power of accurate observation is commonly called cynicism
by those who have not got it." -- George Bernard Shaw

Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com

I must say that I find all of those posts outrageously offensive. I don't say we have proofs of Sebastian's times either, but he must have the benefit of doubts. What I know for sur about him is : - he has probably one of the most technical F2L today ; - his LL is very famous in France, used by the so called members of the absolut team. - his best average was around 16.xx at the time of the french open, not 20.xx - I've heard he works rubik's cube **A LOT** those days. Now if you take as evidence the competition results, you are probably wrong. I can give you numerous example why : - in the German ChShip, Ron VB's average over 15 cubes was around 18.5 how do u explain he could make a 14.59 average one month before ? - what about Gilles Roux's times ? Can you explain why he has problems even getting under 20'' in competition and produce 15.xx at the same times ? - What about Stefan Pochmann ? He was around 26'' in that german open and now he's claiming sub19, when everybody knows that he has a full time job, and that he also achieves numerous performances in 4x4, 5x5, BLD, magic, click, etc. ? Where did he find the time to cut those 7'' ? I think that nobody would doubt about the performances of the 3 guys above. It just tells us that there's a huge gap between competition and cubing at home. By the way, those records are "unofficial". [Snip overagressive and useless comments] > seconds. Just show us a 15.5 second average and it will quell the doubts of everyone. > > You gain nothing from bragging here. No one believes you, and when it comes time for > the competition, you will be beaten by 19 second cubers, and you'll be searching for > excuses, and we'll all turn away, and turn our attention to those who have honest > characters. This is maybe going to far, "everyone", "no-one", why do you think you are allowed to speak in the name of the whole rubik's community ? I advise moderation, Cheers, -- Francois.

493. [Speed cubing group] Magic with one string less
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 12:06:10 +0200

Hello,

I was just practising Magic (found a new technique and I'm improving
my times :-))
but I broke one string.
I searched to repair it on the Magic but I couldn't find where it
broke as it moved a lot while I was solving it.

So I removed it completely.
It seems that the Magic works still very well whithout any problem.

Is it really important to have all the strings ?

Thank you,
Gilles.


494. Pop allowed in comps ? is this really fair ?
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 12:25:31 +0200

Hi there, I'm just a sub30 cubist, and never entered any comp' so far, so I'm maybe not the best one to write this post. Anyway... I was wondering about the fairness of allowing an extra time for pops in comps. If you consider that : - popping is the consequence of bad handling of the cube - popping occurs when you take lots of risks to achieve a great time ; - in other sports like tennis, we don't allow to replay the point when a string gets broken ; in car races, if you go to fast and leave the road, you are not allowed another start ; - in principle you could "fake" a pop when you need another excellent time in comp', and you just have realized that the start of your F2L is rather bad...(ok, enough about "cheating" today ;)) ... I'm wondering if we should really allow extra cube for popping. If we still allow extracube... Would it be clever to change the rule that for the extra cube, you get some kind of penalty like : IDEA1 : add 2'' to the extra cube time ; or IDEA2 : the time of the extra cube cannot be better than your {average(AVG) on the serie] +(alpha x SD). [SD = standard dev.] [example, alpha = 1. You time (T_ex) your extra cube :. If T_ex >= AVG + SD, then you keep T_ex in the Avg T_ex < AVG + SD, you replace T_ex by AVG + SD.] Well, what do you think ? -- Francois.
495. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 10:34:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, isolvecubes <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thylakoid125 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > However, as it stands, no one asked > you for your advice and you simply put out an e-mail with "your view about fridrich". I get > the feeling that you claim to be a master at Fridrich and a foremost authority simply > because you occupy the number 1 slot on the unofficial rankings list. Hi "isolvecubes", "thylakoid125", "Jonathan" or whoever you really are. Yes, I did notice that you "both" only joined the group yesterday. And what's the first thing you do? Attack someone you don't even know. What shall we think about *you* now? And yes, no one asked for his advice here. Well, maybe someone asked in email. Plus, which of the posts here have been asked for? Certainly nobody asked for yours, either! And I myself am happy and thankful Sebastien posted his advice. He did *not* only repeat old ideas, and even if he did, it would reaffirm my faith in those ideas, so it would still be welcome. I would know that I'm on the "right way" to success. And yes, if someone is a "master" on something, he might feel the desire to share his knowledge. Is there anything wrong with this? I know I felt that way for example when making my magic videos. And it has even paid back for me, since Alexander Ooms improved my master magic method and then showed me the improvement. Stefan

497. [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 10:50:45 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@f.. .> wrote: > > I agree with Lars, except that it's possible to have proofs on > videos, using some fancy scramblings. > > The idea of this is shown in one of Gilles (excellent) vids : > http://grrroux.free.fr/me/speed3.avi That's no proof, either. The scramble sequences he used could be identity algs, i.e. not changing the cube. For a better proof, he should repeat (throw into air then make *one* move) let's say 10 times (starting with an already scrambled cube). And a moving environment would be good, e.g. people walking around, so that he can't trick with video editing. Then again, that's all unnecessary. I believe him anyway, I don't need a proof. I don't even need the scrambling he already showed. Then again, it's not useless. It does increase the entertainment value a bit, which I've already noticed comparing Tyson's two blindfold videos. From a "trust" point of view it doesn't matter to me whether he has someone else scrambling and then people walking and talking around him. But it is indeed more lively and entertaining, especially his remark after the solve :-) Cheers! Stefan
498. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 10:53:03 -0000

Jonathan and Mr. thylakoid, I think that you have both read entirely too much into the the initial post of Sebastien. Please go ahead and read it again ... I'll wait. Good. Now, Sebastien's subsequent posts in this topic were simply responses to questions asked of him. I'm not sure where you get the idea that he is trying to pass himself off as the "foremost authority" or a "deity." Your reactions to Sebastien's post are just not warranted by what he wrote. There has been much discussion in this forum of the limits of different solution methods. In his first post Sebastien merely states that he thinks "... we can get sub12" and goes on to give some of his recommendations. He should be free to do this without harassment. First, this is a forum dedicated to the open discussion of speedcubing. Second, while he has not shown himself to be the single fastest cuber in the world in competition, he has shown himself to be one of the fastest in the world. Even though most of what he wrote has been written before, I suspect that it could still give insight to some of us ~30" cubers how a <20" cuber focuses his efforts. Peace, Scott

In addition to being nervous, I had also just a few days earlier learned the last 3 PLLs and switched to block recognition method and I forced myself to use the new stuff. - Uh, if I have a full time job, then it's cubing and I unfortunately don't get paid for it. I pretty much do it all day long, every day. Cheers! Stefan
500. Re: My point of view about fridrich...

You dont have to judge him and call him a cheater. Some guys are nervous during competitions and do much worse times then they usually do at home. That meaans that Felix may have had a personal best of 16-17 when he did 20 in April at a competition. That means that his improvement maybe was "only" 16-13=3 seconds which I think is possible in 4 months. 501. Re: Pop allowed in comps ? is this really fair ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 12:06:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goodxy2002" <goodxy2002@y...> wrote: > hey francois. if a judge sees you pop on purpose, you get kicked out > of the tournament. pops happen, some people have different > styles/different cubes. i think the rules are fine How do you prove that he popped on purpose? I almost never pop myself (thanks to my cubes and my style) but I could imagine someone having a "pop-pll" that looks like a normal algorithm but forces a pop. I know some of my algs are much more prone to popping than others. It could even be an identity algorithm, i.e. in case you fail to pop, you only lose a little time. I don't like the current pop handling, either, and I think the penalty idea is a good compromise. In the rules they're unfortunately called "Puzzle Defects", though actually they're of course the fault of the cuber. Even if you want to blame the puzzle, you must blame the person who chose and prepared the puzzle. My first vote would go to not treating pops specially, i.e. if you pop, you better fix it fast and continue. My second vote would go to Francois' IDEA1 of adding 2 seconds, since the cuber should not get away for free for making a mistake. IDEA2 is too complicated I think. Cheers! Stefan
502. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 13:17:23 -0000

Well, lot of answers, many of them arn't interesting. First I dont
claim to be THE master of fridrich and to be god, i just know that I
average lower than other cubers in front of my PC and want to share
some ideas in order to let cubers see where the loose time.

You treat me of cheater or liar, so F**K you, i dont want to be
recognize as the best, come and do battle with me then you could say
I'm a liar or a cheater.

When i did france championship, my best avg was 16.83, so I lost avout
3s in competition, then win 3.5s on my best avg, about 1s per month
isnt a lot I think...

I know there was people doubting of me but seeing such assholes
astonished me, if you're not happy get out of here, i never asked you
something! And as everybody know in france, still you're not recognize
guilty you're innocent, i say that for people who forget that you must
have proofs to accuse someone.

What will me my interest to give a wrong average, contrary tou you
teenagers who doubt of my abilities, i dont cube in order to try to
have a kool personality and have friends, I get rid about the cube!!!

So thanks to people who read my post smartly and to other suspicious
people...F**K!I'm not an authority because i'm for instance at the 1st
place of the list asshole(Isolvecubes) but if I can do a cube 1s
faster than other cubers(on average) thats because other cubers loose
time somewhere and they can cut those time with my advice(I hope).
concerning thylakoid125, you doubt me to do a video, I already have
5-6 sub15 videos what do you want more! And just a detail, when you're
a smart person, you tell others your name when you came into a
discussion...

thx to Gilles VDP, golgobridge, stefan P, pioneersop and gunnar to
have defended my POW when i was sleeping:)

Well, to summarize, i ignore people who dont trust me and for people
who trust me come talk with me to know if i can help you to save time.

Keep cubing sebastien

PS:for people who dont know, since 7-8 monthes, i just practice 3*3*3
and fridrich method!




503. Re: My point of view about fridrich...

504. Re: [Speed cubing group] Magic with one string less
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 13:54:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > I was just practising Magic (found a new technique and I'm improving > my times :-)) > but I broke one string. Happens all the time. > I searched to repair it on the Magic but I couldn't find where it > broke as it moved a lot while I was solving it. There will be two "gaps" in between tiles, diagonal from each other that have only two strings in them instead of four. > So I removed it completely. > It seems that the Magic works still very well whithout any problem. Key word: "seems"... > Is it really important to have all the strings ? Though you can probably achieve the same times as you normally would (or sometimes even slightly faster times), the puzzle is less stable. You become much more likely to break another string and it becomes quite easy to tangle the puzzle when you are solving it. I know from past experience of solving with a missing string. :( Ugly stuff, really... lol ~ Bob
505. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 14:12:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@h...> wrote: > I forgot to say that in fact i'm quite happy to see that i became such > fast with the fridrich method that now people are doubting that's > real:D :D :D...too comical LOL Hey everybody, I am almost a bit afraid to give a reply in this discussion.. It's already getting a bit tooo crowded in here. Anyway, first of all, I'd like to ask everybody to stay calm, for your own sake. Second, it's very natural for people to have doubts. People want to see before they believe something. And I don't really think there's anything wrong with that. Humans tend to have doubts, try to understand that Sebastian. To the people who have doubts: There's no need to accuse anyone or use bad language or anything. Just remember to always be polite. About the credibility of videos: Of course, we all know that videos proove nothing. However, seeing someone on the internet, on websites, pics, of videos, anything on the net, help me a lot. I remember when Jean Pons had the UWR for the cube, I had a pretty hard time believing him. But we had some chats on MSN and nice races with a webcam (really had that 'race'-feeling), and it made me confident that he was for real. The idea is simple: Katsu has a huge site with video's, tv-appearances etc. so there's no reason to doubt he did a sub-15 average. But if someone cuber posts exactly the same times, it would still be easier to believe Katsu then to believe that new person. We all know it's possible, but it's easier to trust someone you 'know' (even though I only know Katsu by his website). I must say I am also a pretty sceptical about the new records Sebastian is telling us (I hate to say this, Sebastian ;)). But I also had a few chats with him, and he sounds like a pretty nice guy, and I know he's into cubing pretty seriously, so I can't see why any cuber who is into cubing that seriously would make up records like that. There is simply no 'motive'. So yes, I would appreciate to see some more nice videos. And no, I am not calling anyone a *. See you guys, Jol.
506. Re: Pop allowed in comps ? is this really fair ?
From: "al_yyz" <anders.larsson@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 14:30:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > My first vote would go to not treating pops specially, i.e. if you > pop, you better fix it fast and continue. > I second this idea, in particular for events with "average of..." (that is, when slowest and fastest times are removed) and events with "best of...". For such events, one pop will not be decisive for the results. I may have second thoughts about it for events with "mean of" where all solves counts, since then a big pop would be disasterous for the results. /Anders

I thought Sebastien's Fridrich tips were helpful, they weren't regurgitated from other websites... And if he did a 20 avg. in public, and can do 13 at home that doesn't really mean he cut 7s off his time - cubing at home is much different. But even so, I don't think that 3-4 months is too short to cut off that amount of time if he works hard at it everyday. I've only been cubing for 5 months and I've gone from solving in minutes to averaging 29s. Sebastien will you be competing a tournament any time soon? Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... Some of my tips are from other websites but thats most generic ones
like "go slowly look ahead", "adjust your LL to your hand" but many
people dont understand them, it means dont look at algs on the net and
try to reproduce it with your dexterity, thats better to try many
algs, it helps you to develop your dexterity!

surely european championships2006






510. Re: [Speed cubing group] Magic with one string less
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 18:02:54 +0200

I've learned something today : never use a Magic whom doesn't have all
his strings.

It just felt completely apart as 2 others strings broke.

So I have to rebuild it completely :-(

The thing is that I don't know how to do that and the booklet doesn't
explain how to rebuild it...
Could you explain me how to put back all the strings (I have to make
new ones) or give me an address where I can find that ?

Thanks

(hopefully I'll have a new one on monday :p)


511. [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 16:27:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > > But even so, I don't think that 3-4 months is too short to > cut off that amount of time if he works hard at it everyday. Especially if you work not only hard, but also smart. How many times have I told myself to learn the last few missing algs? Or systematically practice/improve/replace the algs that are bad for me? Or to learn algs so that the U adjustment for similarly looking cases is the same? Or use the stackmat? And use computer scrambles? And write down the times and collecting statistics? And always use perfect cubes? Or in general any stuff that requires me to do some serious thinking/work instead of just stupid lazy practicing? Cheers! Stefan P.S. Talent can help, too :-)
512. Re: [Speed cubing group] Magic with one string less
From: "ardraven yahoo.es" <arcdraven@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 18:55:17 +0200

Hi. I am sorry too..
you can rebuild it using fishing wire. but this is a hard thing to do yourself...
I have the same problem and until today I haven't fixed it.
Time ago, rubiks.com offered magic DIY, but not now and I think it will never be on sale again.
I found some web pages were you can take some ideas on how to rebuild your magic.

http://twistypuzzles.com/articles/magic-removestrings.shtml
http://twistypuzzles.com/articles/magic-restringing.shtml
http://twistypuzzles.com/articles/magic-tilearranging.shtml
http://twistypuzzles.com/articles/magic-2x2.shtml
http://twistypuzzles.com/articles/magic-super-master.shtml


The 'only' thing you must do is to make your own strings with some fishing wire... I have not tried yet, but some day maybe. If you experience some advances, please inform me.

have fun...

Alberto

513. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: Frank Morris <ephem825@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 10:58:00 -0700 (PDT)

I guess that since there are more and more opinions being posted, I will post mine. I have talked with Sebastien quite a bit over the past couple of weeks, and his tips have helped alot. Thanks! Also, I was in a chat with him and Jon Morris yesterday, and he walked us through some of his F2L solves. Jon generated the scrambles right there, and the solutions were given quickly. Judging by the way that Sebastien solved the F2L, I can definately see how he can post such fast times. This, coupled with his "perfected" Last Layer, I believe that his times are credible. I know first hand how competitions can affect one's performance. It is much different than relaxing in front of the computer, solving for hours on end. Nerves definately mess with me. Anyhow, I believe you Sebastien, and thanks for the tips! From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 12:22:39 -0600

Tennis is a bad analogy. They allow a second server if you miss the
first time.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 6, 2005, at 4:25 AM, FD-Rubik wrote:

> - in other sports like tennis, we don't allow to replay
> the point when a string gets broken ; in car races, if
> you go to fast and leave the road, you are not allowed
> another start ;
> - in principle you could "fake" a pop when you need another
> excellent time in comp', and you just have realized that
> the start of your F2L is rather bad...(ok, enough about
> "cheating" today ;))
> ... I'm wondering if we should really allow extra cube for
> popping.



516. Re: [Speed cubing group] BLD solving in competitions
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 12:29:02 -0600

Hi Chris,

It's a DNF. I need to write that into the regulations. To provide
basis for this rule, I would like to quote another cube:

"If you end up one move away on a BLD solve, you're just stupid."
-Shotaro Makisumi

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

517. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Pop allowed in comps ? is this really fair ?
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 12:31:10 -0600

Yeah, as always, this is been a controversial topic. The trick, of course, is finding a method that allows us to deal with 'average' competitions and 'mean' competitions. Obviously, in the 'mean' competition, the effects are much more detrimental. Anyway, keep throwing out ideas, but I can say there probably won't be any significant changes before 2006. We don't want to be meddling around too much before WC 2005. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Aug 6, 2005, at 8:30 AM, al_yyz wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: >> >> My first vote would go to not treating pops specially, i.e. if you >> pop, you better fix it fast and continue. >> > > I second this idea, in particular for events with "average of..." > (that is, when slowest and fastest times are removed) and events > with "best of...". For such events, one pop will not be decisive for > the results. I may have second thoughts about it for events with "mean > of" where all solves counts, since then a big pop would be disasterous > for the results. > > /Anders > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >

One more thing... On the WC on August 23/24, 2003, Macky's best time was 20.30 seconds. On the Caltech Spring Tournament, on April 3, 2004 (less than 7 months after), his best time was 12.11 and the average of the all tournament was 15.62. He cuted of 8 seconds on 7 months, both done on oficial competitions. Why Sebastien times aren't posible? I've been cubing since June 15 (i'm not sure about the day, but was around this), and improved from 5 minutes to 45s average, and with a very bad cube from China. 521. Re: [Speed cubing group] Magic with one string less
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 19:02:11 -0000

I hate to say "I told you so." :-P My recommendation: buy a couple Simpson or Harry Potter Magics from rubiks.com and disassemble them for their strings. They are $5 each. I used Jaap's website for putting a Magic together (I have done it before). Over the past few months since I started Magic-ing, I have replaced over 60 strings (maybe an underestimate). It happens. I have never heard of anybody making their own from fishing line (probably not even worth the effort). If it is your first time building a Magic from nothing, it will take a few hours, but it is worth the experience, because you will probably have to do it again. :-P ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > I've learned something today : never use a Magic whom doesn't have all > his strings. > > It just felt completely apart as 2 others strings broke. > > So I have to rebuild it completely :-( > > The thing is that I don't know how to do that and the booklet doesn't > explain how to rebuild it... > Could you explain me how to put back all the strings (I have to make > new ones) or give me an address where I can find that ? > > Thanks > > (hopefully I'll have a new one on monday :p)
522. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 13:02:02 -0600

In Macky's defense, best time comparisons are not the same as average comparisons. All it takes for a 'best time' is just one good solve and we all understand that. If you really want to do a comparison, I think Macky was averaging around 20 back at WC 2003 and took his average down to about 16 at the Caltech tournament. Macky also has a habit of doing well in tournaments. 523. Re: [Speed cubing group] Multislotting
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 6 Aug 2005 13:13:11 -0600

I think multislotting is what Marcus Sturh also uses. Basically, as
you put in a pair, you're doing other things to manipulate the other
pieces to make them easier to put in later. I think... that's the
idea. You probably do it a bit already just from instinct.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 6, 2005, at 1:08 PM, goodxy2002 wrote:

> Hey, could someone explain multislotting? I have no idea what it is!
> Thanks.
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>



524. Re: [Speed cubing group] Magic with one string less
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 19:26:36 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Over the past few months since I started Magic-ing, I have > replaced over 60 strings (maybe an underestimate). Whoa, that's a lot :-) I have maybe broken 15-20 so far... next time you completely disassemble one, you could try lubing the strings, I use pure liquid (but high viscosity) silicone now. It's not only good to make cubes twist faster but also to protect plastic. You could also just go slower. I'd especially suggest that for tournaments, because you're more nervous anyway. Especially I'd suggest that for you, Bob, in Dallas. > I have never heard of anybody making their own from fishing line > (probably not even worth the effort). I know somebody who did, but he said he breaks strings (original or his own) every three solves so he stopped magicing ;-) Cheers! Stefan
525. [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 06 Aug 2005 20:15:18 -0000

Hmm.. Why are you defending Macky? Nobody is offending him.. (?) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > In Macky's defense, best time comparisons are not the same as average > comparisons. All it takes for a 'best time' is just one good solve and > we all understand that. If you really want to do a comparison, I think > Macky was averaging around 20 back at WC 2003 and took his average down > to about 16 at the Caltech tournament. Macky also has a habit of doing > well in tournaments. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Aug 6, 2005, at 12:56 PM, Pedro wrote: > > > One more thing... > > On the WC on August 23/24, 2003, Macky's best time was 20.30 seconds. > > On the Caltech Spring Tournament, on April 3, 2004 (less than 7 months > > after), his best time was 12.11 and the average of the all tournament > > was 15.62. He cuted of 8 seconds on 7 months, both done on oficial > > competitions. Why Sebastien times aren't posible? I've been cubing > > since June 15 (i'm not sure about the day, but was around this), and > > improved from 5 minutes to 45s average, and with a very bad cube from > > China. > > > > Pedro > > > > Frank Morris <ephem825@y...> escreveu: > > I guess that since there are more and more opinions being posted, I > > will post mine. > > > > I have talked with Sebastien quite a bit over the past couple of > > weeks, and his tips have helped alot. Thanks! Also, I was in a chat > > with him and Jon Morris yesterday, and he walked us through some of > > his F2L solves. Jon generated the scrambles right there, and the > > solutions were given quickly. Judging by the way that Sebastien > > solved the F2L, I can definately see how he can post such fast times. > > This, coupled with his "perfected" Last Layer, I believe that his > > times are credible. > > > > I know first hand how competitions can affect one's performance. It > > is much different than relaxing in front of the computer, solving for > > hours on end. Nerves definately mess with me. > > > > Anyhow, I believe you Sebastien, and thanks for the tips! > > > > Frank Morris > > > > zemalinou <l_f_l_x@h...> wrote: > > Some of my tips are from other websites but thats most generic ones > > like "go slowly look ahead", "adjust your LL to your hand" but many > > people dont understand them, it means dont look at algs on the net and > > try to reproduce it with your dexterity, thats better to try many > > algs, it helps you to develop your dexterity! > > > > Maybe i'll come to dutch open, surely to french championships 2006 and > > surely european championships2006 > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > YAHOO! 527. LL problems
From: "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 07 Aug 2005 06:41:00 -0000

When I have a good day, I can do F2L in 10.xx seconds and LL in 6.xx
seconds. When my fingers are tired I do F2L in about 13 seconds and LL
in about 10. Even with stiff cube I can do F2L in under 15 seconds,
but LL takes over 10 seconds. In my avgs it can be like this: 14 15 21
19 16...
For me the best cubing place is outdoors, but then I can take times
only with stopwatch =( My times are then about 16 seconds
And worst is with computer. Than can make me average about 20 seconds.
So what's the problem?




528. Re: LL problems
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 07 Aug 2005 11:49:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@l...> wrote: > When I have a good day, I can do F2L in 10.xx seconds and LL in 6.xx > seconds. When my fingers are tired I do F2L in about 13 seconds and LL > in about 10. Even with stiff cube I can do F2L in under 15 seconds, > but LL takes over 10 seconds. In my avgs it can be like this: 14 15 21 > 19 16... > For me the best cubing place is outdoors, but then I can take times > only with stopwatch =( My times are then about 16 seconds > And worst is with computer. Than can make me average about 20 seconds. > So what's the problem? The thing with LL algs is that you dont just have to do them quickly(about 2-3s in your case) you must always do them at the same speed and have no lock up, thats one of the basic advice you can find on every good speedcubing page, because one alg done slower than usual and you can loose 2-3s on a solve... sebastien
529. Re: [Speed cubing group] LL problems
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 7 Aug 2005 11:59:21 -0600

gathered from the video... you are right handed, you do most of your
moves with your right hand, but somehow you hold the cross on the
right?

Tyson Mao

530. [Speed cubing group] Re: Pop allowed in comps ? is this really fair ?
From: "Frank" <ephem825@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 07 Aug 2005 23:21:51 -0000

I agree with Stefan on this one. If you pop, you have to fix it and then go on. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Yeah, as always, this is been a controversial topic. The trick, of > course, is finding a method that allows us to deal with 'average' > competitions and 'mean' competitions. Obviously, in the 'mean' > competition, the effects are much more detrimental. Anyway, keep > throwing out ideas, but I can say there probably won't be any > significant changes before 2006. We don't want to be meddling around > too much before WC 2005. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Aug 6, 2005, at 8:30 AM, al_yyz wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > >> > >> My first vote would go to not treating pops specially, i.e. if you > >> pop, you better fix it fast and continue. > >> > > > > I second this idea, in particular for events with "average of..." > > (that is, when slowest and fastest times are removed) and events > > with "best of...". For such events, one pop will not be decisive for > > the results. I may have second thoughts about it for events with "mean > > of" where all solves counts, since then a big pop would be disasterous > > for the results. > > > > /Anders > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

Not good for speed cubing at all! I have one, it's very clunky and
unsmooth, besides being strange to look at. I recommend the black DIY
cube (it's very different) or even a 25th anniversary cube, if you
get a nice loose one.


Bryan Mytko

534. Re: [Speed cubing group] White plastic DIY kit
From: "Chris Parlette" <mdcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 02:28:54 -0000

I have one, and it's far better then the best speedcube I've ever had. I don't know how it compares to the black DIYs, since I don't have one, but I love it. Some have said they didn't even have to lube it, but I did have to lube mine, but that made it perfect. As far as looking strange, I don't see that as a negative point, since it makes it stand out from my other cubes. It takes a few solves to get used to having the bright background, but I will vouch for the white kit. -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > Not good for speed cubing at all! 537. Re: [Speed cubing group] White plastic DIY kit
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 09:23:07 +0200

The color of the background is important.
You can understant that you have less contrast when you look at a
white or a yellow sticker, then I think it takes a longer time to
recognize it as white or yellow.

Despite that, I think it's as good as any other cube if it's well
lubed and built. :-)

half was 15.xx and seconds 20.xx.

540. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 11:45:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@h...> wrote: > [...] > but i got one question for your gilles, why don't you use ZBF2L for > the last pair of your 2nd 1*2*3 blok and then use COLL to skip the > orientation stage for your 6 last edges? -) Because you can prepare this last pair while finishing the previous 1x2x2. Recognizing the orientation of 5 or 6 edges takes time. -) Because fixing orientations at the same time requires additional moves, sometimes as much as when you do it later with slices. -) Because CLL is faster than COLL, and "CLL after 2*1x2x3" is even faster. -) Because more substeps in the end means more lucky cases too, and different possible strategies. Quite often, 6E4C (6 edges + 4 centers) can be solved in 10 moves or less. -) Because with an early orientation, 6E4C often begins with a costly M2 move you can avoid when mixing orientation and permutation. -) And more :-) I'm sure there are positive arguments for what you propose, but overall, I feel it's not worth it. Gilles.
541. Re: [Speed cubing group] unknown puzzle
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 12:45:56 -0000

--- Gilles van den Peereboom wrote:
> I've had this puzzle for a while now and I still can't figure out
what
> I can do with it.
> Here are a few pictures of all the possibilities I've found :
> http://gillesvdp.phpnet.org/puzzle_001.jpg


It is not really a puzzle. It is called a Yoshimoto Cube, Shinsei
Mystery, or Starburst. It is just a variation of the well-known
folding
cube, often used to show various pictures.
http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/cubic5.htm#p11


Jaap's Puzzle Page:
http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/




542. New DIY Cube
From: alex_mdc <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 13:17:50 -0000

Hello hello

I just got my new DIY cube in the post. (They said 30-40 business
days to ship to Australia and it arrived in a week :D)

A few questions about putting this baby together:

1) How tight should I adjust the centres? I've tried to make them
even all around with a gap of about 1mm, but not fully tight.

2) Should I play with the cube before I put the lube in? I mean
perhaps cubing a bit before will smooth the cubies a little, does
anyone have any recommendations on the best way to break in a new
cube like this?

3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube had
blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot of cubes
with yellow opposite white instead.

Cheers!

Alex MDC

I've tried to make them > even all around with a gap of about 1mm, but not fully tight. > > 2) Should I play with the cube before I put the lube in? I'm an aussie too. I live in NSW. It's up to you which way you sticker you cube but I did mine in the standard Rubiks configuration, eg. white opp yellow etc. I've also heard that the lube that they come is'nt that good so I just used silicone spray instead. Keith.

545. Re: New DIY Cube

Hey, I'm in Sydney, but don't know many cubers around here :) Only some friends from school but they aren't exactly speed cubers... My latest average is 31.2 seconds so I'm not too shabby but then again I'm a long way from the elite cubers! I'm hoping to find some speed in my new cube as my old cube was always catching and scratching and being a pain. As for the DIY cube, I was kind of hoping the supplied lube would be good but I guess I'll have to go looking in a hardware shop now for some spray-on stuff. One last question is about the centre caps. How do you get them to stay on? They have these little ridges around the edges which stop them even from sitting neatly inside the centre cubes. I guess I'll have to glue them but I still want to be able to pop them off if I need to adjust the screw tension, right? 547. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New DIY Cube
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 17:51:28 +0200

Personnally, I just put them in it and they stay at their place.

Now you might want to glue or use any other technique to be sure they
won't go off, but this means you won't be able to remove them
afterwards (or it'll be a lot more difficult).

I think you should just put them in it, and even if they pop, you
could always glue them or whatever...


548. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New DIY Cube
From: Marco Garbelini <garbelini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 18:03:08 +0200

I guess this is what you are looking for: http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/Speedcube/makinga.htm But I have one other question regarding brand new DIY kit cubes: do you guys sand the inner part of the cubies right away as part of the process? I'm gonna have an american friend to bring a few kits to Mozambique (where I currently live) and don't want to mess up any of them. They are too precious here. Cheers, Marco On 8/8/05, alex_mdc <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Hey, > > I'm in Sydney, but don't know many cubers around here :) Only some > friends from school but they aren't exactly speed cubers... My latest > average is 31.2 seconds so I'm not too shabby but then again I'm a > long way from the elite cubers! I'm hoping to find some speed in my > new cube as my old cube was always catching and scratching and being > a pain. > > As for the DIY cube, I was kind of hoping the supplied lube would be > good but I guess I'll have to go looking in a hardware shop now for > some spray-on stuff. > > One last question is about the centre caps. How do you get them to > stay on? They have these little ridges around the edges which stop > them even from sitting neatly inside the centre cubes. I guess I'll > have to glue them but I still want to be able to pop them off if I > need to adjust the screw tension, right? > > Thanks, > Alex MDC > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "keefdcuber" > <keithrx3c@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Hello hello > > > > > > I just got my new DIY cube in the post. (They said 30-40 business > > > days to ship to Australia and it arrived in a week :D) > > > > > > A few questions about putting this baby together: > > > > > > 1) How tight should I adjust the centres? I've tried to make them > > > even all around with a gap of about 1mm, but not fully tight. > > > > > > 2) Should I play with the cube before I put the lube in? I mean > > > perhaps cubing a bit before will smooth the cubies a little, does > > > anyone have any recommendations on the best way to break in a new > > > cube like this? > > > > > > 3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube > > had > > > blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot of > > cubes > > > with yellow opposite white instead. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > Alex MDC > > > > G'day Alex, where are you from? I'm an aussie too. I live in NSW. > > It's up to you which way you sticker you cube but I did mine in the > > standard Rubiks configuration, eg. white opp yellow etc. I've also > > heard that the lube that they come is'nt that good so I just used > > silicone spray instead. > > > > Keith. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
549. Alex, Gilles vdP, Marco Re: New DIY Cube
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 16:34:03 -0000

alex_mdc, 1. I think that it's easier to start tight and then loosen than to start loose then tighten. 2. play with it for a few hours for about a week. Lube it then do it again. 3. I prefer white opposite blue which was the original color scheme. If you get a Deluxe cube, a Rubik's game cube or the original 2x2x2 and 4x4x4 they are all white opposite blue. The supplied lube is a silicone based lube and works very well. A sliver of paper can help hold the cap on. If you insist of gluing it avoid epoxy because you may never get the cap off again. Gilles van den Peereboom The silicone spray to avoid is the oil-based version. Marco Garbelini Don't sand the inside of the cube at first. Try adjusting the spring tension, and wearing it in, and lubing it first. Very very rarely is any sanding needed. Cheers, David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Marco Garbelini <garbelini@g...> wrote: > I guess this is what you are looking for: > > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/Speedcube/makinga.htm > > But I have one other question regarding brand new DIY kit cubes: do > you guys sand the inner part of the cubies right away as part of the > process? > > I'm gonna have an american friend to bring a few kits to Mozambique > (where I currently live) and don't want to mess up any of them. They > are too precious here. > > Cheers, > Marco > > On 8/8/05, alex_mdc <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > Hey, > > > > I'm in Sydney, but don't know many cubers around here :) Only some > > friends from school but they aren't exactly speed cubers... My latest > > average is 31.2 seconds so I'm not too shabby but then again I'm a > > long way from the elite cubers! I'm hoping to find some speed in my > > new cube as my old cube was always catching and scratching and being > > a pain. > > > > As for the DIY cube, I was kind of hoping the supplied lube would be > > good but I guess I'll have to go looking in a hardware shop now for > > some spray-on stuff. > > > > One last question is about the centre caps. How do you get them to > > stay on? They have these little ridges around the edges which stop > > them even from sitting neatly inside the centre cubes. I guess I'll > > have to glue them but I still want to be able to pop them off if I > > need to adjust the screw tension, right? > > > > Thanks, > > Alex MDC > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "keefdcuber" > > <keithrx3c@h...> wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc > > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Hello hello > > > > > > > > I just got my new DIY cube in the post. (They said 30-40 business > > > > days to ship to Australia and it arrived in a week :D) > > > > > > > > A few questions about putting this baby together: > > > > > > > > 1) How tight should I adjust the centres? I've tried to make them > > > > even all around with a gap of about 1mm, but not fully tight. > > > > > > > > 2) Should I play with the cube before I put the lube in? I mean > > > > perhaps cubing a bit before will smooth the cubies a little, does > > > > anyone have any recommendations on the best way to break in a new > > > > cube like this? > > > > > > > > 3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube > > > had > > > > blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot of > > > cubes > > > > with yellow opposite white instead. > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > > > Alex MDC > > > > > > G'day Alex, where are you from? I'm an aussie too. I live in NSW. > > > It's up to you which way you sticker you cube but I did mine in the > > > standard Rubiks configuration, eg. white opp yellow etc. I've also > > > heard that the lube that they come is'nt that good so I just used > > > silicone spray instead. > > > > > > Keith.

Try adjusting the spring tension, and wearing it in, and lubing it first. Very very rarely is any sanding needed. 551. Time required
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 17:04:14 -0000

Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it
seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good
cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub-20 to
get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and
idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my last
layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I need
to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL?

Pedro

553. Re: Time required
From: "hiei_jaganshi_333" <hiei_jaganshi_333@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 17:10:57 -0000

Hi, I'm Santiago, from argentina, i'm close to be sub-20 (21.97), the best i can tell you is: practice f2l, is the only way to get sub-20 times, and the time to memorize oll and pll, depends of you, i learn it in 2 months aprox. -- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > seems imposible." 554. [Speed cubing group] Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 17:31:29 -0000

Hi Guys, Concerning how much someone can improve over time: The second time I solved the cube it took me an hour. It was immediately scrambled and the third time I solved the cube it took me 15 minutes. So inside of 15 minutes I improved 45 minutes, which was a rate of 7,776,000 seconds per month. :) David J --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > One more thing... > On the WC on August 23/24, 2003, Macky's best time was 20.30 seconds. On the Caltech Spring Tournament, on April 3, 2004 (less than 7 months after), his best time was 12.11 and the average of the all tournament was 15.62. He cuted of 8 seconds on 7 months, both done on oficial competitions. Why Sebastien times aren't posible? I've been cubing since June 15 (i'm not sure about the day, but was around this), and improved from 5 minutes to 45s average, and with a very bad cube from China. > > Pedro > > Frank Morris <ephem825@y...> escreveu: > I guess that since there are more and more opinions being posted, I will post mine. > > I have talked with Sebastien quite a bit over the past couple of weeks, and his tips have helped alot. Thanks! Also, I was in a chat with him and Jon Morris yesterday, and he walked us through some of his F2L solves. Jon generated the scrambles right there, and the solutions were given quickly. Judging by the way that Sebastien solved the F2L, I can definately see how he can post such fast times. This, coupled with his "perfected" Last Layer, I believe that his times are credible. > > I know first hand how competitions can affect one's performance. It is much different than relaxing in front of the computer, solving for hours on end. Nerves definately mess with me. > > Anyhow, I believe you Sebastien, and thanks for the tips! > > Frank Morris > > zemalinou <l_f_l_x@h...> wrote: > Some of my tips are from other websites but thats most generic ones > like "go slowly look ahead", "adjust your LL to your hand" but many > people dont understand them, it means dont look at algs on the net and > try to reproduce it with your dexterity, thats better to try many > algs, it helps you to develop your dexterity! > > Maybe i'll come to dutch open, surely to french championships 2006 and > surely european championships2006 > > > > > > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > > --------------------------------- > > > > __________________________________________________ > Do You Yahoo!? > Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! 555. Re: My point of view about fridrich...
From: "hiei_jaganshi_333" <hiei_jaganshi_333@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 17:32:27 -0000

Hi, I'm Santiago from Argentina, i'm nobody from nowhere, way do you waste words insulting people that you don't care about??? the only you need is to proof yourself and nothing more, when i was having times of 60 y blame my cube (because is one made in china, and here i don't get any original), when i reach my first sub-20 time i stop that, and start to blame miself, because i'm still not good enough to reach that times, think about it, you (all of you who are reading this) has the luck to use one original rubik's cube, or put your hand in a stackmat, or go to a tournament, are things that i dream every day, but i know i never get. Maybe you become the master of the fridich method, maybe not, there is no limit for speedcubing. One anonymus samurai say: "once you become a master of an art, you demostrate it on every aspect of you life" Keep cubing, good luck. :-) Santiago P.D.: sorry for my english --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@h...> wrote: > Well, lot of answers, many of them arn't interesting. First I dont > claim to be THE master of fridrich and to be god, i just know that I > average lower than other cubers in front of my PC and want to share > some ideas in order to let cubers see where the loose time. > > You treat me of cheater or liar, so F**K you, i dont want to be > recognize as the best, come and do battle with me then you could say > I'm a liar or a cheater. > > When i did france championship, my best avg was 16.83, so I lost avout > 3s in competition, then win 3.5s on my best avg, about 1s per month > isnt a lot I think... > > I know there was people doubting of me but seeing such assholes > astonished me, if you're not happy get out of here, i never asked you > something! And as everybody know in france, still you're not recognize > guilty you're innocent, i say that for people who forget that you must > have proofs to accuse someone. > > What will me my interest to give a wrong average, contrary tou you > teenagers who doubt of my abilities, i dont cube in order to try to > have a kool personality and have friends, I get rid about the cube!!! > > So thanks to people who read my post smartly and to other suspicious > people...F**K!I'm not an authority because i'm for instance at the 1st > place of the list asshole(Isolvecubes) but if I can do a cube 1s > faster than other cubers(on average) thats because other cubers loose > time somewhere and they can cut those time with my advice(I hope). > concerning thylakoid125, you doubt me to do a video, I already have > 5-6 sub15 videos what do you want more! And just a detail, when you're > a smart person, you tell others your name when you came into a > discussion... > > thx to Gilles VDP, golgobridge, stefan P, pioneersop and gunnar to > have defended my POW when i was sleeping:) > > Well, to summarize, i ignore people who dont trust me and for people > who trust me come talk with me to know if i can help you to save time. > > Keep cubing sebastien > > PS:for people who dont know, since 7-8 monthes, i just practice 3*3*3 > and fridrich method!
556. Re: [Speed cubing group] Time required
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 10:44:15 -0700

On 8/8/05, pedrosino1 <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? I've been cubing for almost 2 years and I just learned the last of OLL today. That's just me though. If you're anyone else, you can probably learn all the algs in 2-3 months. If you Bob Burton or Chris Hardwick, then you can learn the algs in 2-3 weeks. ;) -Chris
557. Re: [Speed cubing group] White plastic DIY kit
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 17:48:44 +0000 (GMT)

Hum, I think I will buy one... Do you know if they have screws? and how about the 25th anniversary cube? Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> escreveu: The color of the background is important. You can understant that you have less contrast when you look at a white or a yellow sticker, then I think it takes a longer time to recognize it as white or yellow. Despite that, I think it's as good as any other cube if it's well lubed and built. :-) SPONSORED LINKS Computer puzzle game Puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Online puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 558. StackMat Generation 2
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 18:32:20 -0000

Hi friends,

I recently received my StackMat Generation 2 (with a big tournament
display!).
It works fine, it feels a bit faster to stop, but it also requires
more precise positioning of the hands to start and stop.

One issue I found is that for speedcubing the small display is too
close and too soft. So when you throw down your cube, you can
accidentally touch the small display with your cube. I now have a pit
in my display. :-(
Yesterday I glued a small piece of transparent acryl on top of the
display, to protect it.

Have fun,

Ron

560. Re: [Speed cubing group] White plastic DIY kit
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 12:02:36 -0700

On 8/8/05, Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > Do you know if they have screws? They have screws. > and how about the 25th anniversary cube? Are you asking if the 25th anniversary cube has screws? If you are...then I don't think so. I have had mixed results with the 25th anniversary cube. The first one I received was very loose and rattled way too much for my tastes. The second is much better and has the potential to be a nice cube. -Chris
561. Re: [Speed cubing group] White plastic DIY kit
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 19:04:54 +0000 (GMT)

>Are you asking if the 25th anniversary cube has screws? Yes. and not. I'm asking also if the 25th annivesary cube is good for speedcubing. Chris Hunt <huntca@...> escreveu: On 8/8/05, Pedro <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > Do you know if they have screws? They have screws. > and how about the 25th anniversary cube? Are you asking if the 25th anniversary cube has screws? If you are...then I don't think so. I have had mixed results with the 25th anniversary cube. The first one I received was very loose and rattled way too much for my tastes. The second is much better and has the potential to be a nice cube. -Chris --------------------------------- YAHOO! 562. Alex, Gilles vdP, Marco Re: New DIY Cube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 19:25:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > The silicone spray to avoid is the oil-based version. Mmh, I finally looked up "oil" in wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil Maybe petroleum is bad (not sure, just a guess), but not oil in general. I doubt vegetable oil would harm the cube. And these days I'm using pure silicone oil to lube my cubes (all kinds) and it's great. Stefan
563. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New DIY Cube
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 15:45:37 -0400

Don't use Gunk, I made the mistake of putting it on a studio cube and
had to scrub it off each cubie... Try and get lube made my Snap - it
works really well. The cube lube on Rubiks.com is also really good,
but you don't get a lot. One can of snap will last the rest of your
life.


Bryan Mytko
bryanosaurus@...


On Aug 8, 2005, at 10:34 AM, Gilles van den Peereboom wrote:

> recommended for lubing cubes, which one is is ? (if this is true)

564. Re: Time required
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 19:58:34 -0000

Hi Pedro, What system are you using for the F2L? And what are your times like now? And how much experience do you have.. It's easier for me to give you tips when I know the answers to these questions. If you want to know how I improved, just take a look at my cubelog on www.solvethecube.co.uk (I started on december 2003, btw). I can also recommend reading my tips page (see tutorials -> #5). Especially what I see about not focussing on speed too much. It took me about two or three weeks to learn all the PLL's. And it took me a few months to do OLL, yes I took my time for those. For PLL algorithm: Try to search different websites with different algs to find the ones you like most. Do this every once in a while, and also try other algs you rejected a few months before. For OLL algorithms: Try my OLL page :). Maybe it works for you. (but also look for alternatives on other sites! Good luck with getting sub-20! Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good > cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub-20 to > get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and > idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my last > layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I need > to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? > > Pedro

Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 17:05:23 -0300 (ART)

I'm using normal Fridrich method for the F2L. I know most of the algs from www.speedcubing.com. My better average is 42.19 and my best single time is 32.69. 566. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 22:17:19 +0200

I don't like to repeat things, but I think it's really important to
look at different alogrithms for each case (oll & pll) so that you
find the best one for you.

(In my case, I've been cubing for about 6 months now and my best is
20.97. (took me 2 months to get down from a 30 seconds average to
20.97.

Keep up the good work :-))

569. Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 20:26:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > One issue I found is that for speedcubing the small display is too > close and too soft. So when you throw down your cube, you can > accidentally touch the small display with your cube. I now have a pit > in my display. :-( > Yesterday I glued a small piece of transparent acryl on top of the > display, to protect it. > > Have fun, > > Ron Just wait until you are flying through a solve and slam your hands down excited to see a nice fast time on your spiffy new timer, only to realize you have accidentally hit the RESET button with your right thumb, never to know your time. It happens to me almost weekly. I fear it happening in a competition. Why they would not put the reset button on the SIDE of the timer is beyond me. -Dave
