571. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New DIY Cube
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 14:03:05 -0700

On 8/8/05, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > For me that could only be true if I drink it. Ha. I bought two 20oz. cans of Heavy Duty Silicone Lubricant about 18 months ago and I haven't even finished the first. I really like it because it's "99% pure high viscosity silicone" and lasts quite a while. I bought it for $5.99 a can from here: http://www.castleproductsonline.com/silicone_lubricant.html -Chris
572. Re: Time required
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 21:20:52 -0000

Hey Pedro, Hey Pedro, I am not yet sub-20, but here is an idea of my progress once I began "speedcubing" Feb. 7 - Switch from cross on top to cross on bottom, begin learning F2L instead of first layer corners -> middle edges -- 2 week break from learning -- Mid-March - (2 weeks) - Learn PLL -- 2 week break from learning -- Begin taking averages with Fridrich for first time! :) Mid-April - (6 weeks, noncontinuous) - Learn OLL -- 6 week break from learning -- Mid-July - (2 weeks) - Learn COLL Late July - (2 days) - Learn VH edge control (connected first day, non-connected second day) Just over five months after I started learning Fridrich, I got the average that currently stands as my best, 23.49 seconds. Like everybody says, it's all about the F2L. My F2L sucks (17-18 second avg?), and it's the only reason why I'm not sub-20...maybe if I practiced for more than 3 hours per week? :( Don't learn all LL algs from the same place. That's bad. There are TONS of sites with different LL algs, and some will fit you better than others. Does this help? Everybody is different, you know that. :P Remember, a 4-look LL with a lightning fast F2L is faster than a crappy F2L with a 2-look LL. ;) (I don't listen :\) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good > cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub-20 to > get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and > idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my last > layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I need > to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? > > Pedro
573. [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 21:23:35 -0000

Hey Pedro, Those times are very normal for your system and your experience. It is actually very similar to my situation when I was cubing for two months! So keep on going like this, and you will be fine. If you ever want my help, just use the 'contact' option on my site. At this point, my tip about solving the cube very slowly (number 1) is pretty important. Try to find your own shortcuts for the F2L. - Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I'm using normal Fridrich method for the F2L. I know most of the algs from www.speedcubing.com. My better average is 42.19 and my best single time is 32.69. I've been cubing since around June 15th, so I'm going to 2 months of cubing. > > Pedro >
574. Re: New DIY Cube
From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 22:05:13 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc <no_reply@y...> wrote: > 3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube > had blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot > of cubes with yellow opposite white instead. My opinion: I perceive white and yellow to be the brightest colors on my cube, so I like having yellow opposite white on my cube. I feel that it (in Fridrich style solving) helps first in f2l recognition (using white) and then in OLL recognition (using yellow) since those colors stand out the most from the others. I also like the idea of having similar colors (white/yellow, blue/green, red/orange) opposite one another. I think that it helps me with PLL recognition. > One last question is about the centre caps. How do you get them to > stay on? Take a look at Stefan Pochmann's suggestion for using paper to hold the caps in place. I recently tried it with my DIY cube and I like it. Take look at messages #16940 and 17455 in this group to learn more about it. Peace, Scott P.S. My current best average is just barely sub-30, so don't take my post as expert testimony. I'm curious to hear other people's ideas on the color issue.
575. [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 22:08:38 -0000

Hi Pedro,

I've been cubing for about 11 months now. I've gotten 5 sub 20
averages so far, and I can average about 21 seconds consistently once
I'm warmed up. I was using a very basic 7 step LBL method for about 7
months probably. I didn't really practice that much, just when I was
bored in my spare time really, but eventually I could consistenly
average 30 seconds using that crappy method (best average was 27.94).
Then I started getting bored at using the same thing and I decided I
wanted to get faster, so I started learning PLL. It took me about 3
weeks to learn them all. I used just this method for about a month
and was averaging under 30 seconds with it. I went to the Horace Mann
tournament using this, and that REALLY sparked my motivation to get
faster. As soon as I got home from the tournament, I started learning
F2L. It took about two weeks to get through the algs (I had a hard
time seeing things intuitively at first), and I was very frustrated
because I was averaging about 40 seconds. It was really tough for me
to see the pairs for a while. But suddently I just started gradually
improving, and within a few days really I went from averaging 40 to
averaging 26-27. I started working on OLL then while my times
continued to drop. I learned the OLL algs in a little over a month,
and by that point my F2L was still getting better and I was averaging
about 23-24 seconds. For the past two weeks or so, I've just been
working on using all the Fridrich algs. On July 31, I got my first
ever sub 20 average. Since then I've gotten 4 more sub 20 averages
(best is 19.60), and I consistenly average around 21 seconds. I'm
very confident that with some more practice, I'll be able to average
sub 20 all the time.

Anyway, that should give you an idea of how things have gone for me.
Just keep practicing, and don't be lazy with learning algs, and
eventually you'll get to being sub 20. Good luck, and have fun.

-Jason




576. Back!!!
From: Franois Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 9 Aug 2005 00:15:24 +0200 (CEST)

Hey guys!
Yeah, after one month off internet, I'm finally back... I just attended an orchestra camp in Michigan, in case anyone cares where I was, it was fun but the orchestra sucked very, very badly, they had me play with the faculty orchestra and even that one was particularly bad. ANYWAY there were about 1200 kids there (yeah, orchestra was only one of the numerous majors there), but no need to say I was THE attraction of the camp, sadly not for my (*ahum*) amazing cello skills but for my cubing, which eventually became annoying after a while. I started to keep track on a notebook of every single time I got the stickers quote or the "is there a pattern to it" one but I lost count after a while (or got bored or both). Not talking about, I've done it once, I can do one side, oh dude that's freakin'awesome and so on. You know'em all.
So basically there was that camp store, where they started selling cubes after I went to the talent show. They had some of these keychain-like cubes, only crappier and with the worst color scheme ever. It even says Made in china on one of the dark yellow corners (yep the scheme is like, dark yellow, light yellow, light blue, purple-ish, red/orange, green and pink duh). I so should get royalties from them, they're making money out of my talent. Not fair. Not talking about how I was giving cello lessons to the kids there... anyway. Yeah, so I stayed 2 sessions there, went to the talent show the first time and did an horrible 23s 2-handed solve on stage, like, with a guy and his stopwatch next to me (the guy was huge, I was probably scared, like, a lumberjack or something). So i messed up the cross and the F2L and did 2 PLL, horrible. But I was still way faster than anyone the audience had ever seen before so it was cool. When I got back to the dorms, the counselor was like, it's the
slowest solve I've ever seen you doing, but it was still awesome, so I guess I enjoyed doing it anyway. During the second session, I guess they must've heard I had the European record for a while or something, but I got a note from the administration, they wanted me to do the cube one-handed this time. Oh well. But I'm like, you know, having a guy standing alone on stage for 40s solving a rubik's cube is pretty boring and quite long though, plus since I haven't practiced for at least 2 months one-handed and it's not my usual OH cube, it might even get up to 50s, but they say, no, the kids're gonna love it. Ok. So this time, I dressed in black, with a very tight black t-shirt inside-out (yeah the outside said "I love Detroit" or something like that, not my shirt... too tight for me, but with the distance noone could guess I have no muscle...), took my Neo sunglasses with me on stage in my pocket and put some good Matrix music, and when the music started, I put my glasses on and
started solving the cube one-handed. Everyone was screaming, that was so awesome... did quite well on this one, 36s. I was "THE" man... The music and the sunglasses worked perfectly with it.
The sad part of it, besides the comments "hey are you the cube dude" or "did you know that the cube has been invented like, 50 years ago?", was all the ppl asking me to solve their crappy piece of shit they bought off the camp store I didn't even want to even touch (unless the person asking it was a girl and very very cute). We also have a dance at the end of each session, and I guess the cubing has been part of my success here... I should upload that picture of me solving the cube above my head while I'm dancing, it's hilarious... Oh and yes, while I was playing in the faculty/staff orchestra, we had that one piece (Ravel's Bolero for those who know it, it's roughly 18 minutes of straight C-GC-GC-GC-GC-G.....etc. for the cellos), very boring, where you don't even need both hands for playing, so I just plucked my cello as a guitar and solved the cube with the other hand, when I wasn't teaching the counselor next to me how to solve it.
Last couple of factoids and then I'll pretty much be done about my random babbling about my camp experience. 1. do not take your best speedcube out with you at the pool, and 2. Coca-cola is not a good lubricant. A jackass spilled coke all over my bag and it ate the plastic of my cube away, it's horrible. It doesn't turn anymore. Never seen that before.
Oh very last thing. I hate you guys. I forgot to change my preferences before I left, so I kept receiving the emails in my regular box. Result: 942 new emails when I got back yesterday. still a bit over 300 to go. Go figure.
j/k. I love you all.
Francois
PS. But still... 942...


---------------------------------

Tlchargez le ici !

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

578. Re: New DIY Cube
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 22:27:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc <no_reply@y...> wrote: Are you on MSN Alex? It looks like I'm the only person even remotely interested in the cube around here. Most people don't have the patience it takes to take an interest unfortunately. My best average so far is 39.73, that's after about a year's effort. Someone on here suggested cutting the tabs off the centre caps and you will have to glue them on, just don't use too much glue so getting them off isn't too hard. Silicone spray isn't hard to find, I bought some from Kmart. Keith. > Hey, > > I'm in Sydney, but don't know many cubers around here :) Only some > friends from school but they aren't exactly speed cubers... My latest > average is 31.2 seconds so I'm not too shabby but then again I'm a > long way from the elite cubers! I'm hoping to find some speed in my > new cube as my old cube was always catching and scratching and being > a pain. > > As for the DIY cube, I was kind of hoping the supplied lube would be > good but I guess I'll have to go looking in a hardware shop now for > some spray-on stuff. > > One last question is about the centre caps. How do you get them to > stay on? They have these little ridges around the edges which stop > them even from sitting neatly inside the centre cubes. I guess I'll > have to glue them but I still want to be able to pop them off if I > need to adjust the screw tension, right? > > Thanks, > Alex MDC > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "keefdcuber" > <keithrx3c@h...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > Hello hello > > > > > > I just got my new DIY cube in the post. (They said 30-40 business > > > days to ship to Australia and it arrived in a week :D) > > > > > > A few questions about putting this baby together: > > > > > > 1) How tight should I adjust the centres? I've tried to make them > > > even all around with a gap of about 1mm, but not fully tight. > > > > > > 2) Should I play with the cube before I put the lube in? I mean > > > perhaps cubing a bit before will smooth the cubies a little, does > > > anyone have any recommendations on the best way to break in a new > > > cube like this? > > > > > > 3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube > > had > > > blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot of > > cubes > > > with yellow opposite white instead. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > Alex MDC > > > > G'day Alex, where are you from? I'm an aussie too. I live in NSW. > > It's up to you which way you sticker you cube but I did mine in the > > standard Rubiks configuration, eg. white opp yellow etc. I've also > > heard that the lube that they come is'nt that good so I just used > > silicone spray instead. > > > > Keith.
579. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 19:38:27 -0300 (ART)

Wow, 2 days to learn VH edge control?! There are 24 cases...you are fast! Where did you learn? I have a xls file with all the cases. the "b" are just mirror of "a", so, it's not THAAAT difficult (yes, I think I will learn that...:) >Remember, a 4-look LL with a lightning fast F2L is faster than a crappy F2L with a 2-look LL. ;) (I don't listen :\) Yeah, it's true. But I don't have a lightning fast F2L... Bob Burton <bob@...> escreveu: Hey Pedro, Hey Pedro, I am not yet sub-20, but here is an idea of my progress once I began "speedcubing" Feb. 7 - Switch from cross on top to cross on bottom, begin learning F2L instead of first layer corners -> middle edges -- 2 week break from learning -- Mid-March - (2 weeks) - Learn PLL -- 2 week break from learning -- Begin taking averages with Fridrich for first time! :) Mid-April - (6 weeks, noncontinuous) - Learn OLL -- 6 week break from learning -- Mid-July - (2 weeks) - Learn COLL Late July - (2 days) - Learn VH edge control (connected first day, non-connected second day) Just over five months after I started learning Fridrich, I got the average that currently stands as my best, 23.49 seconds. Like everybody says, it's all about the F2L. My F2L sucks (17-18 second avg?), and it's the only reason why I'm not sub-20...maybe if I practiced for more than 3 hours per week? :( Don't learn all LL algs from the same place. That's bad. There are TONS of sites with different LL algs, and some will fit you better than others. Does this help? Everybody is different, you know that. :P Remember, a 4-look LL with a lightning fast F2L is faster than a crappy F2L with a 2-look LL. ;) (I don't listen :\) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good > cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub-20 to > get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and > idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my last > layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I need > to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? > > Pedro SPONSORED LINKS Puzzle games Online puzzle games Free puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Computer puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 580. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New DIY Cube
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 22:45:02 +0000 (GMT)

I agree with Scott. For me, blue and green are more similar than blue and white. I haven't had a white opposite blue cube on my hands, but I think it is kinda strange...And I don't like the idea of having a white/yellow/orange corner or a blue/green/red one. Pedro Scott Mikos <S-Mikos@...> escreveu: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc <no_reply@y...> wrote: > 3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube > had blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot > of cubes with yellow opposite white instead. My opinion: I perceive white and yellow to be the brightest colors on my cube, so I like having yellow opposite white on my cube. I feel that it (in Fridrich style solving) helps first in f2l recognition (using white) and then in OLL recognition (using yellow) since those colors stand out the most from the others. I also like the idea of having similar colors (white/yellow, blue/green, red/orange) opposite one another. I think that it helps me with PLL recognition. > One last question is about the centre caps. How do you get them to > stay on? Take a look at Stefan Pochmann's suggestion for using paper to hold the caps in place. I recently tried it with my DIY cube and I like it. Take look at messages #16940 and 17455 in this group to learn more about it. Peace, Scott P.S. My current best average is just barely sub-30, so don't take my post as expert testimony. I'm curious to hear other people's ideas on the color issue. --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- __________________________________________________ Converse com seus amigos em tempo real com o Yahoo! Messenger http://br.download.yahoo.com/messenger/ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
581. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 8 Aug 2005 22:51:01 +0000 (GMT)

I tought I will never learn all those F2L algs, but when I saw, I had learned almost all of them. Interesting...I hope it goes the same with the OLL... Jason Baum <speedrunningcuber@...> escreveu:Hi Pedro, I've been cubing for about 11 months now. I've gotten 5 sub 20 averages so far, and I can average about 21 seconds consistently once I'm warmed up. I was using a very basic 7 step LBL method for about 7 months probably. I didn't really practice that much, just when I was bored in my spare time really, but eventually I could consistenly average 30 seconds using that crappy method (best average was 27.94). Then I started getting bored at using the same thing and I decided I wanted to get faster, so I started learning PLL. It took me about 3 weeks to learn them all. I used just this method for about a month and was averaging under 30 seconds with it. I went to the Horace Mann tournament using this, and that REALLY sparked my motivation to get faster. As soon as I got home from the tournament, I started learning F2L. It took about two weeks to get through the algs (I had a hard time seeing things intuitively at first), and I was very frustrated because I was averaging about 40 seconds. It was really tough for me to see the pairs for a while. But suddently I just started gradually improving, and within a few days really I went from averaging 40 to averaging 26-27. I started working on OLL then while my times continued to drop. I learned the OLL algs in a little over a month, and by that point my F2L was still getting better and I was averaging about 23-24 seconds. For the past two weeks or so, I've just been working on using all the Fridrich algs. On July 31, I got my first ever sub 20 average. Since then I've gotten 4 more sub 20 averages (best is 19.60), and I consistenly average around 21 seconds. I'm very confident that with some more practice, I'll be able to average sub 20 all the time. Anyway, that should give you an idea of how things have gone for me. Just keep practicing, and don't be lazy with learning algs, and eventually you'll get to being sub 20. Good luck, and have fun. -Jason SPONSORED LINKS Free puzzle games Puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Online puzzle games Computer puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. --------------------------------- --------------------------------- Yahoo! Acesso Grtis: Internet rpida e grtis. Instale o discador agora! [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
582. Re: Time required
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 22:51:53 -0000

Hi Pedro! Is tarted cubing in late 2002 with Petrus' method. Until december last year I didn't cube wery seriously even thou my average was 28,51. Then I descided to start cubing more seriously and to change method to Fridrich. I learn all F2L-algs in about 4 weeks. Then in April 3 months later I knew PLL and 8 OLL-cases and my average record was then 22,44. Kow I finally know all 57 OLL-cases and average 18,84. So it took me approximately 8 months to learn Fridrich's method, but I was familiar with the cube before. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good > cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub-20 to > get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and > idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my last > layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I need > to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? > > Pedro

589. Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 01:02:58 -0000

I also had the same problem with hitting reset at first, which is one reason why I don't practice BLD solves on the stackmat 2. After a while though you get used to the distance of the pads and just hit them near the outside, so there's no risk of hitting reset. I don't mean to belittle the problem, I had the same issue for a while myself. However with practice you don't hit the reset button anymore. I agree that this is a problem with using the stackmat 2 in competition. If there was a way to put a raised barrier of acryllic or plastic or cardboard around the button that would solve the problem for people who aren't used to it. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> > wrote: > > > > One issue I found is that for speedcubing the small display is too > > close and too soft. So when you throw down your cube, you can > > accidentally touch the small display with your cube. I now have a > pit > > in my display. :-( > > Yesterday I glued a small piece of transparent acryl on top of the > > display, to protect it. > > > > Have fun, > > > > Ron > > > > Just wait until you are flying through a solve and slam your hands > down excited to see a nice fast time on your spiffy new timer, only > to realize you have accidentally hit the RESET button with your > right thumb, never to know your time. It happens to me almost > weekly. I fear it happening in a competition. Why they would not > put the reset button on the SIDE of the timer is beyond me. > > -Dave

Non-cuber: no but I mean, what's your trick? Cuber: I use the Force... So by the end of the camp, everyone called me Darth Rubik, I heard they even made a song about me. 593. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>

594. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 9 Aug 2005 00:34:45 -0600

I'm talking to Speed Stacks right now about developing a timer
specifically for Rubik's Cube use. They might design a cover to help
prevent people from hitting the reset button or other things. However,
what happens if you hit the reset button during the championship solve?

It's happy news and you get disqualified. Yeah, so it's not happy.
Why? Starting and stopping the timer and having command of stopping
the timer is your responsibility. If you're worried, it's simple.
Take a second or two and stop the timer carefully. Of course, this is
unreasonable when solves are 20 seconds, so you assume your own risk of
stopping the timer quickly.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 9, 2005, at 12:27 AM, Gilles van den Peereboom wrote:

> what would happen if we hit during a championship solve ?
>
>
>

>
>
>

>
>
>

596. Re: Time required
From: "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 06:40:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good > cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub-20 to > get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and > idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my last > layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I need > to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? > > Pedro I started cubing in April 2004. My father taught me LBL-method. At the beginning my times were about 4 minutes with very bad cube. At the end of May I learned Dan Knight's 4-look LL in two days. In mid-June my average was around 1 minute. Then I learned PLL, and in July my averages were about 40 seconds. And then I started learning F2L. I think it was 16.8.04 when I got 38.xx avg. In September I learned OLOLL and got my average record to 22 seconds. 7.10.04 I did 21.4 sec avg, and then my improving stopped. In November-December I broke two cubes. I smashed them to floor because I was so close to average record. In mid-December I finally broke my record and got 20.54 avg. In mid-January I did my first (rolling)sub-20 averge 19.96. And now my best time is 12 seconds and avg 16.51.
597. How much?
From: "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 06:44:08 -0000

How many cubes you solve in a day? I solve maybe 50-100.

"I have a chicken in my ass, do you wanna see it?"

I'm a weirdo...








598. Re: [Speed cubing group] How much?

602. Re: Back!!!
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 07:05:55 -0000

Great story, Franois, I really enjoyed reading it! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Franois Sechet <frsechet@y...> wrote: > Hey guys! > Yeah, after one month off internet, I'm finally back... I just attended an orchestra camp in Michigan, in case anyone cares where I was, it was fun but the orchestra sucked very, very badly, they had me play with the faculty orchestra and even that one was particularly bad. ANYWAY there were about 1200 kids there (yeah, orchestra was only one of the numerous majors there), but no need to say I was THE attraction of the camp, sadly not for my (*ahum*) amazing cello skills but for my cubing, which eventually became annoying after a while. I started to keep track on a notebook of every single time I got the stickers quote or the "is there a pattern to it" one but I lost count after a while (or got bored or both). Not talking about, I've done it once, I can do one side, oh dude that's freakin'awesome and so on. You know'em all. > So basically there was that camp store, where they started selling cubes after I went to the talent show. They had some of these keychain-like cubes, only crappier and with the worst color scheme ever. It even says Made in china on one of the dark yellow corners (yep the scheme is like, dark yellow, light yellow, light blue, purple-ish, red/orange, green and pink duh). I so should get royalties from them, they're making money out of my talent. Not fair. Not talking about how I was giving cello lessons to the kids there... anyway. Yeah, so I stayed 2 sessions there, went to the talent show the first time and did an horrible 23s 2-handed solve on stage, like, with a guy and his stopwatch next to me (the guy was huge, I was probably scared, like, a lumberjack or something). So i messed up the cross and the F2L and did 2 PLL, horrible. But I was still way faster than anyone the audience had ever seen before so it was cool. When I got back to the dorms, the counselor was like, it's the > slowest solve I've ever seen you doing, but it was still awesome, so I guess I enjoyed doing it anyway. During the second session, I guess they must've heard I had the European record for a while or something, but I got a note from the administration, they wanted me to do the cube one-handed this time. Oh well. But I'm like, you know, having a guy standing alone on stage for 40s solving a rubik's cube is pretty boring and quite long though, plus since I haven't practiced for at least 2 months one-handed and it's not my usual OH cube, it might even get up to 50s, but they say, no, the kids're gonna love it. Ok. So this time, I dressed in black, with a very tight black t-shirt inside-out (yeah the outside said "I love Detroit" or something like that, not my shirt... too tight for me, but with the distance noone could guess I have no muscle...), took my Neo sunglasses with me on stage in my pocket and put some good Matrix music, and when the music started, I put my glasses on and > started solving the cube one-handed. Everyone was screaming, that was so awesome... did quite well on this one, 36s. I was "THE" man... The music and the sunglasses worked perfectly with it. > The sad part of it, besides the comments "hey are you the cube dude" or "did you know that the cube has been invented like, 50 years ago?", was all the ppl asking me to solve their crappy piece of shit they bought off the camp store I didn't even want to even touch (unless the person asking it was a girl and very very cute). We also have a dance at the end of each session, and I guess the cubing has been part of my success here... I should upload that picture of me solving the cube above my head while I'm dancing, it's hilarious... Oh and yes, while I was playing in the faculty/staff orchestra, we had that one piece (Ravel's Bolero for those who know it, it's roughly 18 minutes of straight C-GC-GC-GC-GC-G.....etc. for the cellos), very boring, where you don't even need both hands for playing, so I just plucked my cello as a guitar and solved the cube with the other hand, when I wasn't teaching the counselor next to me how to solve it. > Last couple of factoids and then I'll pretty much be done about my random babbling about my camp experience. 1. do not take your best speedcube out with you at the pool, and 2. Coca-cola is not a good lubricant. A jackass spilled coke all over my bag and it ate the plastic of my cube away, it's horrible. It doesn't turn anymore. Never seen that before. > Oh very last thing. I hate you guys. I forgot to change my preferences before I left, so I kept receiving the emails in my regular box. Result: 942 new emails when I got back yesterday. still a bit over 300 to go. Go figure. > j/k. I love you all. > Francois > PS. But still... 942... > > > --------------------------------- > Appel audio GRATUIT partout dans le monde avec le nouveau Yahoo! Messenger > Tlchargez le ici ! > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

605. Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 13:49:40 -0000

I recently found these two algorithms for the E-perm:

r' R' U' L D' L' U L R U' R' D R U
l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F

I like them both (the second more, it's gonna be my new E-perm alg)
but practicing them was so horrible. I screwed them up all the time,
more than any algs in the past, giving me a half-scrambled cube. I
could imagine it has to do with the lots of L and R turns. Has
somebody experienced something like this before? If someone
tries/practices these algs, please let me know whether you make lots
of mistakes, too :-)

Cheers!
Stefan





606. Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 14:12:08 -0000

Hey Stefan, First off: > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F wow!!! that alg is really nice! The trigger R U' L U R' is very fast, and the R U' l U R' is an easy extension of that. I've also had the same thing you have with error prone algs. One of my ZBLL algs is (U) (L' U2) [L (U) (L' U')] [R (U') L (U) R'] (L' U2) L This alg feels very nice now that I have practiced it a lot, but when I first tried it I locked up very badly _every_ time I did it. The transition between the [L (U) (L' U')] and [R (U') L (U) R'] was particularly brutal at first. Also I tend to look for algs that have the [R (U') L (U) R'] trigger in them becuase it is so fast! For that trigger I do the (U') with my left index finger and the (U) with my right index finger. I really like your E perm alg, I think it could be very fast! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I recently found these two algorithms for the E-perm: > > r' R' U' L D' L' U L R U' R' D R U > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F > > I like them both (the second more, it's gonna be my new E-perm alg) > but practicing them was so horrible. I screwed them up all the time, > more than any algs in the past, giving me a half-scrambled cube. I > could imagine it has to do with the lots of L and R turns. Has > somebody experienced something like this before? If someone > tries/practices these algs, please let me know whether you make lots > of mistakes, too :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan
607. Re: Error-prone algorithms ? (awesome E perm alg)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 14:34:11 -0000

Hey Stefan here's how I do the second alg: [(l' U' L') (U)] [R (U') l (U)] [R' (U') L (U)] [R (U') l' (U)] My notation (U) or (U') means to do that turn with the index finger of the opposite hand used for the previous turn. So [(l' U' L') (U)] the (U) means to do the (U) with the right hand since the left hand is the one used for the first part. [R (U') l (U)] : means the (U') with the left hand (opposite of the R just before it) and the (U) with the right hand opposite of the l just before it. What do you think? I think it is better to split up the R U' l U R' as I did above as I think that makes the ending flow better and a bit faster. How do you do this one? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I recently found these two algorithms for the E-perm: > > r' R' U' L D' L' U L R U' R' D R U > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F

From: "mahtianssi" <mahti-anssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 14:42:49 -0000

This isn't anything cubing related. Because many cubers are musicians,
say could you play these guitar solos =)

609. Re: Error-prone algorithms ? (awesome E perm alg)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 14:53:21 -0000

Hi Chris, I think we both do it pretty much the same way :-) I also pull the U/U' turns with the index fingers all the time, and i do tilt the cube a bit for the last two turns so it's almost like your l' U ending. Not sure I'm able to agree or disagree with splitting it up the way you did, after practicing it a while, it now feels like one long fluent motion (well, after the first three moves which still are a bit slow). I got a lot of low 11s already for doing it four times in a row, I didn't even get close to that with my previous alg. Once I would've had 10.5 or so but I screwed up stopping the stopwatch :-( Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey Stefan here's how I do the second alg: > > [(l' U' L') (U)] [R (U') l (U)] [R' (U') L (U)] [R (U') l' (U)] > > My notation (U) or (U') means to do that turn with the index finger of > the opposite hand used for the previous turn. So [(l' U' L') (U)] the > (U) means to do the (U) with the right hand since the left hand is the > one used for the first part. > > [R (U') l (U)] : means the (U') with the left hand (opposite of the R > just before it) and the (U) with the right hand opposite of the l just > before it. > > What do you think? I think it is better to split up the R U' l U R' > as I did above as I think that makes the ending flow better and a bit > faster. > > How do you do this one? > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I recently found these two algorithms for the E-perm: > > > > r' R' U' L D' L' U L R U' R' D R U > > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F
610. Re: Error-prone algorithms ? (awesome E perm alg)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 15:31:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F Just made two videos, slow and fast: http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/E_PLL_slow.wmv (394 KB) http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/foo/E_PLL_fast.wmv (257 KB) If I don't count the initial regrip, the fast version is a 2 seconds execution. Cheers! Stefan

612. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 12:57:47 -0400

I really like the second alg. I think it's faster than the one I use now. Doing it a bunch of times, I only wound up with a half solved cube the first time around. I can understand mixing the alg up though - the guts of it really only contains L (l), U and R twists and it seems it'd be very easy to mix one of these up. I think this alg will be blazing fast once committed to muscle memory... Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Aug 9, 2005, at 10:12 AM, cmhardw wrote: > Hey Stefan, > > First off: > > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F > > wow!!! that alg is really nice! 613. [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 17:36:03 -0000

Hi Bob! Maybe you practice algs to much and speed to little!? I take my time learning algs, and that way I get a lot of solves for each new alg that I learn. It also give my more F2L practice which, as you already know, is the key to great times. I won't be learning CLL before I master OLL perfectly, which means another one or two months of practice. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Actually, 32 distinct cases. ;-) But only 8 and their mirrors for each > of the two main types. It's pretty intuitive. :) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> > wrote: > > Wow, 2 days to learn VH edge control?! There are 24 cases...you are > fast! Where did you learn? I have a xls file with all the cases. the > "b" are just mirror of "a", so, it's not THAAAT difficult (yes, I > think I will learn that...:) > > >Remember, a 4-look LL with a lightning fast F2L is faster than a > > crappy F2L with a 2-look LL. ;) (I don't listen :\) > > Yeah, it's true. But I don't have a lightning fast F2L... > > > > Bob Burton <bob@c...> escreveu: > > Hey Pedro, > > > > Hey Pedro, > > > > I am not yet sub-20, but here is an idea of my progress once I began > > "speedcubing" > > > > Feb. 7 - Switch from cross on top to cross on bottom, begin learning > > F2L instead of first layer corners -> middle edges > > -- 2 week break from learning -- > > Mid-March - (2 weeks) - Learn PLL > > -- 2 week break from learning -- > > Begin taking averages with Fridrich for first time! :) > > Mid-April - (6 weeks, noncontinuous) - Learn OLL > > -- 6 week break from learning -- > > Mid-July - (2 weeks) - Learn COLL > > Late July - (2 days) - Learn VH edge control (connected first day, > > non-connected second day) > > > > Just over five months after I started learning Fridrich, I got the > > average that currently stands as my best, 23.49 seconds. Like > > everybody says, it's all about the F2L. My F2L sucks (17-18 second > > avg?), and it's the only reason why I'm not sub-20...maybe if I > > practiced for more than 3 hours per week? :( > > > > Don't learn all LL algs from the same place. That's bad. There are > > TONS of sites with different LL algs, and some will fit you better > > than others. > > > > Does this help? Everybody is different, you know that. :P > > > > Remember, a 4-look LL with a lightning fast F2L is faster than a > > crappy F2L with a 2-look LL. ;) (I don't listen :\) > > > > ~ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" > > <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > > Sometimes I think to myself: "man, I will never get to sub-20, it > > > seems imposible." But I think it's posible with dedication and a good > > > cube. I'd like to know how much time took to you that are sub- 20 to > > > get there. I know it is different to each person, but I can have and > > > idea (or maybe do an average...:)). And other important thing: my > last > > > layer. I currently use a 4-look LL. I know it's veeeeeery slow. I > need > > > to improve. How long it takes to memorize OLL an PLL? > > > > > > Pedro > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > Puzzle games Online puzzle games Free puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle > game Computer puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games > > > > --------------------------------- > > YAHOO! 615. [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 18:23:45 -0000

I got a second generation stackmat for christmas and use it regularly.
I have never hit the reset button accidentally. Sure, I'm not sub 20
but I don't take my time stopping the timer either, I hit it as fast
as I can.


I mean come on, you can do 50 something moves in less than 20 seconds
but can't hit the timer pads with your hands? Maybe it's something to
practice since it is a major part of competing.


good luck




616. Re: WC2005 regulations about cubes
From: "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 18:28:15 -0000

> # THE ONLY CUBES ALLOWED FOR COMPETITION ROUNDS MUST BE AUTHENTIC
> RUBIK'S BRAND CUBES. COUNTERFEIT CUBES OR ALTERNATIVE CUBES WILL
NOT
> BE ACCEPTED.

My question is, how do they determine this? The latest DIY kits
with PVC stickers do not include the Rubik logo on the central white
sticker. Granted one of the center caps has an embossed logo but
you can't really see it once the stickers are applied.

The latest cubes all seem to have some kind of lot number printed
inside one of the corners (visible at a 45 degree twist). For
example, mine says M0105B (presumably manufactured January 2005?)
But their older cubes did not have this feature.

Would they allow a classic 80's Ideal cube?

Do they disassemble your cube to verify its authenticity somehow?
To me there would be no way to really tell some of the clones apart
from the real thing.

One other thought-- are the Rubik's brand white plastic cubes
allowed?

I plan to use a DIY cube, so no worries. I was just curious about
that rule as well.

619. [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 19:37:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "skeneegee" <skeneegee@h...> wrote: > > I mean come on, you can do 50 something moves in less than 20 seconds > but can't hit the timer pads with your hands? Maybe it's something to > practice since it is a major part of competing. > Hey, mistakes happen. I did not state I do it every solve, so obviously I am capable of hitting the timer pad with my hands. It is just like I can turn the cube at 8 moves a second at times, but sometimes I lock it up. In fact I am sure you can find more than one of the top cubers in the world that has accidentally dropped his or her cube once while solving. Mistakes happen. Add high pressure to the situation and one may be more likely to be inaccurate as well. And all I said was I was worried, not that I should not be disqualified. Also, I am also not a sub 20 cuber, so I do have more to learn in all areas. Thanks for your input. -Dave
620. [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: "Leyan Lo" <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 19:40:43 -0000

It is still a design flaw and we have a right to complain. And yes,
it is probably not hard to get used to.

I don't understand why Speed Stacks made the changes they did to their
timer. The new generation 2 mats seem more like a personal timer
rather than a competition timer. For competitions using the new
timer, the judge would need to be on top of the competitor, rather
than on the side. Competitors shouldn't have access to those controls.

I'm glad that we are using the original timer for the Caltech
competitions.

Leyan





621. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 9 Aug 2005 13:47:07 -0600

As I said, I'm talking to SpeedStacks and exploring various
possibilities.

In Dallas, we intend to suspend the judges from cables attached to the
ceiling for competitors who are using the Generation 2 StackMat.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

624. [Speed cubing group] Re: Time required
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 20:40:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > Hi Bob! > > Maybe you practice algs to much and speed to little!? I take my time > learning algs, and that way I get a lot of solves for each new alg > that I learn. It also give my more F2L practice which, as you > already know, is the key to great times. I won't be learning CLL > before I master OLL perfectly, which means another one or two months > of practice. I don't really practice algs that much, pretty much only when I'm walking on my way to class or something like that when I should be watching where I'm going. ;) Since there is nothing that I feel is critical for me to learn, I decided that it will be pure F2L practice from now until I am sub-20, and then I will consider tackling something new. ~ Bob PS ~ I saw a video of you doing the 2-cube. Very nice. :)

COUNTERFEIT CUBES OR ALTERNATIVE CUBES WILL > NOT > > BE ACCEPTED. > > My question is, how do they determine this? The latest DIY kits > with PVC stickers do not include the Rubik logo on the central white > sticker. Any other stickers were fine and could be as rotton as you wanted, so long as you still had that logo on the center of the white face. :) ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > actually this thought also went through my head. i remember that at > the last wc (although i didnt go), people had to switch their > stickers. would we have to do that this time as well? or would the > cubesmith stickers or our own stickers be okay for it? and what about > tiles? > > On 8/9/05, christopher_pelley <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > > # THE ONLY CUBES ALLOWED FOR COMPETITION ROUNDS MUST BE AUTHENTIC > > > RUBIK'S BRAND CUBES. 632. [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 21:16:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > wait, isnt someone supposed to be right next to you timing you with a > stopwatch?? Uh, don't say that loud when Tyson is around :-) Stefan
633. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 14:20:00 -0700

In the past, stopwatches were a safety precaution, and the times recorded were only to be used in the event of a solve that takes longer than 10min (longer than what the stackmat can record). Now that we have time limits for each phase, (I think we do... right?), the stopwatches are no longer used to follow the solve. Their only purpose now is for the 15s preinspection phase. Leyan Sapan Upadhyay wrote: > wait, isnt someone supposed to be right next to you timing you with a > stopwatch?? > > > On 8/9/05, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...> wrote: > >>i like the idea of them being suspended from the air :) >> >>On 8/9/05, Leyan Lo <leyanlo@...> wrote: >> >>>It is still a design flaw and we have a right to complain. And yes, >>>it is probably not hard to get used to. >>> >>>I don't understand why Speed Stacks made the changes they did to their >>>timer. The new generation 2 mats seem more like a personal timer >>>rather than a competition timer. For competitions using the new >>>timer, the judge would need to be on top of the competitor, rather >>>than on the side. Competitors shouldn't have access to those controls. >>> >>>I'm glad that we are using the original timer for the Caltech >>>competitions. >>> >>>Leyan >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>>Yahoo! Groups Links >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >> >> >>-- >>-cubekid >> > > >

636. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Back!!!
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 9 Aug 2005 16:25:02 -0500

lol.. sounds a lot like my camp experience... which i will share with the world, because im bored and its kinda funny basically it was me and two other guys who signed up to solve the cube for our talent show. i showed up at the audition place and solved it in 19 seconds (which btw was my 3rd sub-20 time i had ever got.) at the actual talent show, one of my friends was in charge of creating music (he has this thing called the electribe, which basically is a beat synthesizer... its a beast), and he created some music to start us off. the MCs for the talent show then went on stage and threw out three cubes into the audience for them to mix up. then the mc comes back with my friends' cubes and they go up and both solve half of it and in the middle switch cubes and solve each other's cube (it took a little long for them though, because they'er not speedcubers and they were supposed to communicate to each other in some way when they were done, but something got lost in translation, so they spent about 30 extra seconds just messing around because they didnt know that the other was already done). all in all it took them like 2 minutes or so, which is still faster than anyone had camp (except those who knew me) had ever seen. in the meantime, the MC that had my cube came back with it all broken, because some kid accidently popped a couple of pieces. so i had to frantically put it back together and solve it really quickly to makd sure that i had put it in the right way. then i had to get someone in the back to scramble it for me (so they would be sure that i hadn't rigged it or anything). then i came onstage with my hoodie and polarized sunglasses and solved it in about 25 seconds (messed up on the cross and f2l and had a near pop). it was really cool because all of my friends had incited the crowd to chant my name.. though i actually didnt hear it because i was so nervous. man, its fun though :) On 8/9/05, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Great story, Franois, I really enjoyed reading it! :) > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Franois Sechet > <frsechet@y...> wrote: > > Hey guys! > > Yeah, after one month off internet, I'm finally back... I just > attended an orchestra camp in Michigan, in case anyone cares where I > was, it was fun but the orchestra sucked very, very badly, they had me > play with the faculty orchestra and even that one was particularly > bad. ANYWAY there were about 1200 kids there (yeah, orchestra was only > one of the numerous majors there), but no need to say I was THE > attraction of the camp, sadly not for my (*ahum*) amazing cello skills > but for my cubing, which eventually became annoying after a while. I > started to keep track on a notebook of every single time I got the > stickers quote or the "is there a pattern to it" one but I lost count > after a while (or got bored or both). Not talking about, I've done it > once, I can do one side, oh dude that's freakin'awesome and so on. You > know'em all. > > So basically there was that camp store, where they started selling > cubes after I went to the talent show. They had some of these > keychain-like cubes, only crappier and with the worst color scheme > ever. It even says Made in china on one of the dark yellow corners > (yep the scheme is like, dark yellow, light yellow, light blue, > purple-ish, red/orange, green and pink duh). I so should get royalties > from them, they're making money out of my talent. Not fair. Not > talking about how I was giving cello lessons to the kids there... > anyway. Yeah, so I stayed 2 sessions there, went to the talent show > the first time and did an horrible 23s 2-handed solve on stage, like, > with a guy and his stopwatch next to me (the guy was huge, I was > probably scared, like, a lumberjack or something). So i messed up the > cross and the F2L and did 2 PLL, horrible. But I was still way faster > than anyone the audience had ever seen before so it was cool. When I > got back to the dorms, the counselor was like, it's the > > slowest solve I've ever seen you doing, but it was still awesome, > so I guess I enjoyed doing it anyway. During the second session, I > guess they must've heard I had the European record for a while or > something, but I got a note from the administration, they wanted me to > do the cube one-handed this time. Oh well. But I'm like, you know, > having a guy standing alone on stage for 40s solving a rubik's cube is > pretty boring and quite long though, plus since I haven't practiced > for at least 2 months one-handed and it's not my usual OH cube, it > might even get up to 50s, but they say, no, the kids're gonna love it. > Ok. So this time, I dressed in black, with a very tight black t-shirt > inside-out (yeah the outside said "I love Detroit" or something like > that, not my shirt... too tight for me, but with the distance noone > could guess I have no muscle...), took my Neo sunglasses with me on > stage in my pocket and put some good Matrix music, and when the music > started, I put my glasses on and > > started solving the cube one-handed. Everyone was screaming, that > was so awesome... did quite well on this one, 36s. I was "THE" man... > The music and the sunglasses worked perfectly with it. > > The sad part of it, besides the comments "hey are you the cube dude" > or "did you know that the cube has been invented like, 50 years ago?", > was all the ppl asking me to solve their crappy piece of shit they > bought off the camp store I didn't even want to even touch (unless the > person asking it was a girl and very very cute). We also have a dance > at the end of each session, and I guess the cubing has been part of my > success here... I should upload that picture of me solving the cube > above my head while I'm dancing, it's hilarious... Oh and yes, while I > was playing in the faculty/staff orchestra, we had that one piece > (Ravel's Bolero for those who know it, it's roughly 18 minutes of > straight C-GC-GC-GC-GC-G.....etc. for the cellos), very boring, where > you don't even need both hands for playing, so I just plucked my cello > as a guitar and solved the cube with the other hand, when I wasn't > teaching the counselor next to me how to solve it. > > Last couple of factoids and then I'll pretty much be done about my > random babbling about my camp experience. 1. do not take your best > speedcube out with you at the pool, and 2. Coca-cola is not a good > lubricant. A jackass spilled coke all over my bag and it ate the > plastic of my cube away, it's horrible. It doesn't turn anymore. Never > seen that before. > > Oh very last thing. I hate you guys. I forgot to change my > preferences before I left, so I kept receiving the emails in my > regular box. Result: 942 new emails when I got back yesterday. still a > bit over 300 to go. Go figure. > > j/k. I love you all. > > Francois > > PS. But still... 942... > > > > > > --------------------------------- > > Appel audio GRATUIT partout dans le monde avec le nouveau Yahoo! > Messenger > > Tlchargez le ici ! > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > -- -cubekid
637. Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 21:34:26 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F Mmh, we could of course also mirror F<->B to get this: l U L U' R' U l' U' R U L' U' R' U l U' I thought about this because I don't really like to regrip at the start. Btw, just in case somebody is curious, here's how I found the alg: 1. ACube searching in <U,L,R,F> spits out (among lots of others): U F' R U R' U' L' U R U' R' F R' F' L F R U' 2. I remove U/U' at start/end and rewrite like this: (F' R U R' U') (L' U) (R U') (l' U R' U') (L U l) 3. Because I don't like to start with F', I invert it: l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F I like the F<->B mirror as well and will practice it a bit, but I guess I'll stick to the "original". Stefan
638. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 9 Aug 2005 16:38:11 -0500

639. Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 21:40:35 -0000

x' (R U') (R' D) (R U R') u2' (R' U) (R D) (R' U' R) I updated my video because apparently I am .5 seconds faster than the last time I made a video for this case. This one is 2.167 seconds: http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll03fast.avi If that u2 wasn't so slow, the whole thing would flow a lot nicer. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F > > Mmh, we could of course also mirror F<->B to get this: > l U L U' R' U l' U' R U L' U' R' U l U' > > I thought about this because I don't really like to regrip at the > start. Btw, just in case somebody is curious, here's how I found the > alg: > > 1. ACube searching in <U,L,R,F> spits out (among lots of others): > U F' R U R' U' L' U R U' R' F R' F' L F R U' > > 2. I remove U/U' at start/end and rewrite like this: > (F' R U R' U') (L' U) (R U') (l' U R' U') (L U l) > > 3. Because I don't like to start with F', I invert it: > l' U' L' U R U' l U R' U' L U R U' R' F > > I like the F<->B mirror as well and will practice it a bit, but I > guess I'll stick to the "original". > > Stefan
640. Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 22:49:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > x' (R U') (R' D) (R U R') u2' (R' U) (R D) (R' U' R) > > I updated my video because apparently I am .5 seconds faster than the > last time I made a video for this case. This one is 2.167 seconds: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/pll/pll03fast.avi > > If that u2 wasn't so slow, the whole thing would flow a lot nicer. > > ~ Bob Hey Bob I actually really like that algorithm. I used to use one that was similar, but yours changes at the u2' (I believe I got it off of Jesse Bond's site). But I really like the flow of yours, so I switched to that one a few weeks ago. I struggled with the u2' as well at first, but now I use my index finger, as I am brining that last R' up, I place I on the right yellow edge and push down, then the rest just flies. Thanks for that, by the way. Now if only I could find a better alg for your PLL case 4. I will have to try yours out, but I am not a fan of slice moves most of the time. -Dave

643. Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Tue, 09 Aug 2005 23:35:55 -0000

> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog > <no_reply@y...> wrote: I struggled with the u2' as > > well at first, but now I use my index finger, as I am brining that > > last R' up, I place I on the right yellow edge and push down, then > > the rest just flies. That was supposed to read, "as I am bringing the last R' up, I place my right index finger on the yellow edge and push down". > I suppose you wouldn't like the (also fast) algorithm: > > M2'UM'U2M2'U2M'U'M2' ? :P If I could do those slice moves as fast as you, I would probably enjoy that as well. I have no idea how you do that, though. I must admit, I have been using your first one [ x' F (R U') (R' Ua) (R' e) (R' U) (R D2) ] and it is not as bad as I thought it was going to be. After a couple of minutes I have hit a few low 3 second attempts, so with some practice to where I don't have to think about it, I should be able do it around 2 seconds, which is good for me. I am going to have to root through the rest of your algs to look for replacements for a couple other sluggish ones I use. -Dave

646. Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 06:05:15 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y...> wrote: > If I could do those slice moves as fast as you, I would probably enjoy > that as well. I have no idea how you do that, though. I must admit, I > have been using your first one [ x' F (R U') (R' Ua) (R' e) (R' U) (R > D2) ] and it is not as bad as I thought it was going to be. After a > couple of minutes I have hit a few low 3 second attempts, so with some > practice to where I don't have to think about it, I should be able do > it around 2 seconds, which is good for me. I am going to have to root > through the rest of your algs to look for replacements for a couple > other sluggish ones I use. M' is very simple, but people don't like it. Hold the cube with the thumbs on the (front of the) L and R layers and the other fingers on the back face of the same layers. Use the left ring finger and push the middle slice to make it M'. For M2', follow it with the middle finger. :) ~ Bob

649. [Speed cubing group] Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 10:06:33 -0000

Hi Darereck, right now I do pretty much the F<->B mirror (I think, haven't checked ;-) R' U R U' R' F' U' F R U R' F R' F' R U' R It's slightly awkward but at least I never regrip with the left hand and that's a strong plus for me. Well, I do tilt the cube with the left hand a bit near the end. Haven't practiced it much yet, though, I'm usually around 12 seconds. Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darereck@g. ..> wrote: > Hey Stefan I like this algorithm: > > R U' R' U l U F U' R' F' R U' R U R' F R' > > But I'm wondering how do you perform the mirror of the case? 650. [Speed cubing group] Re: Least favourite PLL case
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 10:18:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "darereck" <darereck@g...> wrote: > Hey Stefan I like this algorithm: > > R U' R' U l U F U' R' F' R U' R U R' F R' > > But I'm wondering how do you perform the mirror of the case? Is it > just the mirror of: R U' R' U l U F U' R' F' R U' R U R' F R' or > something else? > > Thanks > Darereck Hey Darereck, I use z U'(RD') (R2'UR'D) U'(RD')(R2'UR'D) [R] Here is how I do it: Pull the first U' with the left index finger When starting the R, hold your right index finger on the BRU corner, so you can make the D' afterwards. I make the (R2'UR'D) move while holding one corner with my right index and middlefinger, which is the FRD piece. It goes all around the R face, finaly ending at BRD. Hope it helps, Jol.

653. Draft WCA regulations
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 16:38:07 -0000

Hi friends,

Tyson and I created a draft version of the WCA regulations, version
2005.
You can find the draft version at:
http://www.speedcubing.com/events/regulations_draft2005.html

Our goals for this version were to not change the basic rules and
procedures, but improve the text and remove unclear things.
On the bottom of the page you can find a list of changes.

You are all very welcome to send in your comments, additions and
other suggestions. For your feedback please use the WCA forum at
http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/forum
If you want to see text or regulations changed, then please post a
new text proposal.

We want to finalize this version on September 5, 2 months before WC
2005. So don't wait too long with your feedback.

We are looking forward to a positive discussion. We expect that
there won't be a consensus on all issues. In that case the WCA board
will need to make a decision. For the 2006 version we are open to
discuss some bigger changes.

Thanks and have fun,

Ron

alberto.

656. [Speed cubing group] Re: StackMat Generation 2

657. Re: Rubik's Game - tiled cube
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 18:26:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@o...> wrote: > Any one have one of these, and know how I can make it looser (ie: how to get to the springs, > or if it uses rivets like the modern cubes) Hi Bryan, They have adjusting screws. You need to remove the tiles to get at the screws. I use a *very* sharp 5/8 inch wood chisel and so I wear work gloves. I push the edge of the chisel under the tile as far as it can go, which really isn't very far, but is important, then I begin gently rocking the tile back and forth. I sometimes find I need to be patient, and gradually the glue lets go. You need to determine which is the correct side to try to lever up so that you aren't working against the structure of the tile and the trough it sits in. There is a trough underneath every tile which has two slanted indentations and two straight edges. The underside of the tile has two straight edges and two slanted edges, and fit neatly into the indentations. These edges are shallow. The straight edges lay flat against the trough in the cube and if you try to lever that way you would bend or break the plastic of the tile. The slanted edges move like a rocker with no resistance. Also the slanted edges are where the glue is and they are the right edges to try to pry up. You may see slight indentations on the top of the tile, at the edge. Underneath the indentation is the slanted edge. Those are the edges you need to pry. I hope this helps. David J
658. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Rubik's Game - tiled cube
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 14:40:10 -0400

Yes this helps a lot. These screws are very sensitive too! Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Aug 10, 2005, at 2:26 PM, d_j_salvia wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bryanosaurus" > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > Any one have one of these, and know how I can make it looser (ie: > how to get to the springs, > > or if it uses rivets like the modern cubes) > > Hi Bryan, > > They have adjusting screws. You need to remove the tiles to get at the > screws. > > I use a *very* sharp 5/8 inch wood chisel and so I wear work gloves. I > push the edge of the chisel under the tile as far as it can go, which > really isn't very far, but is important, then I begin gently rocking > the tile back and forth. I sometimes find I need to be patient, and > gradually the glue lets go. > > You need to determine which is the correct side to try to lever up so > that you aren't working against the structure of the tile and the > trough it sits in. There is a trough underneath every tile which has > two slanted indentations and two straight edges. > > The underside of the tile has two straight edges and two slanted > edges, and fit neatly into the indentations. These edges are shallow. > The straight edges lay flat against the trough in the cube and if you > try to lever that way you would bend or break the plastic of the tile. > The slanted edges move like a rocker with no resistance. Also the > slanted edges are where the glue is and they are the right edges to > try to pry up. > > You may see slight indentations on the top of the tile, at the edge. > Underneath the indentation is the slanted edge. Those are the edges > you need to pry. > > I hope this helps. > > David J > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
659. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: WC2005 regulations about cubes
From: Crispy <redivre@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 12:13:12 -0700 (PDT)

What about the new 25th anniversary cubes that come with silver instead of white? The center has the logo -would you have to change them out or can you leave the silver --- Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: > To be technical, the only sticker that needed to be > swapped was the > white sticker with the Rubik's logo. Any other > stickers were fine and > could be as rotton as you wanted, so long as you > still had that logo > on the center of the white face. :) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan > Upadhyay > <cubekid@g...> wrote: > > actually this thought also went through my head. i > remember that at > > the last wc (although i didnt go), people had to > switch their > > stickers. would we have to do that this time as > well? or would the > > cubesmith stickers or our own stickers be okay for > it? and what about > > tiles? > > > > On 8/9/05, christopher_pelley > <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > > > # THE ONLY CUBES ALLOWED FOR COMPETITION > ROUNDS MUST BE AUTHENTIC > > > > RUBIK'S BRAND CUBES. COUNTERFEIT CUBES OR > ALTERNATIVE CUBES WILL > > > NOT > > > > BE ACCEPTED. > > > > > > My question is, how do they determine this? The > latest DIY kits > > > with PVC stickers do not include the Rubik logo > on the central white > > > sticker. Granted one of the center caps has an > embossed logo but > > > you can't really see it once the stickers are > applied. > > > > > > The latest cubes all seem to have some kind of > lot number printed > > > inside one of the corners (visible at a 45 > degree twist). For > > > example, mine says M0105B (presumably > manufactured January 2005?) > > > But their older cubes did not have this feature. > > > > > > Would they allow a classic 80's Ideal cube? > > > > > > Do they disassemble your cube to verify its > authenticity somehow? > > > To me there would be no way to really tell some > of the clones apart > > > from the real thing. > > > > > > One other thought-- are the Rubik's brand white > plastic cubes > > > allowed? > > > > > > I plan to use a DIY cube, so no worries. 662. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 18:09:22 -0500

I do M' as r R'. Even so, it's still 'lightning fast.' -Mike Bennett >From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ? >Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 06:05:15 -0000 > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog ><no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > If I could do those slice moves as fast as you, I would probably enjoy > > that as well. I have no idea how you do that, though. I must admit, I > > have been using your first one [ x' F (R U') (R' Ua) (R' e) (R' U) (R > > D2) ] and it is not as bad as I thought it was going to be. After a > > couple of minutes I have hit a few low 3 second attempts, so with some > > practice to where I don't have to think about it, I should be able do > > it around 2 seconds, which is good for me. I am going to have to root > > through the rest of your algs to look for replacements for a couple > > other sluggish ones I use. > >M' is very simple, but people don't like it. Hold the cube with the >thumbs on the (front of the) L and R layers and the other fingers on >the back face of the same layers. Use the left ring finger and push >the middle slice to make it M'. For M2', follow it with the middle >finger. :) > >~ Bob > >
663. [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 23:22:23 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > I do M' as r R'. Even so, it's still 'lightning fast.' I only do that when it helps the flow of the algorithm better, like if the R' leads into the next move better than the M'. ~ Bob
664. Second language cubing
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 18:25:15 -0500

Seeing as I'm currently hanging out in Hrz Grenzhausen, Germany, and the
friend I'm staying with thinks cubing is about the coolest thing in the
world (she's obviously very smart), I taught her to solve the cube a few
days ago. She could already solve a layer when I started.

The problem I ran into, even though her English is very very good, is that
some of the necessary concepts are slightly difficult to explain using my
entirely rudimentary German (what with only having learned it the past week,
and all).

I'm curious if anyone has ever tried to teach someone else who speaks a
different language, or very little in the common language you share. Did
you run into problems like this? I think the bits that gave the most
particular trouble involved explaining where to position pieces to set up
moves. Evenually, we resorted to a set of pictures drawn on the back of a
chocolate bar wrapper.

It was very good chocolate, by the way. =)

Spreading the cube across two continents and several countries...

Tsch,
Mike Bennett

P.S. Having the 'y' and 'z' switched is killing me. Zou guzs are crayz. ;P




665. Re: [Speed cubing group] Second language cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 17:38:52 -0600

Yeah, I had a few issues but I was able to work it out. I was in
Taiwan last year and most people my age in Taipei do not speak
Taiwanese so I had to use Mandarin. Unfortunately, my Mandarin is very
weak. I feel ashamed because I've forgotten how to say 'clockwise' and
'counter-clockwise'.

I was able to get through it though. After I explained notation, it
was relatively easy.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

666. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 18:48:53 -0500

I perform all of my M, M', and M2 moves that way, because they are always followed by U, U', or U2. It's super fast, and I don't need to shift my hands at all in order to begin the next move. I began doing it this way when I started practicing with the Roux method, and it works wonders. The 3 cycle PLL clockwise takes me under 1.5, the anti-clockwise one takes 1.5, and the cross PLL takes me about 1.3. I found an algorithm only using U, U2, M', and M2 riding in a car on the way to the Netherlands the other day but I haven't practiced it enough to be very fast, yet. I currently use the case from Dan Knights' site, but I suspect with practice the newer one will be faster than my already sub-2 alg. M2' U M2' U M' U2 M2' U2 M' U2. (insert several minutes here) I've just discovered that speedcubing.com has a similar algorithm, which is a move shorter, and I think, after playing with it, I'll wind up with this: M2' U M' U2' M2' U2' M' U' M2' I do all of the U2 turns as a click with my left index finger followed by the left middle finger. It will be fast, methinks. =) Thoughts? -Mike Bennett >From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ? >Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 23:22:23 -0000 > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" ><mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > I do M' as r R'. Even so, it's still 'lightning fast.' > >I only do that when it helps the flow of the algorithm better, like if >the R' leads into the next move better than the M'. > >~ Bob > >

But I can do it pretty fast. :D My current alg is just over 2 seconds.
