675. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 00:47:49 -0400

Back when I was still using a 4-look last layer, I only had to know 3 PLLs (well you only actually have to know 1, but knowing 3 helps) and up until now I was still using the same one. It was by far my slowest case but I don't tend to see it that often. It was from Fridrich's site : Ls Ds2 Ls D Ls2 U' Bs2 (Ds2 is horrible...) I was actually thinking the other day that I should try and find a new one. The PLL which handles opposite edges can be sub-2 easily, and this one is rather similar, so I definitely think it can be as well. By the way, I think me and you have a similar cubing style, especially for LL - for PLL I used to collect algs from various websites but found that nearly all the ones on your site are best for my hands. (except I really don't like your U perm [cycle 3 edges], I can do 1.2s with mine) Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Aug 10, 2005, at 8:30 PM, Bob Burton wrote: > I just came across it the other day. Have you tried other algs for > that case and decided this is the fastest? It seems very fast. 679. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube names
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>

But he actually has an explanation for it. Kinda > explains how noncubers think ;-) > > http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=5991261200 > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
680. [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 11:56:07 -0000

I assume he means the LL alg which just permutes 3 edges. If the 4th step of the 4-look LL is to permute the edges then this is the only alg that you need to know if going for absolute minimum memorisation. Depending on the LL case though the alg may need to be repeated multiple times which is why people should just learn the other basic LL edge permutation algs! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. > .> wrote: > > Back when I was still using a 4-look last layer, I only had to know > 3 > > PLLs (well you only actually have to know 1, but knowing 3 helps) > > Can you tell which 1 would be enough? > > Cheers! > Stefan
681. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 08:00:11 -0400

The maximum would be for it to be repeated twice (not distinguishing between it and it's inverse) Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... 683. [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?

If you allow mirrors, you could get away with either the R or J perm to solve both corners and edges. All right, I'm not being very practical. :D Mike

686. [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 20:43:26 -0000

Ah, ok... the way you had said it made me think you were saying one PLL (algorithm) would be enough to solve all PLL (cases), i.e. not just edge-PLL but also corners. And I tried a few and didn't succeed. Is there an easy proof that one PLL alg, applied repeatedly to the last layer and with U adjustments allowed, is not enough to solve all PLL cases? Oh, and... is that actually true? Cheers! Stefan --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > The maximum would be for it to be repeated twice (not distinguishing > between it and it's inverse) > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Aug 11, 2005, at 7:56 AM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > I assume he means the LL alg which just permutes 3 edges. 687. [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 20:46:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. > .> wrote: > > Back when I was still using a 4-look last layer, I only had to know > 3 > > PLLs (well you only actually have to know 1, but knowing 3 helps) > > Can you tell which 1 would be enough? You can actually get away with knowing zero PLL algs if you wanted. You can use OLL algs to cycle edges by doing an OLL that doesn't disturb corner permutation and then fixing it with another OLL that restores the OLL but is not the exact inverse of the original OLL. Example: Sune - U - Sune Mirrored U' cycles three edges. The corners can of course be permuted without any algs using simple intuition. :) ~ Bob
688. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 16:47:32 -0400

Yeah what I was saying was for a 4-look LL, where you fix the corners and only have to permute edges. As far as one PLL for all cases, that's curious.... If it IS possible, we could limit it to only PLLs that move edges and corners. I'm going to play around with it. Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... 690. Re: Second language cubing
From: "Alan C." <cub3r_alan@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 12 Aug 2005 03:22:58 -0000

I tried teaching my cousin in Taiwan this year. My Mandarin was really bad and my cousin couldn't speak English at all. After trying unsuccessfully to explain the notation to him, I gave up and drew all the turns for the algs on a piece of paper. On the steps that didn't require algs, I was like "turn this way, then this way, then this way, then this way..." while turing the cube to let him see (and he was teasing me because of that). I was able to teach him how to solve it that way. Alan Chang --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Seeing as I'm currently hanging out in Hrz Grenzhausen, Germany, and the > friend I'm staying with thinks cubing is about the coolest thing in the > world (she's obviously very smart), I taught her to solve the cube a few > days ago. She could already solve a layer when I started. > > The problem I ran into, even though her English is very very good, is that > some of the necessary concepts are slightly difficult to explain using my > entirely rudimentary German (what with only having learned it the past week, > and all). > > I'm curious if anyone has ever tried to teach someone else who speaks a > different language, or very little in the common language you share. Did > you run into problems like this? I think the bits that gave the most > particular trouble involved explaining where to position pieces to set up > moves. Evenually, we resorted to a set of pictures drawn on the back of a > chocolate bar wrapper. > > It was very good chocolate, by the way. =) > > Spreading the cube across two continents and several countries... > > Tsch, > Mike Bennett > > P.S. Having the 'y' and 'z' switched is killing me. Zou guzs are crayz. ;P
691. Wow
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 12 Aug 2005 07:49:16 -0000


It seems that sub-14 averages are becoming pretty common these days.
I remember 3 years ago when I began speed-cubing, Dan Gosbee was the
best cuber with an incredible 16.89 that looked impossible to beat.
Things have changed a lot!

Gilles.

As I mentioned before, J or R will do, provided you supplement it with its mirror. Still believe that is correct, but haven't checked how many/few applications you would need in the worst case. Mike

His quote was: "I know I can go > faster." > > I was right about that!! :-) > > /Gunnar > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jol van Noort > <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > > How about this: > > > > > http://web.archive.org/web/20030220180356/http://www.speedcubing.com/ > > chris/recs_cube_333.html > > > > You would have been 12th! > > > > Or this one: > > > > > http://web.archive.org/web/20030220180356/http://www.speedcubing.com/ > > chris/recs_cube_333av.html > > > > I would have been faster then the great master/legend DanG! > > > > - Jol. > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" > > <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > > I have an old print-out of the ranking in May 23, 2003. Now it's > 150. > > My > > > 15,08 would have given my the 15th place. > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "mahtianssi" > > > <mahtianssi@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > > > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > > It seems that sub-14 averages are becoming pretty common > these > > > days. > > > > > I remember 3 years ago when I began speed-cubing, Dan Gosbee > > was > > > the > > > > > best cuber with an incredible 16.89 that looked impossible > to > > beat. > > > > > Things have changed a lot! > > > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > For non-cubers even sub-1 minute avg is incredible ?=)
704. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Error-prone algorithms ?
From: Ravi Fernando <rubik12346@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 12 Aug 2005 15:21:10 -0700 (PDT)

About Stefan's question: If you allow mirror algs, several different PLL algs can be used. However, if mirrors are not allowed, then one may reason as follows: First, the alg must obviously permute both edges and corners. Otherwise, cases that permute both would be impossible to solve. Second, if the alg only switches a pair of edges and a pair of corners, neither the edges nor the corners can be opposite because this would make 3-cycles of that type of piece impossible to solve. This leaves the L, R, and G PLLs. L can be ruled out because each edge and corner next to it are permuted together and cannot be separated. R can similarly be ruled out by thinking of the separate pairs that are permuted "together" (ex. UFL/UR and UFR/UB). G, on the other hand, might work. I tried it several times and repeatedly made edge and corner 3-cycles (which would be enough to solve PLL), but I can't be sure because I often (accidentally) did the mirror of the alg. Later, Ravi (www.geocities.com/rubik12346/) --- Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...> wrote: > Ah, ok... the way you had said it made me think you > were saying one > PLL (algorithm) would be enough to solve all PLL > (cases), i.e. not > just edge-PLL but also corners. And I tried a few > and didn't succeed. > Is there an easy proof that one PLL alg, applied > repeatedly to the > last layer and with U adjustments allowed, is not > enough to solve all > PLL cases? Oh, and... is that actually true? > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan > Mytko <bmytko@o.. > .> wrote: > > The maximum would be for it to be repeated twice > (not distinguishing > > > between it and it's inverse) > > > > > > Bryan Mytko > > bryanosaurus@b... > > > > > > On Aug 11, 2005, at 7:56 AM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > > > I assume he means the LL alg which just permutes > 3 edges. If the > 4th > > > step of the 4-look LL is to permute the edges > then this is the > only > > > alg that you need to know if going for absolute > minimum > memorisation. > > > Depending on the LL case though the alg may need > to be repeated > > > multiple times which is why people should just > learn the other > basic > > > LL edge permutation algs! :) > > > > > > Jasmine > > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > "Stefan Pochmann" > > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > Bryan Mytko > > > <bmytko@o.. > > > > .> wrote: > > > > > Back when I was still using a 4-look last > layer, I only had to > > > > know > > > > 3 > > > > > PLLs (well you only actually have to know 1, > but knowing 3 > helps) > > > > > > > > Can you tell which 1 would be enough? > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Computer > puzzle game > > > Puzzle games Online puzzle games Free puzzle > inlay games > > > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on > the web. > > > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email > to: > > > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the > Yahoo! Terms of > Service. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been > removed] > > > __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around http://mail.yahoo.com
705. speedcuber/juggler at Silverwood amusement park
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 00:05:52 -0000

hey, I haven't been to this group in AGES, I pretty much don't post
here anymore. still cubin' though.
anyway, I donno if anyone's mentioned this already, I'm guessing no,
so. a couple weeks ago my family and I went to Silverwood, a theme
park near Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. At the restaurant there they always
have entertainment and stuff going on. Today, they had a juggler, and
I thought that was pretty awesome because I'm a bit of a juggler
myself. but what REALLY intrigued me is his final act was solving a
rubiks cube WHILE juggling!! so I thought that was totally awesome.
it took him like five minutes, but still cool (:
after the show I talked to him, of course I had my cube with me, so I
got to show off properly. So, he said that one of his friends told
him about this guy on the internet who could solve a rubiks cube while
juggling, and this kinda bummed him out, because he thought that he
was the only guy to have done that. so he looked online, of course it
was Macky, and he downloaded the video and all. But then he told me
that he thinks Macky was CHEATING, because Macky's not juggling and
solving at the same time, he's juggling two balls in one hand, and
solving the cube in the other. This performer was juggling all of
them, going back and forth between the two hands, so the cube was in
both his left and right hand an equal amount of time.

so Macky, you should take that as a challenge, learn to do it right,
you cheater (; just kiddin, I can't even do it your way, much less
while juggling all of them together. just thought I'd share (:

cube and 2 balls and just solving the one cube?

stuff, I thought that's what he was doing...

711. Does age matter?
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 07:45:17 -0000

Hi friends,

With all these new young talented cubers around, I begin to feel
old!!! :-(

I was wondering whether age matters, like in other sports/hobbies.
Is cubing more like swimming (most records set under age of 20) or
marathon (for the older guys/girls)?

>From recent experiences and competitions I extracted the following
observations:
- young people's addiction and dedication are stronger
- young people have more spare time
- young people learn faster
- young people have speedier fingers and more dexterity
- young people have fewer problems with nerves

Am I right?

Personally I spend too much time on the websites and organizing
tournaments. I have a family and a busy job. Lots of excuses, but no
excuse to perform badly in competitions.

It looks like the young cubers are taking over!
(Except for the bigger cubes, still...)

Have fun,

Ron
PS: let us NOT start an [OldCubers Team] :-)





712. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter?
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 10:22:51 +0200

> Hi friends, > > With all these new young talented cubers around, I begin to feel > old!!! :-( > > I was wondering whether age matters, like in other sports/hobbies. > Is cubing more like swimming (most records set under age of 20) or > marathon (for the older guys/girls)? I had a very long discussion with Stefan, back in february. We did NOT agree :-). I'm 36 now, and have experienced learning cubing twice : 25 years ago, and now. I'm 100% sure that my physical (including brain) abilities have changed slightly in between. It took me less than 1 month when I was 12 to reach around 36-40'' avg, using a LBL method (around 100 moves). I was only cubing for 1 hour a day. My dexterity has gone down today, even if I am sub29 now. I'm sure that 25 years ago, if I had learnt the fridrich and spent the same amount of time as today, I would be close to sub20. > From recent experiences and competitions I extracted the following > observations: > - young people's addiction and dedication are stronger I'm not sure about this one. This has NOT changed for me. > - young people have more spare time That's right. > - young people learn faster Definitely right. I've been teaching bridge to juniors (< 25yo) and elderly (> 60yo). These people have : - the same motivation ; - the same spare time (elderly having even more) ; - the same education ; Juniors learn lightning fast in comparison to elderly. There's also scientific evidence. There's an excellent book (in french :-() made by Alain Lieury ("Psychologie de la mmoire, histoire, thorie, expriences", Dunod), in which scientifical studies about decreases of cognitive abilities throughout the years are presented. In cubing, I guess that short-term memory also plays a huge role. It decreases regularly from age 20 till death :-). I think the only advantage that older people have over younger maybe "experience". They may be able to use their "slightly" reduced capacities better than the younger... to a certain extent. > - young people have speedier fingers and more dexterity Maybe. Muscle tone also decreases years after year. But when I think about Glen Gould or Richter, I'm wondering about loss of dexterity... > - young people have fewer problems with nerves I don't think so. This is IMO some part of all sports (being mindgames or true sports) where you can work A LOT, not depending on ur age. Nowadays, top competitors very often have a coach AND a psy in order to cope with competition pressure, which can devastate your abilities. > Am I right? I think so. > Personally I spend too much time on the websites and organizing > tournaments. I have a family and a busy job. Lots of excuses, but no > excuse to perform badly in competitions. We share the same excuses. I don't even attempt comps ;). > It looks like the young cubers are taking over! > (Except for the bigger cubes, still...) People less than 30 should have a 5'' handicap in comps, IMO. -- FD.
713. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter?
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 09:52:44 +0100

I have to agree with most of this. My main experience is in chess where players tend to peak at about 30-32. But there isnt the same physical element in chess so I think speedcubing probably favours the young slightly more. There are examples of chess players (e.g. Korchnoi, Smyslov) playing very strong chess into their 70s - but even then they aren't as good as in their youth. Their vast experience compensates somewhat for a drop in speed of thought. My feeling is that academics also suffer from a drop off as they age. Most mathematicians produce their best work in their 20's early 30's - that is their most creative work. Experience in this field can provide much greater compensation for slower thought speed though. If we had professional speedcubers then some of the other advantages of youth wouldnt be quite so pronounced - shame no-one will pay us a wage to speedcube :( I think nerves is more a personal thing than age related. And for some people nerves can be a good thing. I usually do better in competition or when demonstrating even though I get very nervous! Still there are some very fast old cubers out there so don't write us off. And we may be just as good at contributing to the theory! If only I was 18 again (sigh). Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, August 13, 2005 9:22 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter? >> Hi friends, >> >> With all these new young talented cubers around, I begin to feel >> old!!! :-( >> >> I was wondering whether age matters, like in other sports/hobbies. >> Is cubing more like swimming (most records set under age of 20) or >> marathon (for the older guys/girls)? > > I had a very long discussion with Stefan, back in february. > We did NOT agree :-). > I'm 36 now, and have experienced learning cubing twice : 25 years > ago, and now. This has NOT changed for me. > >> - young people have more spare time > > That's right. > >> - young people learn faster > > Definitely right. I've been teaching bridge to juniors (< 25yo) > and elderly (> 60yo). These people have : > - the same motivation ; > - the same spare time (elderly having even more) ; > - the same education ; > Juniors learn lightning fast in comparison to elderly. > > There's also scientific evidence. There's an excellent book (in > french :-() made by Alain Lieury ("Psychologie de la mmoire, histoire, > thorie, expriences", Dunod), in which scientifical studies > about decreases of cognitive abilities throughout the years > are presented. It decreases regularly from age 20 till > death :-). > > I think the only advantage that older people have over younger > maybe "experience". They may be able to use their "slightly" > reduced capacities better than the younger... to a certain extent. > > >> - young people have speedier fingers and more dexterity > > Maybe. > Muscle tone also decreases years after year. > But when I think about Glen Gould or Richter, I'm wondering > about loss of dexterity... > >> - young people have fewer problems with nerves > > I don't think so. > This is IMO some part of all sports (being mindgames or true > sports) where you can work A LOT, not depending on ur age. > Nowadays, top competitors very often have a coach AND a > psy in order to cope with competition pressure, which can > devastate your abilities. > >> Am I right? > > I think so. > >> Personally I spend too much time on the websites and organizing >> tournaments. I have a family and a busy job. Lots of excuses, but no >> excuse to perform badly in competitions. > > We share the same excuses. I don't even attempt comps ;). > >> It looks like the young cubers are taking over! >> (Except for the bigger cubes, still...) > > People less than 30 should have a 5'' handicap in comps, IMO. > -- > FD. > > > > > > Yahoo! 717. Re: Does age matter?
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 13:07:58 -0000

Hey Ron, You may be right about some issue's here. - young people's addiction and dedication are stronger. You may be right.. But your dedication beats everybody ;). - young people have more spare time Yes.. That's definately true.. I am very blessed with my spare time as a student, I guess. - young people have speedier fingers and more dexterity Hmm.. I don't really know if this is true. People like Jessica Fridrich, Katsu, you, etc. also seem to be pretty dexterous (how do you spell that word?). I am not sure if there is a significant difference here. - young people have fewer problems with nerves On this point I have to disagree. I kinda believe the 'nerves' issue is not influenced by age. Everybody gets nervous, but there are just some people who can 'transform' that feeling into a positive 'emotion'. > It looks like the young cubers are taking over! > (Except for the bigger cubes, still...) Yes.. There are quite a few talented young cubers getting faster right now.. Maybe it's because a lot of young people who get into cubing know to find their way around the internet better. And about the bigger cubes: I am working on the 4x4 a little right now... Hope to catch up with Koen and Michael sometime... > PS: let us NOT start an [OldCubers Team] :-) Whahaha! That's just hilarious... :D LOL. > Personally I spend too much time on the websites and organizing > tournaments. I have a family and a busy job. Lots of excuses, but no > excuse to perform badly in competitions. You don't need to excuse yourself Ron. We all get nervous in competitions. I still haven't figured out how to get rid of that feeling during competition (maybe I should get into 'hypnotherapy', LOL). One thing I do at home sometimes is just tell my self to go slower. Like I say 'speedlimit: 3 moves/second'. Well not really that strict :)... Anyways, I did the same thing during my 14.99 solve in Germany. It didn't help me in every solve, but I believe that learning a fluent and 'slow' kind of cubing style will pay off in competitions... (I don't claim to be an expert with this of course). See you @ Eindhoven ;), Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > Hi friends, > > With all these new young talented cubers around, I begin to feel > old!!! :-( > > I was wondering whether age matters, like in other sports/hobbies. > Is cubing more like swimming (most records set under age of 20) or > marathon (for the older guys/girls)? > > From recent experiences and competitions I extracted the following > observations: > - young people's addiction and dedication are stronger > - young people have more spare time > - young people learn faster > - young people have speedier fingers and more dexterity > - young people have fewer problems with nerves > > Am I right? > > Personally I spend too much time on the websites and organizing > tournaments. I have a family and a busy job. Lots of excuses, but no > excuse to perform badly in competitions. > > It looks like the young cubers are taking over! > (Except for the bigger cubes, still...) > > Have fun, > > Ron > PS: let us NOT start an [OldCubers Team] :-)
718. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcuber/juggler at Silverwood amusement park
From: "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 15:47:19 -0000

he was just juggling two balls and one cube, and solving the cube. but I suggested to him afterwards to try three cubes all at once, that would be impressive q-: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > Was he juggling 3 rubik's cubes and solving them all, or just one > cube and 2 balls and just solving the one cube? > Pretty cool nonetheless - when I first heard about Macky's juggling > stuff, I thought that's what he was doing... > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Aug 12, 2005, at 8:05 PM, Michael Atkinson wrote: > > > hey, I haven't been to this group in AGES, I pretty much don't post > > here anymore. still cubin' though. > > anyway, I donno if anyone's mentioned this already, I'm guessing no, > > so. a couple weeks ago my family and I went to Silverwood, a theme > > park near Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. At the restaurant there they always > > have entertainment and stuff going on. Today, they had a juggler, and > > I thought that was pretty awesome because I'm a bit of a juggler > > myself. but what REALLY intrigued me is his final act was solving a > > rubiks cube WHILE juggling!! so I thought that was totally awesome. > > it took him like five minutes, but still cool (: > > after the show I talked to him, of course I had my cube with me, so I > > got to show off properly. So, he said that one of his friends told > > him about this guy on the internet who could solve a rubiks cube while > > juggling, and this kinda bummed him out, because he thought that he > > was the only guy to have done that. so he looked online, of course it > > was Macky, and he downloaded the video and all. But then he told me > > that he thinks Macky was CHEATING, because Macky's not juggling and > > solving at the same time, he's juggling two balls in one hand, and > > solving the cube in the other. This performer was juggling all of > > them, going back and forth between the two hands, so the cube was in > > both his left and right hand an equal amount of time. > > > > so Macky, you should take that as a challenge, learn to do it right, > > you cheater (; just kiddin, I can't even do it your way, much less > > while juggling all of them together. just thought I'd share (: > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > Online puzzle games Puzzle games Computer puzzle game > > Free puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games > > > > YAHOO! 720. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcuber/juggler at Silverwood amusement park
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 17:34:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Atkinson" <unipsycho6@y...> wrote: > yeah, he actually did it on stage for everyone. it took maybe five > minutes...I think he did about 1-3 moves every time the cube got into > his hand. Can you tell us how he juggled? When I juggle three items, they're always in my hand for maybe up to a half second. How can he do 3 moves with one hand in such a short amount of time? Stefan
721. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 13 Aug 2005 18:04:01 -0000

Hi! Us veterans who have been cubing since those early days in 1980/81, we won't win anything in competition by knowing theory of the cube. Sad but true ;-) However i find that my experience and theoretical insight gives me advantages on the larger cubes and particularly in fewest moves. So far i haven't really seen any cubing "prodigy" doing well or consistently well in fewest moves. Or to put it another way. I haven't really seen a top top class 3x3x3 speedcuber doing well in fewest moves. They are sufficiently incompatible to be very hard to master both :-) And im glad for that cause im a lousy 3x3x3 speedcuber ;-) Another benefit of being a true veteran is that we have dealt with the pleasures of cubing for a much longer time. We have had more fun ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > I have to agree with most of this. My main experience is in chess where > players tend to peak at about 30-32. But there isnt the same physical > element in chess so I think speedcubing probably favours the young slightly > more. There are examples of chess players (e.g. Korchnoi, Smyslov) playing > very strong chess into their 70s - but even then they aren't as good as in > their youth. Their vast experience compensates somewhat for a drop in speed > of thought. My feeling is that academics also suffer from a drop off as > they age. Most mathematicians produce their best work in their 20's early > 30's - that is their most creative work. Experience in this field can > provide much greater compensation for slower thought speed though. > > If we had professional speedcubers then some of the other advantages of > youth wouldnt be quite so pronounced - shame no-one will pay us a wage to > speedcube > :( > > I think nerves is more a personal thing than age related. And for some > people nerves can be a good thing. I usually do better in competition or > when demonstrating even though I get very nervous! > > Still there are some very fast old cubers out there so don't write us off. > And we may be just as good at contributing to the theory! > > If only I was 18 again (sigh). > > Duncan > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@f...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Saturday, August 13, 2005 9:22 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter? > > > >> Hi friends, > >> > >> With all these new young talented cubers around, I begin to feel > >> old!!! :-( > >> > >> I was wondering whether age matters, like in other sports/hobbies. > >> Is cubing more like swimming (most records set under age of 20) or > >> marathon (for the older guys/girls)? > > > > I had a very long discussion with Stefan, back in february. > > We did NOT agree :-). > > I'm 36 now, and have experienced learning cubing twice : 25 years > > ago, and now. I'm 100% sure that my physical (including brain) > > abilities have changed slightly in between. > > It took me less than 1 month when I was 12 to reach around 36- 40'' > > avg, using a LBL method (around 100 moves). I was only cubing for > > 1 hour a day. > > My dexterity has gone down today, even if I am sub29 now. > > I'm sure that 25 years ago, if I had learnt the fridrich and spent > > the same amount of time as today, I would be close to sub20. > > > >> From recent experiences and competitions I extracted the following > >> observations: > >> - young people's addiction and dedication are stronger > > > > I'm not sure about this one. This has NOT changed for me. > > > >> - young people have more spare time > > > > That's right. > > > >> - young people learn faster > > > > Definitely right. I've been teaching bridge to juniors (< 25yo) > > and elderly (> 60yo). These people have : > > - the same motivation ; > > - the same spare time (elderly having even more) ; > > - the same education ; > > Juniors learn lightning fast in comparison to elderly. > > > > There's also scientific evidence. There's an excellent book (in > > french :-() made by Alain Lieury ("Psychologie de la mmoire, histoire, > > thorie, expriences", Dunod), in which scientifical studies > > about decreases of cognitive abilities throughout the years > > are presented. In cubing, I guess that short-term memory also > > plays a huge role. It decreases regularly from age 20 till > > death :-). > > > > I think the only advantage that older people have over younger > > maybe "experience". They may be able to use their "slightly" > > reduced capacities better than the younger... to a certain extent. > > > > > >> - young people have speedier fingers and more dexterity > > > > Maybe. > > Muscle tone also decreases years after year. > > But when I think about Glen Gould or Richter, I'm wondering > > about loss of dexterity... > > > >> - young people have fewer problems with nerves > > > > I don't think so. > > This is IMO some part of all sports (being mindgames or true > > sports) where you can work A LOT, not depending on ur age. > > Nowadays, top competitors very often have a coach AND a > > psy in order to cope with competition pressure, which can > > devastate your abilities. > > > >> Am I right? > > > > I think so. > > > >> Personally I spend too much time on the websites and organizing > >> tournaments. I have a family and a busy job. Lots of excuses, but no > >> excuse to perform badly in competitions. > > > > We share the same excuses. I don't even attempt comps ;). > > > >> It looks like the young cubers are taking over! > >> (Except for the bigger cubes, still...) > > > > People less than 30 should have a 5'' handicap in comps, IMO. > > -- > > FD. > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

730. 5x5x5 Parity Error Help Needed
From: "Craig B." <chbouchard777@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 14 Aug 2005 21:34:36 -0000

Alright, I have this problem...I can solve the cube edges/wings,
before doing the 3x3x3 part to it, but one of the edges/wings is
flipped (http://img5.imageshack.us/my.php?image=imgp02206rt.jpg) That
is a picture of the situation. Notice the Green/Orange edges. All of
the other edges are correct. Any solutions??? I just need the
algorithm for it. Any help would rock.

Craig




731. Re: 5x5x5 Parity Error Help Needed
From: a_ooms75 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 14 Aug 2005 23:37:33 -0000

Its not 1 thats been flipped its 2 look at this page of stefan: http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/other_stuff/4x4_5x5_algs/ use the algorithm just like on the 4x4x4 Alexander --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig B." <chbouchard777@y...> wrote: > Alright, I have this problem...I can solve the cube edges/wings, > before doing the 3x3x3 part to it, but one of the edges/wings is > flipped (http://img5.imageshack.us/my.php?image=imgp02206rt.jpg) That > is a picture of the situation. Notice the Green/Orange edges. All of > the other edges are correct. Any solutions??? I just need the > algorithm for it. Any help would rock. > > Craig

Mail has the best spam protection around > http://mail.yahoo.com
736. National Records
From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 00:47:00 -0000

I was on http://www.speedcubing.com today, and yesterday, checking out
the Canadian records, and I realised, even though I am almost brand
new to cubing/speedcubing, I could break many National Records. That
would be sweet holding that many records...lol...It seems like no
Canadians cube in Competitions and I am trying to get my parents to
bring me to Florida...I wanna meet you all...that would rock.

Craig

To give you more idea of the difficulty, I gave a friend who > also does Sudoku another grid with the numbers 1,2,... on which > order to fill the squares in! (That was a while ago and he still > hasn't got the second one in yet.) > I don't know where you are in the puzzle, so I'll tell you this - > the second number to put in goes in the square below that I've > labelled with "@". The third one goes where the # is. > (If you get really stuck, I can post a complete solution that > explains how to get each step without trial and error.) > > > > > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 @ > > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > > 5 # . * . . 9 * . . . > > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. 743. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 11:34:41 -0000

Speaking personally (I guess we all are), I feel that my spatial
reasoning ability, memory and dexterity at age 43 are no worse than
they were at age 19. On the the other hand, those are skills that I
made no effort to improve when I was young. Motivation is actually
higher now, even though I have no real hope of ever being faster than
about 30s. A minor physical problem that I didn't have then is a
tenderness and swelling of the wrists, but one can learn to cube
without bending them significantly.

There is a problem I had when young, which I wonder if others have
experienced: When cubing for any significant period (more than half an
hour, say) I would feel quite nauseous and generally ill at ease. It
would become hard to make sense of the appearance of everyday objects;
e.g., people's faces would appear somehow "dislocated" or incoherent,
giving an overall effect rather like a cubist (ahem) portrait.

Is that a familiar feeling at all? It was a strong disincentive to
cubing at the time.

Mike





744. Re: About age
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 11:38:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "peppecuber" <peppecuber@y...> wrote: > I am 51 years old and cube everyday. Am I the oldest in this group? Rune Wesstrm must be in his early to middle 70s... but I don't know if he is the oldest cuber here. Mike

Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 11:57:17 -0000

Possibly educational for the very young. In the old version, you had to add the features to your own, real potato -- sadly, even Mr Potato Head has been dumbed down. :D Mike
746. Re: [Speed cubing group] Does age matter?
From: Marco Garbelini <garbelini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 14:07:58 +0200

I'm 28 and I have a similar problem when cubing for too long. The cube itself starts to get distorted and uneven like the back face was smaller than the front. (It's a natural high) But I think this only happens when I'm hungry or something. To cube in a a moving car is a NO NO, I get dizzy and sick really fast. I don't think this have anything to do with age... or does it? 758. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5x5 Parity Error Help Needed
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 09:23:42 -0400

I am very distressed by the lack of stickers on your 3x3x3 in your picture. Have you heard of http://www.cubesmith.com ? Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... 762. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Dallas
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 08:53:32 -0500

Dallas tournament was so cool. It was my first tournament and im a new
cuber, relatively, and havent practiced that much but by far, that
tournament was amazing.

I just want to say that Bob Burton was downright amazing at Rubik's
Magic and Master Magic. I had never seen anyone do it before, so i was
just amazed. It was great.

Chris Hardwick was amazing with his 55.xx (cant remember) second solve
on the 4x4x4, and Macky was amazing with his oh, Blindfolded, and
speed solve.

Everyone was just amazing

-parth

P.S. Texas is awesome. Dont mess with Texas :-D

O...ok...yah...my mom just hinted that I might actually be going to the World Championships...so if I am going there...and it is going to cost me as much money as it is...then I want to comepte in as many events as I can...so I can make it worth it...and I was interested in the 4x4 and 5x5 anyways...so...I am learning a new method for 5x5...and I need to learn fridrich...I made this rule for myself...that if I can't learn Fridrich, or I can't get sub-minute (for now) average, then I am not coming...but if I do...watch out...If I am at the world championships you can expect some great things from the sole Canadian at the championships...10 national records...here I come...lol Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > It happens, but I 767. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 5x5x5 Parity Error Help Needed
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 10:08:43 -0400

Even doing a layer method on the 3x3 you should be able to get under a minute. Learning Fridrich F2L is very easy - it's all intuitive. Learning the optimized algs is a little harder, but using intuitive method should ensure you are under a minute. Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Aug 15, 2005, at 10:08 AM, Craig Bouchard wrote: > O...ok...yah...my mom just hinted that I might actually be going to > the World Championships...so if I am going there...and it is going to > cost me as much money as it is...then I want to comepte in as many > events as I can...so I can make it worth it...and I was interested in > the 4x4 and 5x5 anyways...so...I am learning a new method for > 5x5...and I need to learn fridrich...I made this rule for > myself...that if I can't learn Fridrich, or I can't get sub-minute > (for now) average, then I am not coming...but if I do...watch out...If > I am at the world championships you can expect some great things from > the sole Canadian at the championships...10 national records...here I > come...lol > > Craig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > It happens, but I don't do the 4x4 or 5x5 nearly as often as I do > the > > 3x3. > > > > > > > > Bryan Mytko > > bryanosaurus@b... > > > > > > On Aug 15, 2005, at 10:02 AM, Craig Bouchard wrote: > > > > > Yah, I've notcied that...Does this happen on your 4x4x4 and > 5x5x5 a > > > quickly???I just got a new 4x4x4 on thursday and have just > gotten into > > > speedsolving it...and am trying to better my times...but the > stickers > > > are starting to peel... > > > > > > Craig > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > > > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > > Haha, I wasn't offended by lack of stickers :) Just trying to > > > offer a > > > > solution because I know how > Which 3x3???I tried to position it so that you couldn't > > > see the > > > > > > > > missing stickers...On my fastest cube I peeled off > all of > > > the > > > > > > > stickers > > > > > > > > to have a black side, because the green were falling > off. I > > > > > have > > > > > > > > heard of cubesmith...but I do not have access to my own > > > credit > > > > > > > card as > > > > > > > > I am only 16...but if I had my own credit card...believe > > > > > me...I'd > > > > > > > have > > > > > > > > tons of replacement stickers, too many cubes to count, > > > and just > > > > > > > about > > > > > > > > every rubik's puzzle that is available to compete for > at the > > > > > world > > > > > > > > champs...so...it really isn't my choice... > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Craig > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan > Mytko > > > > > > > > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > > > > > > > I am very distressed by the lack of stickers on > your 3x3x3 > > > > > in your > > > > > > > > > picture. 772. Re: Dallas
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 14:31:59 -0000

Had a great time myself. The talent there was simply amazing! Bob inspired me and I came home and started working with my magic, got my first sub 3 second solve today :). Frank and Chris inspired me and I'm going to try getting those stinkin big cube times down (thanks for the tips Frank!). And even my father, who has been somewhat nonchalant about my cubing for the past 4 years has asked me to teach him how to do it after attending the competition! It really was a spectacular time, highlight of my summer by far. I'd like to make an addendum to the controversial statement: "I hate Texas...roads." I mean really, they are very poorly marked! Lastly, I'm working up a megaminx solution as promised to some of the guys. I'll post it when it gets up, but drawing pentagons is hard! Hope to see you all sometime soon, Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@g...> wrote: > Dallas tournament was so cool. It was my first tournament and im a new > cuber, relatively, and havent practiced that much but by far, that > tournament was amazing. > > I just want to say that Bob Burton was downright amazing at Rubik's > Magic and Master Magic. I had never seen anyone do it before, so i was > just amazed. It was great. > > Chris Hardwick was amazing with his 55.xx (cant remember) second solve > on the 4x4x4, and Macky was amazing with his oh, Blindfolded, and > speed solve. > > Everyone was just amazing > > -parth > > P.S. Texas is awesome. Dont mess with Texas :-D

775. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 09:48:28 -0500

Initially, I began one handing with my left hand, even though I'm a right handed person with everything else. Somehow, my left hand was faster at it, and I've been working my times down to between 1:00 and 1:30. The past few days, however, I've tried using my right hand and to great success. I'm now even between my two hands, despite having only practiced occasionally and almost never with the right. I've also noticed several things that have helped me improve immensely in the past few days. For turns that are easy to perform in one direction, the inverse is often very difficult. I used to resort to sort of pushing the face with my fingertip, but it was very slow. I realized that it's much easier to slightly shift where you grip the cube, and turn the opposite two layers. Example, since I'm certain that isn't very clear: U' is very hard for me in my right hand. Instead, I now grab the U side, and then turn d' with my middle and ring fingers. Also, I've learned that going slower than a two handed solve works wonders for looking ahead. I can see easy ways to help with multislotting, and to orient LL edges on the third and fourth pairs. I've noticed that often, however, COLL is not very helpful, except in certain very simple cases. I usually do better with my 3 look OLL/PLL. Perhaps once out of ten solves, I use a 4 look LL, because I have trouble with certain PLL cases one handed. I try to use COLL when it comes up because it's good practice, but with only one hand, I find the simple edge PLL's are very difficult. Also, a lot of my COLL algs use both slice and LUR moves, which are hard to reach with one hand. Anywho, I'm not much of an expert, but these are just some of the things I've noticed in the past few days. -Mike Bennett >From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@...> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve >Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 14:32:18 -0000 > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk ><no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > > <chbouchard777@y...> wrote: > > > I am finally going to try this...I don't know any tricks...it will > > > probably take me 4-5 minutes but I will let you all know... > > > > > > Craig > > > > Have you done it yet? We are all waiting... ;) > > > > Mike > >oh...yah...7 minutes...first go...with my left hand...not sure if I >should use my right or left...hmmmmmmmmm... > >Craig > >

779. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: About age
From: Rune Wesstrm <rune.wesstrom@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 17:32:06 +0200

Im over 75 (and will do under 30 in Florida, the nerves being in order). It seems me that my dexterity is the same as 25 years ago, the reaction times being worse. Well, I was over 50, when the cube came. Maybe my dexterity then had detoriated from what it was 25 years ago. Who knows? R ----- Original Message ----- From: "mike_go_uk" <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, August 15, 2005 1:38 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: About age --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "peppecuber" <peppecuber@y...> wrote: > I am 51 years old and cube everyday. 780. [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve
From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 15:29:33 -0000

Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > Just had a question to ask to the one handers. I realized that it's much easier to > > slightly shift where you grip the cube, and turn the opposite two layers. > > Example, since I'm certain that isn't very clear: U' is very hard for me in > > my right hand. Instead, I now grab the U side, and then turn d' with my > > middle and ring fingers. > > > > Also, I've learned that going slower than a two handed solve works wonders > > for looking ahead. I can see easy ways to help with multislotting, and to > > orient LL edges on the third and fourth pairs. > > > > I've noticed that often, however, COLL is not very helpful, except in > > certain very simple cases. I usually do better with my 3 look OLL/PLL. > > Perhaps once out of ten solves, I use a 4 look LL, because I have trouble > > with certain PLL cases one handed. I try to use COLL when it comes up > > because it's good practice, but with only one hand, I find the simple edge > > PLL's are very difficult. Also, a lot of my COLL algs use both slice and > > LUR moves, which are hard to reach with one hand. > > > > Anywho, I'm not much of an expert, but these are just some of the things > > I've noticed in the past few days. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > > > >From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@y...> > > >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve > > >Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 14:32:18 -0000 > > > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk > > ><no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > > > > <chbouchard777@y...> wrote: > > > > > I am finally going to try this...I don't know any tricks...it will > > > > > probably take me 4-5 minutes but I will let you all know... > > > > > > > > > > Craig > > > > > > > > Have you done it yet? We are all waiting... ;) > > > > > > > > Mike > > > > > >oh...yah...7 minutes...first go...with my left hand...not sure if I > > >should use my right or left...hmmmmmmmmm... > > > > > >Craig > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

782. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 16:33:28 +0100

Hi, I use pretty much the same algorithms - in fact I've recently taken to learning them one handed because I think you have to know them better that way! (see chris Hardwick on OH amnesia!) Also I'm right handed and seem pretty unusual in solving OH right handed too! Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Sachin Shirwalkar" <sachinss@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, August 15, 2005 4:17 PM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve > Just had a question to ask to the one handers. Do you use the same > algos for One handed solves as the two handed solves or do u use some > diff ones optimised for one hand? > > On 8/15/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: >> Initially, I began one handing with my left hand, even though I'm a right >> handed person with everything else. Somehow, my left hand was faster at >> it, >> and I've been working my times down to between 1:00 and 1:30. >> >> The past few days, however, I've tried using my right hand and to great >> success. I'm now even between my two hands, despite having only >> practiced >> occasionally and almost never with the right. I've also noticed several >> things that have helped me improve immensely in the past few days. >> >> For turns that are easy to perform in one direction, the inverse is often >> very difficult. I used to resort to sort of pushing the face with my >> fingertip, but it was very slow. I realized that it's much easier to >> slightly shift where you grip the cube, and turn the opposite two layers. >> Example, since I'm certain that isn't very clear: U' is very hard for me >> in >> my right hand. Instead, I now grab the U side, and then turn d' with my >> middle and ring fingers. >> >> Also, I've learned that going slower than a two handed solve works >> wonders >> for looking ahead. I can see easy ways to help with multislotting, and >> to >> orient LL edges on the third and fourth pairs. >> >> I've noticed that often, however, COLL is not very helpful, except in >> certain very simple cases. I usually do better with my 3 look OLL/PLL. >> Perhaps once out of ten solves, I use a 4 look LL, because I have trouble >> with certain PLL cases one handed. I try to use COLL when it comes up >> because it's good practice, but with only one hand, I find the simple >> edge >> PLL's are very difficult. Also, a lot of my COLL algs use both slice and >> LUR moves, which are hard to reach with one hand. >> >> Anywho, I'm not much of an expert, but these are just some of the things >> I've noticed in the past few days. >> >> -Mike Bennett >> >> >> >> >From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@...> >> >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >> >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com >> >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve >> >Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 14:32:18 -0000 >> > >> >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk >> ><no_reply@y...> wrote: >> > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" >> > > <chbouchard777@y...> wrote: >> > > > I am finally going to try this...I don't know any tricks...it will >> > > > probably take me 4-5 minutes but I will let you all know... >> > > > >> > > > Craig >> > > >> > > Have you done it yet? We are all waiting... ;) >> > > >> > > Mike >> > >> >oh...yah...7 minutes...first go...with my left hand...not sure if I >> >should use my right or left...hmmmmmmmmm... >> > >> >Craig >> > >> > >> >> >> >> >> >> >> Yahoo! Groups Links >> >> >> >> >> >> >> > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > >
783. [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 15:33:38 -0000

For most cases I use the same algorithms.. But for some cases, it's easy to choose a more OH-friedly algorithm. For example: Two hands: RUR' F' RUR'U' R'F R2U' R'U' One hand: U LU'R U2 L' U L U2 R'L' I can do the last one pretty fast with one hand.. I kinda execute it with the U face on the right, so I can do the L moves with my left index, and some of the U moves with my (also left :)) ring finger. The last R'L' can be done at the same time this way :). Other example: Two hands: M2 U M2 U2 M2 U M2 One hand: LR U2 L'R' y' L'R' U2 LR These are of course just my personal preferences... -Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > Just had a question to ask to the one handers. Do you use the same > algos for One handed solves as the two handed solves or do u use some > diff ones optimised for one hand? >

lunch.

No, I'm not eating 4.5 pounds of meat.

But yeah... I keep picturing in my head this image where a guy gets
pulled over for speeding and as the cop hands him his ticket, he says,
"Don't mess with Texas!" I bet the chant that when they're handcuffing
people on the hood of their cars. "Don't mess with Texas!"

Keep in mind... Socorro, NM has 5% humidity at some times... meaning
you might all be able to guess the name of the DVD that's coming out.

Tyson Mao (75 minutes before I get out of this state... because... yeah)

California Institute of Technology

805. Re: Dallas
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>

I hope I get to see you in action with my own eyes sometime soon! Best, Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Hey, does it mean are you into Megaminxing again now? 810. [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 21:45:52 -0000

Yes. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > Just had a question to ask to the one handers. Do you use the same > algos for One handed solves as the two handed solves or do u use some > diff ones optimised for one hand? > > On 8/15/05, Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > > Initially, I began one handing with my left hand, even though I'm a right > > handed person with everything else. Somehow, my left hand was faster at it, > > and I've been working my times down to between 1:00 and 1:30. > > > > The past few days, however, I've tried using my right hand and to great > > success. I'm now even between my two hands, despite having only practiced > > occasionally and almost never with the right. I've also noticed several > > things that have helped me improve immensely in the past few days. > > > > For turns that are easy to perform in one direction, the inverse is often > > very difficult. I used to resort to sort of pushing the face with my > > fingertip, but it was very slow. I realized that it's much easier to > > slightly shift where you grip the cube, and turn the opposite two layers. > > Example, since I'm certain that isn't very clear: U' is very hard for me in > > my right hand. Instead, I now grab the U side, and then turn d' with my > > middle and ring fingers. > > > > Also, I've learned that going slower than a two handed solve works wonders > > for looking ahead. I can see easy ways to help with multislotting, and to > > orient LL edges on the third and fourth pairs. > > > > I've noticed that often, however, COLL is not very helpful, except in > > certain very simple cases. I usually do better with my 3 look OLL/PLL. > > Perhaps once out of ten solves, I use a 4 look LL, because I have trouble > > with certain PLL cases one handed. I try to use COLL when it comes up > > because it's good practice, but with only one hand, I find the simple edge > > PLL's are very difficult. Also, a lot of my COLL algs use both slice and > > LUR moves, which are hard to reach with one hand. > > > > Anywho, I'm not much of an expert, but these are just some of the things > > I've noticed in the past few days. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > > > >From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@y...> > > >Reply-To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > >To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > > >Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: One-Handed Solve > > >Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 14:32:18 -0000 > > > > > >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk > > ><no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > > > > <chbouchard777@y...> wrote: > > > > > I am finally going to try this...I don't know any tricks...it will > > > > > probably take me 4-5 minutes but I will let you all know... > > > > > > > > > > Craig > > > > > > > > Have you done it yet? We are all waiting... ;) > > > > > > > > Mike > > > > > >oh...yah...7 minutes...first go...with my left hand...not sure if I > > >should use my right or left...hmmmmmmmmm... > > > > > >Craig > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >

812. Re: [Speed cubing group] smooth?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 00:14:09 -0000

Even before seeing Duncan's reply, I immediately recognised this cube! Yep, Duncan's right, these cubes have been available in Canberra over the past few years, although I very much doubt that they are actually manufactured in Australia. It was briefly my main speedcube, and yes I was using it at Worlds 2003. All the other cubers laughed at my cube. :( ;) I didn't realise how crappy the cube was until I tried everyone else's cube. After Worlds I used the cube they gave us there, and now I'm using a 25th anniversary cube which is very nice. These 'smoothest cubes' are not so smooth straight out of the box, but loosenly up A LOT (too much!) which a little silicone. The cube is probably fine for a beginner, but I wouldn't recommend a non-beginner getting one of these cubes. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: > > I belive Jasmine had one of these at the last WC and > > they are still on sale in Oz. > > Blimey -- I hope it wasn't her main speedcube. ;) The faces on mine > spin very freely, but must be aligned very precisely. It was my only > working 3x3x3 for several years, until I got a Studio cube last year. > > Mike

814. Blank 4x4x4 picture request
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 01:44:38 -0000

Hey everyone,

I want to make a webpage with my 4x4 solution on it, speedsolve and
not the current intermediate/beginner approach I have on my site now.

I made the pictures for my current page myself, and I don't think they
look very professional. Is there a program like Lars Vandenbergh's
ImageCube available for 4x4x4? If not would anyone with some graphic
savvy skills be willing to help me make a blank 4x4x4 template? I
would just need to be able to use the fill tool in photoshop to color
the blank squares different colors and save as for a new picture file.

I really am not very graphics savvy, and I'd like this page to look
nice.

Thanks to anyone who responds,
Chris

flight costs, hotel room, and all that stuff and said he would
probably take me if my school grades didn't start to slip from me
being addicted to cubing over the next 2 months...and I was like...my
times will have to improve too...and he was like...it is your first
competition and I thought to myself...first???you mean I am going to
go to others???

825. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcuber/juggler at Silverwood amusement park
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 15 Aug 2005 21:39:32 -0600

You can imagine why I would be skeptical at something like this. I
think it's pretty much close to without a doubt that there is no better
cuber in the world than Macky. Do you realize the combined cubing +
juggling skill that Macky has? Macky, though not the best juggler in
the world, is probably better than this amusement park performer. I
mean, how good of a juggler was this guy? Are you a juggler yourself?

There are many unskilled jugglers who get by doing tricks that don't
take much technical skill, but look very impressive to someone who
doesn't juggle much. It is of my suspicion that the amusement park
performer can't do this. If you could give us a detailed description
of what was going on, I'd probably be more convinced.

Quinn Lewis can flash 8 balls I believe. I'm pretty sure he'll tell
you that it's pretty hard to juggle a ball and a cube in one hand, and
throw the ball high enough to make three moves with one-hand on a cube.

Unless the guy can juggle 7 balls, he's not better at juggling than
Macky and we certainly know he's not a better cuber than Macky.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 13, 2005, at 12:57 PM, Michael Atkinson wrote:

> well, it looked like he was just juggling normally...kind of slowly, I
> guess, tossing them higher than normally, so I guess he had more time
> that way...I donno exactly. hrmm.

835. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcuber/juggler at Silverwood amusement park
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 09:13:42 -0000


--- Tyson Mao wrote:
> You can imagine why I would be skeptical at something like this.
> There are many unskilled jugglers who get by doing tricks that
> don't
> take much technical skill, but look very impressive to someone who
> doesn't juggle much. It is of my suspicion that the amusement park
> performer can't do this.

Maybe, but I'm pretty sure it is possible to do this using a 55113
juggle pattern (in siteswap notation), because then you have 2 beats
in which to do a cube turn. Or even a 7711113 pattern. To do it
properly, you need to be able to throw the cube across without it
rotating in space.

If I could juggle that pattern well enough to do this, I would still
use a prepared scramble, and just memorize the colours of the faces
that need to be turned. Probably just a repeated cycle of 6 colours.

Jaap

837. Re: Error-prone algorithms? generation by <U,G> impossible
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 10:04:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Ravi Fernando <rubik12346@y...> wrote: > About Stefan's question: > L can be ruled out > because each edge and corner next to it are permuted > together and cannot be separated. R can similarly be > ruled out by thinking of the separate pairs that are > permuted "together" (ex. UFL/UR and UFR/UB). I agree with all this. > G, on the other hand, might work. Although G is the only candidate left, it can also be ruled out. The following argument seems excessively complicated, but I cannot think of a simpler one yet: Let's write the configuration in the form [corners][edges], where the pieces are taken in order clockwise around the U face. The solved state is [0123][0123], and G can be taken to have the action G([0123][0123])=[2013][1203]. Of course, U has the action U([0123][0123])=[3012][3012]. We need to investigate the kinds of positions that can be generated by repeated application of U and G. Obviously there are too many to investigate by hand, so instead consider a reduced representation in which we do not distinguish a piece from its opposite number: 0 & 2 are both represented by 0, and 1 & 3 are represented by 1. Now consider the action of G and U on A = [0011] B = [0101] C = [0110] D = [1001] E = [1010] F = [1100]. We have U{A,B,C,D,E,F} = {D,E,A,F,B,C} for both corners and edges, but G{A,B,C,D,E,F} = {D,A,E,B,F,C} for corners while G{A,B,C,D,E,F} = {B,D,F,A,C,E} for edges. In the reduced representation, several [corner][edge] configurations will be represented by the same ordered pair of symbols XY. For example, the solved state is one of the states represented by BB. By applying U and G repeatedly to BB, you can easily show that the only reduced configurations that can be reached are {BB,EE,BE,EB,AD,FC,DF,CA,DA,CF,FD,AC}. (You can check in a couple of minutes that this set is invariant under U and G -- assuming that I haven't made a silly mistake.) Note in particular that this shows that a 3-cycle on one kind of piece is impossible, since this would require B (the reduced form of the solved state for one kind of piece) to be paired with a reduced configuration other than B or E. Hope the idea is clear enough, but there really ought to be a simpler way of seeing it. Mike

841. Magicians, please?
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 12:30:46 -0000

----------------

Seeing on speedcubing.com: "Unofficial World Record for solving
Rubik's Magic, with a new average record of 1.16 seconds"

And the rules are:

- You must time yourself in the fashion of an official Rubik's Magic
event at an official contest
- The Magic must start flat on the table
- Both hands must start flat on the table or timing device
- You may use a Stackmat timer, or any other timing device where both
hands must be placed flat on the table to stop the timer.

----------------

Tell me, I want to understand how such a thing is possible (I need
more than 1s just to start/stop a stackmat timer!).
Do people really have their fingers flat on the pads before? Do they
clearly drop the Magic before stopping?

Gilles.





842. Re: Magicians, please?
From: "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 12:41:38 -0000

Hey Gilles, Some people are just REALLY fast with their hands...so they do the move and they drop the magic in air and their hands are back to the timer before the magic hits the table. Could you jump onto yahoo quickly, if possible??? Thanks, Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > ---------------- > > Seeing on speedcubing.com: "Unofficial World Record for solving > Rubik's Magic, with a new average record of 1.16 seconds" > > And the rules are: > > - You must time yourself in the fashion of an official Rubik's Magic > event at an official contest > - The Magic must start flat on the table > - Both hands must start flat on the table or timing device > - You may use a Stackmat timer, or any other timing device where both > hands must be placed flat on the table to stop the timer. > > ---------------- > > Tell me, I want to understand how such a thing is possible (I need > more than 1s just to start/stop a stackmat timer!). > Do people really have their fingers flat on the pads before? Do they > clearly drop the Magic before stopping? > > Gilles.

From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 12:44:06 -0000

This is great to hear! I know it's so exciting when you think there's no chance you can go, and then things turn your way! :) For World 2003 I thought there was no chance I was going to make it since I was in Canberra, Australia and Worlds were in Toronto, Canada (15815kms/9828miles away!), but then through a series of events and changed travel plans it looked like I was going to be in Washington DC anyway around the same time as Worlds. An extra trip from DC to Toronto was pretty negligible once I'd already flown from Canberra! I was sooooo excited! 846. Re: Error-prone algorithms? generation by <U,G> impossible
From: _jaap <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 12:53:02 -0000

> --- Ravi Fernando wrote: > > About Stefan's question: > > G, on the other hand, might work. > --- mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Although G is the only candidate left, it can also be ruled out. > The following argument seems excessively complicated, but I > cannot think of a simpler one yet: You can simplify the argument by conflating your A and F, B and E, C and D. The argument then boils down to the following. Let's mark pairs of LL pieces that have opposite colours (i.e. such pieces belong opposite each other in the last layer when it is solved). The starting position it this: abc d d cba Note that I'm using the letters only as labels for identifying which pieces form a pair, not for identifying a particular pair. In other words, the following labelling means just the same: adc b b cda When applying the G perm and U turns to this, there are only two other possibilities of where the pairs can be: aba d b cdc abc b d adc It is easily checked that no other patterns are generated when you apply G or U to these 3 patterns. In particular, the mirror images of the last two patterns is not possible, nor can corners be opposite pairs and edges adjacent pairs (nor vice versa). Jaap
847. Re: [Speed cubing group] I feel like a giddy little school girl right now...
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 13:09:48 -0000

Yeah, I'm old, and I have a job, so I can register on my own and buy my own plane tickets. :) BTW, I'm 28 years so older than a lot of people on this group, but not actually old. ;) BTW, you don't need to have mega fast times to compete. I was averaging over a minute leading up to Worlds. I got my first sub-1min average only about a week before Worlds and my best time at the competition was only 54 seconds. I knew my times were waaay too slow to be really competitive so I was just aiming to do times that were good times for me. For me, Worlds 2003 was primarily about meeting cubers from all around the world, and also getting some competition experience. My current average is about 35 seconds, which is still not internationally competitive, so my aim is just to beat my previous competition times. :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <chbouchard777@y...> wrote: > Jasmine, you have an advantage on me, > > You can travel and register on your own, and you were good enough to > compete...I still have to bring my times down to be competitive, and I > only have another 2 months to do that...so...Believe me, I'll keep you > all posted on my cubing...and Once I beat Macky's time you all will > know...lol...beat Macky's time...yah right...lol... > > Craig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > This is great to hear! Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 13:50:01 -0000

855. Re: Error-prone algorithms? generation by <U,G> impossible
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 14:35:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> wrote: > You can simplify the argument by conflating your A and F, B and E, C > and D. Thanks, Jaap! That makes it quite obvious. In particular, it would seem that there is nothing special about identifying opposite pairs. Any reduced representation in which a 3-cycle can be distinguished from the solved state, a double-swap of adjacent pieces of the same type, or an X-swap should do a similar job. Mike
856. Re: Magicians, please?
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 14:54:55 -0000

Watch Bob Burtons videos at strangepuzzle.com. It's amazingly fast. I've done sub-2 once but I don't understand how he does it. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > ---------------- > > Seeing on speedcubing.com: "Unofficial World Record for solving > Rubik's Magic, with a new average record of 1.16 seconds" > > And the rules are: > > - You must time yourself in the fashion of an official Rubik's Magic > event at an official contest > - The Magic must start flat on the table > - Both hands must start flat on the table or timing device > - You may use a Stackmat timer, or any other timing device where both > hands must be placed flat on the table to stop the timer. > > ---------------- > > Tell me, I want to understand how such a thing is possible (I need > more than 1s just to start/stop a stackmat timer!). > Do people really have their fingers flat on the pads before? Do they > clearly drop the Magic before stopping? > > Gilles.
857. Re: [Speed cubing group] speedcuber/juggler at Silverwood amusement park
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 09:10:02 -0600

The point still being, what this guy claims to do is no trivial task.
I think most likely he had one of those fake cubes where you press a
button and it solves itself.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Aug 16, 2005, at 3:13 AM, _jaap wrote:

>
> --- Tyson Mao wrote:
>> You can imagine why I would be skeptical at something like this.
>> There are many unskilled jugglers who get by doing tricks that
>> don't
>> take much technical skill, but look very impressive to someone who
>> doesn't juggle much. It is of my suspicion that the amusement park
>> performer can't do this.
>
> Maybe, but I'm pretty sure it is possible to do this using a 55113
> juggle pattern (in siteswap notation), because then you have 2 beats
> in which to do a cube turn. Or even a 7711113 pattern. To do it
> properly, you need to be able to throw the cube across without it
> rotating in space.
>
> If I could juggle that pattern well enough to do this, I would still
> use a prepared scramble, and just memorize the colours of the faces
> that need to be turned. Probably just a repeated cycle of 6 colours.
>
> Jaap
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>
>



858. Re: Error-prone algorithms? generation by <U,G> impossible
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 15:24:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, _jaap <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > You can simplify the argument by conflating your A and F, B and E, C > > and D. > > Thanks, Jaap! > > That makes it quite obvious. In particular, it would seem that there > is nothing special about identifying opposite pairs. Any reduced > representation in which a 3-cycle can be distinguished from the solved > state, a double-swap of adjacent pieces of the same type, or an X-swap > should do a similar job. > > Mike Darn, you guys were faster ;-) I had this thought about any PLL (plus U turns): Pairs that belong opposite are either opposite or not. Like a kind of parity. We need an alg that changes this parity, both for edges and corners. But exactly this requirement makes a 3-cycle impossible. Right? Stefan
