860. Re: generation by <U,G> impossible... parity?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 17:35:20 -0000

Sorry, Stefan, I keep posting and deleting. I will stop that now. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Pairs that belong opposite are either opposite or not. Like > a kind of parity. We need an alg that changes this parity, both for > edges and corners. But exactly this requirement makes a 3-cycle > impossible. Right? I badly wanted to believe this, but the parity change depends both on the state and the PLL -- not just the PLL -- so I don't understand how your argument works. To give an explicit example (focusing on corners), suppose the PLL swaps UBR and URF: 12 03 the even-"parity", solved state becomes 13 02 which has odd "parity". Now apply U to get 01 23 which still has odd "parity". Now apply the PLL again to get 03 21. The "parity" is still odd, so there has been no parity change this time. Mike
861. Re: generation by <U,G> impossible... parity?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 18:12:39 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > Sorry, Stefan, I keep posting and deleting. I will stop that now. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Pairs that belong opposite are either opposite or not. Like > > a kind of parity. We need an alg that changes this parity, both for > > edges and corners. But exactly this requirement makes a 3-cycle > > impossible. Right? > > I badly wanted to believe this, but the parity change depends both on > the state and the PLL -- not just the PLL -- so I don't understand > how your argument works. > > To give an explicit example (focusing on corners), suppose the PLL > swaps UBR and URF: Yeah ok, I see. Well, my proof has one big advantage: You all have a reason to laugh now ;-) Another demonstration why my "proof" doesn't work is that it would also prove that e.g. the PLL, its mirror and U together would also not be enough to create a 3-cycle... But there must be a fix, there must be a really short proof... Sigh... Stefan
862. Re: generation by <U,G> impossible... parity?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 16 Aug 2005 18:21:11 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > But there must be a fix, there must be a really short proof... Yep, there "ought" to be. It is horribly tantalizing, but I must stop thinking about it now. ;) Mike

879. competitive ZB
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 04:18:58 -0000

Hey everyone,

I'm going to write a report on Dallas, and actually also on the Horace
Mann tourny (though I'm almost done with that one) pretty soon, but I
wanted to post about ZB.

I did 6 ZB solves in Dallas, 4 of the first round solves (I got
amnesia on the ZBF2L on one of the solves and used Fridrich), and the
last two solves of the final round.

Of those 6 solves I got 2 ZBLL solves, 15.91 which was a PLL skip
after COLL and 17.52 which was the ZBLL case F' R' U' F2 U F2 R U' F'
U' F2 U F2 U2 which I do as y x (L' U') x' (U' L2) (U) ((L)2 F) (U')
[L' U' (L)2 (U) (L')2] U2

I was definitely very nervous trying to recognize the ZBF2L case while
being timed and if you watch my video of the 17.52 solve I have a very
long delay in trying to recognize the ZBLL case. I knew by the COLL
case that I knew the ZBLL one, but it took me a few seconds to fully
recognize it.

I still feel excited about ZB for competitions, though I agree with
pretty much everyone who has posted that I think ZB will take a lot of
work. My motivation comes from the fact that ZBF2L, though harder
than F2L is still manageable in competition. Also, even with a slow
recognition of one of my better practiced ZBLL cases I can still get
17.xx seconds.

I don't expect to see any real results from ZB in competition for a
long time, but after trying it in Dallas I definitely think it is a
viable method for competitions, and this only motivated me even more
to learn it.

I hope people aren't sick of hearing about ZB, but I felt extremely
excited to use it for the first time in competition and I wanted to
post about it.

Chris




880. Re: competitive ZB
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 05:55:44 -0000

Chris, I seriously doubt anyone is tired of hearing about ZB. I personally am facinated at your determination to get it done. Please keep us posted and good luck in your endeavor. -mike - In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I'm going to write a report on Dallas, and actually also on the Horace > Mann tourny (though I'm almost done with that one) pretty soon, but I > wanted to post about ZB. > > I did 6 ZB solves in Dallas, 4 of the first round solves (I got > amnesia on the ZBF2L on one of the solves and used Fridrich), and the > last two solves of the final round. > > Of those 6 solves I got 2 ZBLL solves, 15.91 which was a PLL skip > after COLL and 17.52 which was the ZBLL case F' R' U' F2 U F2 R U' F' > U' F2 U F2 U2 which I do as y x (L' U') x' (U' L2) (U) ((L)2 F) (U') > [L' U' (L)2 (U) (L')2] U2 > > I was definitely very nervous trying to recognize the ZBF2L case while > being timed and if you watch my video of the 17.52 solve I have a very > long delay in trying to recognize the ZBLL case. 881. Re: [Speed cubing group] cute?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 06:44:43 -0000

Hi! Yes it's a nice feeling when it's really new. But i guess u won't like it that much once u get faster;-) U will notice better that it's locking too much. And don't try to take it apart like u do with a normal 3x3x3, popping an edge. That will get u into trouble reassembling it again ;-) U can take off the centercaps of a face to get access to a screw which will let u disassble it properly if u fancy. But i recommend never do that. The cube will get very loose after u do :-( Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@g...> wrote: > Damn that cube is mini, and slick > thats really cool > > parth
882. Re: [Speed cubing group] Gala or not???
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>

886. Re: competitive ZB
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 12:04:32 -0000

Hi Chris, First of all, congratulations on your results! There's something I'd like to ask about "ZB" (I already asked but I think the post didn't appear?!). I don't know if this technique is interesting for super-humans, but it is not for normal humans like me because of an important point that is rarely discussed: Case recognition time. For three years, I've been practicing CLL recognition, and I think I became rather good at it. In my opinion, being fast means: 1) Being able to recognize the case from the best angle immediately. But that's not enough. 2) Being able to recognize it from different point of views. Full identification or partial when this point of view (3 sides) is not enough. 3) Being able to anticipate as much as possible, *before the end of the previous step* (simple example: If you finish the F2L stage with an R turn, start analyzing the ULx corners before). (Tip: Practice Lars Petrus' fifth step if you want to master relative positioning of corners) 4) At any stage of the recognition process, ready your fingers. If there are 3 hypothesis left, your fingers must be ready for any of them, waiting for the last pieces of information. 5) In order to do 4) efficiently, the sequences must be carefully selected. It's useless to optimize a sequence for pure speed only if you need to adjust U or, more seriously, if you need to change your grip at the last moment because you are hesitating between 2 cases and the 2 solving sequences start with very different moves and grip. CLL == - 43 different cases - 24 unique sequences --> Years of optimizations and practice. Now for the question you can guess ;-) What's your estimation of the recognition time for "CLL + LL-edges position", or more precisely, the delay between the last F2L turn and the first move of the LL sequence? Gilles. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I'm going to write a report on Dallas, and actually also on the Horace > Mann tourny (though I'm almost done with that one) pretty soon, but I > wanted to post about ZB. > > I did 6 ZB solves in Dallas, 4 of the first round solves (I got > amnesia on the ZBF2L on one of the solves and used Fridrich), and the > last two solves of the final round. > > Of those 6 solves I got 2 ZBLL solves, 15.91 which was a PLL skip > after COLL and 17.52 which was the ZBLL case F' R' U' F2 U F2 R U' F' > U' F2 U F2 U2 which I do as y x (L' U') x' (U' L2) (U) ((L)2 F) (U') > [L' U' (L)2 (U) (L')2] U2 > > I was definitely very nervous trying to recognize the ZBF2L case while > being timed and if you watch my video of the 17.52 solve I have a very > long delay in trying to recognize the ZBLL case. I knew by the COLL > case that I knew the ZBLL one, but it took me a few seconds to fully > recognize it. > > I still feel excited about ZB for competitions, though I agree with > pretty much everyone who has posted that I think ZB will take a lot of > work. My motivation comes from the fact that ZBF2L, though harder > than F2L is still manageable in competition. Also, even with a slow > recognition of one of my better practiced ZBLL cases I can still get > 17.xx seconds. > > I don't expect to see any real results from ZB in competition for a > long time, but after trying it in Dallas I definitely think it is a > viable method for competitions, and this only motivated me even more > to learn it. > > I hope people aren't sick of hearing about ZB, but I felt extremely > excited to use it for the first time in competition and I wanted to > post about it. > > Chris
887. Re: Prying off center caps
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 16:41:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Hey all, I've decided I need to tweak the action on my megaminx if I'm > ever going to catch stefan ;). Problem is I can't seem to get the > center caps off. Does anyone have any tips on how to remove some > stubborn center caps? > > Thanks all! > Daniel The simplest way might be: Get a new Megaminx from mefferts.com ;-) No, seriously! I think they used much more glue a while ago and nowadays the caps come off easily. Also, they now have good long screws with large heads (and maybe only thread on the ends but I'm not sure). And they do have tiles which make them totally beautiful :-) Other than that, I'd suggest to use a thin rectangular blade like this: http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/images/Center_Remove.JPG Stick it under the cap from all five directions, I think you can go about 2mm deep without causing damage (other than cracking glue, which is what you want). Cheers! Stefan

893. [Speed cubing group] Re: Prying off center caps
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 17:55:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > Would your recommend the same technique for getting the tiles off a > Rubik's Game cube? I managed to get the centers caps off the adjust > the screws, but I desperately want to swap the color scheme. > I had a very difficult time getting the center caps off, and don't > want to go through that again. It seems there is just too much glue > on the tiles.... Yeah, they did use too much glue. Today I also got another game cube and three of the centers had lots of excessive glue where the springs are! The springs were completely paralyzed! It was just terrible. I've repaired one center now (pulled out the spring, used my dremel to remove the glue and make the hole even larger so it had a flat bottom rim again on which I could put a nice metal washer). Just this one center took me at least an hour. The other two will be faster now that I know what to do and have the tools. But to "answer" your question: David recently wrote a description how to get deluxe/game cube tiles off nicely. Don't know whether it was here or over at TPF. And of course minimize the number of tiles you swap (i.e. 8 if you want to swap just two colors). Cheers! Stefan

898. [Speed cubing group] Re: Prying off center caps
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 18:49:20 -0000

Thanks for the tips guys. I have two different megaminxes
(megaminxi?) that I am working on. One is the stickered 6 color style
(though the stickers have since been replaced) and the other is from
the new run of 12 color tiled minxes, both from mefferts.

After trying every prying device known to man to get these center caps
off, I went with drastic measures. I drilled a very small (1/16 inch)
hole at the seem between the cap and the base and stuck a tiny nail in
there. Then grabbed that nail with some pliers and pried them off. I
got all but one to come up this way (and in fact, the one that won't
come off bent the nail at a right angle!) I did that on my test
megaminx to try it out before touching me speed minx, and I think it's
going to work.

However, the tile scheme is not to my liking on the tiled minx, so if
anyone can dig up those tile removal tips, let me know!

Thanks guys!
Daniel

(BTW, I need to swap 5 faces on the minx, I can post a picture of how
if anyone would like to attempt to find the minimum number of tiles to
pry off!)




899. [Speed cubing group] Re: Prying off center caps
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 19:04:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > After trying every prying device known to man to get these center caps > off, I went with drastic measures. I drilled a very small (1/16 inch) > hole at the seem between the cap and the base and stuck a tiny nail in > there. Then grabbed that nail with some pliers and pried them off. I > got all but one to come up this way (and in fact, the one that won't > come off bent the nail at a right angle!) I did that on my test > megaminx to try it out before touching me speed minx, and I think it's > going to work. OUCH!!! That hurt reading it, man :-) So which one did you do this, too? The new 12 color tiled one you have should have only very little glue and the caps should really come off easily just using a thing blade/knife. > However, the tile scheme is not to my liking on the tiled minx, so if > anyone can dig up those tile removal tips, let me know! My tip: Get used to the new color scheme and buy at least four of them so you're safe for the near future (that's what I did ;-). Or you can get just the tiles from mefferts.com and put them on a stickered Megaminx the way you like it. Cheers! Stefan
900. [Speed cubing group] Re: Prying off center caps
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 19:07:14 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Or you can > get just the tiles from mefferts.com and put them on a stickered > Megaminx the way you like it. Oh, and if you don't use superglue then you can take them off whenever you feel the desire/need to change the color scheme again :-). For example like this: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forum/viewtopic.php?t=3765 Cheers! Stefan
901. [Speed cubing group] Re: Prying off center caps
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 17 Aug 2005 19:12:24 -0000

> OUCH!!! That hurt reading it, man :-)
>
> So which one did you do this, too? The new 12 color tiled one you have
> should have only very little glue and the caps should really come off
> easily just using a thing blade/knife.

This was actually the new 12 color tiled minx. Only one cap came off
when I tried to pry them. Having them off now, I can tell maybe 2
others that could have come off had I tried a bit harder, but there is
so much residual glue on the others I'm surprised they ever came off!

> > However, the tile scheme is not to my liking on the tiled minx, so
> if
> > anyone can dig up those tile removal tips, let me know!
>
> My tip: Get used to the new color scheme and buy at least four of them
> so you're safe for the near future (that's what I did ;-). Or you can
> get just the tiles from mefferts.com and put them on a stickered
> Megaminx the way you like it.
> Cheers!
> Stefan

You're probably right on this one :D ... Old habits though! I might
just do the tile set from mefferts, I'd only have to learn two new
colors this way (my gray and black would both become a shade of
blue... I mean really, 3 shades of blue on one puzzle!?!). Those
tiles do seem to be REALLY well stuck down.

Also, does anyone know where I might score some shorter springs? Or at
least less taught ones? I was thinking of checking out ACE or
something like that, but I don't know if they carry too many kinds of
springs.

Thanks again!
Daniel

915. Eastsheen 2x2x2 and 4x4x4
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 12:32:48 -0000

Well, I sent an e-mail to the organizers of WC2005, andthey told me
that the Eastsheen cubes are not allowed at the competition because
"They cannot be legally seen to endorse them." But whatever, guess no
2x2x2 world records will be set at the Worlds if we have to use the
Rubiks 2x2x2...

Craig

917. Re: Eastsheen 2x2x2 and 4x4x4
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 13:46:57 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > Eastsheen cubes are not allowed at the competition because > "They cannot be legally seen to endorse them." It's strange that they cite legal reasons. What are these reasons, exactly? The Eastsheen cubes use different, patented mechanisms from Rubiks, and I believe (correct me if wrong) that Sebesteny's patent for the Revenge mechanism lapsed quite a few years ago. Mike
918. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Eastsheen 2x2x2 and 4x4x4
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 16:29:56 +0200

la raison me semble tout simplement tre commerciale : la marque
rubik's ne va pas organiser un tourner et pouvoir y participer (et
tre vu !) avec des produits concurrents, ce serait comme si Budweiser
servait de la Heineken un festival de la bire !


919. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Eastsheen 2x2x2 and 4x4x4
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 16:31:12 +0200

oops, I writed in french :D The reason seems to be only commercial : they cannot organize an event and allow people to compete (and be seen) with other branded cubes, it would be as if Budweiser was providing Heineken at a beer festival ! Le 18/08/05, Gilles van den Peereboom<gillesvdp@...> a crit : > la raison me semble tout simplement tre commerciale : la marque > rubik's ne va pas organiser un tourner et pouvoir y participer (et > tre vu !) avec des produits concurrents, ce serait comme si Budweiser > servait de la Heineken un festival de la bire ! >

Stefan

924. Re: Eastsheen 2x2x2 and 4x4x4
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 15:48:55 -0000

if you need to see the e-mail he sent me I'll post it right here, although I believe the person who sent me the e-mail is part of the group, cuz he mentioned the gala thing...which I thought odd... Here it is: Dear Craig Eastsheen Cubes are not allowed, we do appreciate that a lot of speedcubers prefer their 2x2 and 4x4 but we cannot legally be seen to endorse them. I have copied this reply to our webmaster regarding your registration question. Looking forward to meeting you in November. Best wishes Dear Responder, Thank you very much for a fast reply, but I believe that only the 2x2x2 is better. The two world champions, Frank Morris and Chris Hardwick, both use Rubik's 4x4x4s and 5x5x5s, it is just the 2x2x2 that is smoother. I got the answer to the registration question from the World Championships FAQ page. How do you tell if a cube is a rubik's or not? Because I have been trying to find the serial numbers on my cubes, but cannot tell. I know they all are because I bought them either at a store in the Rubik's packaging, or off of your website, but I do not know how you would tell the difference. Craig Hi Craig Size and quality and if in doubt the internal mechanism (so I'm told !) Dear Responder, I ordered 2 Eastsheens yesterday, and I am not sure when they will get here, but I am pretty sure they are the same size (5 cm x 5 cm x 5 cm) but I should double check. As for quality, how can you tell??? Someone may have lubed up a Rubik's 2x2x2 and made it seem like an Eastsheen, and the internal parts, how can they be different??? Whatever. I am not trying to argue with you, just trying to support speedcubers worldwide. Craig Hi Craig Yes it would be good if you can check. The point really is that people have to be taken on trust and everyone should be using the same cube. There is also the good point that the costs of these events (or Gala's!) is enormous so the Rubik's guys that pay for it (me) don't think we should support companies like East Sheen who trade off our efforts. Maybe you guys can make something of that...I don't know. I kinda figured he meant that, like Gilles said, they can't support another company...P.S. - Gilles, nice analogy...with the Beer...lol... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I think they have a copyright on the design, i.e. the appearance, > > Ah, thanks... it still seems odd, but perhaps not odder than the > colour "Barbie pink" having legal protection. > > Gilles: Yes, in the past I'd also assumed that the reasons for the > restriction were purely commercial, which is why the tournament > organizers' response to Craig puzzled me. > > Mike

929. [Speed cubing group] stickers regulations at the WC
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 19:58:22 +0200

Hi,

In order to clarify the situation, I wrote an email to Rubik's to know
if we can compete with non-Rubik's stickers.
Here is a copy of the e-mail :
-----------------------------------------
Hello,

My name is Gilles and I'm going to take part to the World Championship
in November.
I have a question about the regulations regarding the cubes. I'm
aware that only Rubik's cubes will be allowed at the competition. But
does that also include the stickers ?
I'm afraid the Rubik's Stickers quality is not very good, and I had to
change my stickers in order to cube in good conditions.
I'd like to know if I'll be allowed to compete at the WC with Rubik's
cubes but with other stickers (which do not show any brand, just plain
stickers).

I hope you anderstand my concerns and can give me a quick answer.
Thank you,
Kind regards,
Gilles.
----------------------------------------

I'll forward the answer to you all so that everybody knows :-)
(I hope I didn't shoked them when I told them their stickers quality
was not very good :P)


930. Mini Mat
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 11:45:03 -0700

I just got my new statckmat 'mini' mat in the mail and I love it
already. I don't do cupstacking, so the huge mat was just a bunch of
wasted space. I can actually use my new stackmat AND my computer at
the same time :) Here are some pics.

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/mat1.jpg
http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/mat2.jpg

-Chris


931. Re: [Speed cubing group] Mini Mat
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 20:50:59 +0200

932. Re: Mini Mat
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 18:54:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > I just got my new statckmat 'mini' mat in the mail and I love it > already. I don't do cupstacking, so the huge mat was just a bunch of > wasted space. I can actually use my new stackmat AND my computer at > the same time :) Here are some pics. > > http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/mat1.jpg > http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/mat2.jpg > > -Chris You must have really good accuracy. If that was me, I would be hitting my cube on the computer a few times each average. I agree, the big mats are a lot of wasted space, but I would really need the mini mat to be about 4 inches bigger. I just have my mat sprawled across my whole computer desk, so my mouse works anywhere I need it to work. So when the first picture loaded I saw your monitor and I thought to myself, that is a really sharp looking desktop image. He must have a really good monitor and graphics card. Then I though, no! He must have a really good camera to capture the quality so vividly. Then I thought, no! I must have a good monitor and graphics card in order to see vividness. Then I thought, no! All three items must have come together in order for all of this to happen! Needless to say, I stopped thinking after that. -Dave
933. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Mini Mat
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 12:06:01 -0700

Frank Morris pointed out to me this past weekend that I do put the cube down rather softly. I'm just not one of those people who throw my cube across the room every time I stop the timer :) It works great for my purposes. > So when the first picture loaded I saw your monitor and I thought to > myself, that is a really sharp looking desktop image. He must have a > really good monitor and graphics card. Then I though, no! He must > have a really good camera to capture the quality so vividly. Then I > thought, no! I must have a good monitor and graphics card in order > to see vividness. Then I thought, no! All three items must have > come together in order for all of this to happen! Needless to say, I > stopped thinking after that. Ha. Here you go: Monitor (Hyundai L90D+): http://www.hyundaiq.com/pro_l90d+.asp Camera (Canon PowerShot A85): http://www.steves-digicams.com/2004_reviews/a85.html -Chris
934. Sub 20 :-D
From: "jwillywonkas" <jwillywonkas@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 19:08:20 -0000

I finally got my first sub-20 average today :-D

I'm very excited, it's been a few months since I switched to Gilles
Roux's Method. After a few years of cubing, and while being very close
to 20, I finally did it :-D

That's it...I'm sure a lot of you know how excited I am, since a bunch
of you have been here before.




935. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sub 20 :-D
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 12:13:46 -0700

That's sweet. You should create some videos because I love watching videos of other methods, and I have only seen Roux use the Roux method :) -Chris On 8/18/05, jwillywonkas <jwillywonkas@...> wrote: > I finally got my first sub-20 average today :-D > > I'm very excited, it's been a few months since I switched to Gilles > Roux's Method. After a few years of cubing, and while being very close > to 20, I finally did it :-D > > That's it...I'm sure a lot of you know how excited I am, since a bunch > of you have been here before. > > > > > > > Yahoo! 943. Cube Software From GabbaSoft
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 19:33:28 -0000

Greetings cube fans,

We are working on some 3D puzzle software that should be of interest
to this group in particular. Please drop over to
http://www.gabbasoft.com and head to the downloads section (excuse
the mess, the site is being re-designed). The demo app only supports
cube-shaped puzzles but we are implementing other shapes and puzzle
styles into the finished product. We would appreciate your feedback
on the product. The demo is for PC only and requires DirectX9.0b or
greater to run.

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...

961. Re: [Speed cubing group] stickers regulations at the WC
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 18:33:26 -0500

if anyone from their company has ever checked this site, im pretty sure they now know quite well that their stickers arent very good :-/ On 8/18/05, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...> wrote: > Hi, > > In order to clarify the situation, I wrote an email to Rubik's to know > if we can compete with non-Rubik's stickers. > Here is a copy of the e-mail : > ----------------------------------------- > Hello, > > My name is Gilles and I'm going to take part to the World Championship > in November. > I have a question about the regulations regarding the cubes. I'm > aware that only Rubik's cubes will be allowed at the competition. But > does that also include the stickers ? > I'm afraid the Rubik's Stickers quality is not very good, and I had to > change my stickers in order to cube in good conditions. > I'd like to know if I'll be allowed to compete at the WC with Rubik's > cubes but with other stickers (which do not show any brand, just plain > stickers). > > I hope you anderstand my concerns and can give me a quick answer. > Thank you, > Kind regards, > Gilles. > ---------------------------------------- > > I'll forward the answer to you all so that everybody knows :-) > (I hope I didn't shoked them when I told them their stickers quality > was not very good :P) > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > -- -cubekid

964. Re: [Speed cubing group] stickers regulations at the WC
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 23:57:41 -0000

Hi :D They earn money from selling bad stickers. They know the vinyl is not good. It cracks easily and the glue is rather ridiculous. After some use the stickers feel like floating on the cubies :-P And also the corners are not rounded well so that also helps wearing them down really fast. A plus however is that the colors are not that bad at all ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@g...> wrote: > if anyone from their company has ever checked this site, im pretty > sure they now know quite well that their stickers arent very good :-/ > > On 8/18/05, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > Hi, > > > > In order to clarify the situation, I wrote an email to Rubik's to know > > if we can compete with non-Rubik's stickers. > > Here is a copy of the e-mail : > > ----------------------------------------- > > Hello, > > > > My name is Gilles and I'm going to take part to the World Championship > > in November. > > I have a question about the regulations regarding the cubes. 967. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Software From GabbaSoft
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 00:31:30 -0000

> What's this ?
> A 6 Mbytes Trojan ? :-)
> --
> FD

6 Megabytes *would* be awfully large for a trojan, wouldn't it? :)
Seriously, folks: this is a legitimate gaming application with no
malicious content whatsoever. We at GabbaSoft are excited to get
feedback from the online cubing community on this product. Feel
free to contact us at info@... with any questions/comments
or you may contact me personally at jpittman@.... We look
forward to your input.

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...
www.gabbasoft.com

972. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Software From GabbaSoft
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 01:12:27 -0000

C'mon people what's with the paranoia? I just downloaded it, scanned it for viruses and malware using Norton, and then ran it. Then it didn't post anything to the net. So this is safeware, unless it will crash my hard disk tomorrow. I'll let you know. Besides that, congratz on the best rubik animated game I have ever seen. The gliding clube is nothing compared to the slick graphics this thing employs. One word: I love it! No that's three.. :( The user interface/usability could use some work though (this is for you programmers at gabba): 1. Enable keyboard usage 2. Make very clear visible help. I was fiddling for 5 minutes before I found out I could rotate the cube by dragging with the right mouse button down (which is quite awkward, but functional). Think of a future mac version people, they don't have a right mouse button. Most applets just use the left button on the outside of the cube for this. That's very natural. 3. Why not zoom even further. Look at how Werner Randelshofer really takes that to the max (www.randelshofer.de). You are obviously using OpenGL, so why the heck not? 4. Enable a few of our favourite things: scramble/alg edit, save session times, look at NetCube e.g. from strangepuzzle.com, or my very own RubikTimer at http://tinyurl.com/926l4 5. How about (going wild) saving the solve as a movie (AVI/SWF or whatever). Then you would finally have created something none of the applets has. 6. Oh, and make it possible to disable the animated background. I get dizzy looking at it. Michiel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pyjamamitten" <jpittman2@c...> wrote: > > What's this ? > > A 6 Mbytes Trojan ? :-) > > -- > > FD > > 6 Megabytes *would* be awfully large for a trojan, wouldn't it? :) > Seriously, folks: this is a legitimate gaming application with no > malicious content whatsoever. We at GabbaSoft are excited to get > feedback from the online cubing community on this product. Feel > free to contact us at info@g... with any questions/comments > or you may contact me personally at jpittman@g... We look > forward to your input. > > Regards, > > Jamey Pittman > President > GabbaSoft, Inc. > jpittman@g... > www.gabbasoft.com
973. How to upload videos for free
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 01:24:59 -0000

I saw this question by someone, don't remember it.

Here's the answer: Go to http://www.putfile.com

That's really easy, and totally free, provided you don't use disturbing
language, like e.g. "I ain't cheating, you punks" at the end of your
movie. Just make sure your video is below 10MB. And that's also really
easy. If you have Windows XP home you will find Windows Movie Maker on
your system, which has the 'save movie wizard'. Then you can just
select a size/quality, and bingo!

Apple users should have it somewhere integrated into every program.
Linux Users know Everything, so I won't give them any advice.

Michiel





974. Worst Stickers on a Cube Contest
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 01:48:49 -0000

Hello Everyone,

I'm hearing a few claims of people having the worst set of cube
stickers, well step up and prove it! ;)

For the next two weeks, send me a picture of your most tattered set
of cube stickers, on a cube of course, and I'll send the worst 3
sets of my Tiles. Enter as many cubes as you like, but I'll only
alow one winner per person.

Send your pictures to:

worststickers@...

There is a little more info on my site, www.cubesmith.com , and I'll
be posting the pictures there as well.

Good luck.

Chris

977. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Software From GabbaSoft
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 03:06:48 -0000

I definately agree on the help front, took me a while to figure out how to efficiently see the other side of the cube. But since it's only an alpha release, my guess is that it's just not implemented yet. I DEFINATELY like the video idea. My tweak to it would be to have a twist recorder that plays back twists on a cube (twists saved in a file which can be shared) and then have an option to export the twists as a video. You'd lose the realtime aspect of the solve this way though... And lastly, who doesn't like to see a 9x9x9 with a cool spot pattern? ? http://tinyurl.com/afdr9 -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > C'mon people what's with the paranoia? From: Douglas Reed <dougreed@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 18 Aug 2005 22:42:58 -0500

Doug (Reed) > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Worst stickers on a cube award goes to Cory Loviglio, by the way. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Aug 18, 2005, at 5:33 PM, Sapan Upadhyay wrote: > > > > > if anyone from their company has ever checked this site, im pretty > > > sure they now know quite well that their stickers arent very good :-/ > > > > > > On 8/18/05, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > >> Hi, > > >> > > >> In order to clarify the situation, I wrote an email to Rubik's to > know > > >> if we can compete with non-Rubik's stickers. > > >> Here is a copy of the e-mail : > > >> ----------------------------------------- > > >> Hello, > > >> > > >> My name is Gilles and I'm going to take part to the World > Championship > > >> in November. > > >> I have a question about the regulations regarding the cubes. I'm > > >> aware that only Rubik's cubes will be allowed at the competition. But > > >> does that also include the stickers ? > > >> I'm afraid the Rubik's Stickers quality is not very good, and I > had to > > >> change my stickers in order to cube in good conditions. > > >> I'd like to know if I'll be allowed to compete at the WC with Rubik's > > >> cubes but with other stickers (which do not show any brand, just > plain > > >> stickers). > > >> > > >> I hope you anderstand my concerns and can give me a quick answer. > > >> Thank you, > > >> Kind regards, > > >> Gilles. > > >> ---------------------------------------- > > >> > > >> I'll forward the answer to you all so that everybody knows :-) > > >> (I hope I didn't shoked them when I told them their stickers quality > > >> was not very good :P) > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> Yahoo! Groups Links > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> > > >> > > > > > > > > > -- > > > -cubekid > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 981. Megaminx Solution
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 04:48:53 -0000

He guys,

I've been working on it for a few days as I promised a few folks at
the Dallas tournament I would. I think it's close enough to done to
call it done! Now no one has read it except myself, so I ezpect a few
errors, just let me know and I'll fix them as soon as I can.
Also let me know if you think I went about the whole thing the wrong
way, as I've never really written a guide like this before!

At any rate, it's a 16 page (lots of pictures) word document located here:

http://members.cox.net/swedishlf/Megaminx%20Solution.doc

I also posted a very similar message to the twistypuzzle forums.

Anywhoo, let me know what you think!

-Daniel




982. I just restrung a magic from scratch!!
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 05:15:25 -0000

Wow the magic is addicting! Before I went to Dallas, where Bob Burton
and Doug Li showed me how to restring a magic, I broke one of my red
magics so bad that a tile came out.

Well tonight I completely disassembled that magic and put it back
together. It was actually pretty cool! It was very time consuming,
but in a way good since now I feel *very* comfortable replacing a
string on a magic now.

This actually was also practice for wanting to string a master magic
from scratch. I actually disassembled two of my other magics as well
to prepare for making a master magic, but I wanted to try a regular
magic from scratch first.

I also now realized that I don't know where to get the design for the
master magic. I checked Jaap's page but he doesn't have printouts for
the master magic design. The closest one I could find was the magic
rings, but I would prefer to use the master magic sheets so I can
solve in competitions.

Does anyone know where I can get the graphics for a master magic to
printout so I can build my own?

Thanks,
Chris





983. Re: I just restrung a magic from scratch!!
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 05:21:47 -0000

>
> Does anyone know where I can get the graphics for a master magic to
> printout so I can build my own?
>

The Rubiks.com site has it in its downloads. It's not the silver
background like Matchbox made, but black like the old Magics.

Matt




984. Re: Cube Software From GabbaSoft
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 05:59:36 -0000

The comments so far (onlist and e-mail) have been very productive -
keep 'em coming! The interface requests have been very informative
in particular. Someone had mentioned enabling the keyboard. The
question is: How does one enable keyboard input for a n-size cube.
In other words, how should we implement keyboard controls that work
on both a 2x2x2 and a 9x9x9 cube? We will try to get a new release
out in the next few days to address using the left mouse button to
turn the cube. We will also include a readme.txt file in the next
release that details the cube interface.

For now, here are a few of the less-obvious controls:

- The up/down arrows keys zoom the cube in/out (as does the mouse
wheel.

- You can produce a 180 degree twist of any face by holding down the
left CTRL key down while turning the cube slice.

- You can change the fullscreen resolution from the default of
1024x768 by editing the sys.rc file in the install directory with
any text editor (notepad, for example) and changing the values on
the "set mode 1024 768" line to any fullscreen mode supported by
your video card (examples: "set mode 640 480" or "set mode 1280
1024").

Thanks again for all the comments so far and please continue to pass
along any ideas you have to make this the best puzzle app out there!

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...
http://www.gabbasoft.com






985. New one handed time
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 07:59:54 +0100

I just did my fastest ever onehanded time of 35.59 - only the second time
I've been under 40 seconds. A long way to go but my times are getting
faster now I'm using the L2L2 strategy :)

Duncan

989. Re: Cube Lube
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 12:10:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > Hey All, I went and bought some Cube Lube today (Motomaster Silicon > Lube) and was wondering if you could check out the pictures of it and > tell me if you think it would be ok to use on my cubes. Being possibly overcautious, I use only 100% pure silicone grease from a tube. Petroleum products can damage ABS plastic quickly. (Bitter experience.) However, of the hydrocarbons listed on your spraycan, heptane is the only one that isn't a gas at room temperature and pressure. I assume that the other two are the propellant, and that the silicone is dissolved in the heptane so that it can be expelled from the can as a liquid. If so, the heptane would be expected to evaporate fairly quickly from the lube -- it should have a mild petroleum smell, so you would know when most of it had gone. Maybe I would risk it, so long as it's /your/ cube. ;) Mike
990. Re: Cube Lube
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 12:37:04 -0000

I tested it out on my really bad cube, my first cube, that barely turned and the stickers came off... And now it turns fairly well...considering where it was before...so I am going to lube up my 2 middle-class 3x3s and see what happens before i use my best 3x3... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > Hey All, I went and bought some Cube Lube today (Motomaster Silicon > > Lube) and was wondering if you could check out the pictures of it and > > tell me if you think it would be ok to use on my cubes. > > Being possibly overcautious, I use only 100% pure silicone grease from > a tube. > > Petroleum products can damage ABS plastic quickly. (Bitter > experience.) However, of the hydrocarbons listed on your spraycan, > heptane is the only one that isn't a gas at room temperature and > pressure. I assume that the other two are the propellant, and that the > silicone is dissolved in the heptane so that it can be expelled from > the can as a liquid. If so, the heptane would be expected to evaporate > fairly quickly from the lube -- it should have a mild petroleum smell, > so you would know when most of it had gone. > > Maybe I would risk it, so long as it's /your/ cube. ;) > > Mike
991. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cube Lube
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 15:07:10 +0200

Don't hesitate to lube A LOT.

I bought once a cube from the 80s on ebay, it was really hard to move
the faces and after maybe a week of lubrification every day, it
finally looked like a bad speedcube.

;-)


992. Re: Cube Lube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 13:08:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > Being possibly overcautious, I use only 100% pure silicone grease from > a tube. I think I use something similar, though mine is called "silicone oil": http://www1.conrad.de/xl/2000_2999/2200/2260/2269/226976_BB_00_FB.EPS. jpg I used to spray some spray into a tiny can and then use a paintbrush to paint the insides of my puzzles. Now with the oil this is much easier and it doesn't seem to smell/evaporate at all. Does yours say something about viscosity? Cheers! Stefan

999. Re: Megaminx Solution
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 18:34:40 -0000

Thanks for the kind words guys! I'm pretty sure that Grant and I have very very similar methods. I'm know we do the faces in the same general order, and we do the same OLLE, PLLE, OLLC, PLLC for the last layer. I'll have to try out his algorithms and see if there's any differences there (though at a glance it really only looks like the OLLE algs are different). Essentially the solutions look almost identical though. And I'll add a link to Grant's solution for sure! -Daniel --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > > > http://members.cox.net/swedishlf/Megaminx%20Solution.doc > > Looks good, especially I like the pictures better than Grant's textual > descriptions (though they're ok). And you've reminded me I might have > to replace some of my LL algs with better ones... > > Are there real differences between your solution and Grant's? If so, > maybe you could point them out so they're easier to see for someone > knowing Grant's method already. And you two could link to each other's > solution, too. > > Thanks! > Stefan

Cool, thanks everybody! I only have one more question though, I have the sheet printed out and the magic tiles and strings ready, but how do the tiles line up? The sheet makes it look like I flip the magic horizontally, so that the right end of the front side becomes the left end of the back side. Is that right? That's all I need to string the master magic, so let me know! 1001. Re: Megaminx Solution
From: "Chris Parlette" <mdcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 19:18:25 -0000

That was an awesome solution guide. I've never gotten into the megaminx much, partly because I used to have a 6-color minx, and then with my new stickers the last layer always gave me problems. Your solution was very easy to follow, and the pictures were great. I just used it to solve mine (well, mostly just the last layer part). One thing that would help is having an index somewhere which lists all the moves you gave greek (I think greek) symbols for, and possibly having the index in a seperate file or something. I say this because it was only a very minor hassle to read the move, then go back and have to look for the different symbols to find the moves. Again, that was just a very tiny issue. Overall, I thought it was great, and maybe I'll start minxing more to put up some good times in Orlando. Thanks again. -Chris Parlette --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Thanks for the kind words guys! > > I'm pretty sure that Grant and I have very very similar methods. 1002. Re: I just restrung a magic from scratch!!
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 19:57:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Wow the magic is addicting! Before I went to Dallas, where Bob Burton > and Doug Li showed me how to restring a magic, I broke one of my red > magics so bad that a tile came out. > > Well tonight I completely disassembled that magic and put it back > together. It was actually pretty cool! It was very time consuming, > but in a way good since now I feel *very* comfortable replacing a > string on a magic now. > > This actually was also practice for wanting to string a master magic > from scratch. I actually disassembled two of my other magics as well > to prepare for making a master magic, but I wanted to try a regular > magic from scratch first. > > I also now realized that I don't know where to get the design for the > master magic. I checked Jaap's page but he doesn't have printouts for > the master magic design. The closest one I could find was the magic > rings, but I would prefer to use the master magic sheets so I can > solve in competitions. > > Does anyone know where I can get the graphics for a master magic to > printout so I can build my own? > > Thanks, > Chris Hey Chris, Congrats on restringing your 2x4 magic. I just finished stringing my master magic, but it was a lot of work. I messed up quite a bit, but heres some tips that will save you time: The strings do NOT start at the top left corner of the tiles, they start at the bottom left corner. The loop that you will creat should work this way: Hold the MM with the linked rings facing you. Fold the top half onto the back of the bottom. This is important to get correct, or else the magic will be upside down, thus unsolvable. If you have anymore questions, feel free to email me: pjgat09@... Good luck!! Peter Greenwood
1003. how does the back relate to the front of a master magic?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 20:27:51 -0000

Hey everyone,

Can someone with a master magic take a picture of the back and the
front, or make a short video where you flip it over?

Or can you just describe how the back side looks in relation to the
front side?

Thanks,
Chris





1004. New Version Of Cube Demo Available From GabbaSoft
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 20:44:37 -0000

A new version of the Cube Demo application is availible from our
website (http://www.gabbasoft.com). It addresses two of the smaller
issues brought up by members of this group:

- You may now rotate the view of the cube with the left mouse button
by click-dragging any empty area of the screen (right click still
works as before).

- There is a readme.txt file included in the installation directory
that describes the available controls.

You should uninstall your existing copy of the software before
installing this one. Keep the feedback coming!

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...
http://www.gabbasoft.com




1005. Re: New Version Of Cube Demo Available From GabbaSoft
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 21:26:33 -0000

Guys! Nevermind that that post was sorta spam. The demo at their site is great! U can test out cubes up to 9x9x9 in very nice 3D. A bit like java applets but much nicer graphics. For those who can't wait for the 6x6x6 olympicube it's well worth checking out. Maybe i should speak to those guys about implementing super-supercubing. Hehe ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@g...> wrote: > A new version of the Cube Demo application is availible from our > website (http://www.gabbasoft.com). It addresses two of the smaller > issues brought up by members of this group: > > - You may now rotate the view of the cube with the left mouse button > by click-dragging any empty area of the screen (right click still > works as before). > > - There is a readme.txt file included in the installation directory > that describes the available controls. > > You should uninstall your existing copy of the software before > installing this one. Keep the feedback coming! > > Regards, > > Jamey Pittman > President > GabbaSoft, Inc. > jpittman@g... > http://www.gabbasoft.com

1008. Guinness Records
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 17:19:09 -0600

Hi Everyone,

I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records
recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the
Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's quite
interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a lot of
other odd things.

Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a
difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a 12.5x
time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, 2004.
However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue.
Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would
undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place.
It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a world
championship are valid.

I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break 12.11
seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do it. In
the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us speed
cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my
suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding the
world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the
authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last two
years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the
world records, we really shouldn't help them out.

And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which no one
of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that is
respected by the community?

Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the most
likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this is
Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this
e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't foresee a
heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of line, please let me know,
but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 seconds shows disrespect
for the work that I have done these last two years and undermine the
work that all competition organizers have put in and so I submit to you
not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology



1009. Re: New Version Of Cube Demo Available From GabbaSoft
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 00:36:25 -0000

You must have DirectX 9.0b or newer installed on your machine to run this program. You can download it from Microsoft here: http://www.microsoft.com/windows/directx/ Regards, Jamey Pittman President GabbaSoft, Inc. jpittman@... http://www.gabbasoft.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I can't run the program... > A message says that d3d9.dll was not found...
1010. First sub-30s average! Woo hoo!!!
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 00:42:53 -0000

I thought it would never happen, but yesterday it did! I got my first
sub-30s average EVER! :)

Here are the details:
Average: 29.56s
Individual times: 30.36, 32.15, (36.94), 28.72, 26.81, 31.63, 30.24,
29.06, 28.84, (26.31), 26.64, 31.13.

I've written a blog entry about it on my site:
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com/

Jasmine

1018. Re: how does the back relate to the front of a master magic?
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 03:33:41 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > Can someone with a master magic take a picture of the back and the > front, or make a short video where you flip it over? > > Or can you just describe how the back side looks in relation to the > front side? > > Thanks, > Chris Hi Chris (again), Check out this page first: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=505 Thats how the front and back will look. Now to make it like the normal master magics, heres how the front and backs line up: If you are looking at the back side, the tile on the lower left corner would be the tile with the signature. Hope this helps!! Peter Greenwood
1019. Re: Guinness Records
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 04:43:50 -0000

Hey! The Guiness requirements for setting speedcubing world records are just outrageous if u ask me. In which other sport or discipline do they require to use brand new equipment that has not been customised for the competitor. I would guess none. What if speeding with cars on a closed circuit should be done with a car straight from the factory, not tested or modified in any way whatsoever. Or shooting w guns that are not heavily prepared to fit the sportsman. No, this is really so stupid that i can't believe people with any sense at all has made it up. I also believe that WCA should contact Guiness and try to make them think logically about this, which they obviously haven't done until now. It's not a big deal for us speedcubers belonging to the community that the book of world records doesn't recognize all times recognized by the WCA. The ptoblem is that the rest of the people will seriously believe that faster than 16.53 hasn't been done in controlled environment. And that is really too stupid. Ok, cubing shouldn't be taken too seriously, but a time set in controlled environment by the sports recognized association should indeed be accepted by Guiness as well. Another serious implication of this is that the World Championships will moist likely always be sponsored by Seventowns. And we all know that they only acceopt their own branded cubes/puzzles where applicable. So they do allow of coz any kind of megaminx simply cause they don't produce thir own ones. But my point then is that Guiness in fact as a consequence only accept world records set with Rubiks.com branded products. Those who are fast with say Eastsheen 2x2x2/4x4x4/5x5x5 and solve faster than world record set with the mentioned branded products in competitions acknowledged by the WCA will automatically not be accepted. Adidas does indeed sponsor many events (not as sole sponsor of coz) but that doesn't mean tracking world records have to be set with Adidas shoes !!! Grrrrr ... Ok, that's enough emotions over this issue. I feel really sorry for those who won't have their achievements acknowledged, when it was truly deserved :-( -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Guinness's lack of respect for the cubing community and especially the > WCA offends me. > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > > > I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records > > recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the > > Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's quite > > interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a lot of > > other odd things. > > > > Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a > > difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a 12.5x > > time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, 2004. > > However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. > > Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would > > undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place. > > It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a world > > championship are valid. > > > > I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break 12.11 > > seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do it. In > > the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us speed > > cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my > > suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding the > > world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the > > authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last two > > years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the > > world records, we really shouldn't help them out. > > > > And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which no one > > of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that is > > respected by the community? > > > > Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the most > > likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this is > > Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this > > e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't foresee a > > heated debate and many flames. Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 05:05:46 -0000

Hey Peter, Thanks for the help with the master magic! It's pretty late now, but I'm going to try to string it tomorrow. I'll let everyone know how it goes. Thanks again! Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > Can someone with a master magic take a picture of the back and the > > front, or make a short video where you flip it over? > > > > Or can you just describe how the back side looks in relation to the > > front side? > > > > Thanks, > > Chris > > > Hi Chris (again), > > Check out this page first: > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=505 > > Thats how the front and back will look. Now to make it like the > normal master magics, heres how the front and backs line up: > If you are looking at the back side, the tile on the lower left > corner would be the tile with the signature. > > Hope this helps!! > > Peter Greenwood
1022. magic harmonic
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 05:09:30 -0000

Hey everyone,

I just took an average for doing the magic harmonic. This is where
you start with unlinked rings, solve to linked rings, then undo back
to unlinked rings. So you start the timer and pick up the magic,
solve then unsolve, then once the magic is solved again you stop the
timer. I got the idea from cupstacking, since for the cycle you start
and end in the same configuration.

Anyway the times were:
3.77 3.34 3.28 4.30 (3.11) (5.11) 3.20 4.35 3.50 3.54 4.13 4.42 = 3.78

Bob Burton and I were trying this out some too in Dallas.

Anyway if you're a magic solver and haven't tried this it's pretty
fun, give it a shot! I know sub-3 will be possible with practice for
a single time, though not sure of the limits for an average.

Chris

happens to get into the book, maybe not.

other night.

1028. [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 08:58:26 -0000

Cupstacking has the same problem, their official cycle record is 7.43 I think, but the Guinness record is only about 8.xx seconds. Emily holds both records, so they're unhappy but not too terribly so about it. I think Guinness just isn't as interested in our "weird" or "off-beat" sports. So if their rules don't fit our sport it doesn't really matter much to them. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Agree with everything said so far. 1029. Re: Guinness Records
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 10:35:52 -0000

I think you're totally right, Tyson! Have you been in contact with Guinness, trying to make them accept 12.11?? I agree that, if they don't accept a world record set during a WCA authorized cometition, we (the cubers) shall not cooperate with them at all. /Gunnar Krig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records > recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the > Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's quite > interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a lot of > other odd things. > > Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a > difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a 12.5x > time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, 2004. > However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. > Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would > undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place. > It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a world > championship are valid. > > I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break 12.11 > seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do it. In > the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us speed > cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my > suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding the > world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the > authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last two > years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the > world records, we really shouldn't help them out. > > And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which no one > of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that is > respected by the community? > > Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the most > likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this is > Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this > e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't foresee a > heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of line, please let me know, > but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 seconds shows disrespect > for the work that I have done these last two years and undermine the > work that all competition organizers have put in and so I submit to you > not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

1031. Re: how does the back relate to the front of a master magic?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 11:42:17 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, pjgat09 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > Can someone with a master magic take a picture of the back and the > > front, or make a short video where you flip it over? > > > > Or can you just describe how the back side looks in relation to the > > front side? > > > > Thanks, > > Chris > > > Hi Chris (again), > > Check out this page first: > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=505 Just a small addition: Between those first two pictures the puzzle was flipped left-right, i.e. not up-down. Of course for solving it doesn't matter. Btw, rubiks.com made a mistake, don't know whether they've fixed it now. The way it was you couldn't just print both sides on the same sheet. Just look at the twistypuzzles pictures how to arrange the tiles. Stefan

I got the idea from cupstacking, since for the cycle you start > and end in the same configuration. > > Anyway the times were: > 3.77 3.34 3.28 4.30 (3.11) (5.11) 3.20 4.35 3.50 3.54 4.13 4.42 = 3. 78 I just tried it and I've beaten both your best and your worst time :-) 3.81 3.63 3.29 3.88 4.75 5.09 3.10 3.60 3.93 (2.86) 7.48 (DNF) => 4.26 average Cheers! 1035. Re: Guinness Records
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 12:21:51 -0000

I don't think this is really worth getting too worried about. Who really cares what's in Guinness anyway? We all know that speedcubing.com is the place to go for checking speedcubing records. I often cube on the train and people always ask me what the world record is, and of course I say 12.11 seconds. If anyone did contradict me and say they read 16.53 seconds in Guinness, they I'd tell them that the book is out of date and 16.53 seconds has been broken many times in official competitions since Worlds 2003. BTW, http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/ also has a records section with cool filters so you can sort by puzzle, year and even by person to see all the official times set by particular solvers. Another cool thing which the WCA site has which speedcubing.com doesn't (but please correct me if I'm wrong) is a list of 3x3x3 official rankings combined across years - this is probably the list I'm most interested in because you can see where you rank relative to solves in all competitions across all years (including the 1982 championships!). BTW, it's actually not quite all years at the moment though because it hasn't yet been updated to include 2005 comps. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Cupstacking has the same problem, their official cycle record is 7.43 > I think, but the Guinness record is only about 8.xx seconds. > > Emily holds both records, so they're unhappy but not too terribly so > about it. > > I think Guinness just isn't as interested in our "weird" or "off-beat" > sports. So if their rules don't fit our sport it doesn't really > matter much to them. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > <duncan@d...> wrote: > > Agree with everything said so far. Couldnt someone arrange with them to > be their > > official representative. > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@h...> > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Saturday, August 20, 2005 7:48 AM > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records > > > > > > > 12.11 is The Official World Record, it just isn't the Guiness Official > > > World Record. 1037. Re: Guinness Records
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

R*0.8" because small misalignments are allowed and this way I could beat your 27 with my 26.8. But I could be wrong. Wait, actually why only save at the end? I could for example write "U*0.9 R*0.8" which works very well cause my cubes forgives some misalignments. Ok, now I'm sure that this is the reason. Cheers! Stefan
