--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records > recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the > Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's quite > interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a lot of > other odd things. > > Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a > difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a 12.5x > time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, 2004. > However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. > Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would > undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place. > It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a world > championship are valid. > > I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break 12.11 > seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do it. In > the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us speed > cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my > suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding the > world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the > authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last two > years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the > world records, we really shouldn't help them out. > > And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which no one > of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that is > respected by the community? > > Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the most > likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this is > Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this > e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't foresee a > heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of line, please let me know, > but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 seconds shows disrespect > for the work that I have done these last two years and undermine the > work that all competition organizers have put in and so I submit to you > not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology I think that there isn't any international laws, which say that Guinness has the monopoly in deciding which records are official. And I must say that my German Open 2005 15.00 sec. solve was lucky.
1043. Re: Guinness Records
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 17:32:28 -0000

Hey Tyson, I really can't be bothered about the cubing records Guinness recognises. Someone else once said (it may have been you), Guinness sucks when you are interested in cube records. So if people in the community know that Guinness sucks when it comes to cubing records, Guinness will certainly not set a 'standard' for what official records really are. You say: 'Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place.' You can say the same thing now about Guinness not recognising the 12.11 records. If you think I am wrong, please tell me why. Bye! Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records > recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the > Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's quite > interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a lot of > other odd things. > > Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a > difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a 12.5x > time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, 2004. > However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. > Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would > undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place. > It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a world > championship are valid. > > I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break 12.11 > seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do it. In > the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us speed > cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my > suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding the > world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the > authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last two > years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the > world records, we really shouldn't help them out. > > And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which no one > of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that is > respected by the community? > > Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the most > likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this is > Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this > e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't foresee a > heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of line, please let me know, > but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 seconds shows disrespect > for the work that I have done these last two years and undermine the > work that all competition organizers have put in and so I submit to you > not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1044. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 11:44:53 -0600

I'm not worried about ourselves. Cubers are smart enough to know what's recognized by what and who has authority. However, think about the publicity during and after the WC 2005? Think about how many non-cubers will think, hmm... what's the world record? Where will they turn? Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Aug 20, 2005, at 11:32 AM, Jol van Noort wrote: > Hey Tyson, > > I really can't be bothered about the cubing records Guinness > recognises. Someone else once said (it may have been you), Guinness > sucks when you are interested in cube records. > > So if people in the community know that Guinness sucks when it comes > to cubing records, Guinness will certainly not set a 'standard' for > what official records really are. > > You say: 'Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, > which would undermine the authority of all of the other competitions > taking place.' > > You can say the same thing now about Guinness not recognising the > 12.11 records. > > If you think I am wrong, please tell me why. > > Bye! > > Jol. > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Hi Everyone, >> >> I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records >> recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the >> Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's > quite >> interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a > lot of >> other odd things. >> >> Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a >> difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a > 12.5x >> time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, > 2004. >> However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. >> Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which > would >> undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking > place. >> It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a > world >> championship are valid. >> >> I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break > 12.11 >> seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do > it. In >> the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us > speed >> cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my >> suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding > the >> world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the >> authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last > two >> years. 1046. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Version Of Cube Demo Available From GabbaSoft
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 23:50:51 +0530

Could you give an option to keep just the clicking sound on and the music off. because i sometimes get bored by the music but i still like when the cube "clicks" when i turn it. Also one more thing. Could you keep a keyboard shortcut like the shift key or something for turning two layers at a time. I mean like when i prs shift and the right layer the rt layer plus the middle should turn simultaneously. This is more quicker than turning the left side in the opposite directn and then turning the whole cube again. Anyways the software is awesome! 1047. Re: Guinness Records
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 18:24:25 -0000

Hi Jasmine :-) Yes i guess i was a bit wound up when i wrote my post. But the truth remains that many people do regard the Guiness book of world records as the De Facto reference for world records. And as such Guiness should have fair and reasonable regulations for accepting world records. Yes, we speedcubers know about all those useful resources on the net about cubing. I'm not worried about us. I'm worried about the 99.9% of the rest of the ppl who will seriously believe that 16.53 is the best. And who knows, if they see better record somewehere they might think it's fake. I think it's actually a semi serious matter. Well, there are worse things happening in the world than this ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I don't think this is really worth getting too worried about. Who > really cares what's in Guinness anyway? We all know that > speedcubing.com is the place to go for checking speedcubing records. > > I often cube on the train and people always ask me what the world > record is, and of course I say 12.11 seconds. If anyone did contradict > me and say they read 16.53 seconds in Guinness, they I'd tell them > that the book is out of date and 16.53 seconds has been broken many > times in official competitions since Worlds 2003. > > BTW, http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/ also has a records section > with cool filters so you can sort by puzzle, year and even by person > to see all the official times set by particular solvers. Another cool > thing which the WCA site has which speedcubing.com doesn't (but please > correct me if I'm wrong) is a list of 3x3x3 official rankings combined > across years - this is probably the list I'm most interested in > because you can see where you rank relative to solves in all > competitions across all years (including the 1982 championships!). > BTW, it's actually not quite all years at the moment though because it > hasn't yet been updated to include 2005 comps. > > Jasmine > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> > wrote: > > Cupstacking has the same problem, their official cycle record is 7.43 > > I think, but the Guinness record is only about 8.xx seconds. > > > > Emily holds both records, so they're unhappy but not too terribly so > > about it. > > > > I think Guinness just isn't as interested in our "weird" or "off- beat" > > sports. So if their rules don't fit our sport it doesn't really > > matter much to them. > > > > Chris > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" > > <duncan@d...> wrote: > > > Agree with everything said so far. The thing about Guiness having > > to have > > > an official representative there though Ive never really understood > > that ... > > > surely they dont have a Guiness employee at every athletics even, > > swimming > > > race, soccer game, cricket match etc etc. So it seem to me they > > must rely > > > on appointed representatives. Couldnt someone arrange with them to > > be their > > > official representative. > > > > > > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > > From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@h...> > > > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > > > Sent: Saturday, August 20, 2005 7:48 AM > > > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records > > > > > > > > > > 12.11 is The Official World Record, it just isn't the Guiness > Official > > > > World Record. I think Guiness has to have someone present when it > > > > happens to get into the book, maybe not. > > > > > > > > It' funny I was just discussing this very topic with my > girlfriend the > > > > other night. > > > > > > > > -mike grimsley
1048. Re: Guinness Records
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 18:30:53 -0000

Hi ! A _WILD_ guess (lol) is that all data presented is extracted from the same table in the database. So basically the number of moves is then treated like it was a time. Hence the 2 decimals in the listing on the webpage. Have fun! -Per PS! I haven't managed to use 23.9 or 23.97 moves yet ... hahaha :-P > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > > > BTW, http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/ also has a records > section > > > > I never knew such a site existed! It is pretty cool. I'm not sure > why the fewest moves > > records need to be listed to 2 decimal places though! > > Maybe that's so I can end my solution with let's say "... R*0.8" > because small misalignments are allowed and this way I could beat your > 27 with my 26.8. But I could be wrong. > > Wait, actually why only save at the end? I could for example write > "U*0.9 R*0.8" which works very well cause my cubes forgives some > misalignments. Ok, now I'm sure that this is the reason. > > Cheers! > Stefan

Well i cant understand the fuss about this. Does it matter to the layman that the world record is 4 seconds off than the real one? Anyways 16 seconds is far too fast for them and they would be as amazed by a 16 second or a 12 second or for that matter even a 25 second solve. and if someone is really curious he'll get to know the real record quite quiclky. But the truth > remains that many people do regard the Guiness book of world records > as the De Facto reference for world records. 1051. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 20:43:36 +0200

>From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@...> >To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> >Sent: Saturday, August 20, 2005 7:44 PM >Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records > >I'm not worried about ourselves. Cubers are smart enough to know >what's recognized by what and who has authority. However, think about >the publicity during and after the WC 2005? Think about how many >non-cubers will think, hmm... what's the world record? Where will they >turn? Hey Tyson, Guinness is just nothing "professional", and I don't trust Guinness at all. This is not even official. Those are just people who try to make money by selling books. The only Guinness I would trust is beer, the rest is just "une grosse plaisanterie" as frenchies say. Would you trust Guinness for tracks and fields records ? You would be wrong. I just made a quick check on : http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com for WRs on 100m, 110m hurdles, and 5000m. They are ALL wrong : - WR on 100m has been beaten last june, this is not updated ; - 110m hurdle has been made again by a chinese during the last olympics in august 2004 : no mention about it, we still have Colin Powell only as the recordholder ; - the time for 5000m is wrong again, despite the current record being 1 year and a half old. If I want to know the truth, I don't look into the guinness. I *drink* a Guinness, and click on http://www.athlerecords.net/ Actually, Guinness is full of mistakes, in many fields, some being rather funny like in mathematics. I would say that : - non-cubers who don't really care about cubing, *may* look in the Guinness and find the wrong rubik record... so what ? - non-cubers that may get interested into cubing will use Google and finally reach speedcubing.com. And they will just trust it and regard Guinness as b******t ; - cubers just look at SC.com and the site is just great. So I would just not bother with the Guinness book. This book is just not serious at all. In all sports, only the federations keep track of records. Guinness is to serious records what your local newspaper is to serious scientific publications. Just almost nothing. -- Francois. On Aug 20, 2005, at 11:32 AM, Jol van Noort wrote: > Hey Tyson, > > I really can't be bothered about the cubing records Guinness > recognises. Someone else once said (it may have been you), Guinness > sucks when you are interested in cube records. > > So if people in the community know that Guinness sucks when it comes > to cubing records, Guinness will certainly not set a 'standard' for > what official records really are. > > You say: 'Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, > which would undermine the authority of all of the other competitions > taking place.' > > You can say the same thing now about Guinness not recognising the > 12.11 records. > > If you think I am wrong, please tell me why. > > Bye! > > Jol. > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Hi Everyone, >> >> I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records >> recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the >> Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's > quite >> interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a > lot of >> other odd things. >> >> Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a >> difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a > 12.5x >> time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, > 2004. >> However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. >> Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which > would >> undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking > place. >> It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a > world >> championship are valid. >> >> I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break > 12.11 >> seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do > it. In >> the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us > speed >> cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my >> suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding > the >> world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the >> authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last > two >> years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the >> world records, we really shouldn't help them out. >> >> And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which > no one >> of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that > is >> respected by the community? >> >> Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the > most >> likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this > is >> Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this >> e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't > foresee a >> heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of line, please let me > know, >> but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 seconds shows > disrespect >> for the work that I have done these last two years and undermine > the >> work that all competition organizers have put in and so I submit > to you >> not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS Computer puzzle game Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Online puzzle games Puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---- YAHOO! 1061. Re: magic harmonic (one-handed magic)
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 21:53:47 -0000

So I took an average. You did it, so it forced me. :P 3.74 3.50 (DNF) 4.14 3.05 4.03 3.08 6.71 4.74 3.55 3.71 (2.97) => 4.03 Can't get much closer to sub-4 average, eh? That 2.97 solve was my only sub-3...and that 6.71 my only solve over 4.74 :( killed it. :( ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Bob you've also gotten me into one-handed magicing as well ;-) > > Here's my best average so far, and it even has my best time in it > too. > > 4.35 (DNF) 6.31 5.34 4.68 6.75 5.07 5.26 4.88 (4.34) (7.56) 6.68 > 6.12 = 5.54 > > My best time is 4.34 so far, can't wait for sub-4! > > Chris

1064. Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 00:20:03 -0000

I often cube on the train. Sometimes no one pays any attention, but
sometimes they do. Tonight was definitely the later. A group of four
girls sitting across from me let out audible gasps when I finished a
solve. I like to take any opportunity to promote cubing, so if anyone
shows any interest on the train (or anywhere!) I'll offer to do them
another demo and ask them to do the scramble themselves (so they know
it wasn't 'set up' and also to get them involved). I did a few more
3x3x3 demos for them and they were very impressed. Then I whipped out
the 4x4x4 and got them to scramble that too. :)

Later during the train trip, another group of people got on. They were
pretty amazed ("Oh my goodness! Did you just solve that thing?!") and
so I handed them my cube. I did several demos as various different
people in train scrambled my cube. They timed one of the solves (32
seconds) and then I got an applause from half the train carriage. When
the train was approaching the final stop, which was also my stop,
there was one guy left from the group. He'd been further down the
carriage and hadn't actually seen my solves, he'd just heard his
friends talking ("Wow! She just solved that in 32 seconds!") So
obviously I offered to do a demo for him. :) He was completely blown
away and asked me what I did. He then asked me if I was looking for a
job and gave me his contact details!

BTW, I beat my PB single solve tonight too - 22.23 seconds. :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 00:42:16 -0000

The buttons (yellow ones) in the center, is the yellow part just like
a sticker on rubik's cube??? Is it needed to push the button???

Quite response needed,

Craig

blindfold cubing? I am certainly one of the oldest, as I am 53. Are
there any blindfold cubists who are older? And who is the youngest?
J Bennett Orlando?




1067. RE: [Speed cubing group] Age limits for blindfold cubing?
From: "Bill MCGAUGH" <bmcgaugh49@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 20 Aug 2005 21:07:37 -0700

I am 56...my best time blindfolded is 4:46, and I average about 7 minutes...next tournament, I will try it for an official time...my best 3x3x3 average under normal conditions is 24.55... and my best competition solve is 23.75... 1068. Version 0.03.004 of Cube Demo Available With Music Mute
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 04:46:03 -0000

A new version of the Cube Demo is now available from GabbaSoft with
the ability to turn the background music on/off. Remember to
uninstall any existing version from your computer before installing
this one. Thanks to everyone who has contributed their suggestions
and ideas. Please continue to send us your feedback and help us to
make the best puzzle game out there!

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...
http://www.gabbasoft.com

1070. RE: [Speed cubing group] Age limits for blindfold cubing?
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 07:14:21 +0100 (BST)

I am 46. I am not a cubist. Yet I can solve 2*2*2, 3*3*3 and 4*4*4 blindfolded. My best 3*3*3 blindfold time is 6 min xx sec. My average may be around 10 min. Bernett orlando is 9 years old. his best timing for 3*3*3 blindfolded is 3 min 25 sec. His 3*3*3 average is 28.xx sec. 1075. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 11:18:37 -0000

I already have a very good job. We all know that anyone can learn to solve the cube if they have the patience and commitment, but it's cool that non-cubers assume that anyone who can solve the cube pretty quickly is obviously brilliant! I think we should use all use this to our advantage and put it in our CVs. I have done this in the past (buried somewhere after educational qualifications and employment history) and at one job interview it was the first thing they commented on! 1076. Re: Brainstring puzzle?
From: "d_can02_03" <howru2day@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 11:20:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@o...> wrote: > Has anyone seen this puzzle before, or does anyone have one? > > http://www.brainstring.com/html/framex.html > > I'm curious about it... I have one. I didn't know that there are so many possibilities. Thanks for showing me the web page. I was just solving it with all strings streight not touching each other. It was pretty boring. Now I'll have more fun playing with it:) Right now I would say if you are good at 3-D seeing brainstring should be pretty easy. I'll try out the solutions on the page, where the strings touch each other and let you know, if it's more difficult or not.
1077. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 11:25:15 -0000

Other thing I meant to say is that I definitely recommend cubing in public. It's valuable pre-competition preparation. I get nervous performing in competitions and my hands shake a bit and this has an adverse effect on my times. My best time at my last competition was 4-5 seconds slower than my average at the time. :( I'm hoping that my public cubing experience over the past month will help me feel less nervous in competition! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I already have a very good job. > > We all know that anyone can learn to solve the cube if they have the > patience and commitment, but it's cool that non-cubers assume that > anyone who can solve the cube pretty quickly is obviously brilliant! I > think we should use all use this to our advantage and put it in our > CVs. I have done this in the past (buried somewhere after educational > qualifications and employment history) and at one job interview it was > the first thing they commented on! > > Jasmine > http://speeducber.blogspot.com > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar > <sachinss@g...> wrote: > > Thats great jasmine! Sometimes no one pays any attention, but > > > sometimes they do. Tonight was definitely the later. A group of four > > > girls sitting across from me let out audible gasps when I finished a > > > solve. I like to take any opportunity to promote cubing, so if anyone > > > shows any interest on the train (or anywhere!) I'll offer to do them > > > another demo and ask them to do the scramble themselves (so they know > > > it wasn't 'set up' and also to get them involved). I did a few more > > > 3x3x3 demos for them and they were very impressed. Then I whipped out > > > the 4x4x4 and got them to scramble that too. :) > > > > > > Later during the train trip, another group of people got on. They were > > > pretty amazed ("Oh my goodness! Did you just solve that thing?!") and > > > so I handed them my cube. I did several demos as various different > > > people in train scrambled my cube. They timed one of the solves (32 > > > seconds) and then I got an applause from half the train carriage. When > > > the train was approaching the final stop, which was also my stop, > > > there was one guy left from the group. He'd been further down the > > > carriage and hadn't actually seen my solves, he'd just heard his > > > friends talking ("Wow! She just solved that in 32 seconds!") So > > > obviously I offered to do a demo for him. :) He was completely blown > > > away and asked me what I did. He then asked me if I was looking for a > > > job and gave me his contact details! > > > > > > BTW, I beat my PB single solve tonight too - 22.23 seconds. :) > > > > > > Jasmine > > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1078. Challenge
From: "peppecuber" <peppecuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 12:44:47 -0000

Five months ago I traveled to So Paulo (I'm brazilian)and went to a
wholesale store and, as we know, they sell only big quantities of one
product. The problem was that I saw a very nice key chain cube and
they wouldn't sell me one or two of it. They could only sell, imagine,
at least 400 unities. I talked to the manager and told him how I would
like to buy only one and that I use to solve the cube. You what? he
said. I solve the cube, I answered. He scrambled one, hung it by the
chain and challenging me said: As I never saw one solving this, if you
do it it's yours. My wife started laughing and the cube is now mine.
Good sunday to all.




1079. Weird instance
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 14:09:03 -0000

the xvb (03:44:48): craziest thing happened yesterday
the xvb (03:45:01): i was at dorney park (an amusement park)
the xvb (03:45:15): and i was waiting in line with my cube (of
course), and this kid was asking me about it and stuff
the xvb (03:45:18): and then he said he had one
the xvb (03:45:23): i was like, oh, okay kid
the xvb (03:45:46): and i see him about 10 hours later when i'm
sitting on a ride, and he is holding a scrambled cube
the xvb (03:45:53): waving it around
the xvb (03:46:03): so when i got off the ride, he gave it to me to
solve for him
the xvb (03:46:11): and i solved it while he was on the ride
the xvb (03:46:18): and then gave it to him
the xvb (03:46:34): but i was wondering, where the hell did he get
that cube from?!?
the xvb (03:46:35): lol

Weird?

Oh, and btw, solving a cube at 70 mph on something with a 280 foot
drop is harder than I remember.

~ Bob

1081. I have a master magic :-D
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 15:10:37 -0000

Hey everyone,

I finished building my master magic last night, and wow this thing is
cool!

I took the tiles from a harry potter and a simpsons magic, printed out
the sheets from rubiks.com and built one from scratch (thanks everyone
for the help with orienting the tiles).

My fastest time so far is 5.33 seconds :-D So I need more practice,
but man this thing is cool!

All told the cost of this magic was $10, the cost of the two magics I
used, plus the time spent to string it. I hear that master magics
cost $40 or so, so if you're like me and don't have $40 to spend, buy
two magics and make one!

Chris

P.S. Hey Peter, did you also make one from scratch? Or were you
stringing one you already had to make it move better? Let us know!

1086. Re: [Speed cubing group] I have a master magic :-D
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 13:51:26 -0400

I've got a master magic now, too. All of this talk about magic inspired me to pull my old master magic out of the box. I thought that it had broken about 7 years ago, and never knew how to fix it. After closer examination, I determined that some of the tiles had been twisted, but none of the strings were broken. I was able to reassemble it with the directions on Jaap's page. On 8/21/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I finished building my master magic last night, and wow this thing is > cool! > > I took the tiles from a harry potter and a simpsons magic, printed out > the sheets from rubiks.com and built one from scratch (thanks everyone > for the help with orienting the tiles).
1087. Re: Cubing on the train
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 17:57:26 -0000

I cube on the train all the time. Sometimes nobody cares just like you
say but sometimes people love it. One night I had the whole train
clapping just like you had and the a guy in his 20's came up and said
he solves too. I handed him my cube and he busted out a 41. The entire
train of people could hardly believe it and they were all fired up.

That was the best train ride ever!

-mike





1088. Tile set Recall
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 18:40:37 -0000

It has come to my attention that some of my recently sent out Tile
sets did not have a white backing applied.

If you received a set of my Tiles and they where not white on the
back, under the liner where the adhesive is, then please contact me so
I can send you a replacement set.

I don't think that there are more that 20 sets that shipped like this,
but I would rather replace them than have them being used like this.

The colors on the tiles are not opaque by themselves and need that
white coat in order to not seem transparent.

Thanks, to Dan Harris (cubestation.uk) for finding this error.

Thanks
Chris
www.cubesmith.com




1089. Re: I have a master magic :-D
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 19:17:28 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I finished building my master magic last night, and wow this thing is > cool! > > I took the tiles from a harry potter and a simpsons magic, printed out > the sheets from rubiks.com and built one from scratch (thanks everyone > for the help with orienting the tiles). > > My fastest time so far is 5.33 seconds :-D So I need more practice, > but man this thing is cool! > > All told the cost of this magic was $10, the cost of the two magics I > used, plus the time spent to string it. Congrats!! but bewarned, the MM's are highly addictive ;) Before i made my master magic from scratch too, but it took a long time cuz the only time i have ever played with on before was at HM. and even tht was for like 5 min. It took me several hours because i messed up quite a few times. First i had to figure out (by my self) how the tiles lined up. Then i started stringing, but i strung it the normal way, so of course it didnt work. After trying like 10 different ways to wire it, i just gave up. (it was like 5 am) The next day i re thought everything and finally put it together I agree, if you dont have $40 to spend, make one!! My PB is now 3.59, and its only like the 3-4 day ive had it!! (told you it was addictive) I hope to break 3 sec soon...(maybe) Good luck with your MM!! Hope you enjoy it! Peter Greenwood

1099. Off topic - but still about crazy obsessions
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 21 Aug 2005 21:26:43 -0000

This isn't about cubing, but it is about crazy obsessions, and there
is a vague cube reference at the end.

I'm currently watching a doco about the "sport" of competitive eating.
It is hilarious. They were talking to the head PR guy from the
Internation Federation of Competitive Eating (!) Yes, there really is
an international association for competitive eating!! I googled and
found it here: http://www.ifoce.com/

Anyway, the guy was saying that it really is a sport and they've been
trying for ages to get it added as an Olympic sport!! He described the
eaters as athletes.

This is a much more crazy activity than speedcubing!!

<... a little while further into the show ...> The PR guy just said
that 'hand speed' is one of the 3 important factors for a competitive
eater?!?!

Jasmine
ttp://speedcuber.blogspot.com

1102. Re: [Speed cubing group] Tile set Recall
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 01:05:14 -0000

You'll have to open the bag. After that, just peel back some of the liner on the colored tiles. If there is no white on the backside, they are defective. I'm pretty sure the problem will only be found on the new Textured Tiles, and to no more than 20 sets total. sorry for any inconveinence this has caused. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > I received one Tiles set recently but I'm not planning on using it right now. > Is there a way to check if there is any problem without opening the > bag or at least without using them ? > > Thx, > Gilles.

If there is no white on the backside, > they are defective. > > I'm pretty sure the problem will only be found on the new Textured > Tiles, and to no more than 20 sets total. > > sorry for any inconveinence this has caused. > > Chris > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den > Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > I received one Tiles set recently but I'm not planning on using it > right now. > > Is there a way to check if there is any problem without opening the > > bag or at least without using them ? > > > > Thx, > > Gilles. > > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1104. New at Speedcubing
From: "goophy00" <goophy00@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 05:56:24 -0000

Hi I have been hanging around this group for a few months, and this is
my first posting

I have been doing the cube for about 20 years now, and my best time is
72 secs, using only about five algs. Basicaly do First Layer, do
Center Layer turn around allingn cross, orient cross, allign corners,
orient corners.

I went out, bought myself a new cube and some silicon spray and lubed
my cube.
Downloaded the Fridrich method and started learning, that was about a
week ago.

I have a question. How do you guys do it. Do you remember the
sequencing i.e. R U R' d' etc or is it just part of your muscle
memmory. I know from learning those five algs i currently do, that
they form part of my muscle memmory, I cannot tell you what I do, but
when I do them they just go. In order to build up the muscle memory, I
need to repeat the alg. over and over again.

In order to repeat the alg I think the best would be to do a certain
case, then reverse the alg. and do again etc. etc. and in doing so,
most propably know the reverse just as well as the forward alg?

What would you guys suggest?

Thanks
Louis






1105. RE: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 08:04:23 +0200

I often cube in the train too and although I am not as quick as most of the people here, I still get a lot of attention. Non-cubers indeed assume that you are brilliant if you can solve the cube. Let's not tell them that anyone can learn it... :) Never had a job offer in the train though... -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens jasmine_ellen Verzonden: zondag 21 augustus 2005 13:19 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train I already have a very good job. We all know that anyone can learn to solve the cube if they have the patience and commitment, but it's cool that non-cubers assume that anyone who can solve the cube pretty quickly is obviously brilliant! I think we should use all use this to our advantage and put it in our CVs. I have done this in the past (buried somewhere after educational qualifications and employment history) and at one job interview it was the first thing they commented on! Jasmine http://speeducber.blogspot.com <http://speeducber.blogspot.com> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > Thats great jasmine! I am a shyish kind of guy and hence dont do > cubing in the public. But im starting to think maybe its not that bad > idea. Afterall it will promote cubing a very lil bit more :) > > And looks like u may get a job frm that guy. All thanks to the cube! > > SAchin > > On 8/21/05, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > I often cube on the train. Sometimes no one pays any attention, but > > sometimes they do. Tonight was definitely the later. A group of four > > girls sitting across from me let out audible gasps when I finished a > > solve. I like to take any opportunity to promote cubing, so if anyone > > shows any interest on the train (or anywhere!) I'll offer to do them > > another demo and ask them to do the scramble themselves (so they know > > it wasn't 'set up' and also to get them involved). I did a few more > > 3x3x3 demos for them and they were very impressed. Then I whipped out > > the 4x4x4 and got them to scramble that too. :) > > > > Later during the train trip, another group of people got on. They were > > pretty amazed ("Oh my goodness! Did you just solve that thing?!") and > > so I handed them my cube. I did several demos as various different > > people in train scrambled my cube. They timed one of the solves (32 > > seconds) and then I got an applause from half the train carriage. When > > the train was approaching the final stop, which was also my stop, > > there was one guy left from the group. He'd been further down the > > carriage and hadn't actually seen my solves, he'd just heard his > > friends talking ("Wow! She just solved that in 32 seconds!") So > > obviously I offered to do a demo for him. :) He was completely blown > > away and asked me what I did. He then asked me if I was looking for a > > job and gave me his contact details! > > > > BTW, I beat my PB single solve tonight too - 22.23 seconds. :) > > > > Jasmine > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com <http://speedcuber.blogspot.com> > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1106. Re: [Speed cubing group] New at Speedcubing
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 01:58:29 -0400

As far as F2L goes (Fridrich Method) my algs are less mechanical, and
more intuitive. But for OLL and PLL it's all muscle memory - I have
difficulty doing PLL during one-handed solves because of this...


Bryan Mytko
bryanosaurus@...

1107. Re: New at Speedcubing
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 06:11:21 -0000

Hello goophy00! The way I remember the moves (algorithms) is by memorizing the moves but while doing that I see where the pieces go when I move them. Typically I find it easier to memorize when algorithms are given in triggers... for example: (R U' R' U) D (F R U). I just memorize the first part: RU'R'U as one move, then D as another and then FRU as one. Eventually after a while it will turn to muscle memory. But I don't keep repeating the algorithm. Try memorizing and soon you'll remember the feeling on your fingers. I hope this helps and good luck on the Fridrich method! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goophy00" <goophy00@g...> wrote: > Hi I have been hanging around this group for a few months, and this is > my first posting > > I have been doing the cube for about 20 years now, and my best time is > 72 secs, using only about five algs. Basicaly do First Layer, do > Center Layer turn around allingn cross, orient cross, allign corners, > orient corners. > > I went out, bought myself a new cube and some silicon spray and lubed > my cube. > Downloaded the Fridrich method and started learning, that was about a > week ago. > > I have a question. How do you guys do it. Do you remember the > sequencing i.e. R U R' d' etc or is it just part of your muscle > memmory. I know from learning those five algs i currently do, that > they form part of my muscle memmory, I cannot tell you what I do, but > when I do them they just go. In order to build up the muscle memory, I > need to repeat the alg. over and over again. > > In order to repeat the alg I think the best would be to do a certain > case, then reverse the alg. and do again etc. etc. and in doing so, > most propably know the reverse just as well as the forward alg? > > What would you guys suggest? > > Thanks > Louis

1109. Re: [Speed cubing group] New at Speedcubing
From: Marco Garbelini <garbelini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 08:44:56 +0200

That's indeed muscle memory as you say. Even with the most simple ones I have trouble doing it slowly when teaching someone. When training any LL algs I start with a solved cube and execute it over and over again untill I have a solved cube again. This is very interesting (and pretty obvious if you think about it), some algs need to be executed only twice, others 8 times, if after any execution the F2L is messed up tou know you did something wrong ... It's part of the fun and it works with any LL alg. Cheers, Marco On 8/22/05, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...> wrote: > As far as F2L goes (Fridrich Method) my algs are less mechanical, and > more intuitive. But for OLL and PLL it's all muscle memory - I have > difficulty doing PLL during one-handed solves because of this... > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@bryanosaurus.com > > > On Aug 22, 2005, at 1:56 AM, goophy00 wrote: > > > Hi I have been hanging around this group for a few months, and this is > > my first posting > > > > I have been doing the cube for about 20 years now, and my best time is > > 72 secs, using only about five algs. 1119. Re: New at Speedcubing

1120. Re: New at Speedcubing
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 14:23:28 -0000

Hi Louis, That's where I was around 12 months ago. I've been speedcubing for about a year now and I'm still learning OLL (I'm up to 23 at last count). I learnt PLL first though as there are fewer algs to learn. You might find that certain algs inverse others. I've found that it's easier to learn a new alg when there's only one case and it's mirror, eg. the "W" pattern OLL alg. But with other cases where there are more possibilities, eg.where two adjasent edges are to be oriented along with four corners (six all up which I'm still to learn), It's easier to learn two at a time then try a different case to save getting confused. For me personally it's easier to repeat a new alg as much as I can, I just need to remember that I've learnt the new alg for that case during a solve before doing the cross orientation that I would've automatically done before learning the new alg. Like someone else mentioned I too have trouble doing some algs slowly without messing them up. BTW, I recently did a new PB of 26.72 sec (WOO HOO!!), still average in the 40's though. Cheers, Keith. In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goophy00" <goophy00@g...> wrote: > Hi I have been hanging around this group for a few months, and this is > my first posting > > I have been doing the cube for about 20 years now, and my best time is > 72 secs, using only about five algs. Basicaly do First Layer, do > Center Layer turn around allingn cross, orient cross, allign corners, > orient corners. > > I went out, bought myself a new cube and some silicon spray and lubed > my cube. > Downloaded the Fridrich method and started learning, that was about a > week ago. > > I have a question. How do you guys do it. Do you remember the > sequencing i.e. R U R' d' etc or is it just part of your muscle > memmory. I know from learning those five algs i currently do, that > they form part of my muscle memmory, I cannot tell you what I do, but > when I do them they just go. In order to build up the muscle memory, I > need to repeat the alg. over and over again. > > In order to repeat the alg I think the best would be to do a certain > case, then reverse the alg. and do again etc. etc. and in doing so, > most propably know the reverse just as well as the forward alg? > > What would you guys suggest? > > Thanks > Louis
1121. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New at Speedcubing
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 20:29:26 +0530

Hello, i may be not the one in a position to give advice but i'll tell you how i learn algs. What i do is try to make some connection between consequitive steps and first just see the algo over and over again. Then i try it on the cube and once that too is done i try to mentally imagine the whole algorithm and do it backwards. That i recommend to everyone because if u can do the alg backward by just imagining then you have surely got the alg. I learn about 5-8 algs at a time and then revise them again during my classes :) After that i take a break and try to implement them during the solves. Happy cubing! Sachin. On 8/22/05, keefdcuber <keithrx3c@...> wrote: > Hi Louis, > > That's where I was around 12 months ago. > > I've been speedcubing for about a year now and I'm still learning > OLL (I'm up to 23 at last count). I learnt PLL first though as there > are fewer algs to learn. You might find that certain algs inverse > others. > > I've found that it's easier to learn a new alg when there's only one > case and it's mirror, eg. the "W" pattern OLL alg. But with other > cases where there are more possibilities, eg.where two adjasent > edges are to be oriented along with four corners (six all up which > I'm still to learn), It's easier to learn two at a time then try a > different case to save getting confused. > > For me personally it's easier to repeat a new alg as much as I can, > I just need to remember that I've learnt the new alg for that case > during a solve before doing the cross orientation that I would've > automatically done before learning the new alg. > > Like someone else mentioned I too have trouble doing some algs > slowly without messing them up. > > BTW, I recently did a new PB of 26.72 sec (WOO HOO!!), still average > in the 40's though. > > > Cheers, Keith. > > > In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goophy00" > <goophy00@g...> wrote: > > Hi I have been hanging around this group for a few months, and > this is > > my first posting > > > > I have been doing the cube for about 20 years now, and my best > time is > > 72 secs, using only about five algs. Basicaly do First Layer, do > > Center Layer turn around allingn cross, orient cross, allign > corners, > > orient corners. > > > > I went out, bought myself a new cube and some silicon spray and > lubed > > my cube. > > Downloaded the Fridrich method and started learning, that was > about a > > week ago. > > > > I have a question. How do you guys do it. Do you remember the > > sequencing i.e. R U R' d' etc or is it just part of your muscle > > memmory. I know from learning those five algs i currently do, that > > they form part of my muscle memmory, I cannot tell you what I do, > but > > when I do them they just go. In order to build up the muscle > memory, I > > need to repeat the alg. over and over again. > > > > In order to repeat the alg I think the best would be to do a > certain > > case, then reverse the alg. and do again etc. etc. and in doing so, > > most propably know the reverse just as well as the forward alg? > > > > What would you guys suggest? > > > > Thanks > > Louis > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1122. Dyslexic Cubers?
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 14:59:23 -0000

It seems obvious to me that a just about everyone that's capable of
speedcubing seems to be well educated and has done well with their
schooling, especially with mathematics.

Well, I'm completely the oppossite, I had trouble with learning
difficulties at school and was put into a slow learners class.
Obviously I can read and write well enough but I absolutly suck at
maths, even basic stuff.

I've done a bit of research into dyslexia and found that I possess a
lot of the symptoms that describe the problems that dyslexics have.
The most prominant one's being daydreaming and getting confused easily.
I'm good with problem solving and being creative and I'm told I have a
bit of a flair for writing.

So you're probably reading this and thinking "but dylexics can't read
or write" which is the common missconseption.

What I really wanted to know is, are there any other speedcubers that
have similar problems?


Cheers, Keith.

I googled and > found it here: http://www.ifoce.com/ > > Anyway, the guy was saying that it really is a sport and they've been > trying for ages to get it added as an Olympic sport!! He described the > eaters as athletes. > > This is a much more crazy activity than speedcubing!! > > <... a little while further into the show ...> The PR guy just said > that 'hand speed' is one of the 3 important factors for a competitive > eater?!?! > > Jasmine > ttp://speedcuber.blogspot.com

1125. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New at Speedcubing
From: Marco Garbelini <garbelini@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

I learn them in groups as well. When I'm comfortable enough with them, i other words, no amnesia during solves for a few days, I move to the next 5 or 6. Obviously I can read and write well enough but I absolutly suck at maths, even basic stuff. The most prominant one's being daydreaming and getting confused easily. I'm good with problem solving and being creative and I'm told I have a bit of a flair for writing. What I really wanted to know is, are there any other speedcubers that have similar problems? Cheers, Keith. 1130. Scrambles generation query
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 21:09:35 +0530

Hello all. i have been wondering lately that how is exactly a scramble
generated? Is it just a random selection of moves or is there any
checking done to ensure that the cube each time gets away from the
scrambled state?

I think this one needs to by repeated13 times. (R2' U R') B' (R U')(R2' U l U l') /Gunnar Krig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Marco Garbelini > <garbelini@g...> wrote: > > > > When training any LL algs I start with a solved cube and execute it > > over and over again untill I have a solved cube again. 1135. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles generation query
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 12:21:05 -0400

The moves are random, but the moves are restricted so that once a face is turned, it is not allowed to be turned again until an adjacent face is turned. Scrambling programs shouldn't create sequences like "U2 U'" or "U2 D U'". On 8/22/05, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...> wrote: > Hello all. i have been wondering lately that how is exactly a scramble > generated? Is it just a random selection of moves or is there any > checking done to ensure that the cube each time gets away from the > scrambled state?
1136. Re: Cubing on the train
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 16:22:51 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > I often cube in the train too and although I am not as quick as most of the > people here, I still get a lot of attention. I cube daily on public transport (it is a good time to practise), but it doesn't usually provoke much reaction beyond eye-rolling and the odd chuckle. Maybe 3 or 4 times I've been asked a question about cubing. Elsewhere (still in public) I've had coins thrown at me because I /wasn't/ cubing... the total was only 17 pence. :( > Non-cubers indeed assume that > you are brilliant if you can solve the cube. Well, that's nice. I'll just try to imagine that I have lots of admirers who are too shy to speak. ;) Mike
1137. Re: [Speed cubing group] New at Speedcubing
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 16:29:52 -0000

Hi Gunnar! That can't possibly be right? Order 13? Every algorithm (sequence of moves) has a cyclic decomposition (corners and edges). U have to repeat an algorithm a number of times to yield the state u started from. This number is equal to the least common multiple of the orders of all the subcycles produced by this algorithm. Hence the overall order can't be a prime number (unless 2 or 3 or 5 or 7 or 11). The 7 and 11 could be corner cycles of those respective order. Im now talking general of coz, not necessarily restricted to LL. So i can't see how order 13 can be possible. Ok, i checked w FMC Companion now. Ur given algorithm has order 12. So probably just wrongly spelt from ur side ... ;-) Cheers, -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > I think this one needs to by repeated13 times. > > (R2' U R') B' (R U')(R2' U l U l') > > /Gunnar Krig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Marco Garbelini > > <garbelini@g...> wrote: > > > > > > When training any LL algs I start with a solved cube and execute it > > > over and over again untill I have a solved cube again. This is very > > > interesting (and pretty obvious if you think about it), some algs > > need > > > to be executed only twice, others 8 times > > > > Can you please show me one that needs 8 times? I don't think this is > > possible. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan
1138. Re: Cubing on the train
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>

1139. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-)
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 17:47:22 +0100 (BST)

>>>> I found a simple move to swap two center pieces on adjacent sides. You mean one piece of a centre with another piece of its adjacent centre. If so what is the algm ? John Louis Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: Bwahahahahaha. Victory. After much playing around with my 4x4 (read: working), I found a simple move to swap two center pieces on adjacent sides. Using this move, coupled with r2u2r2u2, I've managed to solve my 4x4 with this new method. Also, I've found a way around the difficult parity, but it's intuitive and difficult. I still think someone out there has to know a simpler way to fix this. Anywho, November is creeping up quickly, and I'd like to be ready by then, so if Per could just share all his secrets right now, that would be great. =) -Mike Bennett ----- Original Message ----- From: uberstuberizzle To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, July 04, 2005 1:59 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: 4x4x4 method :-) One problem I found with this method is too many slice moves. I Can't do fast slice moves for my life, but if you can do 'em it could be fast. Which commuter do you use for two edges left? For centers, r2b2r2b2, ldl' U ld'l' U', and r'urUr'u'd'rU'r'dr are nice. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Nope. 1144. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles generation query
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 11:10:07 -0700

On 8/22/05, David Barr <david20708@...> wrote: > The moves are random, but the moves are restricted so that once a face > is turned, it is not allowed to be turned again until an adjacent face > is turned. Scrambling programs shouldn't create sequences like "U2 > U'" or "U2 D U'". That is almost perfectly correct, but we can allow two turns at a time in the same plane! This is how it works: - The first move can be any move - The seconds move can be any move EXCEPT one on the same face as the last turn - The next 23 moves can be any move EXCEPT one on the same face as the last turn and it cannot be in the same plane as the last turn if the last turn and the one before it are also in the same plane. Thus only two turns in a row can be in the same plane. If we just said that each turn had to be in a different plane, then we would get a scramble like: R U L' F L B .... This is fine, but it doesn't allow for all possible positions of the cube, a scramble like this is more desirable: F B' U R D U2 ... Notice that some turns are in the same plane! -Chris

1148. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles generation query
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 16:48:58 -0400

On 8/22/05, Chris Hunt <huntca@...> wrote: > On 8/22/05, David Barr <david20708@...> wrote: > > The moves are random, but the moves are restricted so that once a face > > is turned, it is not allowed to be turned again until an adjacent face > > is turned. Scrambling programs shouldn't create sequences like "U2 > > U'" or "U2 D U'". > > That is almost perfectly correct, but we can allow two turns at a time > in the same plane! This is how it works: > My description doesn't disallow sequences like "F B". My way of thinking it may be simpler or more complex depending on your point of view. The logic that you stated is one possible way of implementing my description. Here's another possible implementation. Keep track of the faces that can possibly be the next turn. Initially, all faces are in this set. Now repeat this 25 times: Pick a face randomly from the set to turn. Remove that face from the set. Place all of the faces that are adjacent to that face back in the set if they are not there already. Both implementations are equivalent. The method I desribed has the advantage that the rules for picking a face don't differ on the first, second and remaining steps. The method probably has other disadvantages, but that isn't my point. My point is that my description is perfectly correct (as far as I can tell).
1149. Re: [Speed cubing group] Scrambles generation query
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 13:59:12 -0700

On 8/22/05, David Barr <david20708@...> wrote: > My point is that my description is perfectly correct (as far as I can tell). I guess I just misunderstood this statement: >The moves are random, but the moves are restricted so that once a face >is turned, it is not allowed to be turned again until an adjacent face >is turned. I read it as: "once a face is turned, moves in the same plane are not allowed to be turned until an adjacent face is turned." That is a different way of looking at it then I have done in the past...it's cool to think about it that way. Thanks for correcting me. -Chris

1154. Re: Megaminx Solution
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 23:02:26 -0000

Hehe, I reinvented one of the algorithms... I mean the one to orient two adjacent corners (that you solve with the theta algorithm). I had seen yours and noticed it's shorter than mine but since I had the pc turned off I looked for a shorter one myself and found the same (well, somewhat mirrored, since I solve left-handed and your F is my U). And then today I got the same case for 3x3 cube OLL and used the new algorithm (cause I don't yet have a good alg for that) which resulted in a PLL skip. Proof enough that this alg is good, huh? Hey, try this 2-gen alg (for Megaminx, of course): R / F / R' / F / R / F'' / R'' / F'' / R / F / R' / F / R Cheers! Stefan P.S. How about a naming scheme for Megaminx cases ;-) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > He guys, > > I've been working on it for a few days as I promised a few folks at > the Dallas tournament I would. I think it's close enough to done to > call it done! Now no one has read it except myself, so I ezpect a few > errors, just let me know and I'll fix them as soon as I can. > Also let me know if you think I went about the whole thing the wrong > way, as I've never really written a guide like this before! > > At any rate, it's a 16 page (lots of pictures) word document located here: > > http://members.cox.net/swedishlf/Megaminx%20Solution.doc > > I also posted a very similar message to the twistypuzzle forums. > > Anywhoo, let me know what you think! > > -Daniel

Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 01:00:47 -0000

I was in high shcool when the big cube craze hit the world and learnt to solve it completely just after I left school but I've only been speedcubing for around a year now. My times are usually in the 30/40 sec bracket, my best time as of a few days ago is 26.72. Keith. 1160. Re: [Speed cubing group] Dyslexic Cubers?
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 01:13:20 -0000

ADD and ADHD are forms of dyslexia in the way that the person experiences "disorientations" which is were some other symptoms kick in, like getting letters mixed up. One of my young nephews has been diagnosed with ADD and another (like myself) only began talking when he was 4 years old. Some people say that letters and words swim around or shimmer on the page. dyslexia.com is a very good source of information on the subject. Keith. In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, David Barr <david20708@g...> wrote: > This sounds more like attention deficit disorder (ADD) than dyslexia. > I've got some symptoms of ADD, although I've never been professionally > evaluated. I bet that a lot of cubers have ADD. > > On 8/22/05, keefdcuber <keithrx3c@h...> wrote: > > Yeah I had other problems too, I had a really hard time > > concentrating and I was very slow with my work, I very rarely > > finnished what I was supposed to be doing. > > > > Kieth. > >
1161. Re: [Speed cubing group] Dyslexic Cubers?
From: "keefdcuber" <keithrx3c@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 01:20:43 -0000

Your parents sound like mine, a bit old fashioned and don't like the idea that there might be something "wrong" with their son. There are a lot of benefits to being dyslexic/ADD, just look at Albert Einstien, Leonardo Devinchi (spelling), and Thomas Edison, not to mention a lot of modern day celebrities like Whoopie Goldberg, Tom Cruize, Woody Harolson, Danny Glover... Keith. But still, crazy -E On 8/22/05, Chris Hunt <huntca@...> wrote: > > On 8/22/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > > No no... let's not get into this. I was in Amarillo on my way to the > > Dallas tournament and, well, here: > > Dude, the macro shots are gross, but I could eat it :) > > -Chris > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Puzzle games<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Puzzle+games&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Online+puzzle+games&w5=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=ZZdd7R8dNvVr5Eg0kuhsTw> Free > puzzle games<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+games&w1=Puzzle+games&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Online+puzzle+games&w5=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=xnh5nqFZa_TlywO8mS69Dw> Computer > puzzle game<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Computer+puzzle+game&w1=Puzzle+games&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Online+puzzle+games&w5=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=F5blgkcYjsw6agVM87P-ew> Online > puzzle games<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Online+puzzle+games&w1=Puzzle+games&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Online+puzzle+games&w5=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=BiWwh2NQLBdOyQ1JexXysw> Jigsaw > puzzle game<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Puzzle+games&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Online+puzzle+games&w5=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=X387sfH9wPVndeWBSkJxrg> Free > puzzle inlay games<http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Puzzle+games&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Online+puzzle+games&w5=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=PK0mqOIyMqyqPC4NBnqniw> > ------------------------------ > YAHOO! 1164. Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers
From: "goophy00" <goophy00@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 05:28:43 -0000

Thanks for all the good advice on starting speedcubing.

On the topic of the Dyslexic cubers It will be interesting to know the
average IQ of the group. Even if you are Dyslexic (Why is the word for
people who can't spell such a difficult one to spell), or have ADD and
do bad at math it doesnt mean that you have a low IQ. People with a
High IQ have an affinity for problem solving, such as the rubicks
cube. I am of the oppinion that the group average would be at least
125, where the general population average is 100.

If you which to know your own IQ you could do an online test (Not very
accurate) or go to your local MENSA and take a test for a fee.
To find your local MENSA try Google.

Louis






1165. Getting Faster - best "bang for the buck" (short and long term)???
From: "Jeff" <yeff@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 06:19:13 -0000

All --

Long time cuber, first time poster. I'm looking to get faster, and
thought I'd see what opinions this group has about the best approach
to try next.

First, my story. I first cubed back in high school in Texas
(1980/1981) - I used a layer-by-layer method, turning with my whole
hand, and got to the point where I could average about 1:10-1:15,
which was decent back then and helped me do well in local
competitions. This was back before the Internet, before anyone in my
area knew of the Fridrich or finger tricks or any of that "new-
fangled" cubing :-)

Fast forward to November 2004, when I pick up a cube at Target.
Looking for info on the web, I find the San Francisco competition in
Jan 2005. Re-learned my old layer-by-layer method, went to SF and
did alright (1:05-1:10).

After being impressed by the incredible times at the competition, I
wanted to get faster. My first step was to learn cross/F2L, which
brought me to consistently to below a minute. Changing my LL
approach from (permute corners, orient corners, permute edges,
orient edges) to (orient edges, permute corners, orient corners,
permute edges) took me to around 50-55 seconds. Lubing up the cube
and a lot of practice took me to around a 50 second average, with a
best of 47 second average (and occasional times below 41 seconds).

Since I was still turning with my hands, with the cross on top, I
realized it was probably time to start learning a better approach. I
switched over to cross on bottom and started learning finger turning.

That's where I was a couple months ago, and since then progress has
been very slow. I'm just now getting back to 50 second averages, but
not quite yet. I seem plagued by mistakes and brain stalls and the
occasional jam or slip.

At this point, I'm looking at various ideas on how to get faster,
and I thought I'd run them by the group and see what thoughts people
have. I'm also restricted by the fact that I've got a pretty busy
life: work, family, kids, etc, so I don't have a lot of time to
devote to cubing. So, I'm looking for the best "bang for the buck",
in terms of effort - both short term (in prep for the Norcal
tournament in a month) and longer term.

Here's my ideas:

- learn OLL/PLL. This seems like a lot of work, and while it would
make me faster (due to cutting moves down to around 60 from my
current 80) I'm not sure I can get through OLL/PLL in any time.
Eventually, long term, I'll have to do this.

- learn just PLL. I could switch my LL approach to (orient sides,
orient corners, PLL). The PLL would be easier to learn (21? algs),
but I'm not too sure about what the benefit would be (maybe cut out
10 moves?).

- better cube. Not as sure about this one - my cubes seem pretty
good (esp the 25th anniv ones), I could make them a little slicker
but I'm not sure I could easily control them. I might get more jams
and slips (this has happened in the past).

- faster moves. I could work on making my sequences faster. I'm
unsure about this one, since total time is (find sequence + perform
sequence), faster sequences could help but there's still
the "search" time.

- practice "lookahead". I could work on being better about
recognizing the next sequence, especially during F2L. This follows
with the "F2L is everything" philosophy discussed in group.

- practice technique. Work on being clean with my movements, with
the hope of reducing jams and keeping movements clean.

- slow down. Following with the "go slower to go faster" philosophy,
I could slow down on sequences with the hope of finding the next
sequence faster. This is an analog to the 'practice lookahead' above.

So, what do you folks think? I've got some ideas, but I'd like to
hear other's opinions as well - what could I tackle, both short-term
(in the next month) and long term in order to get faster??

Thanks for the help!

yeff





1166. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing on the train
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 08:37:54 +0200

Just wait a few days, it'll become much more stable with time :-)


1167. What was I thinking?!?
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 09:02:36 -0000

I was using the slice algs for edge 3-cycles since way before learning
Fridrich, when I used to end with ELL (not necessarily 1 step,
though). I just learned I guess 12 2-gen algs for edge 3-cycles today
and I think I have gotten all of them faster than the slice ones I was
using. I can't believe I wasn't using these sooner! What a
difference it will make!

Thanks to Chris, Doug, Ian, and Joel for the algs and demonstrations
of some of them. :D

~ Bob

Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 10:25:59 -0000

Is anyone aware of a cubing club in the Honolulu area? Or any cubists
in Honolulu?

turtleparadise

1176. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 15:00:37 +0200

I had 108.

THe IQ is calculated by dividing your results to the test by the
average result of the people of your age.

For exemple : You are 20 years old and you scored 5000 where other
people at 20 score 4000, your IQ is (5000/4000)*100 = 125


1177. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 15:09:15 +0200

Actually it is a normal distribution with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. This means that 90% of all people on earth score between 70 and 130 (mean + - 2x standard deviation). 2.5% of the world population has an IQ < 70 and 2.5% has an IQ > 130. -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Gilles van den Peereboom Verzonden: dinsdag 23 augustus 2005 15:01 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers I had 108. THe IQ is calculated by dividing your results to the test by the average result of the people of your age. For exemple : You are 20 years old and you scored 5000 where other people at 20 score 4000, your IQ is (5000/4000)*100 = 125 _____ YAHOO! 1181. Way way overdue sub 30 second average to the sound of Tubular Bells
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 14:39:51 +0100

I'm not even excited now - just fed up because it took me so long to do
this! I beat my previous best of 10 average by 0.08 seconds to get 29.96.
Maybe now the barrier is down it won't be so hard the second time.
Individual times:

28.39, 28.40, 26.62, 35.52, 28.38, 33.07, 27.46, 23.44, 33.71, 34.56 (see
the nerves kicking in at the end ;) )

Incidentally I just bought a CD of Mike Oldfields Tubular bells for 1 which
I haven't listened to for about 25-30 years and did my average the first
time I listened to it. Its going to be my favourite music for a while now
:)

Most of the solves were L2L1 method although the 23.44 was L2L2.

Duncan




1182. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers
