1183. Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 13:48:38 -0000

I did a test on a webpage that seemed serious. It took 40 minutes and I got 137. The limit for MENSA-membership is 132 if I recall correctly. Am I right? /Gunnar Krig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > Well, I guess I'll start this one. I have taken IQ tests multiple > times with scores of: > > 144 > 161 > 180... > > so...it seems I have a pretty high IQ...but you guys probably have > higher... > > Craig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "goophy00" > <goophy00@g...> wrote: > > Thanks for all the good advice on starting speedcubing. > > > > On the topic of the Dyslexic cubers It will be interesting to know the > > average IQ of the group. Even if you are Dyslexic (Why is the word for > > people who can't spell such a difficult one to spell), or have ADD and > > do bad at math it doesnt mean that you have a low IQ. People with a > > High IQ have an affinity for problem solving, such as the rubicks > > cube. I am of the oppinion that the group average would be at least > > 125, where the general population average is 100. > > > > If you which to know your own IQ you could do an online test (Not very > > accurate) or go to your local MENSA and take a test for a fee. > > To find your local MENSA try Google. > > > > Louis
1184. Re: [Speed cubing group] Getting Faster - best "bang for the buck" (short and long term)???
From: David Barr <david20708@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 09:57:15 -0400

It sounds like you have a good idea of what you need to do. The following tips are based on what people told me to do to get better: 1. Make sure you have a decent cube. It sounds like you do already. 2. Make sure you are doing the F2L properly. Rather than focusing on the clock for a while, focus on the number of turns that you are taking. You should be able to complete the first two layers in fewer than 35 turns consistently. 3. Learn the PLL. This will let you do a three step LL. I've heard that people can get to at least the low 20's with this method. And after you learn the PLL, you can start learning the OLL. 4. After you are comfortable with #2, practice solving the first two layers at a constant pace of one or two turns per second with no pauses. This excercise is useful for getting rid of pauses when you are going faster. On 8/23/05, Jeff <yeff@...> wrote: > - learn OLL/PLL. This seems like a lot of work, and while it would > make me faster (due to cutting moves down to around 60 from my > current 80) I'm not sure I can get through OLL/PLL in any time. > Eventually, long term, I'll have to do this. > > - learn just PLL. I could switch my LL approach to (orient sides, > orient corners, PLL). The PLL would be easier to learn (21? algs), > but I'm not too sure about what the benefit would be (maybe cut out > 10 moves?). > > - better cube. Not as sure about this one - my cubes seem pretty > good (esp the 25th anniv ones), I could make them a little slicker > but I'm not sure I could easily control them. I might get more jams > and slips (this has happened in the past). > > - faster moves. I could work on making my sequences faster. I'm > unsure about this one, since total time is (find sequence + perform > sequence), faster sequences could help but there's still > the "search" time. > > - practice "lookahead". I could work on being better about > recognizing the next sequence, especially during F2L. This follows > with the "F2L is everything" philosophy discussed in group. > > - practice technique. Work on being clean with my movements, with > the hope of reducing jams and keeping movements clean. > > - slow down. Following with the "go slower to go faster" philosophy, > I could slow down on sequences with the hope of finding the next > sequence faster. This is an analog to the 'practice lookahead' above. > > So, what do you folks think? I've got some ideas, but I'd like to > hear other's opinions as well - what could I tackle, both short-term > (in the next month) and long term in order to get faster?? > > Thanks for the help! > > yeff > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1185. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: New Cuber and Dyslexic cubers

Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 16:00:20 +0200

1187. Re: [Speed cubing group] Getting Faster - best "bang for the buck" (short and long term)???
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 17:47:00 +0200

Hello,

> 3. Learn the PLL. This will let you do a three step LL. I've heard
> that people can get to at least the low 20's with this method. And
> after you learn the PLL, you can start learning the OLL.
(my best average is 20.16 and I know 20/22 PLL and 32/57 OLL;-))

so, F2L is really the main point to gain time at first, then try to
accelerate your LL by switching from a 3-look to a 2-look method.

Anoter important point is to train with some regularity (example :
once a day), even if it's not for a long time. You could try to train
in the public transportations because this will put you under stress
(if people are looking at you), you'll have some disurbance (noise,
unexpected shock,...) which is a good training for the competition.
:-)

Good luck :-)
Gilles.

Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 17:50:36 +0200

Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 17:26:27 -0000

Jeff,


I think looking ahead is the key. I just learned PLL since the last
tournament, it only took a couple of weeks and I think it is totally
worth it. If you can manage to come down to Oakland sometime, maybe I
can get you rolling.

I have kids too, maybe they could play and it would give you an excuse.

Don't get discouraged, it seems like the fruits of your labor will hit
all at once. I'm sure it will click for you soon.

-mike grimsley




1192. Re: [Speed cubing group] Challenge
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>

For me, it was only $5, but we hustled the guy. I had some of my friends egging him on and saying stuff like "Man, that thing is impossible. NOBODY can do that thing." He bet me $5 that I can't do it in under 2 mins. and I agreed. When I succeeded, I TOOK that money. It was mine and I deserved it. ~ Bob :P --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Marco Garbelini <garbelini@g...> wrote: > Heheh . I did the exact same thing. 1195. Re: [Speed cubing group] Challenge
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 14:00:49 -0700

I was in Las Vegas about a month ago (for two weeks) and was waiting to see the Blue Man Group. It was about 45 minutes until the door opened, so I took my bag off and sat down to solve the cube. About 40 minutes later I had $32 sitting on my bag because people kept putting money down. I should take the drive down to Seattle and see if it works there too. :) -Chris On 8/23/05, Bob Burton <bob@...> wrote: > For me, it was only $5, but we hustled the guy. 1196. Re: [Speed cubing group] Challenge
From: "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 21:32:46 -0000

At school last year, Joe Spadafora and I were in line for dinner. Joe
was in the middle of doing a solve, and this kid in front of us turns
around and says "If you can solve that in under 10 minutes I'll give
you $5000." So Joe extended his hand and they shook on it. A few
seconds later he finished his solve and the kid was pretty amazed.
Unfortunately he didn't have $5000 cash on him to give so Joe didn't
get it. It's funny though because to a non cuber, $5000 to solve
in 10 minutes seems like a safe bet.

Then there was another time that Joe and I were cubing in my dorm
room. The guy that lived next to me had a bunch of people over and
they were all REALLY wasted. He knocks on my door and asks us to cube
for them in his room. We go over there, and they mix up our cubes,
and then he says "the winner of this race gets a blowjob from his
choice of girl in this room, and the loser gets kicked in the nuts by
all of us." Of course, this was when Joe was still faster than me, so
he won. :(

Ahh... good times cubing with Joe.

Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 16:43:41 -0500

noncubers feeding cubers? Damn, if that's not true, then I have to
rethink my life plans..."

hahahahaha

1202. Re: [Speed cubing group] wife? kids? what?!?

1203. Re: [Speed cubing group] Challenge
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 19:47:06 -0500

I had two rather inebriated patrons come into the gas station I was working
at a while back. One of them saw the cube sitting on top of the register I
was at and proceeded to tell me at length about how impossible they were.
So, I nonchalantly picked it up and nodded politely as he was talking and
solved it in about 25 seconds. He nearly wet himself.

He excitedly explained to his friend that I had just solved it in slightly
over 2 minutes. I was a tad miffed. I was no speed demon at the time,
especially under no inspection circumstances, but two minutes hurt me deep.
I corrected him, and he challenged me to a timed solve. I accepted, and
solved in 24 seconds. I then performed two more sub 25 solves, which he
witnessed and saw the stopwatch. I was feeling pretty good for no
inspection.

Then, the alcohol kicked in. He, after having seen me solve (with a timer)
sub 25 three times, challenged me to solve it in under 30, to the tune of
$3, which was all he had on him, sadly. I solved the cube in 21, dropped
the stopwatch, picked it up and handed it to him, and he saw it at 24. I
told him to keep his money, because it wasn't a fair bet. He mumbled in
unintelligible drunk speak something about 'amazing' and 'circus', threw the
money on the counter, and left, telling his disinterested friend about how I
just blew his mind.

I took the money, and those three dollars are still hiding in my dresser as
a trophy.

-Mike Bennett

_________________________________________________________________

1204. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 01:04:07 -0000

> Non-cubers indeed assume that you are brilliant if you can solve
the cube. Let's not tell them that anyone
> can learn it... :) Never had a job offer in the train though...

just a funny encounter:

Today in the bank was the second time I got the same reaction: "Are
you a rocket scientist?". I simply replied: "no, but I am a computer
scientist".
Her: "Oh, thank God for you, now we have Dell computers. Now I still
can't remember my password"
Me: (no reply to that)
--- Me moving into PLL just finishing up with last 3 moves
"Can you actually solve that?"
--- Solved.
Me: "ehm yes, apparantly"
Her: "Oh my God you solved it. How often have you solved it?"
--- I really couldn't think of an answer that would be correct or
something witty and I just didn't want to give her an approximation
and have her fall off her chair or anything
Me: I can just solve it
Her: "How long does it take you"
Me: "under 30 seconds"
--- see I don't ever want people to be very disappointed. I once did
a demo of 19 seconds, but that is not a very common time for me.
Me: "actually most of us can solve it that fast, a lot of us even
faster"
Her: "You seriously mean there are more like you?"
--- this was getting creapy. Are we some alien life form? Maybe to
non-cubers it does seem like that

anyway, still a nice conversation. I tend to get a lot more attention
from the tourists then from the locals. I think people on vacation
are not as worried with daily life and like the
distraction/attraction.

Michiel

1208. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 02:08:02 -0000

I had another 'cubing on the train' encounter yesterday. I was at the
train station waiting for my train. As usual, I was cubing while
waiting. A guy sat down about two seats away and after a few moments
he said "Excuse me, did I see you in a magazine recently?" To which I
replied "TNT Magazine? Yep, that was me." We proceeded to talk about
cubing till the train arrived, and then as we were catching the same
train we sat together and I explained my beginner method. He then
asked me where he should go to buy cubes! :)

Cubing moments like this on trains are cool. Sometimes people make
really really lame comments though. The other day a guy said to me "Do
you solve that often? Is that how you know how to do it?" What I was
thinking, but didn't actually say, was "Yes, there are only 43+
quintillion configurations so I figured if I randomly work through
them I'll eventually get there!" (Duh, obviously there's a system!)

Then tonight I was out with some friends and, as usual, I had my cube
out. When the waitress came by she commented on the cubes. My friends
told her that I could solve it really quickly and so I offered to do a
demo. I got her to scramble and then time me. After thousands and
thousands of solves, I can generally make a pretty good estimate of
the time of my solves and this one felt like low 30s (my current
avaerage). The waitress looked at her watch and said 3 minutes!! I
told her it definitely wasn't 3 mins and that it was much more like
30s and she didn't believe me. When she left, my friend said that he
agreed she was definitely very wrong and you don't need to have a
watch to know that the brief period of time that passed was no where
near 3 minutes. Then my friend joked that we certainly wouldn't want
her adjudicating at a competition! I'm not sure how she came up with 3
minutes since she was the one who had the watch!!

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

1210. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 02:18:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > anyway, still a nice conversation. I tend to get a lot more attention > from the tourists then from the locals. I think people on vacation > are not as worried with daily life and like the > distraction/attraction. > > Michiel I'm living in London at the moment and I've noticed that many of the people who actually come and ask me about the cube when they see me cubing are not English. This doesn't necessarily mean they're tourists though as there are so many different people from everywhere who live in London. The other thing I've noticed is that it's pretty much always guys who'll come and talk to me about cubing. It's very rarely girls, and when it is a girl, she'll just make a brief comment ('wow, that's impressive!' or 'you solved that thing so quickly!'). The girls are never interested in the actual solving or method or logic or anything like that. It's only the guys who ask me more detailed questions about the cube and how to solve it. This is not really that surprising though. I think we all know that any girl who is really interested in cubing is an anomaly!! :) Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

see if you can work out which one

1217. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Getting Faster - best "bang for the buck" (short and long term)???
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 23:50:22 -0500

>3. Learn the PLL. This will let you do a three step LL. I've heard >that people can get to at least the low 20's with this method. And >after you learn the PLL, you can start learning the OLL. yea.. im in the low 20s and one of my friend's only knows half of the OLLs and is a sub-18 cuber. so pll definitely helps (though i think f2l makes much more of a difference) if you want to train for the norcal competition, get your f2l to be amazing. imo, it will help more. On 8/23/05, skeneegee <skeneegee@...> wrote: > Jeff, > > > I think looking ahead is the key. I just learned PLL since the last > tournament, it only took a couple of weeks and I think it is totally > worth it. If you can manage to come down to Oakland sometime, maybe I > can get you rolling. > > I have kids too, maybe they could play and it would give you an excuse. > > Don't get discouraged, it seems like the fruits of your labor will hit > all at once. I'm sure it will click for you soon. > > -mike grimsley > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > -- -cubekid

From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>

The way I folded it in my mind...that edge was Blue/Green ...so I figured that was the bad edge because we know we can't have a blue/green with that color scheme. -Chris On 8/23/05, Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...> wrote: > hmm.. that doesn't seem correct.. because that would make that edge > cubie have both sides as orange.. > > it has to be one of the green-yellow edges... as there are two of them.. > > although i could be wrong :-/ > > On 8/23/05, Chris Hunt <huntca@...> wrote: > > This looks correct .. > > > > http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/eccehomo.jpg > > > > -Chris > > > > On 8/23/05, jackrubyslippers <xerocorp2@...> wrote: > > > in the following diagram > > > which represents an 'unfolded' cube > > > one of the orange squares has been coloured green > > > see if you can work out which one > > > > > > http://i3.photobucket.com/albums/y92/xerocorp/eccehomo.jpg > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1220. Re: speed solving tutorial for 4*4*4 and 5*5*5

Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 05:16:14 -0000

I'm currently working on one for the 4x4x4, though it isn't quite finished yet. I have all the stuff about solving the centers done, and now I am working on finishing the stuff about edges. I think I will be done in a few days, but I hope it will be sooner. I'll post the URL once I'm finished. Chris P.S. 1224. Re: an unconventional problem
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 06:12:36 -0000

Jack, Well, there should only be 4 green corners and 4 green edges pieces. I counted 5 green edge pieces. There are 2 green/yellow edges. (Getting close...) The one on the left and far bottom faces of the cross diagram. Yet I don't know which one of those green edges should be orange. I suppose you could run a parity check on the edges and deduct that way which green should be orange. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jackrubyslippers" <xerocorp2@y...> wrote: > in the following diagram > which represents an 'unfolded' cube > one of the orange squares has been coloured green > see if you can work out which one > > http://i3.photobucket.com/albums/y92/xerocorp/eccehomo.jpg

jackrubyslippers wrote:

> one of the orange squares has been coloured green

1228. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Way way overdue sub 30 second average to the sound of Tubular Bells
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 08:18:04 +0100

Hi Bryan, I picked up a cube again in September 2003 after a 20 years lay off. Had to work out my new strategies and algorithms and have done a lot of one handed cubing in that time but for the last 6 months or so I've averaged under 35 seconds but never put in that extra effort to get under 30. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Bryan Mytko" <bmytko@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Wednesday, August 24, 2005 12:09 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Way way overdue sub 30 second average to the sound of Tubular Bells ''I'm not even excited now - just fed up because it took me so long to do > this!' 1242. Fridrich upside down
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 16:28:12 -0000

Someone here cubes with cross on top? I don't like that, because you
have to use a lot of D turns, and I prefer U turns. Anyway, when you do
the cross on top, how is the LL done? on bottom or you turn the cube
upside down and do it on top?

anybody else that updates the record lists?

1260. Tile Recall Update
From: "jello33" <chris@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 19:09:54 -0000

Update:

Ok, it looks like some of the tiles shipped between 7/24/05 and
8/24/05 may have been bad. I've gone through all the orders that were
placed between those dates and am resending all the tiles from those
orders. I'd rather not wait for everyone to contact me so I'm going
to just play it safe and resend them all.
I'll send a confirmation to each person as I ship them. All the bad
tiles that I had in stock have been found and tossed out, to prevent
this from happening again.

Thanks
Chris
www.cubesmith.com

so that the cross is at the bottom ;-)

know, you can swap to edges without changing anything else.

1267. Re: [Speed cubing group] an unconventional problem
From: "jackrubyslippers" <xerocorp2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 20:39:50 -0000

well just scrambling a cube and painting its portrait was the idea but i'm slightly colourblind and the shades of green and orange are very similar and so in transferring them to the sketch (which i posted) i made a mistake having further scrambled the cube in the meantime i could no longer work out where the mistake was it doesn't take a cuber to work out that ten green squares isn't right but it does take one to work out which one is the wrong one though i did consider painting the mistaken version i'm going to paint the corrected one which is why i asked i thank you for your responses and, as i say when the paintings are finished i'll post pics in the cube art folder --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y ...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > Because art has to be mysterious... Only a real cuber can figure out > that > > the painting isn't right. > > Haha! I wonder if it's really going to be one of those "What is wrong > with this picture?" puzzles for children. You know the kind of thing: > woman with 2 left hands, door-handle on the hinged side of the door, > dog with 3 legs, and... cube with one orange facelet coloured green ?!
1268. Re: [Speed cubing group] an unconventional problem
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 21:09:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "jackrubyslippers" <xerocorp2@y...> wrote: > > i thank you for your responses > and, as i say > when the paintings are finished > i'll post pics in the cube art folder Well *thank you* for your respect for the cube :-) Most artists never care about whether they get it right. Recently I saw a box that looked like a cube, it was large and stylish etc and the seller wanted lots of money for it. And it had two yellow centers :-(. When I asked about this he (or she?) got pretty angry at me ;-) Plus, not even on the official Rubik's boxes that the cubes are sold in, or on their booklets, did the artists get them right. The pictures on the Rubik's Magic box and in the booklet are also very wrong. Sigh. .. Cheers! Stefan

1270. 3x3x1
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 21:11:44 -0000

I've been playing around with making my cube a 1x3x3. Just only allow
F2,R2,B2,and L2. It's pretty cool cause it's only a few moves away
from solved at any point.

So far my best average is 2.82 and my best time 0.44

If you guys haven't tried this you should. It's a lot of fun.




1271. Re: Deleted record
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 21:32:42 -0000

Hey Jol, The only thing I can think of is that the excel file Ron is using now has a macro to save the HTML file, which I had never used before (I stopped doing updates all the time a few months ago). It took me a while to figure out how to get the macro setup, so maybe something went weird when I tried to save the HTML file? I'll ask Ron when he gets back. If anyone did have a record go weird and revert back to an earlier one, just send it in again and put something in the post somewhere about how your old record got changed. I'll fix any stray ones that went weird, and then ask Ron what could have happened. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jol van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey Chris, > > Something also went wrong with my 4x4 record. It used to be 1:24.xx, > but now it went back to 1:32.xx. Do you know what could have > happened? > > - Jol. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey Gunnar, > > > > Yes Ron is on vacation and I am updating the records while he is > gone. > > He will be back August 31. > > > > I'm sorry that something went weird with your record. Ron has > backups > > of the records files on his computer, so we can check and see what > > went wrong when he gets back. As far as right now, go ahead and > send > > in your 18.00 average again and I will post it the next time I > update. > > > > Chris > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" > > <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > > Hi everybody! > > > > > > Today when I was checking out the average records, I notced that > my > > > latest record 18.00 was gone and replaced with my former record > 18.84. > > > Wierd!? I wonder why they (Ron?) took my newest record away. Is > there > > > anybody else that updates the record lists? > > > > > > /Gunnar
1272. Re: [Speed cubing group] an unconventional problem
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 24 Aug 2005 21:49:15 -0000

I played around in Cube Explorer a bit, and it turns out the green
sticker on the green yellow cubie which touches both the green and
white centers is the problem. If the other green-yellow piece were
the culprit, you'd have a parity problem.

-Daniel

I'm about to turn 29 years old in 2 days and everyone always assumes I'm younger that this. 1284. Re: [Speed cubing group] wife? kids? what?!?
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 01:46:57 -0000

Nah, Dan definitely does not look old! :) Recently, heaps more people have approached me while I've been cubing on the train or in other public places - it happens a couple of times a week now. I wondered why the sudden change and I came up with two ideas based on the timing of the change. My first thought was because there was a fair bit of publicity about the cube in the UK in July for the 25th anniversary of the cube. I wondered if maybe it got people reminicising about the cube they used to own adn therefore more likely to talk to someone they saw cubing. Another possibility, which someone else reminded me of, was that there were other significant events last month in London. It was suggested to me that after the train bombings last month, people are generally more observant about what's going on around them on the train and particularly things that are unusual. I like to think that it's the former - much happier to think about cube birthday celebrations! :) BTW, Per, I saw you in some pics on someones website from the Euros last year and I definitely didn't think you were almost 40 then! Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hmmm ... > > Jasmine, are you saying that Dan looks old? 1285. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich upside down
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 01:55:20 -0000

I used to do *everything* with cross on top. It was such a crappy way to do things, but I until I found this group and everyone's website I didn't know any better. I found it *really* difficult to change after years of cross on top, so I highly recommend that people just learn it with cross on bottom to begin with. I have now moved to having the cross somewhere between top and left for forming the actual cross, then I have the cross on the left for most of the F2L, and I do most of the LL with cross on bottom. There's just one or two PLLs that I do with cross on left. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I agree. That's why I do cross on bottom. But I asked if someone does all F2L with cross on top. > > Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@g...> escreveu:Doesnt doing the cross on bottom make it faster? you dont have to take > the time to turn the cube around > lol > > parth > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Free puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Online puzzle games Computer puzzle game Puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! 1286. Re: 2006 Guiness Book of World Records
From: "mackymakisumi" <mackymakisumi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 05:36:46 -0000

Thanks for the news! At least now the people who buy the book will know the right time. Of course, this is still very stupid since the Guinness now contradicts the book on their site. I was amused by this, though: "Fastest 100m On A Unicycle Peter Rosendahl set a unicycle sprint record for 100 m from a standing start of 12.11 sec (29.72 km/h, or 18.47 mph) at Las Vegas, Nevada, USA, on March 25, 1994. His unicycle talents have achieved him eight Guinness World Records, taken him to 36 countries and won him appearances on 75 TV shows." I wonder, what's his best average of 12? ;) Macky --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@o...> wrote: > My friend just told me that he saw the 2006 Guiness Book of World Records and that Macky > has the fastest solve at 12.11 > > Wasn't this a big topic last week, about them not printing his true fastest solve?

1289. Cubing + Driving
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 07:14:46 -0000

I was driving today. I had my cube in my left hand (bad idea, I drive
a stick). I was just doing some algs, not even solving. Well, the
window was open. I dropped the cube out the window as I turned at an
intersection (*tear*). There was somebody behind me. I pulled over
immediately and raced to my cube. Luckily, it was unharmed, but the
people crossing the street at that intersection (a mother and her
children) laughed at me. No more cubing while I drive (unless the
window is CLOSED :D)

~ Bob





1290. YAY
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 07:15:12 -0000

I taught my girlfriend how to solve! :D

I bet her $100 she will never be faster than me ;)

~ Bob

1293. Adjusting screws on 25th anniversary cube
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 08:04:03 -0000

I just bought a couple 25th anniversary cubes today. The ones with the
silver stickers instead of white.

Does anyone know how to get to the screws? One cube was very tight and
the other was very loose. You would think the factory would have
standards concerning screw tension. It looks like the center piece
caps are glued in. Why would they do that!?

1298. Making promotional video/commercial for a company
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 11:05:08 -0000

Hey everybody,

Some company has asked me to help them with a promotional video or
commercial... And I accepted, of course :). Pretty exited about this!
The want me solve some cubes, and the video should express something
like 'complex problems, short and fast solutions'. The goal is not to
do it as fast as possible, but they want to close-up on my hands and
see some cool and fluent finger-trick action. It's the first time I am
actually going to earn a little money by solving cubes :). Not much
probably, but I can use all little bits when I am in Florida!! The
shooting of the video will take place next tuesday... They want me to
come in a nice fancy suit :).

Well.. Just wanted to share this with you guys.

See you :),

Jol.

I think it might be something for a more specific group of people, maybe just to put it on a website or something. Anyway, I will try to ask them if they can send me a digital version of it, I am pretty sure that should be possible. - Joel. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Can you post the commercial when it airs? I's like to see it.... :) > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Jol van Noort > Verzonden: donderdag 25 augustus 2005 13:05 > Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Making promotional video/commercial for a > company > > > Hey everybody, > > Some company has asked me to help them with a promotional video or > commercial... And I accepted, of course :). Pretty exited about this! > The want me solve some cubes, and the video should express something > like 'complex problems, short and fast solutions'. The goal is not to > do it as fast as possible, but they want to close-up on my hands and > see some cool and fluent finger-trick action. It's the first time I am > actually going to earn a little money by solving cubes :). Not much > probably, but I can use all little bits when I am in Florida!! The > shooting of the video will take place next tuesday... They want me to > come in a nice fancy suit :). > > Well.. Just wanted to share this with you guys. > > See you :), > > Jol. > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+gam > e&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Puzzle+games&w5=Online+puz > zle+games&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=YrBxUkryOWjfkIOKnYni3w> > puzzle game Free > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game > &w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Puzzle+games&w5=Online+puzz > le+games&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=qtfBk7FHDG6sI2vso-Umow> > puzzle games Computer > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Computer+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+g > ame&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Puzzle+games&w5=Online+p > uzzle+games&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=u7K-coRiksOvKI6dtrjjeQ > > puzzle game > Puzzle > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=F > ree+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Puzzle+games&w5=Online+puzzle+ga > mes&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=YWQQFHCOTunMuwEMki3WCQ> games > Online > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Online+puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+ga > me&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Puzzle+games&w5=Online+pu > zzle+games&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=IuXRJzY7-WhyboJjC5uHCw> > puzzle games Free > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzl > e+game&w2=Free+puzzle+games&w3=Computer+puzzle+game&w4=Puzzle+games&w5=Onlin > e+puzzle+games&w6=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&c=6&s=145&.sig=zsMkg2SV2X6P5mVxITF > AFQ> puzzle inlay games > > _____ > > YAHOO! 1304. Sanding the internals
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 13:50:30 -0000

Does it actually help to sand the internals of a 3x3x3 cube? -- i.e.,
not just to deal with molding defects, but perhaps to reduce the
frequency of lock-ups. If so, does anyone know of pictures showing
where to do this, and how much to sand away?

Sorry if this topic comes up frequently, but I don't remember it being
discussed.

Mike




1305. RE: [Speed cubing group] Sanding the internals
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 15:58:02 +0200

If so, does anyone know of pictures showing where to do this, and how much to sand away? Sorry if this topic comes up frequently, but I don't remember it being discussed. Mike _____ YAHOO! 1306. Re: [Speed cubing group] Sanding the internals
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 14:00:43 -0000

1307. Re: Sanding the internals
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 14:15:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Does it actually help to sand the internals of a 3x3x3 cube? -- i.e., > not just to deal with molding defects, but perhaps to reduce the > frequency of lock-ups. If so, does anyone know of pictures showing > where to do this, and how much to sand away? > > Sorry if this topic comes up frequently, but I don't remember it being > discussed. > > Mike I thought I had read it was not legal to sand your cube for anything other than to remove manufacturing defects? It was a while ago that I read that, so I can't confirm the source. Can anyone else verify this? -Dave
1308. Re: Sanding the internals
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 14:23:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > Does it actually help to sand the internals of a 3x3x3 cube? -- i.e. , > not just to deal with molding defects, but perhaps to reduce the > frequency of lock-ups. If so, does anyone know of pictures showing > where to do this, and how much to sand away? > > Sorry if this topic comes up frequently, but I don't remember it being > discussed. > > Mike I'm doing that sometimes. I noticed some of my cubes have quite sharp edges (not edge pieces, but internal edges of pieces) that lock up too often. So I rounded them more. Mainly the "cubic edges", though (Imagine the pieces as small perfect cubes and round the edges that are actually there, that is for 3x3, I round three edges of each corner piece and four 0.7 edges of each edge pieces). Another reason I got this idea was because the Deluxe/Game cubes pretty much never lock up and they're a bit more rounded than other cubes, I think. I'm gonna do it with an Eastsheen 5x5 some (very long ;-) day, too. Cheers! Stefan
1309. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Sanding the internals
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 15:26:38 +0100

I can't believe that would be the case - it sounds pretty unenforceable not
mention completely mad! Also its arguable that anything that slows down
your cube is a manufacturing defect.

Having said that I've never sanded my "internals".

Duncan (poking his nose into posts that have no relevance for him)

> I thought I had read it was not legal to sand your cube for anything
> other than to remove manufacturing defects? It was a while ago that
> I read that, so I can't confirm the source. Can anyone else verify

1310. Re: Sanding the internals
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 14:28:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. .> wrote: > > I thought I had read it was not legal to sand your cube for anything > other than to remove manufacturing defects? It was a while ago that > I read that, so I can't confirm the source. Can anyone else verify > this? Probably nobody can verify that. Have a look at Article 3 of the rules, I guess that's what you meant: http://www.speedcubing.com/events/regulations_draft2005.html This is the new draft and explains with examples what's not allowed. So for example if you sand the internals so much that you can rotate the 9 centers of your 5x5 cube alone, that's not allowed. But if you sand them just so that the X-centers don't get accidentally rotated all the time thanks to locking up, that's ok. Cheers! Stefan
1311. Re: Sanding the internals
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 14:30:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > So for example if you sand the internals so much that you can rotate > the 9 centers of your 5x5 cube alone, that's not allowed. I.e. something like this: http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/Cube_46222_core.jpg Stefan

1315. Re: Sanding the internals
From: thewetdog <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 14:55:49 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Probably nobody can verify that. Have a look at Article 3 of the > rules, I guess that's what you meant: > http://www.speedcubing.com/events/regulations_draft2005.html > > Stefan Thanks, Stefan. I had been going on the pretence that it was not allowed. I was sure I had read that somewhere, so I did some quick searching and found the page (it is in the 5th paragraph after the section header "Rubik's.com cube speedcube"): http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/Speedcube/makinga.htm Since it was on the speedcubing.com site, I think I must have taken it as law. But I realize now that it is not an official document, like the one you provided. So I am glad this has been cleared up. -Dave
1316. New Cube Demo With Input Method Change + Help Screen
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 15:06:49 -0000

Greetings,

We want to thank everyone from the online cubing community who has
been kind enough to send us their comments, ideas, and suggestions.
Over the past week, we have accumulated some great ideas from you
folks as to how we can make our product better! Please keep sending
us feedback and continue to try out the new versions as we post them.

The biggest change in the new version is related to the comments
we've received about wanting an alternate method of orienting your
view of the cube. So, without losing the existing freedom of
rotation, we have added a secondary way to change your view of the
cube. Holding down the left shift key while rotating a slice of the
cube will turn the *entire* cube 90 degrees (or 180 if you also have
the left CTRL key down) in the same axis/direction the single slice
would have moved. This eases the ability to 'flip' the cube around
and see the backside without losing your current perspective on the
cube. Thanks to Jol van Noort for this suggestion!

An in-game help screen has been added that details all the available
controls as well. The change log for the demo project is now posted
on the downloads page of our website (http://www.gabbasoft.com) if
anyone is interested in seeing everything that has been modified to
date.

Again, thanks so much for all of your input and we hope you will
continue to send us your thoughts and ideas for making our product
better.

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...
http://www.gabbasoft.com

1321. Re: Sanding the internals
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 17:59:43 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, thewetdog <no_reply@y.. .> wrote: > > Thanks, Stefan. I had been going on the pretence that it was not > allowed. I was sure I had read that somewhere, so I did some quick > searching and found the page (it is in the 5th paragraph after the > section header "Rubik's.com cube speedcube"): > > http://www.speedcubing.com/ton/Speedcube/makinga.htm I think this page is a bit old already. Ton has added a few things at some point but I think it's older than the WCA rules. Also, Dan Gosbee I think once came up with very strict rules for WC 2003. For example, I remember someone had the idea to glue very strong little magnets under the center caps instead of glueing them to the center piece, and Dan said that's not allowed (maybe even that you'd be disqualified). So that kind of rules might've been around earlier, but not anymore. Cheers! Stefan
1322. Re: Sanding the internals
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 18:10:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > > four 0.7 edges of each edge pieces). > > What do you mean by "0.7 edges"? When you auctioned a speedcube > recently, I thought from the picture that the "circular edges" might > have been modified. That's one reason I posted my question, btw. > > [By "circular edges" I mean the concave edges of the edge pieces -- > they form part of the circle that you see when you remove all the > pieces of one layer. Um... it's hard to describe things clearly...] Yeah, I know what you mean. That cube actually came mainly that way, I did round other edges but those circular parts had been that way already (the picture might give a too strong impression, btw, it's not that much different than a normal edge piece). First I thought it would be bad but surprisingly it isn't. With "0.7 edges" I meant the straight part, maybe it's closer to 0.6, anyway it's not a "whole" edge because of the circular cut (which I didn't sand except its edges a bit, i.e. I did sand the outer edge of the circular edge of the edge piece ;-). Stefan
1323. Re: Sanding the internals
From: "skeneegee" <skeneegee@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 18:30:09 -0000

Take your cube to the beach. Try to avoid getting sand into your cube and some will still get in there but not very much. Then play with it in the sun (wear sunblock) for an hour or so then go home and clean your cube out really well and relube it. That gets cubes really smooth. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Does it actually help to sand the internals of a 3x3x3 cube? -- i.e., > not just to deal with molding defects, but perhaps to reduce the > frequency of lock-ups. If so, does anyone know of pictures showing > where to do this, and how much to sand away? > > Sorry if this topic comes up frequently, but I don't remember it being > discussed. > > Mike

1327. Re: PLL probabilities
From: "darereck" <darereck@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 22:15:58 -0000

Visit speedcubing.com and it tells you the probablities on the PLL algortihms. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I was wondering why some permutations cases have lower chances to > occur...Someone knows?

1332. [Speed cubing group] Re: PLL probabilities
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 23:13:52 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I want to know WHY some cases occur more often... That's simple. Each INDIVIDUAL case has the exact same likelyhood of occuring. For example. A pure PLL skip is 1/288. There are 288 distinct PLL cases (count them! :)) But, you can consider that if the cube is only U/U'/U2 away from solved, it is also a PLL skip. So there are 4/288 PLL skips => 1/72. Now take for example, something like the H-perm (edges cross perm). You will find it has the same probability. Look now at an edge 3-cycle. There are the 4 cases to align the edge (do nothing, U', U, U2). However, the "solved" edge can be any of the 4 colors. So, we have 4*4 = 16/288 = 1/18 chance for a particular edge cycle. The other edge cycle is the same. Look at the Z-perm. There are only two angles to apply the algorithm that result in a different permutation (ignoring the AUF at the end). So, There is a 2*4 = 8/288 = 1/36 chance of getting the Z-perm. Etc. For OLLs, think of it this way: If you rotate the cube and get a different angle, then it is a different case: For example: The "X" OLL: probability 1/216 (only 1 angle) The "H" OLL: probability 2/216 (two distinct angles) Most OLLs: probability 4/216 (four distinct angles) This help? ~ Bob
1333. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: PLL probabilities
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 20:32:02 -0300 (ART)

Yes, helps a lot, thanks for the explanation, Bob. Pedro PS.: Probabilities are just probabilities, they are not exactly the reality. I was doing some solves today and the F permutation occured 4 times on 20.That's 1/5. The G case occured 4 times too. The J occured 2 times and also the R. Maybe I have to do 288 solves... Bob Burton <bob@...> escreveu: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I want to know WHY some cases occur more often... That's simple. Each INDIVIDUAL case has the exact same likelyhood of occuring. For example. A pure PLL skip is 1/288. There are 288 distinct PLL cases (count them! :)) But, you can consider that if the cube is only U/U'/U2 away from solved, it is also a PLL skip. So there are 4/288 PLL skips => 1/72. Now take for example, something like the H-perm (edges cross perm). You will find it has the same probability. Look now at an edge 3-cycle. There are the 4 cases to align the edge (do nothing, U', U, U2). However, the "solved" edge can be any of the 4 colors. So, we have 4*4 = 16/288 = 1/18 chance for a particular edge cycle. The other edge cycle is the same. Look at the Z-perm. There are only two angles to apply the algorithm that result in a different permutation (ignoring the AUF at the end). So, There is a 2*4 = 8/288 = 1/36 chance of getting the Z-perm. Etc. For OLLs, think of it this way: If you rotate the cube and get a different angle, then it is a different case: For example: The "X" OLL: probability 1/216 (only 1 angle) The "H" OLL: probability 2/216 (two distinct angles) Most OLLs: probability 4/216 (four distinct angles) This help? ~ Bob SPONSORED LINKS Computer puzzle game Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Puzzle games Online puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1336. Simplified Blindfold Cubing
From: "bmcgaugh49" <bmcgaugh49@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 00:09:56 -0000

I made a site last night about my first method for solving
the 3x3x3 blindfolded...I like to think it's something like

my method: Macky's method :: layer by layer method : Fridrich method

That is, it's a place to start...it is kind of tedious because
it is so simplified...not much mental gymnastics.

I am evolving past this method, but I thought I would share it.
I keep finding bugs in the document, so I hope some people will
not hesitate to send me things to correct. If anyone actually
learns to solve blindfolded because of the site, let me know...
that would be great.

Thanks to all blindfold cubers for their inspiration and methods:
Stefan Pochmann, who definitely gave me ideas for my method
Shotaro, Leyan, Tyson, Chris Hardwick: You are all awesome
Richard Carr and Stiff hands: pioneers


Blindfold cubing is great...now I just need to succeed in
competition. ;-)

Bill McGaugh

Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 00:11:46 -0000

http://home.earthlink.net/~bmcgaugh

1339. Re: Adjusting screws on 25th anniversary cube
From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 00:56:17 -0000

I'm only about 90% sure (pretty sure) about this since I don't have one of those cubes myself, but since no one else is answering: The 25th anniversary cubes and generally any Rubik's cube you find in your average store do not have screws under the center caps. Instead, it has these annoying rivets that cannot be adjusted (except possibly to push them in further) to hold the centers in place. If you want to be able to adjust screw tension, the way to go is the DIY cube from the rubiks.com. You could also search around for a Rubik's Studio cube which also has screws, but those are harder to come by. Hope this helps, Scott p.s. If I'm wrong and they do have screws beneath the caps, someone correct me so I can feel quite dumb for not having purchased one. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, turtleparadise <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I just bought a couple 25th anniversary cubes today. The ones with >the > silver stickers instead of white. > > Does anyone know how to get to the screws? One cube was very tight >and > the other was very loose. You would think the factory would have > standards concerning screw tension. It looks like the center piece > caps are glued in. Why would they do that!?
1340. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: PLL probabilities
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 20:24:22 -0500

> PS.: Probabilities are just probabilities, they are not exactly the > reality. I was doing some solves today and the F permutation > occured 4 times on 20.That's 1/5. The G case occured 4 times too. > The J occured 2 times and also the R. Maybe I have to do 288 > solves... yes, but the more you solve, the closer your actual will get to the theoretical (the law of large numbers). you probably wont get the same probability by doing 288, but you will be pretty close. 1343. Teaching a young'in
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 02:26:00 -0000

Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice?

I'm teaching my little (9-year old) sister how to solve. She's
starting to learn the concept of the "cross." Nothing is really
obvious to her, like certiain things are to others who first get
started, so I find that I have to explain every single detail.

~ Bob

1346. Re: [Speed cubing group] Teaching a young'in
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 23:53:17 -0400

I've been trying to teach my 7 year old sister (my father bet me $100
she couldn't learn it - kinda like your bet Bob, only in my favor :) )
She understands the cross, but has difficulties completing it. It's a
very slow process. I think the intuitive stuff will be the most
difficult, as children are usually very quick to memorize things,
especially when it comes to games. I think a few algs will be easily
handled.


Bryan Mytko
bryanosaurus@...

1347. Re: Teaching a young'in
From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 05:13:33 -0000

My wife and I (mostly my wife) recently taught my 10 year old sister- in-law to finish the f2l with a working corner method (cross/bottom corners/bottom edges/cross on top). My wife did have to explain a lot more details than you'd expect from an adult, but that's not a surprise. Also, a big help was that we were on a long, boring six hour car ride, so attention span wasn't an issue. Her choices were learn to cube or be completely bored. (hmm.... that sounds mean.) Scott --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> >wrote: > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any >advice? > > I'm teaching my little (9-year old) sister how to solve. She's > starting to learn the concept of the "cross." Nothing is really > obvious to her, like certiain things are to others who first get > started, so I find that I have to explain every single detail. > > ~ Bob

1349. 4x4x4 speedsolve tutorial (update)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 06:23:02 -0000

Hey everyone,

I'm still working on my 4x4x4 tutorial, it's pretty long so far with
lots of pictures and detailed explanations.

Anyway I'm done with the centers page, my method for the edges, and
now I'm working on a page with a detailed example solve of the 6 pair
method.

Again I wouldn't use that approach except for in very rare special
cases for my method, but I've done a lot of practicing with it, so I
want to include it to be fair to those who like it, especially since
it can be VERY fast.

So anyway I think I can finish either tomorrow (well Friday lol) or
Saturday. I'll post the link once I'm finished with everything.

So if you're looking for a really detailed explanation of a 4x4x4
speed solve method you don't have to wait long!

Chris

P.S. This entire page is only on how to transform your scrambled 4x4
into a scrambled 3x3 (with the potential for parities still). So your
4x4 times will still very much depend on your 3x3x3 times, but as I
say on the page you might as well use a nice method for the
transforming part to help your times. Anyway it'll be up soon!





1350. F2L algoritms
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>

Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 08:28:38 +0200

You probably all know the answer to this, but since I'm new to this, I am
wondering where I can find the best F2L algoritms. I assume there is a site
that lists them all, but I haven't found it yet...

- Bram

onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en
de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren.

and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you
receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents
herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail.

1352. RE: [Speed cubing group] F2L algoritms
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 08:38:36 +0200

Thanks a lot... This is a great page!! - Bram -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Chris Hunt Verzonden: vrijdag 26 augustus 2005 8:31 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L algoritms Bob has the answer :) Visit Bob's F2L page and if you don't like some of his algs, he has links to several other F2L pages at the bottom of this page: http://cubewhiz.com/f2l.html <http://cubewhiz.com/f2l.html> -Chris On 8/25/05, Beer, Bram de <bbeer@...> wrote: > Hi all, > > You probably all know the answer to this, but since I'm new to this, I am > wondering where I can find the best F2L algoritms. I assume there is a site > that lists them all, but I haven't found it yet... > > - Bram ================================================ De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Does anyone know how to insert your photos into the Customizable
Sticker Sheets MS Word Template from Rubiks.com? I bought the
customizable sticker sheets that you can print your own photos onto
and then apply to your cube. However, I have tried everything from
drag and drop, right click and paste, Insert -> Picture from the file
menu at the top of MS Word and the photos wont drop into a grid of 9
squares. The photos always go to the top left corner of the document
and they wont allow you to drag and drop it anywhere else in the
document. Has anyone else figured this out?





1354. bigcubes anyone?
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 23:50:43 -0700 (PDT)

ok after about 2 months of hella work i'd like to
unveil a pretty much completed www.bigcubes.com i
hope this site will help with all the the ?'s i've
seen lately on bigger cubes. i'd like to thank frank
morris for his massive contribution with videos and
methodology, this site wouldn't be as good or nearly
as accurate without his help. also chris hardwick for
help with the 4x4 ideas and some proofreading. and
last but not least lars petrus who's extremely badass
applet filled 3x3 page inspired me to try and reach
the same great level with page, and getting me to
start speedsolving. many edits will be made i'm sure
there's lots of spelling and other things, and i'm
adding specific points of acheivement and other things
to help people along. please email me via the group or
the link on the site for any ?s or comments.

clancy

1356. Re: [Speed cubing group] Teaching a young'in
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 08:22:14 +0100

Not read any other replies but in teaching my kids who are 9 and 10 I found they developed a real interest and feel after I showed them some very simple patterns to practice (and they wanted me to time them making the patterns too lol). Things like checks, spots and stripes. They found making the cross pretty tricky (I showed them how to get orientation right and then position them by putting things on the bottom layer and matching them with centres. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, August 26, 2005 3:26 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Teaching a young'in > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? > > I'm teaching my little (9-year old) sister how to solve. She's > starting to learn the concept of the "cross." Nothing is really > obvious to her, like certiain things are to others who first get > started, so I find that I have to explain every single detail. > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >

I can't wait! :) - Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I'm still working on my 4x4x4 tutorial, it's pretty long so far with > lots of pictures and detailed explanations. > > Anyway I'm done with the centers page, my method for the edges, and > now I'm working on a page with a detailed example solve of the 6 pair > method. > > Again I wouldn't use that approach except for in very rare special > cases for my method, but I've done a lot of practicing with it, so I > want to include it to be fair to those who like it, especially since > it can be VERY fast. > > So anyway I think I can finish either tomorrow (well Friday lol) or > Saturday. I'll post the link once I'm finished with everything. > > So if you're looking for a really detailed explanation of a 4x4x4 > speed solve method you don't have to wait long! > > Chris > > P.S. This entire page is only on how to transform your scrambled 4x4 > into a scrambled 3x3 (with the potential for parities still). So your > 4x4 times will still very much depend on your 3x3x3 times, but as I > say on the page you might as well use a nice method for the > transforming part to help your times. Anyway it'll be up soon!
1361. Re: New Zealand Champion
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 10:42:01 -0000

Hi Nicola, I am reasonably certain that no New Zealander has even competed in any WCA recognised competitions (WCA = World Cubing Association). I'm Australian and as far as I can tell I'm the only Australian who's competed in any WCA recognised competitions! I'm sure there are people in New Zealand who solve, but I've never meet any at any cube events and I haven't met any cubers online from New Zealand. This Yahoo forum is where most cubers around the world congregate so it's certainly a good group to contact! Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "riskyb111" <riskyb111@y...> wrote: > Hi My name is Nicola Barnes. 1363. Cubist population ratio?
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 10:44:20 -0000

Has anyone heard statistics about cubist population ratios? I wonder
how many people in the western world can solve the cube in say 5
minutes or less. 1 in 500? 1 in 1000? It seems we are few and far
between. Not because we are smart, but because we were patient and
didn't give up.





1364. Re: 4x4x4 speedsolve tutorial (update)
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 10:52:43 -0000

Jol, When I got my first 4x4x4 back around 1983 I almost solved it with just the 3x3x3 algorithms and some basic logic. I got stuck with the edge piece parity problem and how to permute center pieces. Since the parity problem comes around only 50 percent of the time I would just shuffle the edges up a bit and permute them again until the parity problem didn't appear. A book helped me with permuting center pieces. I now have a 15 move algorithm that permutes two edge pieces and solves the parity problem. If you can solve the 3x3x3 I'm sure you are close. How close can you get to solving the 4x4x4 now? --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jol van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey Chris! > > When I read the title of your message, I tought: "Cool, Chris has > done some updating on his 4x4 page!". But no.. Have to wait longer : > (... Since I have been practicing the 4x4 a little more lately, I am > certainly interested in it! I can't wait! :) > > - Jol. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > > > > I'm still working on my 4x4x4 tutorial, it's pretty long so far > with > > lots of pictures and detailed explanations. > > > > Anyway I'm done with the centers page, my method for the edges, and > > now I'm working on a page with a detailed example solve of the 6 > pair > > method. > > > > Again I wouldn't use that approach except for in very rare special > > cases for my method, but I've done a lot of practicing with it, so > I > > want to include it to be fair to those who like it, especially > since > > it can be VERY fast. > > > > So anyway I think I can finish either tomorrow (well Friday lol) or > > Saturday. I'll post the link once I'm finished with everything. > > > > So if you're looking for a really detailed explanation of a 4x4x4 > > speed solve method you don't have to wait long! > > > > Chris > > > > P.S. This entire page is only on how to transform your scrambled > 4x4 > > into a scrambled 3x3 (with the potential for parities still). So > your > > 4x4 times will still very much depend on your 3x3x3 times, but as I > > say on the page you might as well use a nice method for the > > transforming part to help your times. Anyway it'll be up soon!
1365. Re: Teaching a young'in
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 11:00:58 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? Yes, I taught one of my daughters when she was 9 (or possibly 8), because she asked me to. The cube was tough for her, trying on her own, and she had got discouraged, even though she had already solved the pyraminx partly by herself. The cross was no problem for her, but placing 3 corners with the correct orientations was difficult for her to grasp. The first 3 middle layer edges were no problem. "Picking up the last edge with the last corner" was harder again. I encouraged her to practice F2L a lot before we went on to LL. She "got" the commutator principle surprisingly quickly. All of her LL methods are based on commutators. And no conjugates, I think. The whole process took several weeks, with a session every few days when she asked for one: we took it slowly, so she would understand what she was doing and perhaps tackle other puzzles on her own. However, the only other puzzle she tries regularly is Square-1 -- just solving the shapes and getting edges into their correct layers so far (i.e., the intuitive steps). Mike

Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 06:50:42 -0500

1367. Re: Cubist population ratio?
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 11:52:07 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, turtleparadise <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Has anyone heard statistics about cubist population ratios? I wonder > how many people in the western world can solve the cube in say 5 > minutes or less. 1 in 500? 1 in 1000? It would be interesting to know, but I don't think you could get reliable stats on that, short of going out on the street and asking several thousand strangers if they can solve the cube. (If someone can solve the cube reliably, the chances are that they can do it in under 5 minutes, wouldn't you think?) > It seems we are few and far > between. Not because we are smart, but because we were patient and > didn't give up. And you have to really /want/ to do it. ;) Of course, if more people around you are doing it, this will help generate the necessary interest: at university in the early 80s quite a lot of people I knew (male and female) could solve the Cube in a few minutes. But students of maths, science and engineering are not a typical subset of the population. :D Mike
1368. Re: Customizable Sticker Sheets MS Word Template
From: "mgwallisa" <mattwallisa@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 12:03:58 -0000

I've never made the custom stickers, but I did make up little flash cards of OLL where I tried to use the pictures in MS Word and I had the same problem. I never figured out how to move them, so I just e- mailed the pictures to myself, one by one, where they ended up in the middle of the page. I don't know how the sticker sheet is set up, but I'm thinking you could do it sort of the way I did my flash cards by first printing on paper your picture. You would then know just where your picture ends up, and tape the sticker sheet exactly over that, running it through the printer again. Like I said, I don't know what the sticker sheets look like, or if they're too thick for your printer to feed them with another sheet of paper. My printer wouldn't feed the card when it was on the left side of the page, but it could when it was in the middle. Matt --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, turtleparadise <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Does anyone know how to insert your photos into the Customizable > Sticker Sheets MS Word Template from Rubiks.com? I bought the > customizable sticker sheets that you can print your own photos onto > and then apply to your cube. However, I have tried everything from > drag and drop, right click and paste, Insert -> Picture from the file > menu at the top of MS Word and the photos wont drop into a grid of 9 > squares. The photos always go to the top left corner of the document > and they wont allow you to drag and drop it anywhere else in the > document. Has anyone else figured this out?

1370. Re: Simplified Blindfold Cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 12:43:54 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "bmcgaugh49" <bmcgaugh49@m...> wrote: > > I made a site last night about my first method for solving > the 3x3x3 blindfolded...I like to think it's something like I don't have time right now to read it completely, but there's one comment I'd like to give already. You say: "This system, because it uses 2-cycles, will not allow you to break the world record for solving blindfolded." That is wrong. I'm using 2-cycles as well and I've solved the cube (just not blindfolded) under 1 minute this way. With more practice and some more algorithms I'm sure I can average 1 minute. The unofficial world record might be harder to beat, but the official one stands at over 2 minutes so with fast memorization it's definitely possible to beat it. Cheers! Stefan
1371. Re: Teaching a young'in
From: "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 12:52:52 -0000

> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> wrote: > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? My brother and I learned when I was 12 and he was 9. We had a page of hints from our older cousin as our only guide. I mastered it in about a week. He had it about a week later. We were on long road trip (vacation) at the time, so we had plenty of time to practice! He was pretty fast, too, as I recall. About 3-4 minutes-- not bad for a 9-year old! Chris
1372. Re: 4x4x4 speedsolve tutorial (update)

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, turtleparadise <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Jol, > > If you can solve the 3x3x3 I'm sure you are close. How close can you > get to solving the 4x4x4 now? 1373. Re: Teaching a young'in
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 13:02:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? > > I'm teaching my little (9-year old) sister how to solve. She's > starting to learn the concept of the "cross." Nothing is really > obvious to her, like certiain things are to others who first get > started, so I find that I have to explain every single detail. > > ~ Bob Does she *want* to learn it? If not, you're lost anyway ;-). But if yes, why don't you let her find out things herself first. It's not like she only has a few days left in life, is it? Maybe with some guidance like "solve the white face", then when she can safely do that, "solve the first layer". Or just tell her "solve as much as you can" and see where that leads her and go on from there. Maybe she'd go a corners first way. I could imagine she'll learn faster when she thinks on her own rather than trying to remember what you tell her. Cheers! Stefan

1376. 15 seconds in 1981

for? Single or average, lucky or nonlucky?

1378. Re: 15 seconds in 1981
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 15:15:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > Does anyone have this book? What's the method? What are the 15 seconds > for? Single or average, lucky or nonlucky? > > http://www.twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pid=1374 > > Stefan Thierry told us his average was 19s (more precisely 18.95s), not 15s. His method looks like this: - A face minus an edge. - Corners. - Edges. Gilles.

1380. Re: Teaching a young'in
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 17:18:11 -0000

I learned when I was 11. I had no teacher. I just wanted to learn. I was able to consistently solve the first layer and 3 edges of the 2nd layer. I bought a book and learned the rest that way. In elementary school one teacher claimed he could solve it so we raced one day. I surprised when beat him. In middle school I knew only one other kid that could solve it. We were good friends and met at lunch often. I moved and in high school I think I was the only one in the whole school that could colve a cube. :( --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > <bob@c...> wrote: > > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? > > My brother and I learned when I was 12 and he was 9. We had a page of > hints from our older cousin as our only guide. I mastered it in about > a week. He had it about a week later. We were on long road trip > (vacation) at the time, so we had plenty of time to practice! > > He was pretty fast, too, as I recall. About 3-4 minutes-- not bad for > a 9-year old! > > Chris
1381. Magic Strings
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 18:06:33 -0000

I broke 1 string...how can I fix it without taking the whole thing
apart???

Craig




1382. Re: Caltech Dallas Tournament DVD is ready!
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 18:39:26 -0000

I got my copy of the Dallas DVD and it's very well done. The quality of the footage is very good and the main menu theme song is hilarious (spliced with audio of some crowd reactions)! I also really like that each solve has its own chapter and title so at the beginning of a clip the screen might say "Ian Winokur 24.40 seconds" and you might say "Who wants to watch Ian solve in 24? Not me." and then hit the next chapter button. Great job, Chris! Ian --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > Hello everyone, > > I know that everyone has been on the edge of their seat just waiting > for me to finish the Dallas DVD, so I'm proud to announce that it is > ready for me to share! :) > > If you are interested at all at getting a copy of the Dallas DVD or > would like more details, please visit the page below: > > http://strangepuzzle.com/dvd.html > > As the page above mentions, the price of the DVD includes free > shipping to anywhere in the world. Thanks for taking a look and have a > splendid day! > > -Chris
1383. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Teaching a young'in
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 19:41:12 +0100 (BST)

Hello everyone here, I am J.bernett orlando.I AM 9 NOW. I learnt 3*3*3 when I was 7 from my dad. He knows only LBL method even today. He is happy with his under 2 min solves. Mr.Stefan Pochmann then tutored me for blindfold. He really made me to think rather than just tutoring. Thanks to him. Then I learnt F2L I understood the theory behind these algm on my own. Now I know all 57 OLL and 21 PLL. by heart but can not explain the theory of these algms. I learnt 4*4*4 from chris hardwick page. I learnt 5*5*5 and megaminx myself. I am not sure what those methods are called. I have to improve my solving 5*5*5 and megaminx. I am still learning fingering from Bob Burtons video. Mr.Ron Van Bruchem, Mr. Tyson Mao are really encouraging me to come back fair and genuine after the biggest mistake I made 2 months ago. Thanks to both of them. I have successfully tutored few of my relatives and friends(not less than 10 and all are below 13). I successfully taught my elder sister 3*3*3 blindfolded. She is doing correctly!! J.Bernett Orlando turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: I learned when I was 11. I had no teacher. I just wanted to learn. I was able to consistently solve the first layer and 3 edges of the 2nd layer. I bought a book and learned the rest that way. In elementary school one teacher claimed he could solve it so we raced one day. I surprised when beat him. In middle school I knew only one other kid that could solve it. We were good friends and met at lunch often. I moved and in high school I think I was the only one in the whole school that could colve a cube. :( --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "christopher_pelley" <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > <bob@c...> wrote: > > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? > > My brother and I learned when I was 12 and he was 9. We had a page of > hints from our older cousin as our only guide. I mastered it in about > a week. He had it about a week later. We were on long road trip > (vacation) at the time, so we had plenty of time to practice! > > He was pretty fast, too, as I recall. About 3-4 minutes-- not bad for > a 9-year old! > > Chris --------------------------------- YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. 1385. New Relay to Try
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 18:58:01 -0000

Try doing the relay

2x2x2+3x3x3+3x3x3+3x3x3+3x3x3+4x4x4+4x4x4

its 1 2x2x2, 4 3x3x3s, and 2 4x4x4s, in any order. Send it in to
speedcubing.com, I already did...

Craig
