Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 21:35:26 -0000

Have you noticed that every time USA wakes up, this mailinglist gets
like a thousand new messages!! When I check this site for new messages
in day time, there is only a few new messages but now when it's night
here in Sweden it's suddenly 40 new messages. Interesting!? I think
that!

/Gunnar

1394. First blindfold on tape.
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 15:04:33 -0700

I decided to take a video of myself doing blindfold. This was a pretty
fast solve for me, but, as usual, I had trouble with the memorization:

http://www.plu.edu/~huntca/blindfold.wmv

It's a small download, so enjoy!

-Chris

1399. 4x4x4 speedsolve solution is online
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 00:40:57 -0000

Hey everyone,

The page is finally done. It's huge, so don't expect to get through
it quickly.

I still need to add some more organization, break up the longer pages,
and things like that, but all the content is already there.

http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/4speedsolve.html

I did include a walk-through solve using the 6-pair method, but please
keep in mind that in no way am I an expert in using the 6 pair method.
So if you really want to learn that method well, then ask around. I
did try to put in the tricks that I know for it though, which really
isn't much.

The 2 pair method is extremely detailed with all the special case
situations that I would recognize, so feel free to check that out too.

Many thanks to Clancy, and Richard Patterson for helping me proofread
and getting feedback on layout.

Also the most thanks goes to Jon Morris for the great 4x4 template!
The graphics look really nice, so Jon thanks a bunch!

Let me know what you all think. Keep in mind, although the content is
all there, it's still a work in progress. I just couldn't wait any
longer to post it :-D

Chris




1400. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4x4 speedsolve solution is online
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 26 Aug 2005 17:47:33 -0700

On 8/26/05, cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > The page is finally done. It's huge, so don't expect to get through > it quickly. Thanks a lot Chris. I'm going to grab a bottle of water and enjoy :) -Chris
1401. Re: [Speed cubing group] F2L algoritms
From: "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 01:22:17 -0000

Wow! Both are great! I finished learning all of F2L algs from Dan
Harris' page while waiting at the doctor's. Oh no, that sounds very
cocky. Admitted, I already knew every one of them but three. But it's
great to check your solutions with others.

I am certainly going to check my algs against yours, David.

F2L is fun!
Michiel

> http://puzzlingaddiction.com/Cube/f2l/
> > http://cubewhiz.com/f2l.html

I am not sure what those methods are called. I > have to improve my solving 5*5*5 and megaminx. > > I am still learning fingering from Bob Burtons video. > Mr.Ron Van Bruchem, Mr. Tyson Mao are really encouraging me to come > back fair and genuine after the biggest mistake I made 2 months ago. > Thanks to both of them. > > I have successfully tutored few of my relatives and friends(not > less than 10 and all are below 13). I successfully taught my elder > sister 3*3*3 blindfolded. She is doing correctly!! > > J.Bernett Orlando > > > > turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > > I learned when I was 11. I had no teacher. I just wanted to learn. I > > was able to consistently solve the first layer and 3 edges of the > 2nd > > layer. I bought a book and learned the rest that way. In elementary > > school one teacher claimed he could solve it so we raced one day. I > > surprised when beat him. In middle school I knew only one other kid > > that could solve it. We were good friends and met at lunch often. I > > moved and in high school I think I was the only one in the whole > > school that could colve a cube. :( > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "christopher_pelley" > > <christopher_pelley@y...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > > > > <bob@c...> wrote: > > > > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? 1403. Re: Magic Strings
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 01:41:44 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > I broke 1 string...how can I fix it without taking the whole thing > apart??? I wrote this guide as an e-mail to Dave Campbell a few weeks ago. I don't remember the details and I don't feel like re-reading them, so some of this stuff may not apply, but I believe it will give you enough information to do what you need: This explains how to (re)place a string. 1) Identify the location of where the string belongs. This part is simple. Look for the two gaps in which there are only two strings instead of four. It's quite easy to notice. The gaps will be diagonal from each other. The three tiles that "touch" those gaps are the ones that the missing string belongs on. If any of the gaps are above/below tiles instead of next to the tiles (ie - not all in the same row of tiles), then fold the magic, shift the magic so that the gaps will be in the same row, and then open it again. 2) Find the location of the missing metal bit. There are two main options: a) place it so that there are 2 metal bits on every other tile; or: b) place it so that there is 1 metal bit on every tile. Choose which pattern you wish to follow (or follow the existing pattern). This will determine where you will "start" in the string. 3) Place the string around the first corner (it will be diagonal and to the outside of either of the gaps that has fewer strings. Make sure you have an idea of where the metal bit will go when you put the string around the first corner. You will want to put the string behind the corner, not in front, so this will determine how you hold the puzzle. You have to follow the over-and-under pattern already existing on the puzzle. 4) String the puzzle. Follow the over-under pattern along the three tiles, wrap it around, and bring it back the other way. Make sure you place the strings properly into the gaps. You will want to achieve a "sandwich" of strings. This means that you will have one string going in a direction, two strings above it going in the perpendicular direction, and then a fourth string at the top going in the original direction. 5) Place the last loop of the string. This part is the most difficult, but becomes easy with practice. When you place the last loop of the string, you want to make sure you do this on an inside corner, so that there is an even distribution of tension. Try to flex the tiles to make this easier. You may want to use something to bring the string over the last corner. I used to use a pencap, but I have also used a pen/pencil for this (though this may put a nick in the string, I suspect). I believe Stefan Pochmann uses gift twine. Now, I just use my fingers. It will seem like it will not go, but if you force it (not too hard!) it will go over the corner. ~ Bob
1404. repost
From: "perscription_death" <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 01:46:33 -0000

sorry if this is a repeat but a couple people said they didn't ever
see this message for some reason..

ok after about 2 months of hella work i'd like to
unveil a pretty much completed http://www.bigcubes.com i
hope this site will help with all the the ?'s i've
seen lately on bigger cubes. i'd like to thank frank
morris for his massive contribution with videos and
methodology, this site wouldn't be as good or nearly
as accurate without his help. also chris hardwick for
help with the 4x4 ideas and some proofreading. and
last but not least lars petrus who's extremely badass
applet filled 3x3 page inspired me to try and reach
the same great level with page, and getting me to
start speedsolving. many edits will be made i'm sure
there's lots of spelling and other things, and i'm
adding specific points of acheivement and other things
to help people along. please email me via the group or
the link on the site for any ?s or comments.

1408. Cube Demo Updated For 20x20x20 Cube Support
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 03:35:28 -0000

Cube Demo Updated For 20x20x20 Cube Support

Greetings,

I can't believe how many requests we've received about the desire
for larger cubes! Of course, I should have known better after I saw
that someone in Japan had solved the 9x9x9 in a little over 2 hours
and posted the screenshots on his site. So, as of this release, we
now support cube sizes up to 20x20x20. I would certainly expect
that performance will noticably degrade on slower/older systems when
you get up to 15x15x15 and above but you are free to give `em a
try. Ton from Speedcubing.com made the request for changing the
timer behavior to wait until the first move is made after a scramble
to start seemed to be a good idea to me so that has been added as
well. We've also received enough comments about the moving
background making people dizzy to change it and make it static we
hope you like it better! You can get the latest version from our
downloads page: http://www.gabbasoft.com/download.htm

As always, thanks so much for all of your input and we hope you will
continue to send us your thoughts and ideas for making our product
better.

Regards,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@gabbasoft.com
http://www.gabbasoft.com

1411. New Personal Best
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 05:12:57 -0000

(16.93) 22.29 20.37 23.18 23.48 26.40 21.76 (27.21) 26.47 21.76 26.27
22.00 => 23.40

The 16.93 is my first sub-17 non-lucky solve:

L2 B' U2 F2 L' B F2 L' U' R2 F' L' B2 U F L' B' D2 U B R' U2 F' L' R

Try it! :D

~ Bob

1419. Re: First blindfold on tape.
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 16:51:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > I decided to take a video of myself doing blindfold. Thanks -- that's the first laugh I've had today! :D Mike
1420. Original Cube packaging
From: "bryanosaurus" <bmytko@...>

Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 18:13:04 -0000

some come in little cylinders: http://cgi.ebay.com/Original-RUBIKS-CUBE-as-new-in-
Box_W0QQitemZ5233164358QQcategoryZ80547QQrdZ1QQcmdZViewItem


and others in a black/yellow box: http://cgi.ebay.com/ORIGINAL-RUBIKS-CUBE-MIP-Ideal-
Toys-1980-Mint_W0QQitemZ5994443170QQcategoryZ19187QQrdZ1QQcmdZViewItem



Is there any difference between these cubes?




1421. Re: Original Cube packaging
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 18:56:24 -0000

Wow, my first post!

The metal cylinders were sold in Europe, the black/yellow boxes in the
USA. Also in the USA, the first generation of Ideal cubes (before the
boxes) were sold in plastic cylinders. I was once the proud owner of
one of these, waaay back in the early 80's, but it broke within a few
days. :(

1424. [Speed cubing group] Re: Original Cube packaging
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 20:24:35 -0000

The sad thing is, I don't think it genuinely broke. Just one of the edge cubies popped out and maybe a corner. When I brought it sadly to my stepdad to fix, we didn't have the Jim Nourse book and he had no idea that you had to turn it 45 degrees to put it back. I think he ended up with a cube without one corner piece, at which point he gave up and returned it to the toy store. In that short time, however, the store had switched from the cylinder cubes to the boxed ones, so I never got the cylinder cube back. :( --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Rune Wesstrm <rune.wesstrom@h...> wrote: > How does a cube break? > > ----- Original Message ----- > > USA. 1425. Re: Cubing + Driving
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 20:24:58 -0000

I never would have survived that early moring drive to Chicago had I not cubed while driving. Cubing while driving a stick isn't that hard, especially if you one hand. (I also drive a stick; it's cooler) It makes drives across states much more enjoyable, and is a great way to cement algs. -Mike Bennett > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> > wrote: > > I was driving today. I had my cube in my left hand (bad idea, I drive > > a stick). I was just doing some algs, not even solving. Well, the > > window was open. I dropped the cube out the window as I turned at an > > intersection (*tear*). There was somebody behind me. I pulled over > > immediately and raced to my cube. Luckily, it was unharmed, but the > > people crossing the street at that intersection (a mother and her > > children) laughed at me. No more cubing while I drive (unless the > > window is CLOSED :D) > > > > ~ Bob
1426. Re: Teaching a young'in
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 20:51:20 -0000

I taught my younger brother (turned ten a few days ago) to solve the first two layers a couple of weeks ago, before I left the country. Depending on whether people have an easier time seeing corners or edges, I teach them a corners first approach or a layer one. He, like most, sees edges fairly easily, so that's the way we went. For most beginners, I try to remember the things that helped me when I was teaching myself, thinking back to the days of elation after ten or more minute solves. A good 'trick' is to get the pieces directly below where they need to end up. Then there are two simple cases: F2; or adjust D, RF'R or L'FL. Same for corners. Directly under where they should be, matching up the sticker colors to the center in front. (cross on white on top) 'If white is on the right, hold the white sticker on the right side; then, R'D'R.' If it's on the left, hold the white sticker on the left, then show them LDL'. The one that gives people the most trouble, in my experience, is the case where the white sticker is facing down. The most successful way to tackle this is to show them to solve it like either case, but make a D2 turn instead, to 'make it usable.' >From there, I think using the algs FU2RUR'U2F' and FU2RU'R'U2F' are very easy to understand, because the target spot is always in the same place, and the algs differ only in the direction of a single turn. If they do well with this, working corners are next, using a similar approach to the corner pieces. For the LL, they always seem to do the best with a sheet of paper with the steps described clearly and with pictures. Some people get OeLL+PCLL+OCLL+PELL very easily, which can be very fast. Others have trouble recognizing the corner permutation cases, so I have them do OELL+OCLL+PCLL+PELL. This will probably be more conducive later to upgrading to full PLL, but I think is harder to learn at the outset. That's all the advice I have at the moment, and I may write more if I have time later. -Mike Bennett --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Has anybody taught a young child how to solve the cube? Any advice? > > I'm teaching my little (9-year old) sister how to solve. She's > starting to learn the concept of the "cross." Nothing is really > obvious to her, like certiain things are to others who first get > started, so I find that I have to explain every single detail. > > ~ Bob
1427. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Cubing + Driving
From: Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 13:53:46 -0700 (PDT)

i to am stupid enough to cube while driving....its kind of dangerous in the bay area, i've restricted it to stoplights now because then the worst consequense is a honk, but as for mobile cubing i don't really recommend it, especially if u live in a heavy traffic area. its rather hard for me not to look every now and then, but if u can control ur urges, its a great thing to get algs down for OH solving...but make sure u have good insurance.. :) --- Mike Bennett <mikebennett_one@...> wrote: > I never would have survived that early moring drive > to Chicago had I > not cubed while driving. > > Cubing while driving a stick isn't that hard, > especially if you one > hand. 1430. Fun ways to abuse your cube.
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 21:33:48 -0000

Ok, I'll start, if you insist. :) Here's an adventure I had with the
second cube I ever owned.

As you may have noticed, the faces of the Rubik's Cube TURN.
Therefore, said my flawless 8-year-old boyhood logic, I can stand on
the cube, on one leg, and spin around like a ballarina. So I tried it
and managed to spin about 1/8 turn. I tried it again and got up to a
quarter turn. Then I really cranked it up and spun (span?) as hard and
fast as I could.

CRRUNCH

Suddenly I was on the ground, with my cube in about a dozen pieces.
One of the centers had completely come off, screw and all. I told my
stepdad, "Uhh my cube broke again" and he replied, "I'm going to
exchange this one more time. If you break it again, you will not get
another one."

Needless to say, that third cube was not used as a Stand-n-Spin. It
lasted a LONG time.

A lot of these categories also don't exist anymore. -Ben --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" > <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > And I have a nice record for one-footed, blindfolded solve under > > water. > > > > /Gunnar > > I think that one would actually get on speedcubing.com if you can > convince Ron that it's real ;-). He'd probably create a general > category like "amazing bld stuff" again, though. When I'm fast enough > I'm gonna try blindfolded under water and submit it... > > Stefan

1434. Re: [Speed cubing group] Fridrich upside down
From: Franois Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 28 Aug 2005 02:02:53 +0200

Huh? Doug, I haven't solved a F2L on top in 1.5 year... you might want to ask me though, but I'm not sure I'll want be able to answer... I know Per does LL on bottom (yeah he is crazy, but eh, he is Norvegian... :-p), but I think (only my guess but I have actually never seen anyone doing elseways, besides Per) most people will just turn the cube upside down after the F2L is done so they get the LL on top. And for the record, cross on the left rocks. Franois PS. if someone answered that mail already, just forget about me, but I've been away for a few days so I missed a lot. I'm trying to catch up on the recent topics... Douglas Reed a crit : > I think Francios Sechet used to do the F2L on top. You might want to > ask him. > > Doug > > pedrosino1 wrote: > > >Someone here cubes with cross on top? I don't like that, because you > >have to use a lot of D turns, and I prefer U turns. 1435. Team Blindfold
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 28 Aug 2005 04:51:08 -0000

Wow, this is so much fun (not to mention ADDICTING!). Ian came over
my house today and we did team blindfold for the 2nd time together
(1st being last weekend). :)

We got a best average of 44.72 seconds:
Individual Times:
37.91 L' R' D B' F2 D' B2 L' F B L D' F2 D2 R' F U' L U' F R' L' B2 U F
46.37 D' U' B U' R2 L B L2 B D2 F2 U L D U2 L' B' D F L' D2 R F U2 L'
(1:01.59) D2 R F' R' D2 F U2 R U' F2 L' D' B' F' R L2 D U F D2 R2 L2
U2 D R2
43.87 B2 L U' R F U D R F2 D2 R2 L2 D' B' D2 L R2 D2 U' B2 L2 B' F R2 D2
51.17 R' B F2 L D2 B F2 L' R2 D U' L' F B' U D L' U2 D' R U' R B2 F' R
46.35 B' U2 F B U2 R F2 R U L2 D' R' D2 L' U' B2 R2 L2 F' B2 U L' F' R D'
43.88 D2 B' R2 U2 L' F2 B' R B' R U' F' R U' R D U2 F B2 D2 R2 B D B2 R
42.45 B U F2 L2 U' D' L2 F' R' U' F' R2 B' D F D' B2 U' F' B2 U' D'
L2 D' F'
43.36 R U2 F' B' R U2 B L B' U2 F2 R2 D' R2 L' D B' F L2 U2 F L D B F
55.58 F R L D L' B' D' B2 F2 D' F B R' B2 R L2 D' R' D2 R2 F' R2 B D' U2
36.22 F' B' L2 F U B' F2 U' L' D' L2 R2 F' L2 D R' D' R' F' U2 L U2
B2 L B'
(35.44) U R' F' R B2 U2 D B' U L2 U L' B D2 B' R F L' R' F U2 F2 D B' L

...and perhaps the first ever average of 100: 54.90 seconds. ;)

Here is a 36.98 second solve we got on video:
http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonwinokurteambld3698.wmv

The file is just unde 4 MB.

Our best single was a 33.98, though we did get a 29.80 PLL skip early
on. :)

I believe we are both shocked at our average being 14 seconds faster
than last week. :D

~ Bob

1441. [Speed cubing group] Re: New Relay to Try
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>

I'd like to try it once. - Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Wow, this is so much fun (not to mention ADDICTING!). Ian came over > my house today and we did team blindfold for the 2nd time together > (1st being last weekend). :) > > We got a best average of 44.72 seconds: > Individual Times: > 37.91 L' R' D B' F2 D' B2 L' F B L D' F2 D2 R' F U' L U' F R' L' B2 U F > 46.37 D' U' B U' R2 L B L2 B D2 F2 U L D U2 L' B' D F L' D2 R F U2 L' > (1:01.59) D2 R F' R' D2 F U2 R U' F2 L' D' B' F' R L2 D U F D2 R2 L2 > U2 D R2 > 43.87 B2 L U' R F U D R F2 D2 R2 L2 D' B' D2 L R2 D2 U' B2 L2 B' F R2 D2 > 51.17 R' B F2 L D2 B F2 L' R2 D U' L' F B' U D L' U2 D' R U' R B2 F' R > 46.35 B' U2 F B U2 R F2 R U L2 D' R' D2 L' U' B2 R2 L2 F' B2 U L' F' R D' > 43.88 D2 B' R2 U2 L' F2 B' R B' R U' F' R U' R D U2 F B2 D2 R2 B D B2 R > 42.45 B U F2 L2 U' D' L2 F' R' U' F' R2 B' D F D' B2 U' F' B2 U' D' > L2 D' F' > 43.36 R U2 F' B' R U2 B L B' U2 F2 R2 D' R2 L' D B' F L2 U2 F L D B F > 55.58 F R L D L' B' D' B2 F2 D' F B R' B2 R L2 D' R' D2 R2 F' R2 B D' U2 > 36.22 F' B' L2 F U B' F2 U' L' D' L2 R2 F' L2 D R' D' R' F' U2 L U2 > B2 L B' > (35.44) U R' F' R B2 U2 D B' U L2 U L' B D2 B' R F L' R' F U2 F2 D B' L > > ...and perhaps the first ever average of 100: 54.90 seconds. ;) > > Here is a 36.98 second solve we got on video: > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonwinokurteambld3698.wmv > > The file is just unde 4 MB. > > Our best single was a 33.98, though we did get a 29.80 PLL skip early > on. :) > > I believe we are both shocked at our average being 14 seconds faster > than last week. :D > > ~ Bob

1444. Public cubing
From: "mahtianssi" <mahtianssi@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 28 Aug 2005 11:55:36 -0000

Yesterday i did two 3x3 solves in front of over 20 people.
At first I was nervous and did 20.87.
Seconds time I had a very good LL and did 15.44.
I will rule the Swedish Open!

nice man. love that. same thing yesterday, in my neighborhood we had a summer jubilee. so i did some public cubing in front of soo many ppl i lost count. Then went to starbucks and did more cubing, suddenly this lady walks up and asked me how i do it soo fast and i explained myself. I gave her the website of speedcubing and she left :) PS: to all ppl, do more public cubing. raise awareness. 1457. Different LL proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 02:05:48 -0000

Some weeks ago I posted a very excited email detailing something
like a plan for a method involving C(O)LL and (E)PLL. After much
experimenting, a lot of number crunching, and more struggling than I
care to put into words, I've decided against this for several
reasons.

Some people thought it would be too complicated, or that the
benefits wouldn't be enough. To the former, I still think
otherwise, especially after certain people named Chris successfully
used large chunks of ZB in Dallas. To the latter, I think this now
to be true.

Instead, I now think cases 1 and 2 of ZBF2L, along with COLL and
EPLL will be a much better full time strategy entailing better
rewards and fewer algs and decisions.

However, I would like to go farther than that. Inspired both by
Chris' recent performance, and by Bob's decision to persue ZB as a
method, and after playing with ZBF2L a bit for my COLL, I think a
modified COLL+some specialized ZB approach would be either a decent
method in its own right, or at least a useful stepping stone to full
ZB.

For ZBF2L, I would pretty much learn it as is, or with a few added
special cases for some corner orienting. Then, COLL+EPLL. I would
also take advantage of OLL skips due to ZBF2L by employing PLL when
applicable. The stats for this seem to me something like the
following:

Chance to skip
EPLL step: 1/12
OLL step: 1/8
LL entirely: 1/1944
Any other things I'm missing at the moment, which there seem to be,
that I can't quite remember, and the less frequent COLL solves due
to OLL skips leave us with the grand total at about a 20% chance of
a skipped step during a solve. This is similar to
Vandenbergh/Harris, I believe.

Now, adding in the ZB cases only for correctly permuted corners, we
get
better odds for when we still do COLL. The odds to skip the PLL
after COLL are 1/12. The odds for cases with correct corner
permutation are something like 18% of COLL cases, meaning we have
odds of 1/12 for 82% of cases, and odds of 100% for 18% of COLL
cases. The total odds for PLL skip after our COLL would then be
something like 25% or 1/4. Factoring in the reduced occasion for
COLL because of OLL skips the stats begin to look more like...

Chance to skip
Step during COLL: 1/5
OLL step: 1/8
other special cases: x
Total: ~32.5+% or a little over 3/10

I'm sure there are ways to add in special cases and tricks to
further this, but even without any a 1/3 chance for a one step LL is
very powerful, especially in comparison with standard OLL+PLL, with
a chance to skip a step at about 1/8 with early edge orienting and
almost neglibible without.

The reason I'm considering cases with corners correctly permuted as
opposed to learning specific orientation cases fully is that they're
generally easier to recognize than other cases as a whole, and can
often be completed by using Sune/Antisunes from different angles,
making them fast, and easy to execute. Also, when I do get one of
those cases, it feels almost lazy to just do a simple Sune/Antisune
instead of a longer COLL alg.

Of course, this leaves us with lots of cases to learn (158 for ZBF2L
and about 75 new cases for ZBLL, assuming you already know COLL,
putting us at around 380 new cases total with reflections), but I
still think that's a managable number, considering simple
reflections, the massive benefits, and the staggering abilities
demonstrated by people who already know and use hundreds of
algorithms.

Since I'm writing this at 3:44 in the morning local time after a
long day, I'm not entirely certain I've explained myself well, so
feel free to comment/criticize as necessary. Any thoughts are much
appreciated, especially from those of you using similar approaches.

-Mike Bennett

1459. Re: Different LL proposal
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 04:06:49 -0000

Correct me if I'm wrong. The chance to skip the OLL after ZBF2L is 1/27, not 1/8. ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Some weeks ago I posted a very excited email detailing something > like a plan for a method involving C(O)LL and (E)PLL. After much > experimenting, a lot of number crunching, and more struggling than I > care to put into words, I've decided against this for several > reasons. > > Some people thought it would be too complicated, or that the > benefits wouldn't be enough. To the former, I still think > otherwise, especially after certain people named Chris successfully > used large chunks of ZB in Dallas. To the latter, I think this now > to be true. > > Instead, I now think cases 1 and 2 of ZBF2L, along with COLL and > EPLL will be a much better full time strategy entailing better > rewards and fewer algs and decisions. > > However, I would like to go farther than that. Inspired both by > Chris' recent performance, and by Bob's decision to persue ZB as a > method, and after playing with ZBF2L a bit for my COLL, I think a > modified COLL+some specialized ZB approach would be either a decent > method in its own right, or at least a useful stepping stone to full > ZB. > > For ZBF2L, I would pretty much learn it as is, or with a few added > special cases for some corner orienting. Then, COLL+EPLL. I would > also take advantage of OLL skips due to ZBF2L by employing PLL when > applicable. The stats for this seem to me something like the > following: > > Chance to skip > EPLL step: 1/12 > OLL step: 1/8 > LL entirely: 1/1944 > Any other things I'm missing at the moment, which there seem to be, > that I can't quite remember, and the less frequent COLL solves due > to OLL skips leave us with the grand total at about a 20% chance of > a skipped step during a solve. This is similar to > Vandenbergh/Harris, I believe. > > Now, adding in the ZB cases only for correctly permuted corners, we > get > better odds for when we still do COLL. The odds to skip the PLL > after COLL are 1/12. The odds for cases with correct corner > permutation are something like 18% of COLL cases, meaning we have > odds of 1/12 for 82% of cases, and odds of 100% for 18% of COLL > cases. The total odds for PLL skip after our COLL would then be > something like 25% or 1/4. Factoring in the reduced occasion for > COLL because of OLL skips the stats begin to look more like... > > Chance to skip > Step during COLL: 1/5 > OLL step: 1/8 > other special cases: x > Total: ~32.5+% or a little over 3/10 > > I'm sure there are ways to add in special cases and tricks to > further this, but even without any a 1/3 chance for a one step LL is > very powerful, especially in comparison with standard OLL+PLL, with > a chance to skip a step at about 1/8 with early edge orienting and > almost neglibible without. > > The reason I'm considering cases with corners correctly permuted as > opposed to learning specific orientation cases fully is that they're > generally easier to recognize than other cases as a whole, and can > often be completed by using Sune/Antisunes from different angles, > making them fast, and easy to execute. Also, when I do get one of > those cases, it feels almost lazy to just do a simple Sune/Antisune > instead of a longer COLL alg. > > Of course, this leaves us with lots of cases to learn (158 for ZBF2L > and about 75 new cases for ZBLL, assuming you already know COLL, > putting us at around 380 new cases total with reflections), but I > still think that's a managable number, considering simple > reflections, the massive benefits, and the staggering abilities > demonstrated by people who already know and use hundreds of > algorithms. > > Since I'm writing this at 3:44 in the morning local time after a > long day, I'm not entirely certain I've explained myself well, so > feel free to comment/criticize as necessary. Any thoughts are much > appreciated, especially from those of you using similar approaches. > > -Mike Bennett
1460. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Demo Updated For 20x20x20 Cube Support
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 05:24:12 +0100 (BST)

I have only windows-98. Your software is not opened in windows-98. Can you make it possible ? Although I downloaeded your first version a week ago, I am not able to install and run it. Could not wait anymore!! John Louis pyjamamitten <jpittman@...> wrote: Cube Demo Updated For 20x20x20 Cube Support Greetings, I can't believe how many requests we've received about the desire for larger cubes! Of course, I should have known better after I saw that someone in Japan had solved the 9x9x9 in a little over 2 hours and posted the screenshots on his site. So, as of this release, we now support cube sizes up to 20x20x20. I would certainly expect that performance will noticably degrade on slower/older systems when you get up to 15x15x15 and above but you are free to give `em a try. Ton from Speedcubing.com made the request for changing the timer behavior to wait until the first move is made after a scramble to start seemed to be a good idea to me so that has been added as well. We've also received enough comments about the moving background making people dizzy to change it and make it static we hope you like it better! You can get the latest version from our downloads page: http://www.gabbasoft.com/download.htm As always, thanks so much for all of your input and we hope you will continue to send us your thoughts and ideas for making our product better. Regards, Jamey Pittman President GabbaSoft, Inc. jpittman@... http://www.gabbasoft.com SPONSORED LINKS Online puzzle games Computer puzzle game Free puzzle games Puzzle games Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1461. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube Demo Updated For 20x20x20 Cube Support
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 05:36:41 -0000

Hi ! Yes i agree that demanding DirectX 9.0b or whatever it was is a bit over the top. But that's typical. Those developers of coz have the latest software and hardware. A game like this would work perfectly with DirectX 6 or 7. And would then be compatible with windows98 as well as windows95 even. And older hardware. That said it's probably a minority who don't have at least windows 2000 professional today. The problem with DirectX 9.0b on old computers is not that it's impossible to install that DirectX version on the OS. The problem is that the graphics cards on old computers won't support it, more specifially won't support the instruction set (API) of the Direct X version. Actually installing DirectX 9 on systems with non- compatible graphics cards probably means that the OS needs to be reinstalled as there is no (easy) to uninstall it. This happened to me some yrs ago. The marvellous installtion CD coming with the screencard kindly installed DirectX 9 even my specific card didn't support it. Had i only installed it the manual way it would have been fine ... grrrr ... Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@y...> wrote: > I have only windows-98. Your software is not opened in windows-98. Can you make it possible ? > Although I downloaeded your first version a week ago, I am not able to install and run it. 1462. Need help repairing Rubik's 2x2x2
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 08:22:08 +0200

Hi all,

Yesterday my Rubik's 2x2x2 fell apart and although I managed to reconstruct
it, I cannot turn one of the directions. I assume this has to do with the
different kind of quarter circular things that are in there. I just put them
in arbitrarily, which was probably the wrong way to go. Can anyone tell me
how I should have put them in?

I hope somebody can help me.

- Bram

1463. Re: Need help repairing Rubik's 2x2x2
From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 07:08:53 -0000

Bram, In the Photos section of this group, there is an album called "Fix your 2x2x2" where someone posted photos of the reassembly of a Rubik's 2x2x2 with instructions. And you're right that you have to be more selective as to where you put the little wedges. Hope that helps, Scott --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Hi all, > > Yesterday my Rubik's 2x2x2 fell apart and although I managed to >reconstruct > it, I cannot turn one of the directions. Can anyone >tell me > how I should have put them in? > > I hope somebody can help me. > > - Bram

1467. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 07:13:49 -0500

nice. I personally do not public cube. In school i just take out the
cube and casually solve it during lunch and stuff like that, making
myself as unnoticable as possible. Because then everyone starts
gathering and they're like "I can do that in 10 seconds" and tons of
crap like that. gets annoying. feel like slapping them, but its still
school. My science teacher managed to figure out that i could do it
and he was impressed (but he was cool). So i usually stay away from
public cubing.

-parth

1469. Re: [Speed cubing group] Team Blindfold
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 13:03:19 -0000

Chris Hardwick is almost done updating a page with our F2L codes. Here are the first few codes. The F2L slot to be filled is always placed in the FR spot. A1 - edge is correctly placed, corner is in the top layer with white facing right A2 - same but white faces front A3 - same but white faces up C1 - edge is placed backwards, corner in the top layer with white facing right C2 - same but white faces front C3 - same but white faces up In message 18337 I wrote up a detailed explanation of a team solve that Chris and I caught on tape. One of the codes is C3. Check it out! Ian --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > How do you guys identify the F2L algs - I can never understand what's > being said > > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Aug 28, 2005, at 12:51 AM, Bob Burton wrote: > > > Wow, this is so much fun (not to mention ADDICTING!). Ian came over > > my house today and we did team blindfold for the 2nd time together > > (1st being last weekend). :) > > > > We got a best average of 44.72 seconds: > > Individual Times: > > 37.91 L' R' D B' F2 D' B2 L' F B L D' F2 D2 R' F U' L U' F R' L' > > B2 U F > > 46.37 D' U' B U' R2 L B L2 B D2 F2 U L D U2 L' B' D F L' D2 R F U2 L' > > (1:01.59) D2 R F' R' D2 F U2 R U' F2 L' D' B' F' R L2 D U F D2 R2 L2 > > U2 D R2 > > 43.87 B2 L U' R F U D R F2 D2 R2 L2 D' B' D2 L R2 D2 U' B2 L2 B' F > > R2 D2 > > 51.17 R' B F2 L D2 B F2 L' R2 D U' L' F B' U D L' U2 D' R U' R B2 > > F' R > > 46.35 B' U2 F B U2 R F2 R U L2 D' R' D2 L' U' B2 R2 L2 F' B2 U L' > > F' R D' > > 43.88 D2 B' R2 U2 L' F2 B' R B' R U' F' R U' R D U2 F B2 D2 R2 B D > > B2 R > > 42.45 B U F2 L2 U' D' L2 F' R' U' F' R2 B' D F D' B2 U' F' B2 U' D' > > L2 D' F' > > 43.36 R U2 F' B' R U2 B L B' U2 F2 R2 D' R2 L' D B' F L2 U2 F L D B F > > 55.58 F R L D L' B' D' B2 F2 D' F B R' B2 R L2 D' R' D2 R2 F' R2 B > > D' U2 > > 36.22 F' B' L2 F U B' F2 U' L' D' L2 R2 F' L2 D R' D' R' F' U2 L U2 > > B2 L B' > > (35.44) U R' F' R B2 U2 D B' U L2 U L' B D2 B' R F L' R' F U2 F2 D > > B' L > > > > ...and perhaps the first ever average of 100: 54.90 seconds. ;) > > > > Here is a 36.98 second solve we got on video: > > http://www.cubewhiz.com/videos/burtonwinokurteambld3698.wmv > > > > The file is just unde 4 MB. > > > > Our best single was a 33.98, though we did get a 29.80 PLL skip early > > on. :) > > > > I believe we are both shocked at our average being 14 seconds faster > > than last week. :D > > > > ~ Bob > > > > > > > > > > > > YAHOO! 1472. Re: another scrambler
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 15:56:06 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi Stefan! > > Wow! What a hardcore scrambler ;-) No user options at all ... hehe . .. > Well that's what u wanted so im not gonna suggest u add options for > scramble length and stuff like that :D > > But i have an idea anyway. I know u have just dumped the numbers from > the main control loop, hence first scramble is number zero (0). How > about letting it start from 1 and go up to 50? It's just that little > bit more natural for ordinary deadly humans ... lol ... Starting with 1 is a terribly flawed habit. I'd like the first digit of every block of 10 scrambles to be the same. Imagine it'd generate 100 scrambles, then the last would be a 3-digit number if I started with 1. Ugly. Now I only wish I weren't used to start with 1 in real life. My teachers/parents/generalEnvironment suck. Computer programmers should rule the world. Maybe I should just remove the index column ;-) Cheers! Stefan P.S. One thing for which I really want to start with 0 in real life is memorization. I've built a memo home with 100 points, i.e. 10 rooms with 10 points each. I'd like the index of the point tell me both the room and the point inside the room, which is nicer if I have 00-99 than if it's 01-100. Also, when memorizing digit sequences and memorizing two digits at a time, I get 00-99 anyway.
1473. Re: Public cubing
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 16:10:25 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I was quietly cubing in a cafe late the other night Which reminds me. I was cubing on a nearly empty tram a few evenings ago, when an attractive young woman sat down near me and /also/ expressed her love of things Rubikal. I grunted approvingly. She then asked (a propos de rien) whether I would like to find Britney and Paris cuddled up in my front room. "What -- /my/ front room?" I asked. "Yes," said she. "Can they do the Cube?" I asked. At this point she changed the subject again... Mike
1474. Re: Need help repairing Rubik's 2x2x2
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 17:25:12 -0000

Hello Bram, Even though its not complete yet, maybe my page can help? http://www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc2a.html After you finish the steps on my page, find the UBR corner, and put the heart shaped piece into it facing the other square center, then put another rounded edge piece into the other side of it, then slide it into its correct place. Then take the UBL corner, and put a rounded edge piece into in, and slide it into place. Next, take the UFL corner, put the remaining squared edge piece into facing the other one and slide it on. Now heres the hard part: Take your selected corner, and slide it over the 2 squared edge pieces. Notw push and pull it over the heart shaped edge until it "pops" into place. You cube should now work fine!! Good luck! Tell me how it goes. Peter Greenwood --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Hi all, > > Yesterday my Rubik's 2x2x2 fell apart and although I managed to reconstruct > it, I cannot turn one of the directions. I assume this has to do with the > different kind of quarter circular things that are in there. I just put them > in arbitrarily, which was probably the wrong way to go. Can anyone tell me > how I should have put them in? > > I hope somebody can help me. > > - Bram > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you > receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents > herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. > ================================================
1475. Re: [Speed cubing group] Team Blindfold
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 18:15:48 -0000

I watched the videos again (Ian+Chris, Bob+Ian) and noticed you're
cheating. Quote from the rules: "at no point may team member 2 touch
the cube". That's the guy telling the other what to do. But you do
touch the cube and even put it down oriented after inspection.

Suggestion: Really only the twister should touch the cube. The
commander can talk to the twister during inspection, e.g. tell him how
to orient the cube and tell him the first few moves already.

It's similar to one-handed cubing. We're imitating how a person with
just one hand would solve the cube. Where the hell do we magically get
a second hand from during inspection? Same for team blindsolving,
we're imitating two cubers, one who has no hands and one who is blind.
Where the hell does the former magically get hands from during
inspection?

Stefan





1476. Re: [Speed cubing group] Team Blindfold
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 19:25:06 -0000

Tyson is of the same philosophy about not touching the cube during inspection. When Chris and I did a solve on stage in Dallas, I held the cube over my head for him to look at during inspection. I'll start doing it that way from now on. You suggest that the first few moves can be called out during the inspection. We've always considered that cheating but it isn't outlawed explicitly anywhere. Anybody else have thoughts on this? Ian --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I watched the videos again (Ian+Chris, Bob+Ian) and noticed you're > cheating. Quote from the rules: "at no point may team member 2 touch > the cube". That's the guy telling the other what to do. But you do > touch the cube and even put it down oriented after inspection. > > Suggestion: Really only the twister should touch the cube. The > commander can talk to the twister during inspection, e.g. tell him how > to orient the cube and tell him the first few moves already. > > It's similar to one-handed cubing. We're imitating how a person with > just one hand would solve the cube. Where the hell do we magically get > a second hand from during inspection? Same for team blindsolving, > we're imitating two cubers, one who has no hands and one who is blind. > Where the hell does the former magically get hands from during > inspection? > > Stefan
1477. Re: Different LL proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 19:29:19 -0000

I think you're correct about that. Let's update the stats, then. Instead of 20% odds for the scenario with regular COLL, ZBF2L, and PLL when applicable, it's now more like 12%. And, instead of 33% odds for with the correct corners ZBLL cases, it's now more like 27.78%. Not great, but still much better. More than twice as good, in fact. It still means the odds for a 1 look LL are something greater than 1 out of 4, and when you don't skip, you've still only got an edge PLL case for the second one. So, pending further experimentation, this is now my new plan. I suppose I should finish learning the last few COLL's first... More feedback, please. -Mike Bennett --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > Correct me if I'm wrong. The chance to skip the OLL after ZBF2L is > 1/27, not 1/8. > > ~ Bob
1478. Re: [Speed cubing group] Team Blindfold
From: Chris Hunt <huntca@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 13:10:55 -0700

On 8/29/05, Ian <iwinoky@...> wrote: > You suggest that the first few moves can be called out during the > inspection. We've always considered that cheating but it isn't > outlawed explicitly anywhere. Anybody else have thoughts on this? When you solve the cube yourself, you know the first couple of moves in advance before you begin. It makes sense to me to allow that in a team blindfold solve as well. It will probably only help your times by a second or two...if at all. -Chris
1479. Re: Different LL proposal
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 21:05:41 -0000

Hey Mike, my comments below:

> Some weeks ago I posted a very excited email detailing something
> like a plan for a method involving C(O)LL and (E)PLL. After much
> experimenting, a lot of number crunching, and more struggling than
I
> care to put into words, I've decided against this for several
> reasons.
>
> Some people thought it would be too complicated, or that the
> benefits wouldn't be enough. To the former, I still think
> otherwise, especially after certain people named Chris
successfully
> used large chunks of ZB in Dallas. To the latter, I think this
now
> to be true.

I haven't done much experimenting with strictly COLL/(E)PLL, but it
sounds like you put a lot of work into this and I trust your
judgement. I had thought for a while that maybe the 1/12 chance for
a PLL skip or the 1/27 chance for an OLL skip might add up to
overcome the slower COLL, but if you don't think that does then I
think that is good to know.

>
> Instead, I now think cases 1 and 2 of ZBF2L, along with COLL and
> EPLL will be a much better full time strategy entailing better
> rewards and fewer algs and decisions.

Why not also add the ZBF2L with all LL edges either correctly
oriented or all incorrectly oriented? Those are all, for the most
part, some of the fastest ZBF2L algs.

>
> However, I would like to go farther than that. Inspired both by
> Chris' recent performance, and by Bob's decision to persue ZB as a
> method, and after playing with ZBF2L a bit for my COLL, I think a
> modified COLL+some specialized ZB approach would be either a
decent
> method in its own right, or at least a useful stepping stone to
full
> ZB.

So far I think my LL skip count is up to 23.xx% maybe 24.xx% and I
like this type of method so far. I have thought that maybe only
know the "T" orientation, and the other orientation where two
adjacent corners are twisted, but the other direction as the "T"
("H" orientation on Dan Harris' page) would be a good method just by
itself. Those two OLL cases are some of the easiest to recognize,
since two corners are twisted correctly and can be used as
a "base". Also knowing those two cases and all COLL would give you
a 1/27 + 8/27 + (18/27)*(1/12) = 38.89% chance of a 1 look LL.

I think those two are the easiest ZBLL cases for recognition, and
knowing just those two and COLL gives you a nearly 40% chance of a 1
look LL, which would be realyl powerful! In fact, after I finish
with the "T" orientation I'm going to start learning the "H"
orientation next for just the reason of using the two together for
that nearly 40% chance of a 1 look.

>
> For ZBF2L, I would pretty much learn it as is, or with a few added
> special cases for some corner orienting. Then, COLL+EPLL. I
would
> also take advantage of OLL skips due to ZBF2L by employing PLL
when
> applicable. The stats for this seem to me something like the
> following:
>
> Chance to skip
> EPLL step: 1/12
> OLL step: 1/8
> LL entirely: 1/1944
> Any other things I'm missing at the moment, which there seem to
be,
> that I can't quite remember, and the less frequent COLL solves due
> to OLL skips leave us with the grand total at about a 20% chance
of
> a skipped step during a solve. This is similar to
> Vandenbergh/Harris, I believe.

After trying ZB some in Dallas I've come to the conclusion that ZB2L
is totally reasonable for competitive solving. Each fo the 23 F2L
cases is broken down into 8 sub-cases, with lots of cool
simplifications for symmetry. So your recognition has two phases,
F2L case (by looking ahead you know this before finishing the 3rd
F2L pair) and LL edges case. You can recognize the LL edges case by
looking at only the LL edges currently in the LL after solving the
3rd F2L pair, so even this is possible by looking ahead leaving no
transition from 3rd to 4th pair.

So I think your idea to learn ZBF2L is totally reasonable, even for
competitions. It will take a lot of practice obviously, but I don't
think it is too much to recall under pressure given enough practice.

>
> Now, adding in the ZB cases only for correctly permuted corners,
we
> get
> better odds for when we still do COLL. The odds to skip the PLL
> after COLL are 1/12. The odds for cases with correct corner
> permutation are something like 18% of COLL cases, meaning we have
> odds of 1/12 for 82% of cases, and odds of 100% for 18% of COLL
> cases. The total odds for PLL skip after our COLL would then be
> something like 25% or 1/4. Factoring in the reduced occasion for
> COLL because of OLL skips the stats begin to look more like...
>
> Chance to skip
> Step during COLL: 1/5
> OLL step: 1/8
> other special cases: x
> Total: ~32.5+% or a little over 3/10
>
> I'm sure there are ways to add in special cases and tricks to
> further this, but even without any a 1/3 chance for a one step LL
is
> very powerful, especially in comparison with standard OLL+PLL,
with
> a chance to skip a step at about 1/8 with early edge orienting and
> almost neglibible without.
>
> The reason I'm considering cases with corners correctly permuted
as
> opposed to learning specific orientation cases fully is that
they're
> generally easier to recognize than other cases as a whole, and can
> often be completed by using Sune/Antisunes from different angles,
> making them fast, and easy to execute. Also, when I do get one of
> those cases, it feels almost lazy to just do a simple
Sune/Antisune
> instead of a longer COLL alg.

I'm not sure whether or not I agree on the recognition for the
corners correctly permuted ZBLL cases. I've found that the first
thing my brain has to settle on for ZBLL recognition is always the
COLL case. There are many examples of cases that look exactly the
same for edges, but the COLL case is different. So for the reason
of avoiding mis-reading the case I prefer to always look for the
COLL case first.

Maybe it wouldn't be bad, but personally I think it would be hard,
since my brain always seems to settle on seeing the COLL case first,
but it could also be that I've trained that way from the start.

> Of course, this leaves us with lots of cases to learn (158 for
ZBF2L
> and about 75 new cases for ZBLL, assuming you already know COLL,
> putting us at around 380 new cases total with reflections), but I
> still think that's a managable number, considering simple
> reflections, the massive benefits, and the staggering abilities
> demonstrated by people who already know and use hundreds of
> algorithms.
>

I also agree to that being a manageable number. I think knowing 2-3
full OLL cases should be manageable for most people. I think that
ZB is just a mental barrier right now. Once more people start to
learn the algs I think that barrier will break down and people won't
be afraid to learn so many algs. Right now it seems like a lot
because most people only use around 100 or so algs (23+57+21=101 for
Fridrich F2L + OLL + PLL).

Most people wouldn't consider the 23 algs for F2L as "algs" per se
but as intuition. That is my exact same feeling about a LOT of
ZBF2L cases, so it's not 158 algs per se, because lots of cases are
reductions to a few common recurring short cases.

> Since I'm writing this at 3:44 in the morning local time after a
> long day, I'm not entirely certain I've explained myself well, so
> feel free to comment/criticize as necessary. Any thoughts are
much
> appreciated, especially from those of you using similar approaches.

I tried to give my thoughts as best I could, and would also
appreciate feedback, particularly about recognizing ZBLL differently
from COLL then EPLL. I think that would be hard, but I would love
to be proved wrong!

>
> -Mike Bennett

Chris




1480. Re: [Speed cubing group] Team Blindfold
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 21:56:21 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" <iwinoky@y...> wrote: > > You suggest that the first few moves can be called out during the > inspection. We've always considered that cheating but it isn't > outlawed explicitly anywhere. Anybody else have thoughts on this? Why should that be cheating? Again, think of it as imitating a cuber without hands and blind cuber who participate as a pair, but following the normal rules as close as possible. Would be quite strange if they didn't talk. For example, the commander should really tell the twister how to orient the cube at the start. Stefan

We've always considered that cheating but it isn't >> outlawed explicitly anywhere. Anybody else have thoughts on this? > > Why should that be cheating? Again, think of it as imitating a cuber > without hands and blind cuber who participate as a pair, but following > the normal rules as close as possible. Would be quite strange if they > didn't talk. 1483. Re: Different LL proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 22:55:19 -0000

Hi Chris, Thanks for the post. My replies are below. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > > Instead, I now think cases 1 and 2 of ZBF2L, along with COLL and > > EPLL will be a much better full time strategy entailing better > > rewards and fewer algs and decisions. > > Why not also add the ZBF2L with all LL edges either correctly > oriented or all incorrectly oriented? Those are all, for the most > part, some of the fastest ZBF2L algs. Sorry for the lack of clarity. I meant to say that I felt cases 1 and 2, along with COLL and EPLL will be faster than the method I previously suggested. I'm currently only using chunks of cases 1 and 2, and most of the COLL algs, but intend to use full ZBF2L eventually. > > > > The reason I'm considering cases with corners correctly permuted > as > > opposed to learning specific orientation cases fully is that > they're > > generally easier to recognize than other cases as a whole, and can > > often be completed by using Sune/Antisunes from different angles, > > making them fast, and easy to execute. Also, when I do get one of > > those cases, it feels almost lazy to just do a simple > Sune/Antisune > > instead of a longer COLL alg. > > I'm not sure whether or not I agree on the recognition for the > corners correctly permuted ZBLL cases. I've found that the first > thing my brain has to settle on for ZBLL recognition is always the > COLL case. There are many examples of cases that look exactly the > same for edges, but the COLL case is different. So for the reason > of avoiding mis-reading the case I prefer to always look for the > COLL case first. > > Maybe it wouldn't be bad, but personally I think it would be hard, > since my brain always seems to settle on seeing the COLL case first, > but it could also be that I've trained that way from the start. Actually, I would really see the COLL case first, then the edges permutation. That's how it's going so far, at least. I know the 2 Z perms for the two cases with adjacent corners flipped. All you need to see is two adjacent edges to know the case. It's similar to recognizing the EPLL as a separate step. It may be less efficient to do it this way, but I think it will work for me, given my currently atrocious LL times at present. In fact, I think the longer recognition won't be a problem at all, because even when I perform a 3 cycle to finish perfectly after COLL, it still takes over 1 second. This doesn't include any recognition. I think I can be competitive this way, but it may be too much for other cubers. > Most people wouldn't consider the 23 algs for F2L as "algs" per se > but as intuition. That is my exact same feeling about a LOT of > ZBF2L cases, so it's not 158 algs per se, because lots of cases are > reductions to a few common recurring short cases. Actually, I've never considered them algs, because I never learned them as such. I taught myself an intuitive F2L after Chicago, and edge orienting is really just a simple extension. Most of the ZB algs I know right now either involve pairing up, then inserting+flipping, or flipping, then pairing+inserting. Since this is the same as an intuitive approach, just slightly more concrete, the going is easy. The only cases giving me problems are the ones without clear pairing/flipping/inserting stages. These really aren't that bad, though, because they're generally simple and short. > I tried to give my thoughts as best I could, and would also > appreciate feedback, particularly about recognizing ZBLL differently > from COLL then EPLL. I think that would be hard, but I would love > to be proved wrong! Like I said, it's really not much different, except that you recognize the EPLL before you perform COLL. It's very simple for me, because I use the recognition method on Gilles' and Lars V's sites. The sticker method everyone else seems to use boggles my mind. Again, it may be less efficient because it would be harder to see the EPLL ahead of time, as you could with COLL, but I think it will balance in the end due to the effectiveness of the 1 look LL. Anywho, thanks for the feedback, and keep the ideas coming. -Mike Bennett P.S. I replied to this once, with a nicely planned out, long, fantastically well written email. Then, I hit 'Send' and waited. Yahoo decided to lose the post and give me an error message. Unfortunately, the friend I'm staying with has yet to switch to Firefox and IE doesn't save the text changes I made. That ruined my whole night.
1484. Re: Different LL proposal
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 23:01:11 -0000

And, because I forgot to include it in the second go-round on the
reply, here's an extra bit of fun:

When I recognize the edge perm case on the two ZB cases I know some
of, I nearly always seem to hold the cube so I can see the UF and UL
edges. I often use the UR edge, instead, though, because sometimes
I see that one first. I think, I will have to pick one side and
stick to it, though, because recognizing from two different angles
all the time would make twice as many cases to see.

If I can train myself to always look to the UL and UF edges after I
AUF for the COLL case, I think it will help. Since the cases I know
now are rather symmetrical, it's not a problem, but I think could be
very harmful in the end if not taken care of.

Again, it differs very little from standard COLL+EPLL, except in the
timing of the recognition steps. I think it will be very fast, once
I get used to it, but for now it's still somewhat slow. Time will
tell.

And now, goodnight.

-Mike Bennett





1485. Re: Different LL proposal
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 23:16:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> wrote: > Like I said, it's really not much different, except that you > recognize the EPLL before you perform COLL. It's very simple for > me, because I use the recognition method on Gilles' and Lars V's > sites. The sticker method everyone else seems to use boggles my > mind. Again, it may be less efficient because it would be harder to > see the EPLL ahead of time, as you could with COLL, but I think it > will balance in the end due to the effectiveness of the 1 look LL. I have used the method of recognition where I just look to see what corners need to be swapped in the past (until February). Now, I use the sticker method for recognition of COLL. I think it is easier, personally. It is better for me to not know what goes where and instead just recognize by some sort of pattern. :) ~ Bob

1488. cubing on the train and public cubing
From: JohnLouis Louis <pjlmem@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 06:07:35 +0100 (BST)

I had been to our - tamil nadu capital city - Madras on saturday and sunday which is 400 km far from my place. It is a 6 hrs journey by train. I was cubing in the train. So many asked me to solve fast and BLD. I amazed everyone and taught the tricks of it to them.
on sunday, I demonstrated for an hour solving all the cubes 2*2*2, 3*3*3, 3*3*3 BLD, 4*4*4, 5*5*5 and megaminx for a gathering of 100 Rotarians(Rotary club) in a well organised show in a 5 star hotel in Madras. 3*3*3 BLD was the most attractive one for the audience. It was excellent and I had a nice time as well - very good food and a gift. This is my first public cubing after 2 months.

Bernett Orlando

1490. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Need help repairing Rubik's 2x2x2
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 08:22:54 +0200

I already put it back together. Just adding all the non-standard pieces to one corner piece and putting it between the non-turning core pieces seemed to work fine. Friction is still high, but that can be due to the fact that the cube is new. I will have a look at your page anyway. Thanks for the reaction. - Bram -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens pjgat09 Verzonden: maandag 29 augustus 2005 19:25 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: Need help repairing Rubik's 2x2x2 Hello Bram, Even though its not complete yet, maybe my page can help? http://www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc2a.html <http://www.geocities.com/pjgat09/misc2a.html> After you finish the steps on my page, find the UBR corner, and put the heart shaped piece into it facing the other square center, then put another rounded edge piece into the other side of it, then slide it into its correct place. Then take the UBL corner, and put a rounded edge piece into in, and slide it into place. Next, take the UFL corner, put the remaining squared edge piece into facing the other one and slide it on. Now heres the hard part: Take your selected corner, and slide it over the 2 squared edge pieces. Notw push and pull it over the heart shaped edge until it "pops" into place. You cube should now work fine!! Good luck! Tell me how it goes. Peter Greenwood --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Hi all, > > Yesterday my Rubik's 2x2x2 fell apart and although I managed to reconstruct > it, I cannot turn one of the directions. I assume this has to do with the > different kind of quarter circular things that are in there. I just put them > in arbitrarily, which was probably the wrong way to go. Can anyone tell me > how I should have put them in? > > I hope somebody can help me. > > - Bram > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. the inner and outer slices instead? It would make scrambling a LOT
easier.

1492. RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 09:57:58 +0200

To GameOfDeath2: Still did not solve it. Can you please post the solution with explanation. It is a really difficult one... -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Beer, Bram de Verzonden: vrijdag 22 juli 2005 8:22 Aan: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com' Onderwerp: RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku Thanks for the info. I will get started again. If I don't get it by the end of my holiday, I'll send you an email. -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens GameOfDeath2 Verzonden: donderdag 21 juli 2005 18:33 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > Hi all, > > > > Last week, this Sudoku was posted in this group: It is difficult - I take it you've already put in a 6 (that part is easy). To give you more idea of the difficulty, I gave a friend who also does Sudoku another grid with the numbers 1,2,... on which order to fill the squares in! (That was a while ago and he still hasn't got the second one in yet.) I don't know where you are in the puzzle, so I'll tell you this - the second number to put in goes in the square below that I've labelled with "@". The third one goes where the # is. (If you get really stuck, I can post a complete solution that explains how to get each step without trial and error.) > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 @ > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > 5 # . * . . 9 * . . . > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. Can anyone give me some tactical > > advise on how to solve it? Seems I can't solve it without > > trial-and-error... > > > > -Bram ================================================ De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. 1497. Re: [Speed cubing group] scrambling metric

To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com

On 8/30/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > Have people thought about letting lower case letters stand for "both" > the inner and outer slices instead? It would make scrambling a LOT > easier. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > -- -cubekid
1498. Re: [Speed cubing group] scrambling metric
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 04:36:19 -0700

Basically, we need people to do the math to see if it would indeed scramble a cube "enough" for use in a tournament, and then it would be nice if programs started incorporating it. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Aug 30, 2005, at 3:28 AM, Sapan Upadhyay wrote: > Surprisingly, I was just thinking that the other day. 1499. Promotional video for a company [recording was today]
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 12:22:12 -0000

Hey guys, I just got back from Hilversum, where I had to record that video. The cameraman and the director were very nice, so we had a good time shooting the video. I got there about an hour early, so got to meet some people who were working at the studio. After having a nice cup of coffee and doing a little chatting with those guys, I showed them a few nice and fluent sub17 solves. They all liked it very much. (And someone mentiond: "I used to peel of the stickers!!). After that they showed my around the studio, and told me a bit more about what the video should look like. It's gonna be just a small 1-minute video. The company is called 'Deloitte', and I understand that's it's a worldwide company, with people working in like... every country in the world :). The video is going to be shown on a big meeting/congress with shareholders. So, after doing a few warm up solves, we recorded some solves from different angle, while standing still, and a few while rotating around on a platform. We also did a lot of different other shots (close up on my eyes, showing off the solved cube, picking up the scrambled cube, putting down a solved cube etc.), it took about 1.5 hours I think. The director promised me they are gonna edit the whole thing until it looks perfect, so I expect it to look very cool.. They are gonna send me a DVD with the whole movie on it when they finish it, so I'll try to upload it to my site. They also gave me a brand new anniversery cube, because they didn't need that one anymore.. And they promised a nice 'payment', which I am gonna need if I want to have fun in Florida. AND... The director told me he could get me in touch with the marketing guys from Deloitte.. If they like the video, maybe they want to sponser me for the WC.. (Well, don't really expect that to happen, but it's worth a shot!). So.. I'll tell you guys when I got the video, Cya! Jol. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Jol van Noort <joel_vn@y...> wrote: > Hey everybody, > > Some company has asked me to help them with a promotional video or > commercial... And I accepted, of course :). Pretty exited about this! > The want me solve some cubes, and the video should express something > like 'complex problems, short and fast solutions'. The goal is not to > do it as fast as possible, but they want to close-up on my hands and > see some cool and fluent finger-trick action. It's the first time I am > actually going to earn a little money by solving cubes :). Not much > probably, but I can use all little bits when I am in Florida!! The > shooting of the video will take place next tuesday... They want me to > come in a nice fancy suit :). > > Well.. Just wanted to share this with you guys. > > See you :), > > Jol.

1502. Re: scrambling metric
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 13:28:53 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Basically, we need people to do the math to see if it would indeed > scramble a cube "enough" for use in a tournament, and then it would be > nice if programs started incorporating it. What do you mean "start incorporating it"? Oh, and I assume you mean 4x4 and 5x5, right? Well, the programs already spit out lower and upper case letters, so just interpret the lower case letters as double layer turns. No? But be warned, I tried that recently and it *slowed me down* because I got confused all the time. Try it. Cheers! Stefan

1504. Re: scrambling metric
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 13:52:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > just interpret the lower case letters as double > layer turns. There's still the issue of how many turns to use in the scramble. I doubt that this would depend significantly (if at all) on the "metric", but how were the original figures arrived at for the various puzzles? Was it just a matter of: (1) estimating the number of distinct sequences (not positions) of length d (2) finding d such that the above number exceeds the number of possible configurations of the puzzle (3) adding a few turns for safety. If so, the the safety margin looks rather high for 2x2x2 and Square-1 (the only ones I've really thought about, apart from 3x3x3). Mike

1508. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: scrambling metric
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 07:45:53 -0700

The way to determine the needed scramble number would seem to be to determine the average number of moves required by a perfect solver for each number of scramble moves. That is, scramble 18 moves and solve it in Cube Explorer 20 times and compute the average solve length. Do the same for 19, 20 etc, until the average stops increasing. That is the number of NEEDED to do a full scramble. That would actually be interesting to see from 1 - 25 for other reasons. /Lars On Aug 30, 2005, at 6:52, mike_go_uk wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: >> just interpret the lower case letters as double >> layer turns. > > There's still the issue of how many turns to use in the scramble. I > doubt that this would depend significantly (if at all) on > the "metric", but how were the original figures arrived at for the > various puzzles? Was it just a matter of: > > (1) estimating the number of distinct sequences (not positions) of > length d > > (2) finding d such that the above number exceeds the number of > possible configurations of the puzzle > > (3) adding a few turns for safety. > > If so, the the safety margin looks rather high for 2x2x2 and Square-1 > (the only ones I've really thought about, apart from 3x3x3). > > Mike > > - - - - - - - - - - - - "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." --- Frank Zappa Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com
1509. First succesful BLD solve !!!
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 20:41:02 +0530

Hello all, I am very happy at this moment and had noone to share this
with so am writing here. I just had my first succesful BLD solve of
the 3x3x3.

It took about 6 days for me to learn it completely..there was a gap of
3-4 days in between as i had gotten sick, and when today i took the
cube again, i had a unseccusful solve for the first time but the
second time when i opened my eyes there it was the solved cube...i was
never so happy to see a solved cube before !

I made a mistaske in the last part doing a R while permuting the
edges...then when i realised it i had to undo the moves and do it
again, i was so tensed.

Anyway i would like to say a lot of thanks to Tyson and Macky for
their BLD tutorials. It was quite a journey learning the BLD
solution(though typo errors in Tyson's document made it more like an
adventure ;) )

Bye then.
Happy (BLD) Cubing.


1510. [Speed cubing group] Re: scrambling metric
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 15:35:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@n...> wrote: > The way to determine the needed scramble number would seem to be to > determine the average number of moves required by a perfect solver for > each number of scramble moves. That's fine for the 3x3x3, Square-1, etc, where we have optimal solvers. Unfortunately, we do NOT have optimal solvers for 4x4x4, 5x5x5 and the megaminx, which is why I was wondering how you could estimate the necessary scramble lengths independently. Taking the 3x3x3 as an example, the minimum d from "my" criterion would be 18, which is comparable with the median number of turns (about 18) actually needed to solve random cubes optimally. Of course, you then have to add a few more turns to this d to stand a chance of sampling the "deepest" configurations... But my question is still: How were the WCA scramble lengths /actually/ determined? Mike
1511. Re: [Speed cubing group] Promotional video for a company [recordi ng was today]
From: "davehj999" <davej@...>
