1513. World Championships
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 12:07:05 -0700

Hi Everyone,

This is just a reminder to register online for the WC 2005 if you
haven't done so. Registering will help give the competition organizers
an idea of the numbers of competitors for the events and will give them
a better idea of the timing situation. Also, the hotel discounts run
out on October 4.

Hope to see you all in Florida!

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




1514. [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 19:15:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > To GameOfDeath2: > > Still did not solve it. Can you please post the solution with explanation. > It is a really difficult one... > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Beer, Bram de > Verzonden: vrijdag 22 juli 2005 8:22 > Aan: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com' > Onderwerp: RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku > > > Thanks for the info. I will get started again. If I don't get it by the end > of my holiday, I'll send you an email. > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens GameOfDeath2 > Verzonden: donderdag 21 juli 2005 18:33 > Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > Hi all, > > > > > > Last week, this Sudoku was posted in this group: > > It is difficult - I take it you've already put in a 6 (that part is > easy). To give you more idea of the difficulty, I gave a friend who > also does Sudoku another grid with the numbers 1,2,... on which > order to fill the squares in! (That was a while ago and he still > hasn't got the second one in yet.) > I don't know where you are in the puzzle, so I'll tell you this - > the second number to put in goes in the square below that I've > labelled with "@". The third one goes where the # is. > (If you get really stuck, I can post a complete solution that > explains how to get each step without trial and error.) > > > > > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 @ > > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > > 5 # . * . . 9 * . . . > > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. Can anyone give me some > tactical > > > advise on how to solve it? Seems I can't solve it without > > > trial-and-error... > > > > > > -Bram > > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you > receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents > herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. > ================================================ > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] Hi Bram, I too have become interesting in sudoku lately, and have found this program: http://www.angusj.com/sudoku/index.php It is very handy if you get stuck on a puzzle. It will tell you what to do to solve it step by step. I have also saved you some time by making the file you need to open for that puzzle: http://www.geocities.com/pjgat09/bramsudoku.zip Install the program (you will like it alot), then unzip the file in the second link, and save it in a folder somewhere. Then open it with the program. When you have opened it, heres how it can show you how to solve it step by step: Click on View-Hint. It will show you a hint, and tell you at the bottom why it is. Then click View-Solve Next Step. This will use the hint to get the puzzle closer to solved. I hope this helped!! Peter Greenwood

1518. Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving Sudoku)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 20:21:56 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > To GameOfDeath2: > > Still did not solve it. Can you please post the solution with explanation. > It is a really difficult one... > R1-R9, C1-C9 will denote the rows and columns and B1-B9 the boxes (in the order 123 456 789 ). I will not put in too many diagrams as it takes up a lot of space but here is the full solution - at least the one I came up with. Probably there are several. The crucial bit here wasdtep 27. I hadn't used anything like that before: basically if you get a pattern of possibilities ab ac ab bc as in this case (crucially, although they lie in 3 different columns they do lie in only 2 rows and in only 2 boxes) then because the two on the right lie in the same box they can't both be c. Thus the two on the left can't be a and b (a above b) so must be b and a (b above a). That allows for 1 and 3 to be determined and without guessing because they follow this logical pattern (above). Other than that the most difficult stages are probably 2 and 3 to get a start. 2. isn't really so bad - it's just observing that the triple 4,7,8 can only appear in 3 squares (so splitting C9 into 2 subsets) whence 7 can be placed straightaway (this step can be done first but is less obvious than step 1.). 3. is a bit technical too but I think 27. is the key stage. It relies on spotting a triple in 4 squares that do not lie all in the same column, row or box. NB You can also solve the same initial puzzle except with a 7 in the middle instead of a 4. It is quite similar. 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a 6). 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must contain 7. Initial Grid: *2*|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ ***|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*1* 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 5**|**9|*** ***|***|*4* For convenience label rows R1 to R9 (downwards), columns C1-C9 (left to right), boxes B1-B9 (right then down). 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a 6). 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must contain 7. 3. In B5, 1 and 8 must appear on the leading diagonal as they are already present in C5 and R5. Thus since 7 is in R5, 7 must occur in the intersection of B5 and C5. In particular in C5, 4,7 and 8 appear before B8. Thus in R8 4,7,8 must occur in C2-C4 and hence 4 lies in the intersection of C2 and R8. 4. Thus in B4, 4 goes in the intersection of R4 and C1. 5. Thus in C1, 7 must go in R9. 6. Recalling that in R8, C2-C4 contain 4,7 and 8, 8 must go in C3 (because B7 contains 4,7) and so 7 in C4. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 4**|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7**|***|*4* 7. In C1, neither 1 nor 8 can go in R5 or R7 (because they both appear elsewhere in R5 and R7) so both must appear in B1 and further 3 doesn't appear in the intersection of R2 and B1 so in B1 3 must be in C1. That leaves 5 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and R2 which means that (recalling 7 is in the intersection of B5 and C5) the intersection of R2 and C5 must be a 2. 8. Thus 2 must appear in the intersection of B5 and R5 (since 1,8 are on the leading diagonal of that box) and 2 can't appear in the intersection of C1 and R5. Since the intersection of C1 and B1 contains 1,3 and 8 it follows that 2 must appear in the intersection of C1 and R7 and 9 in the intersection of C1 and R5. 9. In B4, 2 must appear in C3 but neither in R4 nor (because 2 appears in the intersection of B5 and R5) in R5, so 2 must appear in the intersection of C3 and R6. 10. Therefore in B4, 7 appears in the intersection of R4 and C3. 11. So in B5, recalling 7 is in C5, 7 must occur in R6. 12. Now 9 already appearing in R5 and 1,8 being on the leading diagonal of B5, 9 must appear in B5 at the intersection of R4 and C5. 13. Again, 6 being already in C4 and R6, 6 must be in B5 at the intersection of C6 and R5. 14. 2s being in B4 and B6, the only remaining place in R5 for a 2 is the intersection with B5, i.e. in C4. 15. In B4, 1 must fall in C2, hence 1 must fall in C3 in B7, but not in R7 as we already have a 1 in R7. So 1 must fall in R9 and C3 in B9. 16. Moreover, in B8, 2 must lie in C6 but not in R7 (hence in R9). 17. Again in B8, 8 can't appear in R7 or C5 so it must be in the intersection of C4 and R9. 18. Thus in B5 we have that 1 lies in R4 and 8 lies in R6. 19. Now in B4, 1 lies in R6, 5 lies in R4, leaving 3 in R5. 20. In R4 8 can't lie in C8 and so must lie in C7, leaving 6 in C8 to complete R4. Also 5 completes R5. 21. Way back in 2, we figured that in C9, 4, 7 and 8 could lie only in R1, R5 and R6. From B6, we conclude that 4 must lie in the intersection of C9 and R6 and so 8 in the intersection of C9 and R1. 22. Now in B1, 8 must lie in R2 and C1. 23. From 7., in B1 5 and 9 are in R2. Since also 5 is in C2 and B4, 5 must lie in the intersection of B1 and C3 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and C2. 24. In C3, 9 must go in R7 (as that is all that remains in C3). 25. In R2 only 1,4 and 7 remain but in C8 both 1 and 4 are placed, so 7 lies in the intersection of R2 and C8. 26. Hence the final 7 must go in B2 in the intersection of R1 and C6. *26|**7|**8 895|62*|*73 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 457|193|862 983|246|517 612|578|**4 ------------------ 2*9|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7*1|8*2|*4* 27. The intersection of C5 and R1 is either 3 or 5. Similarly the intersection of C6 and R3 is either 1 or 5. Also in B1 the remaining numbers are 1 and 3. Since 5 cannot occupy two places in B2 either the intersection of C5 and R1 is 3 or the intersection of C6 and R3 is 1. In the first case 3 can't go into the intersection of R1 with B1 (so 1 goes there and 3 in the remaining space of B1) and in the second 1 can't go in the intersection of R3 with B1 (so 3 goes there and 1 in the remaining space of B1). Either way 1 goes in the intersection of R1 with B1 and 3 in the intersection of R3 with B1. 126|**7|**8 895|62*|*73 374|*8*|*** ------------------ 457|193|862 983|246|517 612|578|**4 ------------------ 2*9|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7*1|8*2|*4* 28. In C4, only 3, 4 and 9 remain to be filled but R3 already contains 3 and 4, so the intersection of C4 with R3 contains 9. 29. Thus 9 is not in the intersection of R3 and C9, so it is in the intersection of C9 and B9 but it isn't in R7 or R8 so it is at the intersection of C9 and R9. 30. This implies that in R9 5 lies in C5. 31. Thus in B9, 5 must occur in R7 and hence also in C9 and also in B8 6 must lie in C5 and so in R8. 32. So in R7, 6 must lie in C2, then in C2, 3 must lie in R9 and in R9 6 must lie in C7 and 3 is the only remaining number to be filled in C5. 33. In B8, 3 must lie in C4 leaving 4 in C6. 34. 4 is the only thing left to go in C4, so in R2 4 must go in C7 leaving 1 in C6 to complete R2 and thus 5 in R3 to complete B2. 35. In R1 5 must go in C8 and hence 9 in C7 to complete. Thus in R6 9 must go in C8 and so 3 in C7 to complete. 36. In C8, 3 must go in R8 leaving 2 in R3 to complete. Thus in C7 2 must go in R8 leaving 1 in R3 to complete. Thus in C9 1 must go in R3 leaving 2 in C8 to complete the puzzle. 126|437|958 895|621|473 374|985|231 ------------------ 457|193|862 983|246|517 612|578|394 ------------------ 269|314|785 548|769|123 731|852|649
1519. Re: World Championships
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

Is this kind of thing something you need to know about from already registered people? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > This is just a reminder to register online for the WC 2005 if you > haven't done so. 1520. WC blindfold cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 14:00:53 -0700

Hi Everyone,

A reminder to all blindfold cubers, please change your stickers before
the competition or make sure you stickers are in top notch shape. The
competition organizers will be very strict in judging the quality of
the stickers on cubes to be used in the blindfold competition. If your
stickers do not meet the standards of the competition, you will be
asked to replace your stickers. Such action may result in a
disadvantage for the competitor which is why this warning is being
given out now.

Stickers may be purchased from www.cubesmith.com . www.cubesmith.com
provides high quality stickers that do not have plastic films that peel
and do not lose their color. They will last a couple of months even
for the most strenuous of cubers. Stickers from www.cubeesmith.com are
approved for the WC 2005 competition given that they are not altered in
any way.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology




1521. Re: [Speed cubing group] WC blindfold cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 14:04:41 -0700

Actually, even for the speed solve competition, you should try to get
some good stickers for your cube. If some of your green faces are
white, the judges at the competition are not obligated to accept your
cube and may ask you to resticker. Please play it safe and resticker
your cube before the competition so you're using something you're used
to

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Aug 30, 2005, at 2:06 PM, Bob Burton wrote: > What if your name is Cory Loviglio and your stickers look like they > have been eaten so they are so small that you need a microscope to see > a color other than black? :D > > ~ Bob > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Actually, even for the speed solve competition, you should try to get >> some good stickers for your cube. If some of your green faces are >> white, the judges at the competition are not obligated to accept your >> cube and may ask you to resticker. Please play it safe and resticker >> your cube before the competition so you're using something you're used >> to >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology >> >> On Aug 30, 2005, at 2:00 PM, Tyson Mao wrote: >> >>> Hi Everyone, >>> >>> A reminder to all blindfold cubers, please change your stickers >>> before >>> the competition or make sure you stickers are in top notch shape. >>> The >>> competition organizers will be very strict in judging the quality of >>> the stickers on cubes to be used in the blindfold competition. If > your >>> stickers do not meet the standards of the competition, you will be >>> asked to replace your stickers. Such action may result in a >>> disadvantage for the competitor which is why this warning is being >>> given out now. >>> >>> Stickers may be purchased from www.cubesmith.com . www.cubesmith.com >>> provides high quality stickers that do not have plastic films that > peel >>> and do not lose their color. They will last a couple of months even >>> for the most strenuous of cubers. Stickers from > www.cubeesmith.com are >>> approved for the WC 2005 competition given that they are not > altered in >>> any way. >>> >>> Tyson Mao >>> MSC #631 >>> California Institute of Technology >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> Yahoo! Groups Links >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> >>> > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1524. Re: WC blindfold cubing
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 21:47:56 -0000

Tyson, can we assemble the cube such that we can tell the orientation of a popped piece? Or is this "cheating"? I'm sure this has been asked before, but to be honest I forget what or if we came to a conclusion. Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > A reminder to all blindfold cubers, please change your stickers before > the competition or make sure you stickers are in top notch shape. The > competition organizers will be very strict in judging the quality of > the stickers on cubes to be used in the blindfold competition. If your > stickers do not meet the standards of the competition, you will be > asked to replace your stickers. Such action may result in a > disadvantage for the competitor which is why this warning is being > given out now. > > Stickers may be purchased from www.cubesmith.com . www.cubesmith.com > provides high quality stickers that do not have plastic films that peel > and do not lose their color. They will last a couple of months even > for the most strenuous of cubers. Stickers from www.cubeesmith.com are > approved for the WC 2005 competition given that they are not altered in > any way. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1525. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: WC blindfold cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 30 Aug 2005 14:54:31 -0700

You may assemble the cube so that you can tell orientation. In fact, I think everyone should always sticker their cube in this manner. However, the spirit of the law allows you to feel for orientation during a BLD solve if you pop. You can't pop pieces out on purpose, feel for which way they belong in, and then stick them in. If anyone wants to try that, I'd be happy to race them. I'll give you a minute head start too. (I think trying to tell orientation that way would slow you down like mad.) Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Aug 30, 2005, at 2:47 PM, cmhardw wrote: > Tyson, can we assemble the cube such that we can tell the orientation > of a popped piece? Or is this "cheating"? > > I'm sure this has been asked before, but to be honest I forget what or > if we came to a conclusion. > > Chris > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Hi Everyone, >> >> A reminder to all blindfold cubers, please change your stickers before >> the competition or make sure you stickers are in top notch shape. The >> competition organizers will be very strict in judging the quality of >> the stickers on cubes to be used in the blindfold competition. If >> your >> stickers do not meet the standards of the competition, you will be >> asked to replace your stickers. Such action may result in a >> disadvantage for the competitor which is why this warning is being >> given out now. >> >> Stickers may be purchased from www.cubesmith.com . www.cubesmith.com >> provides high quality stickers that do not have plastic films that >> peel >> and do not lose their color. They will last a couple of months even >> for the most strenuous of cubers. Stickers from www.cubeesmith.com >> are >> approved for the WC 2005 competition given that they are not altered >> in >> any way. >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >

Can you please post the solution with explanation. > It is a really difficult one... > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Beer, Bram de > Verzonden: vrijdag 22 juli 2005 8:22 > Aan: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com' > Onderwerp: RE: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku > > > Thanks for the info. If I don't get it by the end > of my holiday, I'll send you an email. > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens GameOfDeath2 > Verzonden: donderdag 21 juli 2005 18:33 > Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Re: Solving Sudoku > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" > <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > > Hi all, > > > > > > Last week, this Sudoku was posted in this group: > > It is difficult - I take it you've already put in a 6 (that part is > easy). To give you more idea of the difficulty, I gave a friend who > also does Sudoku another grid with the numbers 1,2,... on which > order to fill the squares in! (That was a while ago and he still > hasn't got the second one in yet.) > I don't know where you are in the puzzle, so I'll tell you this - > the second number to put in goes in the square below that I've > labelled with "@". The third one goes where the # is. > (If you get really stuck, I can post a complete solution that > explains how to get each step without trial and error.) > > > > > > > > . 2 . * . . . * . . . > > > . . . * 6 . . * . . 3 > > > . 7 4 * . 8 . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . . 3 * . . 2 > > > . 8 . * . 4 . * . 1 @ > > > 6 . . * 5 . . * . . . > > > * * * * * * * * * * * > > > . . . * . 1 . * 7 8 . > > > 5 # . * . . 9 * . . . > > > . . . * . . . * . 4 . > > > > > > > > > I tried to solve it, but I am stuck. Can anyone give me some > tactical > > > advise on how to solve it? Seems I can't solve it without > > > trial-and-error... > > > > > > -Bram > > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you > receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents > herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. > ================================================ > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] Hi Bram, I too have become interesting in sudoku lately, and have found this program: http://www.angusj.com/sudoku/index.php <http://www.angusj.com/sudoku/index.php> It is very handy if you get stuck on a puzzle. It will tell you what to do to solve it step by step. I have also saved you some time by making the file you need to open for that puzzle: http://www.geocities.com/pjgat09/bramsudoku.zip <http://www.geocities.com/pjgat09/bramsudoku.zip> Install the program (you will like it alot), then unzip the file in the second link, and save it in a folder somewhere. Then open it with the program. When you have opened it, heres how it can show you how to solve it step by step: Click on View-Hint. It will show you a hint, and tell you at the bottom why it is. Then click View-Solve Next Step. This will use the hint to get the puzzle closer to solved. I hope this helped!! Peter Greenwood SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+gam e&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+g ame&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw > puzzle game Free <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzl e+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puz zle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6 ReWEw> puzzle inlay games Educational <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+p uzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word +puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R 94IVKMFNQ> game and puzzle Word <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game& w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+gam e&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> puzzle game Kid <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w 2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game &w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> puzzle game Puzzle <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=F ree+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5 =Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> games _____ YAHOO! 1531. RE: [Speed cubing group] Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving Su doku)
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 08:40:28 +0200

Thanks for the solution. It helped a lot with understanding the difficulties I was having with the puzzle. Combined with the program I got from pjgat09, I fully understand what to look for in my next really difficult Sudoku. Unfortunately only simple Sudoku puzzles are published here... :( -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens GameOfDeath2 Verzonden: dinsdag 30 augustus 2005 22:22 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving Sudoku) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > To GameOfDeath2: > > Still did not solve it. Can you please post the solution with explanation. > It is a really difficult one... > R1-R9, C1-C9 will denote the rows and columns and B1-B9 the boxes (in the order 123 456 789 ). I will not put in too many diagrams as it takes up a lot of space but here is the full solution - at least the one I came up with. Probably there are several. The crucial bit here wasdtep 27. I hadn't used anything like that before: basically if you get a pattern of possibilities ab ac ab bc as in this case (crucially, although they lie in 3 different columns they do lie in only 2 rows and in only 2 boxes) then because the two on the right lie in the same box they can't both be c. Thus the two on the left can't be a and b (a above b) so must be b and a (b above a). That allows for 1 and 3 to be determined and without guessing because they follow this logical pattern (above). Other than that the most difficult stages are probably 2 and 3 to get a start. 2. isn't really so bad - it's just observing that the triple 4,7,8 can only appear in 3 squares (so splitting C9 into 2 subsets) whence 7 can be placed straightaway (this step can be done first but is less obvious than step 1.). 3. is a bit technical too but I think 27. is the key stage. It relies on spotting a triple in 4 squares that do not lie all in the same column, row or box. NB You can also solve the same initial puzzle except with a 7 in the middle instead of a 4. It is quite similar. 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a 6). 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must contain 7. Initial Grid: *2*|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ ***|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*1* 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 5**|**9|*** ***|***|*4* For convenience label rows R1 to R9 (downwards), columns C1-C9 (left to right), boxes B1-B9 (right then down). 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a 6). 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must contain 7. 3. In B5, 1 and 8 must appear on the leading diagonal as they are already present in C5 and R5. Thus since 7 is in R5, 7 must occur in the intersection of B5 and C5. In particular in C5, 4,7 and 8 appear before B8. Thus in R8 4,7,8 must occur in C2-C4 and hence 4 lies in the intersection of C2 and R8. 4. Thus in B4, 4 goes in the intersection of R4 and C1. 5. Thus in C1, 7 must go in R9. 6. Recalling that in R8, C2-C4 contain 4,7 and 8, 8 must go in C3 (because B7 contains 4,7) and so 7 in C4. *26|***|*** ***|6**|**3 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 4**|**3|**2 *8*|*4*|*17 6**|5**|*** ------------------ ***|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7**|***|*4* 7. In C1, neither 1 nor 8 can go in R5 or R7 (because they both appear elsewhere in R5 and R7) so both must appear in B1 and further 3 doesn't appear in the intersection of R2 and B1 so in B1 3 must be in C1. That leaves 5 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and R2 which means that (recalling 7 is in the intersection of B5 and C5) the intersection of R2 and C5 must be a 2. 8. Thus 2 must appear in the intersection of B5 and R5 (since 1,8 are on the leading diagonal of that box) and 2 can't appear in the intersection of C1 and R5. Since the intersection of C1 and B1 contains 1,3 and 8 it follows that 2 must appear in the intersection of C1 and R7 and 9 in the intersection of C1 and R5. 9. In B4, 2 must appear in C3 but neither in R4 nor (because 2 appears in the intersection of B5 and R5) in R5, so 2 must appear in the intersection of C3 and R6. 10. Therefore in B4, 7 appears in the intersection of R4 and C3. 11. So in B5, recalling 7 is in C5, 7 must occur in R6. 12. Now 9 already appearing in R5 and 1,8 being on the leading diagonal of B5, 9 must appear in B5 at the intersection of R4 and C5. 13. Again, 6 being already in C4 and R6, 6 must be in B5 at the intersection of C6 and R5. 14. 2s being in B4 and B6, the only remaining place in R5 for a 2 is the intersection with B5, i.e. in C4. 15. In B4, 1 must fall in C2, hence 1 must fall in C3 in B7, but not in R7 as we already have a 1 in R7. So 1 must fall in R9 and C3 in B9. 16. Moreover, in B8, 2 must lie in C6 but not in R7 (hence in R9). 17. Again in B8, 8 can't appear in R7 or C5 so it must be in the intersection of C4 and R9. 18. Thus in B5 we have that 1 lies in R4 and 8 lies in R6. 19. Now in B4, 1 lies in R6, 5 lies in R4, leaving 3 in R5. 20. In R4 8 can't lie in C8 and so must lie in C7, leaving 6 in C8 to complete R4. Also 5 completes R5. 21. Way back in 2, we figured that in C9, 4, 7 and 8 could lie only in R1, R5 and R6. From B6, we conclude that 4 must lie in the intersection of C9 and R6 and so 8 in the intersection of C9 and R1. 22. Now in B1, 8 must lie in R2 and C1. 23. From 7., in B1 5 and 9 are in R2. Since also 5 is in C2 and B4, 5 must lie in the intersection of B1 and C3 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and C2. 24. In C3, 9 must go in R7 (as that is all that remains in C3). 25. In R2 only 1,4 and 7 remain but in C8 both 1 and 4 are placed, so 7 lies in the intersection of R2 and C8. 26. Hence the final 7 must go in B2 in the intersection of R1 and C6. *26|**7|**8 895|62*|*73 *74|*8*|*** ------------------ 457|193|862 983|246|517 612|578|**4 ------------------ 2*9|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7*1|8*2|*4* 27. The intersection of C5 and R1 is either 3 or 5. Similarly the intersection of C6 and R3 is either 1 or 5. Also in B1 the remaining numbers are 1 and 3. Since 5 cannot occupy two places in B2 either the intersection of C5 and R1 is 3 or the intersection of C6 and R3 is 1. In the first case 3 can't go into the intersection of R1 with B1 (so 1 goes there and 3 in the remaining space of B1) and in the second 1 can't go in the intersection of R3 with B1 (so 3 goes there and 1 in the remaining space of B1). Either way 1 goes in the intersection of R1 with B1 and 3 in the intersection of R3 with B1. 126|**7|**8 895|62*|*73 374|*8*|*** ------------------ 457|193|862 983|246|517 612|578|**4 ------------------ 2*9|*1*|78* 548|7*9|*** 7*1|8*2|*4* 28. In C4, only 3, 4 and 9 remain to be filled but R3 already contains 3 and 4, so the intersection of C4 with R3 contains 9. 29. Thus 9 is not in the intersection of R3 and C9, so it is in the intersection of C9 and B9 but it isn't in R7 or R8 so it is at the intersection of C9 and R9. 30. This implies that in R9 5 lies in C5. 31. Thus in B9, 5 must occur in R7 and hence also in C9 and also in B8 6 must lie in C5 and so in R8. 32. So in R7, 6 must lie in C2, then in C2, 3 must lie in R9 and in R9 6 must lie in C7 and 3 is the only remaining number to be filled in C5. 33. In B8, 3 must lie in C4 leaving 4 in C6. 34. 4 is the only thing left to go in C4, so in R2 4 must go in C7 leaving 1 in C6 to complete R2 and thus 5 in R3 to complete B2. 35. In R1 5 must go in C8 and hence 9 in C7 to complete. Thus in R6 9 must go in C8 and so 3 in C7 to complete. 36. In C8, 3 must go in R8 leaving 2 in R3 to complete. Thus in C7 2 must go in R8 leaving 1 in R3 to complete. Thus in C9 1 must go in R3 leaving 2 in C8 to complete the puzzle. 126|437|958 895|621|473 374|985|231 ------------------ 457|193|862 983|246|517 612|578|394 ------------------ 269|314|785 548|769|123 731|852|649 _____ YAHOO! 1533. powerball
From: "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 09:13:28 +0200

Got my hand on a cool gadget called a "powerball" yesterday, and i cant
seem to put it down. It's great fun and a very good workout for forarms
/ wrists.

Have anyone else here tried this ? I wonder if it's good training for
cubing. Wouldnt hurt to have stronger wrists, especially when using the
big cubes.

Here's a website : http://www.powerballs.com

Terje

-----Opprinnelig melding-----
Fra: Beer, Bram de [mailto:bbeer@...]
Sendt: 31. august 2005 10:00
Til: 'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'
Emne: *****SPAM***** RE: [Speed cubing group] powerball

Spam filtrering.

WebOn skanner din e-post for spam, denne e-posten ble merket av vrt
spamfilter.
Spamfilteret gr igjennom avsender, overskrift og innholdet i all
inngende e-post, og basert p vektede regler, avgjr om e-posten er
spam
eller ikke.

Den innkommene e-posten blir IKKE slettet. Dersom programmet finner ut
at
dette er spam, legger den inn teksten "*****SPAM*****" i overskriften,
og gir samtidig en rapport over hvilke regler som er benyttet til
avgjre
at dette er spam. Den originale e-posten blir lagt med som et vedlegg.

rsaken til at vi ikke sletter e-posten er i hovedsak at reglene i
programmet KAN ta feil - og vi nsker derfor ikke slette din e-post.

Dersom du merker at filteret er for "strengt", dvs. at det markerer
e-post
som faktisk ikke er spam, ber vi deg rapportere dette til oss
(support@webon.net), slik at vi kan korrigere p mten reglene blir
benyttet.

Med vennlig hilsen
WebOn Support

Content preview: Had one for over a year. They work great for many
sports. Had mine for rock climbing... -----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----

Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
[mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Terje Kristensen

Verzonden: woensdag 31 augustus 2005 9:13 Aan:
speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group]

powerball [...]

Content analysis details: (4.7 points, 4.0 required)

pts rule name description
---- ----------------------
--------------------------------------------------
0.0 HTML_MESSAGE BODY: HTML included in message
0.0 BAYES_50 BODY: Bayesian spam probability is 40 to 60%
[score: 0.5000]
0.2 MIME_HTML_ONLY BODY: Message only has text/html MIME parts
2.0 FORGED_IMS_HTML IMS can't send HTML message only
2.4 FORGED_IMS_TAGS IMS mailers can't send HTML in this format
0.0 AWL AWL: From: address is in the auto white-list

The original message was not completely plain text, and may be unsafe to
open with some email clients; in particular, it may contain a virus,
or confirm that your address can receive spam. If you wish to view
it, it may be safer to save it to a file and open it with an editor.

1540. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: powerball
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 04:17:51 -0700

I have a couple knock-off cheap versions from Taiwan. My brother and I got into it awhile back but we could only judge 'speed' by the pitch that the powerball was making. I can totally see myself getting obsessed given that these models now give you actual rpm numbers. It's kinda like running or whatever... I dunno, maybe I think I've just got problems with being too competitive. If I go out for a normal run, it's all nice and happy. If I'm on a track, I have the sudden urge to time myself. 1545. Re: First succesful BLD solve !!!
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 12:57:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > Hello all, I am very happy at this moment and had noone to share this > with so am writing here. I just had my first succesful BLD solve of > the 3x3x3. > > It took about 6 days for me to learn it completely..there was a gap of > 3-4 days in between as i had gotten sick, and when today i took the > cube again, i had a unseccusful solve for the first time but the > second time when i opened my eyes there it was the solved cube...i was > never so happy to see a solved cube before ! > > I made a mistaske in the last part doing a R while permuting the > edges...then when i realised it i had to undo the moves and do it > again, i was so tensed. > > Anyway i would like to say a lot of thanks to Tyson and Macky for > their BLD tutorials. It was quite a journey learning the BLD > solution(though typo errors in Tyson's document made it more like an > adventure ;) ) > > Bye then. > Happy (BLD) Cubing. Congratz, Sachin! I'm learning BLD too, but I'm having some troubles with edge permutation...sometimes I flip the corners when permuting the edges...

1547. Re: [Speed cubing group] Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving Su doku)
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 17:29:26 +0200

Your time: 6 minutes, 18 seconds
Top 20%

That site is interesting, but you can easily cheat, I prefer my book :p


1548. [Speed cubing group] Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving Su doku)
From: pjgat09 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 16:14:08 -0000

Hi Bram, If you look in the program that i showed you inder File-Creat New, you can make 5 different levels of difficult puzzles. Each is a few steps up from the previous one, with like 2-3 more techniques you will need. The methods are all included in the help file, so if you dont understand, you can just check there. Have fun and good luck! Peter Greenwood --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > Thanks for the solution. It helped a lot with understanding the difficulties > I was having with the puzzle. Combined with the program I got from pjgat09, > I fully understand what to look for in my next really difficult Sudoku. > Unfortunately only simple Sudoku puzzles are published here... :( > > -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- > Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens GameOfDeath2 > Verzonden: dinsdag 30 augustus 2005 22:22 > Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving > Sudoku) > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> > wrote: > > To GameOfDeath2: > > > > Still did not solve it. Can you please post the solution with explanation. > > It is a really difficult one... > > > > R1-R9, C1-C9 will denote the rows and columns and B1-B9 the boxes (in the > order > > 123 > 456 > 789 > ). > > I will not put in too many diagrams as it takes up a lot of space but here > is the full solution > - at least the one I came up with. Probably there are several. The crucial > bit here wasdtep > 27. I hadn't used anything like that before: > > basically if you get a pattern of possibilities > > ab ac > > ab bc > > as in this case (crucially, although they lie in 3 different columns they do > lie in only 2 rows > and in only 2 boxes) then because the two on the right lie in the same box > they can't both > be c. Thus the two on the left can't be a and b (a above b) so must be b and > a (b above a). > That allows for 1 and 3 to be determined and without guessing because they > follow this > logical pattern (above). Other than that the most difficult stages are > probably 2 and 3 to > get a start. 2. isn't really so bad - it's just observing that the triple > 4,7,8 can only appear in > 3 squares (so splitting C9 into 2 subsets) whence 7 can be placed > straightaway (this step > can be done first but is less obvious than step 1.). > 3. is a bit technical too but I think 27. is the key stage. It relies on > spotting a triple in 4 > squares that do not lie all in the same column, row or box. > NB You can also solve the same initial puzzle except with a 7 in the middle > instead of a 4. > It is quite similar. > > 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 > that can contain a > 6). > 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections > with R1, R5 and > R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and > R5 must > contain 7. > Initial Grid: > > *2*|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > ***|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*1* > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 5**|**9|*** > ***|***|*4* > > For convenience label rows R1 to R9 (downwards), columns C1-C9 (left to > right), boxes > B1-B9 (right then down). > > 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 > that can contain a > 6). > > 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections > with R1, R5 and > R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and > R5 must > contain 7. > > 3. In B5, 1 and 8 must appear on the leading diagonal as they are already > present in C5 > and R5. Thus since 7 is in R5, 7 must occur in the intersection of B5 and > C5. In particular > in C5, 4,7 and 8 appear before B8. Thus in R8 4,7,8 must occur in C2-C4 and > hence 4 lies > in the intersection of C2 and R8. > > 4. Thus in B4, 4 goes in the intersection of R4 and C1. > > 5. Thus in C1, 7 must go in R9. > > 6. Recalling that in R8, C2-C4 contain 4,7 and 8, 8 must go in C3 (because > B7 contains > 4,7) and so 7 in C4. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 4**|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7**|***|*4* > > 7. In C1, neither 1 nor 8 can go in R5 or R7 (because they both appear > elsewhere in R5 and > R7) so both must appear in B1 and further 3 doesn't appear in the > intersection of R2 and > B1 so in B1 3 must be in C1. That leaves 5 and 9 in the intersection of B1 > and R2 which > means that (recalling 7 is in the intersection of B5 and C5) the > intersection of R2 and C5 > must be a 2. > > 8. Thus 2 must appear in the intersection of B5 and R5 (since 1,8 are on the > leading > diagonal of that box) and 2 can't appear in the intersection of C1 and R5. > Since the > intersection of C1 and B1 contains 1,3 and 8 it follows that 2 must appear > in the > intersection of C1 and R7 and 9 in the intersection of C1 and R5. > > 9. In B4, 2 must appear in C3 but neither in R4 nor (because 2 appears in > the intersection > of B5 and R5) in R5, so 2 must appear in the intersection of C3 and R6. > > 10. Therefore in B4, 7 appears in the intersection of R4 and C3. > > 11. So in B5, recalling 7 is in C5, 7 must occur in R6. > > 12. Now 9 already appearing in R5 and 1,8 being on the leading diagonal of > B5, 9 must > appear in B5 at the intersection of R4 and C5. > > 13. Again, 6 being already in C4 and R6, 6 must be in B5 at the intersection > of C6 and R5. > > 14. 2s being in B4 and B6, the only remaining place in R5 for a 2 is the > intersection with > B5, i.e. in C4. > > 15. In B4, 1 must fall in C2, hence 1 must fall in C3 in B7, but not in R7 > as we already have > a 1 in R7. So 1 must fall in R9 and C3 in B9. > > 16. Moreover, in B8, 2 must lie in C6 but not in R7 (hence in R9). > > 17. Again in B8, 8 can't appear in R7 or C5 so it must be in the > intersection of C4 and R9. > > 18. Thus in B5 we have that 1 lies in R4 and 8 lies in R6. > > 19. Now in B4, 1 lies in R6, 5 lies in R4, leaving 3 in R5. > > 20. In R4 8 can't lie in C8 and so must lie in C7, leaving 6 in C8 to > complete R4. Also 5 > completes R5. > > 21. Way back in 2, we figured that in C9, 4, 7 and 8 could lie only in R1, > R5 and R6. From > B6, we conclude that 4 must lie in the intersection of C9 and R6 and so 8 in > the > intersection of C9 and R1. > > 22. Now in B1, 8 must lie in R2 and C1. > > 23. From 7., in B1 5 and 9 are in R2. Since also 5 is in C2 and B4, 5 must > lie in the > intersection of B1 and C3 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and C2. > > 24. In C3, 9 must go in R7 (as that is all that remains in C3). > > 25. In R2 only 1,4 and 7 remain but in C8 both 1 and 4 are placed, so 7 lies > in the > intersection of R2 and C8. > > 26. Hence the final 7 must go in B2 in the intersection of R1 and C6. > > *26|**7|**8 > 895|62*|*73 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 457|193|862 > 983|246|517 > 612|578|**4 > ------------------ > 2*9|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7*1|8*2|*4* > > 27. The intersection of C5 and R1 is either 3 or 5. Similarly the > intersection of C6 and R3 > is either 1 or 5. Also in B1 the remaining numbers are 1 and 3. Since 5 > cannot occupy two > places in B2 either the intersection of C5 and R1 is 3 or the intersection > of C6 and R3 is 1. > In the first case 3 can't go into the intersection of R1 with B1 (so 1 goes > there and 3 in the > remaining space of B1) and in the second 1 can't go in the intersection of > R3 with B1 (so 3 > goes there and 1 in the remaining space of B1). Either way 1 goes in the > intersection of R1 > with B1 and 3 in the intersection of R3 with B1. > > 126|**7|**8 > 895|62*|*73 > 374|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 457|193|862 > 983|246|517 > 612|578|**4 > ------------------ > 2*9|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7*1|8*2|*4* > > 28. In C4, only 3, 4 and 9 remain to be filled but R3 already contains 3 and > 4, so the > intersection of C4 with R3 contains 9. > > 29. Thus 9 is not in the intersection of R3 and C9, so it is in the > intersection of C9 and B9 > but it isn't in R7 or R8 so it is at the intersection of C9 and R9. > > 30. This implies that in R9 5 lies in C5. > > 31. Thus in B9, 5 must occur in R7 and hence also in C9 and also in B8 6 > must lie in C5 > and so in R8. > > 32. So in R7, 6 must lie in C2, then in C2, 3 must lie in R9 and in R9 6 > must lie in C7 and 3 > is the only remaining number to be filled in C5. > > 33. In B8, 3 must lie in C4 leaving 4 in C6. > > 34. 4 is the only thing left to go in C4, so in R2 4 must go in C7 leaving 1 > in C6 to > complete R2 and thus 5 in R3 to complete B2. > > 35. In R1 5 must go in C8 and hence 9 in C7 to complete. Thus in R6 9 must > go in C8 and > so 3 in C7 to complete. > > 36. In C8, 3 must go in R8 leaving 2 in R3 to complete. Thus in C7 2 must go > in R8 leaving > 1 in R3 to complete. Thus in C9 1 must go in R3 leaving 2 in C8 to complete > the puzzle. > > > 126|437|958 > 895|621|473 > 374|985|231 > ------------------ > 457|193|862 > 983|246|517 > 612|578|394 > ------------------ > 269|314|785 > 548|769|123 > 731|852|649 > > > > > > > _____ > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > * Visit your group " speedsolvingrubikscube > <http://groups.yahoo.com/group/speedsolvingrubikscube> " on the web. > > > * To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > <mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com? subject=Unsubscri > be> > > > * Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service > <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> . > > > _____ > > > ================================================ > De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en > is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht > onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en > de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. > ================================================ > The information contained in this message may be confidential > and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. 1549. [Speed cubing group] Re: 2x2x2 algorithms
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 31 Aug 2005 19:23:56 -0000

1553. New GabbaSoft Cube Demo With SuperCubes
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 04:07:45 -0000

Greetings,

Our newest cube demo (ver 0.03.0007) includes (among other changes)
supercube versions for every puzzle size! It is available now on
our website (http://www.gabbasoft.com). Although not originally
something we had considered doing, you online cubers have been so
wonderful about sharing your ideas and comments with us that we
wanted to make something just for you: the only folks we know that
might not cry at the thought of solving a 20x20x20 supercube. We
also increased the range of the timer and move counters to
accomodate the larger cube sizes. So enjoy and keep the suggestions
coming!!

Thanks again,

Jamey Pittman
President
GabbaSoft, Inc.
jpittman@...
www.gabbasoft.com





1554. Re: New GabbaSoft Cube Demo With SuperCubes
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 06:46:43 -0000

It is available now on > our website (http://www.gabbasoft.com). Although not originally > something we had considered doing, you online cubers have been so > wonderful about sharing your ideas and comments with us that we > wanted to make something just for you: the only folks we know that > might not cry at the thought of solving a 20x20x20 supercube. We > also increased the range of the timer and move counters to > accomodate the larger cube sizes. So enjoy and keep the suggestions > coming!! > > Thanks again, > > Jamey Pittman > President > GabbaSoft, Inc. > jpittman@g... > www.gabbasoft.com
1555. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 1 Sep 2005 12:37:36 +0200

I was sitting at the pool last week, practicing 5x5x5, when the guy next to me said that he could solve 1 face when he was a kid. Why don't they see the difference between a 3x3x3 and a 5x5x5? I had to show him a 3x3x3 before he saw the difference. :-) Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: mike_go_uk To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, August 29, 2005 5:47 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@g...> wrote: > they're like "I can do that in 10 seconds" and tons of > crap like that. gets annoying. feel like slapping them, but its still > school. I was quietly cubing in a cafe late the other night and a woman with a rather loud voice informed me that (1) she loved Rubik's cubes (a good start, I thought) (2) she had never actually owned a cube (3) she could solve it in 5 seconds. It's no use arguing... I just told her that that was a pretty good time. There ought to be a special UWR page for these folk. ;) Mike ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS a.. 1556. [Speed cubing group] Re: World Championships
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 11:34:33 -0000

I think I've found an error in the Posting about legal/illegal cubes.
On the site that describes the tournament it says Rubik's 3x3x3,
Rubik's 4x4x4 and so on...but it does NOT say Rubik's 2x2x2 or
Megaminx or Square-1, then it says "Only Rubik brand puzzles will be
allowed for the Rubik's events." But it does not say the 2x2x2 is a
Rubik's event, so therefore you can use an Eastsheen, according to
those rules...

Craig

1559. Rewrote my 'simple solution'
From: Jol van Noort <joel_vn@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 14:36:46 -0000

Hey guys,

I did a lot of work today to improve my 'simple solution', the first
tutorial on my site. A friend of mine solved it using that solution
before, but he had some difficulties with some of the steps. Based on
his comments, and also comments I got from other people, I rewrote the
whole thing. It's still 'simple' (as in: it's does not require a lot
of reading, centainly if you have a natural 'feeling' for cubing), but
easier than before, IMHO.

If you think I forgot to mention some tips, please give me feedback
about that :).

-Jol.

(www.solvethecube.co.uk)

1563. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 1 Sep 2005 17:26:23 +0200

Hi Jasmine,

Wow, English train travellers are obviously nicer than Dutch commuters.
When I cube in the train, most of the time people demonstratively move to a seat far away. Or they ask me to stop, because of the noise that cubing makes.
Only once in a while people are interested or amazed.
But then again, I am not a good looking lady like you. :-)

Have fun,

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: jasmine_ellen
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, August 21, 2005 2:20 AM
Subject: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train


I often cube on the train. Sometimes no one pays any attention, but
sometimes they do. Tonight was definitely the later. A group of four
girls sitting across from me let out audible gasps when I finished a
solve. I like to take any opportunity to promote cubing, so if anyone
shows any interest on the train (or anywhere!) I'll offer to do them
another demo and ask them to do the scramble themselves (so they know
it wasn't 'set up' and also to get them involved). I did a few more
3x3x3 demos for them and they were very impressed. Then I whipped out
the 4x4x4 and got them to scramble that too. :)

Later during the train trip, another group of people got on. They were
pretty amazed ("Oh my goodness! Did you just solve that thing?!") and
so I handed them my cube. I did several demos as various different
people in train scrambled my cube. They timed one of the solves (32
seconds) and then I got an applause from half the train carriage. When
the train was approaching the final stop, which was also my stop,
there was one guy left from the group. He'd been further down the
carriage and hadn't actually seen my solves, he'd just heard his
friends talking ("Wow! She just solved that in 32 seconds!") So
obviously I offered to do a demo for him. :) He was completely blown
away and asked me what I did. He then asked me if I was looking for a
job and gave me his contact details!

BTW, I beat my PB single solve tonight too - 22.23 seconds. :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com

Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle games Free puzzle inlay games

1564. F2L style: Macky "vs" Jean
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 15:28:50 -0000

Watch out for fast d and d2 turns during F2L with left hand: http://strangepuzzle.com/videos/3x3x3%20JeanPons%2014.79.wmv http://strangepuzzle.com/videos/3x3x3%20ShotaroMakisumi%2012.26.wmv Jean solves F2L with <y, U, R> using left hand for cube rotations (y) and right hand for solving (U, R). Now after watching Macky's video I think he does it very similarly, though sometimes he also seems to hold the cross more on the left than on the bottom. Cheers! Stefan
1565. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 15:42:29 -0000

European trains must be much quieter than the London Tube if the noise from a cube is disturbing people! The London Tube is very loud and bumpy - no one would ever even hear me cubing on the Tube. I was just in the US very briefly (flew back into London earlier today) and cubed on the train there too. One guy said he'd seen someone on TV do it blindfolded and behind their back and asked if I could do this. I said no, but that I knew people who could. I asked who he'd seen on TV doing this because I assumed it was probably someone from this group. He didn't remember the name though. Anyone done any blindfolded cubing on TV? See "Extreme Ironing" (www.extremeironing.com) for a comparison. Is the "photos" section of this group a resonable place for such photos??? 1571. [Speed cubing group] Re: 2x2x2 algorithms
From: "movies648" <movies648@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 17:36:42 -0000

I used to use the Petrus Niklas and Sune to solve the 2x2x2. It works out okay because you don't have to worry about the edges permuting, of course. Since Petrus was the only method I knew to solve the 3x3x3 at the time, it was what I used. I recently learned the PLL algorithms so my approach to the 2x2x2 has changed to use those instead. A strict Petrus type approach to the 2x2x2 probably isn't ideal because a couple of the corner orientations require 2 Sunes or something in order to get the whole LL oriented. Probably faster to use a simple OLL algorithm and then a PLL. I suppose that you could learn the Sune orientations well enough to be able to do a 2 look LL on the 2x2x2 (1 for permutation, one for orientation) instead of the opposite approach. Still more turns though probably. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Has anyone thought about using Lars Petrus' method for solving the > 2x2x2 cube? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology
1572. Puzzle question (sokoban)
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 18:22:07 -0000

Hey everyone,

I have a question about sokoban puzzles (where you push boxes around
into designated spots).

My girlfriend recently gave me the link to this page
http://www.addictinggames.com/ledix

and of course I'm addicted to it :-)

I'm almost done with it, there are 24 levels and I'm on #18.

Anyway I had an idea, do they have team sokoban puzzles? Where you
can control two characters to move the boxes around?

It seems like you could make some really crazy puzzles like this.
Like you could completely box in one guy to move boxes out of the way,
then the boxed in guy would have to, at the right moment, start moving
those 4 boxes around, stuff like that.

Anyone know a simple way to make sokoban puzzles online? If no one
has ever made pair sokoban puzzles then I'd love to try it and see if
it works.

Anyway, if there are any other sokoban fans, let me know if pair
sokoban solving exists. I'm curious.

Chris

1574. Re: F2L style: Macky "vs" Jean
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Now after watching Macky's video I > think he does it very similarly, though sometimes he also seems to > hold the cross more on the left than on the bottom. Mmh, I thought about the latter again. It's like he does z turns or rather holds the cube at about z/2, enabling him to do <L,U,R> all with his right hand! Pretty cool... Cheers! Stefan
1575. Re: supercube gabbasoft - works fine
From: "Rob Butler" <futuese@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 20:01:44 -0000

It seems to work fine for me. To test this I went first to a cube size I know well - 5x5x5. I do prefer Stefan's style of supercube sticker available at cubesmith but I was able to get used to the arrow verson easily enough. I solved a 5x5x5 - 526 moves in 26 min 08 sec and then a 6x6x6 - 890 moves in 45 min 42 sec bigger supercube solves to come :) Rob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@y...> wrote: > hmmmm. i don't think that each and every piece is > unique is it? you can still swap some pieces, i think > the colored band around the edge is the only way to > make each piece unique, so there would be a box around > every ever subsequent layer to the edge...or am i off > my rocker > > --- pyjamamitten <jpittman@g...> wrote: > > > A new version of the Cube Demo is now available from > > GabbaSoft with > > the ability to turn the background music on/off. > > Remember to > > uninstall any existing version from your computer > > before installing > > this one. 1576. Re: 2x2x2 algorithms
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 20:23:39 -0000

Although I don't practice 2*2*2, the system I use for corners(guimond
system) is pretty usefull, I know joel use(d?) this system so he will
agree me:p

email me for algs if you want on my hotmail account.

keep cubing

sebastien




1577. Re: F2L style: Macky "vs" Jean
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 20:27:23 -0000

I don't know a lot about macky's style but I know jean use only RUL
and u or u' moves(cube rotations) but with practice learnt how to do
good grip changes, when you insert a pair using R U R' you just have
to rotate your cube in your right hand and regrip you're left hand. I
use that way too or do Dw moves when it's better, its just intuitive
for him to have always good grips:)

keep cubing

sebastien

1579. [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 20:44:51 -0000

This happens to me too just about every time I have my 4x4x4 or 5x5x5 out in public (which isn't as frequently as I have my 3x3x3 out!). It both astounds and annoys me that non-cubers have so much trouble telling the difference between a 5x5x5, a 4x4x4 and a 3x3x3. Until you put a 3x3x3 next to it they don't even realise it's different puzzle! Grrr! Everyone notices that the 2x2x2 is a different puzzle though. People see the 2x2x2 and say "that looks easy, I reckon I can do that one!" To which I always reply "well, I challenge you then!" Of course, they NEVER can solve it. The 2x2x2 is only easy for a cuber. Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@s...> wrote: > I was sitting at the pool last week, practicing 5x5x5, when the guy next to me said that he could solve 1 face when he was a kid. > Why don't they see the difference between a 3x3x3 and a 5x5x5? I had to show him a 3x3x3 before he saw the difference. :-) > > Have fun, > > Ron > ----- Original Message ----- > From: mike_go_uk > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Monday, August 29, 2005 5:47 PM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Parth Upadhyay > <parth.upadhyay@g...> wrote: > > they're like "I can do that in 10 seconds" and tons of > > crap like that. gets annoying. feel like slapping them, but its still > > school. > > I was quietly cubing in a cafe late the other night and a woman with a > rather loud voice informed me that > (1) she loved Rubik's cubes (a good start, I thought) > (2) she had never actually owned a cube > (3) she could solve it in 5 seconds. > > It's no use arguing... I just told her that that was a pretty good time. > There ought to be a special UWR page for these folk. ;) > > Mike > > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! 1580. Dallas comp publicity
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 20:52:37 -0000

As I mentioned in a recent post, I was in the US very briefly over the
past few days. I met a guy from Dallas and he commented that there was
'a big cube event' recently. This guy was not a cuber at all, so I
asked him how he knew about this. He said it had been all over the
news in Dallas!

Just thought you'd be interested to know that the publicity for the
Dallas event must have been pretty good as non-cubers knew about the
event too. :)

Jasmine
http://speedcuber.blogspot.com






1581. [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 21:15:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, jasmine_ellen <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > It both astounds and annoys me that non-cubers have so much trouble > telling the difference between a 5x5x5, a 4x4x4 and a 3x3x3. Until you > put a 3x3x3 next to it they don't even realise it's different puzzle! > Grrr! Yeah, I was once cubing with a 4x4 and someone said something about how he used to play with it, too. I took out my 3x3 and asked "are you sure you don't mean this one?" and he insisted it was the 4x4. Well ok, it's not impossible. But then he insisted it was a keychain one. Ever saw a keychain 4x4? Cheers! Stefan
1582. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 1 Sep 2005 14:18:00 -0700

Macky did it blindfolded 'behind his back' on the Discovery Channel.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Sep 1, 2005, at 8:42 AM, jasmine_ellen wrote:

> European trains must be much quieter than the London Tube if the noise
> from a cube is disturbing people! The London Tube is very loud and
> bumpy - no one would ever even hear me cubing on the Tube.
>
> I was just in the US very briefly (flew back into London earlier
> today) and cubed on the train there too. One guy said he'd seen
> someone on TV do it blindfolded and behind their back and asked if I
> could do this. I said no, but that I knew people who could. I asked
> who he'd seen on TV doing this because I assumed it was probably
> someone from this group. He didn't remember the name though.
>
> Anyone done any blindfolded cubing on TV?
>
> Jasmine




1583. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 21:31:54 -0000

The guy said the solver took 12 minutes. This surprised me since most of the BLD solvers here do it much faster than that. Perhaps it was something he saw ages ago? Or perhaps the guy mis-remembered how long it took? 1586. Happy
From: "Frank" <ephem825@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 23:26:58 -0000

I sat down earlier, just planning to do a couple of solves. I ended
up doing an average of 100. The final average was 16.45 with a best
rolling average of 15.56. Not too great considering how fast everyone
is getting, but All of the solves were under 20, which is what I am
particularly proud of. Just thought I would share.

Frank




1587. 4x4x4 50 cube average
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 00:25:05 -0000

Hey everyone,

I just did my second ever 50 cube average on the 4x4x4. The first
time I was incredibly close to sub-1:10 and was kind of mad, so I did
another one today and I made it!

It was incredibly hard to stay concentrated. I was at about a 1:07.xx
average after 30 solves, but after that point I totally lost my focus.
I think with more practice sub-1:08 for 50 cubes should be possible.

I thought about doing a 100 cube average, but I think that would be a
bit much for the 4x4, but maybe others have done it.

Anyway I was very happy with this average and wanted to post:

----- JNetCube Session Statistics for Thu Sep 01 20:18:11 EDT 2005 -----

Cubes Solved: 50
Total Pops: 0
Average: 1:09.67
Best Rolling Average: 1:05.99
1:02.48, 1:07.70, 1:00.53, 1:06.76, 1:19.21, 1:17.17, 1:00.62,
1:03.83, (1:21.79), 58.11, 1:03.48, (58.08) = 1:05.99

Fastest Time: 58.08
Slowest Time: 1:25.83
Standard Deviation: 07.79

Individual Times:

l2 d' U' L2 d F2 r' u2 U l' f2 R d' D R2 l' b2 L u' d2 F2 R' B

U' d L F' L d F2 L' l2 U' D f u2 b2 L' D2 F2 L' U2 R f' d D' L U2

b R U' F r2 U2 b R' F' l b2 D2 R2 D2 u' B2 R2 U r' f2 l' R' D F'

L2 d R r F U L u U l' f2 L2 u U L2 B' l L2 d U' r u l' D2

r2 L2 F b u2 b2 B2 U D' f' F' l2 U' l' F r' f2 B r R' U' D2 f2 L'

1588. TV Cubing
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 00:29:40 -0000

I remember quite a few years ago (maybe 3 or 4), I saw somebody doing
the cube on one of the Network morning shows, like "Today". It seems
like it was NBC, but I might be wrong. Anyone here know who it was?

My guess would be Dan Knights, cause he was the only well known really
fast cuber a few years ago, but I'm not sure.

He got about a 20-24 second solve if I remember.

1590. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cubing on the train
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 01:05:23 -0000

I'm not really as fast as all of you guys, but I am always around 1 minute for an average solve...The other day I was out golfing with my dad and his co-workers and after we had lunch and I pulled out my cube, which my mom once commented was like a soother cuz I never go anywheres without it, and then one guy was like, can you do it???Let me time you, and then he pulled out his watch and i went...and it was not the greatest solve of mine ever but it wasn't bad...and then when I was done he said it had taken me 3 minutes 21 seconds and I was like...no...that's not right...and he was like...yah...it is...and then he amazed me and solved it using a weird method, mainly intuitive... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > Or, "That guy just solved the cube in less than 3 minutes!!!". When you did > it in 17 seconds. 1:03.83, (1:21.79), 58.11, 1:03.48, (58.08) = 1:05.99 > > Fastest Time: 58.08 > Slowest Time: 1:25.83 > Standard Deviation: 07.79 > > Individual Times: > 1) 59.62 d l U B u' U' r2 D' d r2 L' b U D' R' 1595. Re: Cubing on the train
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 02:46:58 -0000

I was at Dorney Park solving my cube and a guy decided to "time" me. He looked at his cell phone and it said 5:15 when I started. It said 5:16 when I finished. His claim to his friends was "This guy can solve a cube in about a minute." The solve was probably closer to 1/3 of that. :( ~ Bob --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Chris Hunt <huntca@g...> wrote: > Or, "That guy just solved the cube in less than 3 minutes!!!". When you did > it in 17 seconds. What an insult :) > > -Chris > > On 9/1/05, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > > > > Probably similar to the "guy who can solve the cube in like... whoa... > > 3 seconds!!!" but just on the opposite end of the spectrum. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Sep 1, 2005, at 2:31 PM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > > > The guy said the solver took 12 minutes. This surprised me since most > > > of the BLD solvers here do it much faster than that. Perhaps it was > > > something he saw ages ago? Or perhaps the guy mis-remembered how long > > > it took? > > > > > > Jasmine > > > http://speedcuber.blogspot.com > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > > > wrote: > > >> Macky did it blindfolded 'behind his back' on the Discovery Channel. > > >> > > >> Tyson Mao > > >> MSC #631 > > >> California Institute of Technology > > >> > > >> On Sep 1, 2005, at 8:42 AM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > >> > > >>> European trains must be much quieter than the London Tube if the > > >>> noise > > >>> from a cube is disturbing people! The London Tube is very loud and > > >>> bumpy - no one would ever even hear me cubing on the Tube. > > >>> > > >>> I was just in the US very briefly (flew back into London earlier > > >>> today) and cubed on the train there too. One guy said he'd seen > > >>> someone on TV do it blindfolded and behind their back and asked if I > > >>> could do this. I said no, but that I knew people who could. I asked > > >>> who he'd seen on TV doing this because I assumed it was probably > > >>> someone from this group. He didn't remember the name though. > > >>> > > >>> Anyone done any blindfolded cubing on TV? > > >>> > > >>> Jasmine > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! But I'm quite sure he said so because the 4x4 was the first he saw me with so he immediately thought that's what he had, too, and when I pulled out the 3x3 it looked different but at that point he was already convinced the 4x4 was what he had so he sticked to that. Stefan

1600. RE: [Speed cubing group] Puzzle question (sokoban)
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>
To: "'speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com'" <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 2 Sep 2005 08:11:39 +0200

lvl 4 is already too difficult for me :) Nice game, though... -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens cmhardw Verzonden: donderdag 1 september 2005 20:22 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: [Speed cubing group] Puzzle question (sokoban) Hey everyone, I have a question about sokoban puzzles (where you push boxes around into designated spots). My girlfriend recently gave me the link to this page http://www.addictinggames.com/ledix <http://www.addictinggames.com/ledix> and of course I'm addicted to it :-) I'm almost done with it, there are 24 levels and I'm on #18. Anyway I had an idea, do they have team sokoban puzzles? Where you can control two characters to move the boxes around? It seems like you could make some really crazy puzzles like this. Like you could completely box in one guy to move boxes out of the way, then the boxed in guy would have to, at the right moment, start moving those 4 boxes around, stuff like that. Anyone know a simple way to make sokoban puzzles online? If no one has ever made pair sokoban puzzles then I'd love to try it and see if it works. Anyway, if there are any other sokoban fans, let me know if pair sokoban solving exists. I'm curious. Chris _____ YAHOO! Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com <http://speedcuber.blogspot.com> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Macky did it blindfolded 'behind his back' on the Discovery Channel. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Sep 1, 2005, at 8:42 AM, jasmine_ellen wrote: > > > European trains must be much quieter than the London Tube if the noise > > from a cube is disturbing people! Terms of Service <http://docs.yahoo.com/info/terms/> . _____ ================================================ De informatie opgenomen in dit bericht kan vertrouwelijk zijn en is uitsluitend bestemd voor de geadresseerde. Indien u dit bericht onterecht ontvangt, wordt u verzocht de inhoud niet te gebruiken en de afzender direct te informeren door het bericht te retourneren. ================================================ The information contained in this message may be confidential and is intended to be exclusively for the addressee. Should you receive this message unintentionally, please do not use the contents herein and notify the sender immediately by return e-mail. ================================================ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1604. Re: [Speed cubing group] 12.11 MINUTES???????
From: "Peter Douthwright" <pdouthwright0513@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 2 Sep 2005 05:28:51 -0400

Very funny. But I get people who are amazed I can do it in lees then a minute. When I tell them the world record is 12.11 SECONDS they are truly shocked.

1609. Rubik's Clock
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 12:32:50 -0000

I guess this a question more to Stefan than to anyone else, but if
anyone else can answer this then shoot...

My rubik's clock is plastic, not metal, and it is kinda sticky, as in
everything has to be lined up perfect for things to move, can I lube
my clock??? Or is this the way all clocks are??? I got it last night
and got a sub-40 average a minute ago...

Craig





1610. Re: Rubik's Clock
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 12:50:16 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > I guess this a question more to Stefan than to anyone else, but if > anyone else can answer this then shoot... Stefan describes disassembly here: http://www.stefan-pochmann.de/spocc/disassemble/rubiks_clock/ > My rubik's clock is plastic, not metal, and it is kinda sticky, as in > everything has to be lined up perfect for things to move, can I lube > my clock??? Apparently yes, but he doesn't give details. My own question is whether it can be done without getting silicone on the paper inserts. I hate the sight of silicone-soaked paper. ;) Mike
1611. Re: [Speed cubing group] 12.11 MINUTES???????
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 12:54:10 -0000

I met two girls at university who knew how to solve the cube in lika 2:30 minutes. I borrowed one of the girs cubes and solved it. Since it was not lubed I did it in like 1 minute, but they were amazed that I could solve it that fast. Then I told them that my record was below 20 seconds and they just stared at me. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@g...> wrote: > People watch me solve the 4x4x4 in like, 3-5 minutes (i am extremely > unconsistent), and they;re like,"OMG!! how did you solve it that fast!!!" i > just laugh. > > parth > > On 9/2/05, Peter Douthwright <pdouthwright0513@r...> wrote: > > > > Very funny.
