1612. Re: Rubik's Clock
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 13:24:04 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > > > My rubik's clock is plastic, not metal, and it is kinda sticky, as in > > everything has to be lined up perfect for things to move, can I lube > > my clock??? > > Apparently yes, but he doesn't give details. My own question is > whether it can be done without getting silicone on the paper inserts. > I hate the sight of silicone-soaked paper. ;) > > Mike Yeah, just disassemble it, then clean it, then lube a towel piece and polish all pieces (except the paper ;-) with it. Leave a "dry" film, i.e. very thin, if necessary polish a bit more with an unlubed piece. Btw, who has a metal clock? Cheers! Stefan
1613. WCA regulations, version 2005, final draft
From: "Ron" <ron@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 13:24:32 -0000

Fellow cubers,

Thanks for all the great feedback on the draft version of the WCA
regulations, version 2005!
We tried to use all your remarks and additions.

Please check out the final draft version at:
http://www.speedcubing.com/events/regulations_draft2005.html

On the bottom of the page you can find a list of changes (* means
latest changes).

You are all very welcome to send in your comments, additions and
other suggestions. For your feedback please use the WCA forum (
http://www.worldcubeassociation.org/forum ).
If you want to see text or regulations changed, then please post a
new text proposal.

We want to finalize this version on September 5, 2 months before WC
2005. So don't wait too long with your feedback.

Thanks,

Ron van Bruchem





1614. Re: WCA regulations, version 2005, final draft
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 13:37:48 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ron" <ron@s...> wrote: > > Please check out the final draft version at: > http://www.speedcubing.com/events/regulations_draft2005.html "While competing competitors may not use sound or other electronic equipment (like walkmans, dictaphones or additional lighting)." Then I'm happy I didn't buy that head light. Ok, so no electronics... But I'm still allowed to set my hair on fire, right? Cheers! Stefan

1621. Re: Guinness Records
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 15:30:34 -0000

Hi Tyson, You and/or Ron, in the role of representing WCA, need to take a professional stand on this: inform Guiness *formally* that they may no longer publish Rubik's cube records unless they adopt WCA standards and criteria. Do it politely but in an authoritative tone. Consider how the Olympic's governing body would write such a letter. Regards, David J I've been away for two weeks (and there have been 700 additional posts) and I've not read to the present time. Sorry if my suggestion is a repeat. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book of World Records > recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If you've seen the > Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve attempt, it's quite > interesting. They require two cubes new from the package and a lot of > other odd things. > > Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, they will have a > difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you can't claim a 12.5x > time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set on April 3, 2004. > However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee the slight issue. > Guinness will recognize this record as the world record, which would > undermine the authority of all of the other competitions taking place. > It will propagate the standard that only records achieved in a world > championship are valid. > > I'm most likely not going to be the one in contention to break 12.11 > seconds, but there are some of you out there that just might do it. In > the event that the single speed solve record is broken (and us speed > cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important as 14.52), my > suggestion is to not accept the Guinness recognition of holding the > world record. Accepting their recognition would undermine the > authority of all the tournament work that has happened in the last two > years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the WCA's records as the > world records, we really shouldn't help them out. > > And anyway, what's important? Having a record in the book which no one > of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or having a record that is > respected by the community? > > Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. Obviously, the most > likely candidate that would have to deal with something like this is > Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I really hope that this > e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, and I don't foresee a > heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of line, please let me know, > but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 seconds shows disrespect > for the work that I have done these last two years and undermine the > work that all competition organizers have put in and so I submit to you > not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology

1624. Re: Top cuber or not?
From: "zemalinou" <l_f_l_x@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 17:04:07 -0000

I'm quite astonished that someone ask this... Do you just want to be
recognize as one of the best cuber?
why such a question...I'm think you would probably love to hear "yeah
anssi you're one of the best!!!" but what is the interest?
I'm just amazed to see how some people could be pretentious, lets see
this question which clearly show that the author want to hear people
say he's one of the best...

Any interest in this question to my mind...

keep cubing

sebastien

1631. Re: lubing the strings of a magic
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 18:21:02 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > So I'm tired of breaking strings all of the time, and I'm wondering > how you guys do this exactly? > > Thanks in advance, > Chris I take them all out and hold them all as one ring with the metal parts on one place. Then I lube a towel piece and wipe along the strings, leaving out the metal parts. It also depends a lot on how you treat your Magic. Bob wrote he broke more than 60, I don't think I've broken more than 20 and not many in recent times. Ok, maybe he has practiced more. Also, I recently heard from Josef Jelinek (also very fast) that he only ever broke one string and another person was involved in that. So be nice to your Magic :-) Cheers! Stefan

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o.. .> wrote: > > That look uncomfortable... Nah, it's pretty ok. The helmet was uncomfortable. But this new construction is pretty lightweight. Cheers! Stefan

1637. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Guinness Records
From: Crispy <redivre@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 2 Sep 2005 11:41:32 -0700 (PDT)

Is Guinness (or any other publication) allowed to publish records without consent? Doesn't one have to give the OK to publish something like that or not? Do the participants in a competition sign something that gives the consent automatically to publish all writen and recorded events? Just a question? --- d_j_salvia <d_j_salvia@...> wrote: > Hi Tyson, > > You and/or Ron, in the role of representing WCA, > need to take a > professional stand on this: inform Guiness > *formally* that they may no > longer publish Rubik's cube records unless they > adopt WCA standards > and criteria. Do it politely but in an authoritative > tone. > > Consider how the Olympic's governing body would > write such a letter. > > Regards, > > David J > > I've been away for two weeks (and there have been > 700 additional > posts) and I've not read to the present time. Sorry > if my suggestion > is a repeat. > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson > Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > > > I was just thinking, right now, the Guinness Book > of World Records > > recognizes 16.53 seconds as the fastest solve. If > you've seen the > > Guinness Book's criteria for a Rubik's speed solve > attempt, it's quite > > interesting. They require two cubes new from the > package and a lot of > > other odd things. > > > > Anyway, if no one breaks 12.11 in Florida, well, > they will have a > > difficult time ignoring the WCA. After all, you > can't claim a 12.5x > > time is the world record when a 12.11 time was set > on April 3, 2004. > > However, if someone does break 12.11, I foresee > the slight issue. > > Guinness will recognize this record as the world > record, which would > > undermine the authority of all of the other > competitions taking place. > > It will propagate the standard that only records > achieved in a world > > championship are valid. > > > > I'm most likely not going to be the one in > contention to break 12.11 > > seconds, but there are some of you out there that > just might do it. In > > the event that the single speed solve record is > broken (and us speed > > cubers know that 12.11 isn't nearly as important > as 14.52), my > > suggestion is to not accept the Guinness > recognition of holding the > > world record. Accepting their recognition would > undermine the > > authority of all the tournament work that has > happened in the last two > > years. Until Guinness is ready to accept the > WCA's records as the > > world records, we really shouldn't help them out. > > > > And anyway, what's important? Having a record in > the book which no one > > of any authority or knowledge recognizes, or > having a record that is > > respected by the community? > > > > Anyway, these are just my initial impressions. > Obviously, the most > > likely candidate that would have to deal with > something like this is > > Macky, but 12.11 can be broken by anyone. I > really hope that this > > e-mail doesn't spark an outrage in the community, > and I don't foresee a > > heated debate and many flames. If I'm out of > line, please let me know, > > but I feel that Guinness' ignorance of 12.11 > seconds shows disrespect > > for the work that I have done these last two years > and undermine the > > work that all competition organizers have put in > and so I submit to you > > not to acknowledge the Guinness Book of Records. > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > "Hope you have the time of your life" - GD Christy (Crispy) ____________________________________________________ Start your day with Yahoo! - make it your home page http://www.yahoo.com/r/hs
1638. Hello
From: "Chris Sz..." <s2chris2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 19:51:03 -0000

Hi fellow cubers! It's been months since I've posted here or even read
the messages. It's amazing to see how much the community has grown and
how times have improved. The best average is now 13 seconds! and a
sub20 average would only place me 62 on the UWR list. I remember when
I was 36th(i think) with 20.96.
Anyway, I've barely solved a cube in the last few months but I'm
getting back into it now seeing that I only have 2 months of practice
left before the world championships. I took a couple averages. My
first was 27.xx and my second 23.xx so I'm getting back to my old
times but I still need to learn/relearn many algs and hopefully I will
be sub20 before the champs. Just thought I'd drop by and say hi. I'm
looking foward to finally meeting everyone in November.

--barefoot Chris




1639. Re: lubing the strings of a magic
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 02 Sep 2005 21:06:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > It also depends a lot on how you treat your Magic. Bob wrote he broke > more than 60, I don't think I've broken more than 20 and not many in > recent times. Ok, maybe he has practiced more. Also, I recently heard > from Josef Jelinek (also very fast) that he only ever broke one string > and another person was involved in that. So be nice to your Magic :-) That number has jumped up over 80, master magic strings included, I believe. Never broken any on my Magic Balls, though. :) I'm gentler with that puzzle, though. I think that I am actually abusive to my puzzle. The "angry magic" video Craig mentioned is only the end of that segment. I was just as violent for a few minutes prior to that clip, but grew increasingly violent when the puzzle was being mean to me back. ~ Bob

1645. Cube questions 2005
From: Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...>

Date: Fri, 2 Sep 2005 15:27:54 -0700 (PDT)


Hello cube pals and gals, long time no see. I was curious on a few things.
1) Jess Bonde's downloadable timer- anywhere to be found? hm...
2) How many people are we expecting for wc2005?
3) During wc2005, will there be free tickets for rides? Hah, just _curious_, that's all. 4) Oh, and is there a particular place that people will be staying at in Florida?

Hm..I see that someone changed my "major/interest" information on the database to a rather 'obscene' message... We are all friends aren't we?... Anyway, it's always nice to be rolling on the cube pages again :).
world peace,
_Brento_

1655. Re: Tiles vs. Stickers
From: "Chris Sz..." <s2chris2@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Sep 2005 04:20:28 -0000

I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you have an advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the color around a corner easier. (e.g. if you look at a side square on, you will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they have depth) Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? Please do share. --barefoot Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > Which would you guys say are better??? I was thinking about getting > tiles, but am not sure if I want them... > > Craig

From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Sep 2005 04:44:07 -0000

Take a look at http://www.cubesmith.com ; the one-stop shop for your sticker and tile needs. Scott --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Sz..." ><s2chris2@h...> wrote: > I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you have an > advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the color > around a corner easier. (e.g. if you look at a side square on, you > will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they have >depth) > Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? Please >do > share. > > --barefoot Chris
1657. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Sep 2005 03:18:15 -0400

The thing about tiles is that if your hands are sweaty they might be a little bit slippery... I haven't tried out the new grip ones from cubesmith, but with the old ones I make sure my hands are dry before cubing with them Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... 1658. Re: Tiles vs. Stickers
From: "Scott Mikos" <S-Mikos@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 03 Sep 2005 07:47:00 -0000

Yeah, I think it's really just a matter of personal preference. Myself, I like my cubesmith stickers and don't have any desire to change the feel of my cube. To barefoot Chris: As for durability, I've have had my stickers on my main speedcube for three months, and they show almost no signs of wear. Also, note that cubesmith tiles are very thin (.01") so the benefit of being able to see around corners would likely be minimal. Having said that, lots of people love the tiles. Scott --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko <bmytko@o...> wrote: > The thing about tiles is that if your hands are sweaty they might > be > a little bit slippery... > I haven't tried out the new grip ones from cubesmith, but with > the > old ones I make sure my hands are dry before cubing with them > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@b... > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 12:44 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: > > > Take a look at http://www.cubesmith.com ; the one-stop shop for >your > > sticker and tile needs. > > > > Scott > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Sz..." > s2chris2@h...> wrote: > I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you > have an > advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the color > around a corner easier. (e.g. if you look at a side square on, you > will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they have > depth) > Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? Please > do > share. > > --barefoot Chris

From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>

Everyone I know has had the same cubesmith stickers for months - me, I replace them almost every week. I don't know why, but I chip the hell out of them Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... 1660. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 3 Sep 2005 10:18:05 +0100

Back to an old question - are tiles acceptable for competition solves? In particular are they allowed in the WC? I don't see why they shouldnt be but I'm very wary of the rules. Someone said they had asked whether non-official stickers could be used but I never saw the answer to that one. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Bryan Mytko" <bmytko@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, September 03, 2005 8:45 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers > Everyone I know has had the same cubesmith stickers for months - me, > I replace them almost every week. I don't know why, but I chip the > hell out of them > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@... > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 3:47 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: > >> Yeah, I think it's really just a matter of personal preference. >> Myself, I like my cubesmith stickers and don't have any desire to >> change the feel of my cube. >> >> To barefoot Chris: As for durability, I've have had my stickers on >> my main speedcube for three months, and they show almost no signs of >> wear. Also, note that cubesmith tiles are very thin (.01") so the >> benefit of being able to see around corners would likely be >> minimal. Having said that, lots of people love the tiles. >> >> Scott >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko >> <bmytko@o...> wrote: >> > The thing about tiles is that if your hands are sweaty they might >> > be >> > a little bit slippery... >> > I haven't tried out the new grip ones from cubesmith, but with >> > the >> > old ones I make sure my hands are dry before cubing with them >> > >> > Bryan Mytko >> > bryanosaurus@b... >> > >> > >> > On Sep 3, 2005, at 12:44 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: >> > >> > > Take a look at http://www.cubesmith.com ; the one-stop shop for >> >your >> > > sticker and tile needs. >> > > >> > > Scott >> > > >> > > >> > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Sz..." >> > s2chris2@h...> wrote: >> > I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you >> > have an >> > advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the color >> > around a corner easier. (e.g. if you look at a side square on, you >> > will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they have >> > depth) >> > Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? Please >> > do >> > share. >> > >> > --barefoot Chris >> >> >> >> >> >> SPONSORED LINKS >> Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle >> Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games >> >> YAHOO! Having said that, lots of people love the tiles. > > > > Scott > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > The thing about tiles is that if your hands are sweaty they might > > > be > > > a little bit slippery... > > > I haven't tried out the new grip ones from cubesmith, but with > > > the > > > old ones I make sure my hands are dry before cubing with them > > > > > > Bryan Mytko > > > bryanosaurus@b... > > > > > > > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 12:44 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: > > > > > > > Take a look at http://www.cubesmith.com ; the one-stop shop for > > >your > > > > sticker and tile needs. > > > > > > > > Scott > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Sz..." > > > s2chris2@h...> wrote: > > > I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you > > > have an > > > advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the color > > > around a corner easier. 1664. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 3 Sep 2005 14:40:45 +0200

Hi Duncan, If you check the WCA regulations, you will find that there are regulations about the stickers, but none about the logos in the center or which trade mark. Competitions may have additional rules. For WC2005 the only additional rule is that the CUBES must be Rubik's. But the stickers don't need to be Rubik's. We are thinking about adding a sticker set to the WC2005 gift pack. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: Duncan Dicks To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Saturday, September 03, 2005 11:18 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers Back to an old question - are tiles acceptable for competition solves? In particular are they allowed in the WC? I don't see why they shouldnt be but I'm very wary of the rules. Someone said they had asked whether non-official stickers could be used but I never saw the answer to that one. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Bryan Mytko" <bmytko@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Saturday, September 03, 2005 8:45 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers > Everyone I know has had the same cubesmith stickers for months - me, > I replace them almost every week. I don't know why, but I chip the > hell out of them > > Bryan Mytko > bryanosaurus@... > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 3:47 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: > >> Yeah, I think it's really just a matter of personal preference. >> Myself, I like my cubesmith stickers and don't have any desire to >> change the feel of my cube. >> >> To barefoot Chris: As for durability, I've have had my stickers on >> my main speedcube for three months, and they show almost no signs of >> wear. Also, note that cubesmith tiles are very thin (.01") so the >> benefit of being able to see around corners would likely be >> minimal. Having said that, lots of people love the tiles. >> >> Scott >> >> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko >> <bmytko@o...> wrote: >> > The thing about tiles is that if your hands are sweaty they might >> > be >> > a little bit slippery... >> > I haven't tried out the new grip ones from cubesmith, but with >> > the >> > old ones I make sure my hands are dry before cubing with them >> > >> > Bryan Mytko >> > bryanosaurus@b... >> > >> > >> > On Sep 3, 2005, at 12:44 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: >> > >> > > Take a look at http://www.cubesmith.com ; the one-stop shop for >> >your >> > > sticker and tile needs. >> > > >> > > Scott >> > > >> > > >> > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Sz..." >> > s2chris2@h...> wrote: >> > I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you >> > have an >> > advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the color >> > around a corner easier. (e.g. if you look at a side square on, you >> > will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they have >> > depth) >> > Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? Please >> > do >> > share. >> > >> > --barefoot Chris >> >> >> >> >> >> SPONSORED LINKS >> Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle >> Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games >> >> YAHOO! (e.g. if you look at a side square on, > you > > > > will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they > have > > > > depth) > > > > Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? > Please > > > > do > > > > share. > > > > > > > > --barefoot Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games > Educational game and > puzzle > > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > > > > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > > > > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > > > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > > > > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of > Service. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to the Yahoo! Terms of Service. > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

I've never visited New Zealand, which is pretty slack since I was
living in Australia for 28 years! Surprisingly, I think most
Australians visit Europe before they visit their nearest neighbour!

Jasmine

The F2L slot to be filled is always > placed in the FR spot. Is that page up yet, by any chance? I'm really interested in practicing with my friend, but we are terrible at the F2L, and I see no reason to make up our own naming system, since you guys have already done it. 1685. Spoilers (full solution) (Re: Solving Sudoku)
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Sep 2005 07:53:20 -0000

Wow thanks a lot. Very thourgh explaination. #27 was the key for me, been stuck there for weeks. That type of logic seems to break a lot of solving programs or they'd have to resort to guessing. For the longest time I was convinced that it was not even possible to get pass this point without trial-and-error. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > To GameOfDeath2: > > > > Still did not solve it. Can you please post the solution with explanation. > > It is a really difficult one... > > > > R1-R9, C1-C9 will denote the rows and columns and B1-B9 the boxes (in the order > > 123 > 456 > 789 > ). > > I will not put in too many diagrams as it takes up a lot of space but here is the full solution > - at least the one I came up with. Probably there are several. The crucial bit here wasdtep > 27. I hadn't used anything like that before: > > basically if you get a pattern of possibilities > > ab ac > > ab bc > > as in this case (crucially, although they lie in 3 different columns they do lie in only 2 rows > and in only 2 boxes) then because the two on the right lie in the same box they can't both > be c. Thus the two on the left can't be a and b (a above b) so must be b and a (b above a). > That allows for 1 and 3 to be determined and without guessing because they follow this > logical pattern (above). Other than that the most difficult stages are probably 2 and 3 to > get a start. 2. isn't really so bad - it's just observing that the triple 4,7,8 can only appear in > 3 squares (so splitting C9 into 2 subsets) whence 7 can be placed straightaway (this step > can be done first but is less obvious than step 1.). > 3. is a bit technical too but I think 27. is the key stage. It relies on spotting a triple in 4 > squares that do not lie all in the same column, row or box. > NB You can also solve the same initial puzzle except with a 7 in the middle instead of a 4. > It is quite similar. > > 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a > 6). > 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and > R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must > contain 7. > Initial Grid: > > *2*|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > ***|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*1* > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 5**|**9|*** > ***|***|*4* > > For convenience label rows R1 to R9 (downwards), columns C1-C9 (left to right), boxes > B1-B9 (right then down). > > 1. The intersection of R1 and C3 contains 6 (it is the only square in B1 that can contain a > 6). > > 2. In C9, 4,7 and 8 cannot go into R3 or B9, leaving only the intersections with R1, R5 and > R6. In particular, R5 already contains 4 and 8 so the intersection of C9 and R5 must > contain 7. > > 3. In B5, 1 and 8 must appear on the leading diagonal as they are already present in C5 > and R5. Thus since 7 is in R5, 7 must occur in the intersection of B5 and C5. In particular > in C5, 4,7 and 8 appear before B8. Thus in R8 4,7,8 must occur in C2-C4 and hence 4 lies > in the intersection of C2 and R8. > > 4. Thus in B4, 4 goes in the intersection of R4 and C1. > > 5. Thus in C1, 7 must go in R9. > > 6. Recalling that in R8, C2-C4 contain 4,7 and 8, 8 must go in C3 (because B7 contains > 4,7) and so 7 in C4. > > *26|***|*** > ***|6**|**3 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 4**|**3|**2 > *8*|*4*|*17 > 6**|5**|*** > ------------------ > ***|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7**|***|*4* > > 7. In C1, neither 1 nor 8 can go in R5 or R7 (because they both appear elsewhere in R5 and > R7) so both must appear in B1 and further 3 doesn't appear in the intersection of R2 and > B1 so in B1 3 must be in C1. That leaves 5 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and R2 which > means that (recalling 7 is in the intersection of B5 and C5) the intersection of R2 and C5 > must be a 2. > > 8. Thus 2 must appear in the intersection of B5 and R5 (since 1,8 are on the leading > diagonal of that box) and 2 can't appear in the intersection of C1 and R5. Since the > intersection of C1 and B1 contains 1,3 and 8 it follows that 2 must appear in the > intersection of C1 and R7 and 9 in the intersection of C1 and R5. > > 9. In B4, 2 must appear in C3 but neither in R4 nor (because 2 appears in the intersection > of B5 and R5) in R5, so 2 must appear in the intersection of C3 and R6. > > 10. Therefore in B4, 7 appears in the intersection of R4 and C3. > > 11. So in B5, recalling 7 is in C5, 7 must occur in R6. > > 12. Now 9 already appearing in R5 and 1,8 being on the leading diagonal of B5, 9 must > appear in B5 at the intersection of R4 and C5. > > 13. Again, 6 being already in C4 and R6, 6 must be in B5 at the intersection of C6 and R5. > > 14. 2s being in B4 and B6, the only remaining place in R5 for a 2 is the intersection with > B5, i.e. in C4. > > 15. In B4, 1 must fall in C2, hence 1 must fall in C3 in B7, but not in R7 as we already have > a 1 in R7. So 1 must fall in R9 and C3 in B9. > > 16. Moreover, in B8, 2 must lie in C6 but not in R7 (hence in R9). > > 17. Again in B8, 8 can't appear in R7 or C5 so it must be in the intersection of C4 and R9. > > 18. Thus in B5 we have that 1 lies in R4 and 8 lies in R6. > > 19. Now in B4, 1 lies in R6, 5 lies in R4, leaving 3 in R5. > > 20. In R4 8 can't lie in C8 and so must lie in C7, leaving 6 in C8 to complete R4. Also 5 > completes R5. > > 21. Way back in 2, we figured that in C9, 4, 7 and 8 could lie only in R1, R5 and R6. From > B6, we conclude that 4 must lie in the intersection of C9 and R6 and so 8 in the > intersection of C9 and R1. > > 22. Now in B1, 8 must lie in R2 and C1. > > 23. From 7., in B1 5 and 9 are in R2. Since also 5 is in C2 and B4, 5 must lie in the > intersection of B1 and C3 and 9 in the intersection of B1 and C2. > > 24. In C3, 9 must go in R7 (as that is all that remains in C3). > > 25. In R2 only 1,4 and 7 remain but in C8 both 1 and 4 are placed, so 7 lies in the > intersection of R2 and C8. > > 26. Hence the final 7 must go in B2 in the intersection of R1 and C6. > > *26|**7|**8 > 895|62*|*73 > *74|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 457|193|862 > 983|246|517 > 612|578|**4 > ------------------ > 2*9|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7*1|8*2|*4* > > 27. The intersection of C5 and R1 is either 3 or 5. Similarly the intersection of C6 and R3 > is either 1 or 5. Also in B1 the remaining numbers are 1 and 3. Since 5 cannot occupy two > places in B2 either the intersection of C5 and R1 is 3 or the intersection of C6 and R3 is 1. > In the first case 3 can't go into the intersection of R1 with B1 (so 1 goes there and 3 in the > remaining space of B1) and in the second 1 can't go in the intersection of R3 with B1 (so 3 > goes there and 1 in the remaining space of B1). Either way 1 goes in the intersection of R1 > with B1 and 3 in the intersection of R3 with B1. > > 126|**7|**8 > 895|62*|*73 > 374|*8*|*** > ------------------ > 457|193|862 > 983|246|517 > 612|578|**4 > ------------------ > 2*9|*1*|78* > 548|7*9|*** > 7*1|8*2|*4* > > 28. In C4, only 3, 4 and 9 remain to be filled but R3 already contains 3 and 4, so the > intersection of C4 with R3 contains 9. > > 29. Thus 9 is not in the intersection of R3 and C9, so it is in the intersection of C9 and B9 > but it isn't in R7 or R8 so it is at the intersection of C9 and R9. > > 30. This implies that in R9 5 lies in C5. > > 31. Thus in B9, 5 must occur in R7 and hence also in C9 and also in B8 6 must lie in C5 > and so in R8. > > 32. So in R7, 6 must lie in C2, then in C2, 3 must lie in R9 and in R9 6 must lie in C7 and 3 > is the only remaining number to be filled in C5. > > 33. In B8, 3 must lie in C4 leaving 4 in C6. > > 34. 4 is the only thing left to go in C4, so in R2 4 must go in C7 leaving 1 in C6 to > complete R2 and thus 5 in R3 to complete B2. > > 35. In R1 5 must go in C8 and hence 9 in C7 to complete. Thus in R6 9 must go in C8 and > so 3 in C7 to complete. > > 36. In C8, 3 must go in R8 leaving 2 in R3 to complete. Thus in C7 2 must go in R8 leaving > 1 in R3 to complete. Thus in C9 1 must go in R3 leaving 2 in C8 to complete the puzzle. > > > 126|437|958 > 895|621|473 > 374|985|231 > ------------------ > 457|193|862 > 983|246|517 > 612|578|394 > ------------------ > 269|314|785 > 548|769|123 > 731|852|649

1687. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers
From: Parth Upadhyay <parth.upadhyay@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 4 Sep 2005 07:39:14 -0500

Tiles are better stickers if you ask me, but when they start losing their adhesiveness, the corners of them come up and when you're cubing it can dig under your nail and hurt.life a mofo. (believe me, its happened 2wice) But they stay on way longer, and look cool too, parth ---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...> Date: Sep 3, 2005 11:04 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Tiles vs. Stickers To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Yeah that was mine. I don't know I'm brutal when I cube and think I grind my nails on them a lot. It's definitely my fault, not yours : ) I love your stickers - and they don't chip for any of my friends. Bryan Mytko bryanosaurus@... On Sep 3, 2005, at 6:22 AM, jello33 wrote: > Where are they chipping? Was that your cube I saw a picture of with > the mini stackmat pad? It had my logo sticker in the middle but all > the stickers around it were chipped up from the center cubie out. > > I'd be interested to find out why they're chipping. > > Chris > www.cubesmith.com <http://www.cubesmith.com> > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > Everyone I know has had the same cubesmith stickers for months - > me, > > I replace them almost every week. I don't know why, but I chip > the > > hell out of them > > > > Bryan Mytko > > bryanosaurus@b... > > > > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 3:47 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: > > > > > Yeah, I think it's really just a matter of personal preference. > > > Myself, I like my cubesmith stickers and don't have any desire to > > > change the feel of my cube. > > > > > > To barefoot Chris: As for durability, I've have had my stickers > on > > > my main speedcube for three months, and they show almost no > signs of > > > wear. Also, note that cubesmith tiles are very thin (.01") so > the > > > benefit of being able to see around corners would likely be > > > minimal. Having said that, lots of people love the tiles. > > > > > > Scott > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Bryan Mytko > > > <bmytko@o...> wrote: > > > > The thing about tiles is that if your hands are sweaty they > might > > > > be > > > > a little bit slippery... > > > > I haven't tried out the new grip ones from cubesmith, but with > > > > the > > > > old ones I make sure my hands are dry before cubing with them > > > > > > > > Bryan Mytko > > > > bryanosaurus@b... > > > > > > > > > > > > On Sep 3, 2005, at 12:44 AM, Scott Mikos wrote: > > > > > > > > > Take a look at http://www.cubesmith.com ; the one-stop shop > for > > > >your > > > > > sticker and tile needs. > > > > > > > > > > Scott > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Chris Sz..." > > > > s2chris2@h...> wrote: > > > > I would definately say tiles - they never wear out and you > > > > have an > > > > advantage over stickers because tiles allow you to see the > color > > > > around a corner easier. (e.g. if you look at a side square on, > you > > > > will be able to see the 9 tiles around the edges since they > have > > > > depth) > > > > Is there some place to get tiles that I don't know about??? > Please > > > > do > > > > share. > > > > > > > > --barefoot Chris > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > > > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games > Educational game and > puzzle > > > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > > > YAHOO! 1688. Re: [Speed cubing group] Cube sighting.
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Sep 2005 12:41:47 -0000

Paul Nixon (a cuber, but not so active on this group) sent me this site the other day because I love cats. Neither of us had seen this particular pic though. I LOVE it! Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Cute... but PLEASE no comments on that 5x5x5. 1689. Re: [Speed cubing group] Team Blindfold
From: "Ian" <iwinoky@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Sep 2005 15:25:03 -0000

Some of the codes are outdated. Here are the letters that have changed: E,F,S,V,W (the Vs and Ws have become splits) I'd suggest learning the codes that haven't changed and waiting on Chris to update the others. Thanks for adopting our codes! Ian --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeremy Fleischman" <jeremyfleischman@s...> wrote: > Wait, one more thing. Is it possible that the F2L codes are outdated > or something? I remember that one of the codes was "Split 1 2" which > is not in the list on Chris Hardwick's website. Why would that be? > > Thanks for the help, > Jeremy Fleischman > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> wrote: > > http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/teambld.html > > > > http://s92413871.onlinehome.us/bdteam/ > > > > If I am wrong, correct me. > > > > This is mostly up to date, but not fully. > > > > _ Bob > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" > <bob@c...> > > wrote: > > > :) > > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Jeremy > Fleischman" > > > <jeremyfleischman@s...> wrote: > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ian" > <iwinoky@y...> > > > > wrote: > > > > > Chris Hardwick is almost done updating a page with our F2L > codes. > > > > > Here are the first few codes. The F2L slot to be filled is > always > > > > > placed in the FR spot. > > > > > > > > Is that page up yet, by any chance? I'm really interested in > > > > practicing with my friend, but we are terrible at the F2L, and > I see > > > > no reason to make up our own naming system, since you guys > have > > > > already done it. Who knows, maybe we'll get a chance to > practice > > > > together sometime! > > > > But I'll have to learn all the OLL algorithms first, > urrghhhhh.... > > > > > > > > Jeremy Fleischman

1691. Cubing on roller coaster
From: "lkyawkyaw" <lkyawkyaw@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 04 Sep 2005 22:43:46 -0000

I went to sixflags on saturday and realized i had my keychain 3x3x3
with me. I therefore decided to solve it while on one of the rides.

Did it in about 1min 13sec. boy! was i disoriented after the ride. i
could have solve it faster if it wasnt for the g forces i felt on the
ride, my fingers just failed to turn LOL!

1696. An observation...
From: jasmine_ellen <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 17:11:33 -0000

I was noticing that the proliferation of posts to the group this weekend has not been as overwhelming as usual. Someone suggested to me that it might be because it's a long weekend in the US (Labor Day weekend?). If this is true then it means that <shock! amazement!> *sometimes* cubers might actually get out of the house and do other things! Surely not! :o Although, I guess that just because cubers aren't sitting in front of their computers doesn't mean they aren't cubing... Jasmine http://speedcuber.blogspot.com
1697. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 5 Sep 2005 19:48:56 +0200

Hi there,


I wanted to share my thoughts about the effect of public
cubing.

I'm "seriously" into speedcubing since late april (did
BLD before). I'm usially averaging between 27 and 31 now,
my personal best AVG10 being around 27.5.

I'm mostly cubing in the metro, in Paris. This is the place
where I make my best times. I'm 100% sure I am sub23 in
the metro, where usually 2-3 people are glaring at the
cube. I don't need to time myself : I KNOW that my F2L is
way faster in the metro. Is that the effect of public
cubing ?

OK, then I'll talk about my times, in different contexts,
in a decreasing order of efficiency.

1. REHEARSAL : I execute the same scrambling over and over.
In that case, my times are between 17 and 20, depending
on the OLL/PLL case mostly. It means that I lose about
10 secs on recognition. This is my "dexterity time".

2. METRO : I would say between 22 and 25 secs

3. BUS : between 27 and 31

4. TIMING MYSELF W/ NETCUBE : between 27 and 31

5. TAKING VIDEOS : between 23 and 40 (!!!)

6. IN FRONT OF FRIENDS : between 28 and 38 (!!)

There's something weird about the difference between "METRO"
and "FRIENDS". I came up with this explanation : the parisian
METRO is one of the MOST unpersonal place I know. People are
never communicating. This is a DEAD place. So maybe, the only
thing my brain can do is : "focus on the cube, and do nothing
else". And it seems to work.

The Bus is more convivial. You know that somebody may ask you
questions about cubing. It happens often actually. It seems
to disturb my concentration.

Then "taking vids" or "timing" : I'm JUDGING MYSELF, so, I'm
not 100% focused. Not to talk about friends... then if I run
into a difficult case, it can become terrible.

My (not so original) conclusion about this is : find a way
to focus 100% on your cube, and forget about the environment.
For some, it may help to train in their worst "conditions"
(i.e. : in public).
For others, it may help to change the conditions of
performing, just in order to see how one can keep 100% of
the concentrations on the moves and the anticipations.

My best performances are in front of the DEAD public of the
metro ;).

I've never attended a competition so far. It might be my
worst case scenario. See you in the next french open I hope...
--
FD.






1698. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 13:54:18 -0400

What would happen if you took a video of you solving in the metro?


Bryan Mytko
bryanosaurus@...

1699. Extreme Cubing
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 18:42:16 -0000

Has anyone timed themselves solving the cube after drinking a case of
beer? How much does it affect your time?





1700. Re: [Speed cubing group] Extreme Cubing
From: Bryan Mytko <bmytko@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 14:47:17 -0400

I tend to cube faster when I'm wasted - I think because it slows my
reaction time and forces me to slow down on F2L.
There's records for cubing while drunk on speedcubing.com


Bryan Mytko

1702. Re: [Speed cubing group] Extreme Cubing
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Sep 2005 20:53:10 +0200

I solved a cube after a bottle of Sangria (1.5 litres). Actually, I
did one very good time at that time (around 40 seconds).

But I definitely not recommend this.

I assume you will be kicked out of a tournament if you want to compete drunk...


1703. Re: [Speed cubing group] Extreme Cubing
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Sep 2005 11:56:28 -0700

I think I'd probably let a drunk competitor do a solve just so I could
get it on video. It goes without saying, of course, that already,
though it's not recommended, it's definitely not encouraged if you're
under the age of 21.

Now... with that said, trying to blindfold 5 cubes consecutively is
MUCH easier if you haven't had anything.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1704. CLL algorithm
From: Anthony Hsu <erwaman@...>
To: Speedsolving Group <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 15:43:56 -0400

Hi, I am currently learning the CLL algorithms from Masayuki Akimoto's website, and the algorithm on the right on this page doesn't seem to work for me: http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm
Could somebody please help me out? Thank you.

Anthony


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]



1705. Re: Extreme Cubing
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 20:13:12 -0000

One night after drinking quite a lot if beer I timed some solves and none were sub-30. My average record at that time was sub-20. Recognition is hard if your drunk. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, turtleparadise <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Has anyone timed themselves solving the cube after drinking a case of > beer? How much does it affect your time?
1706. Re: CLL algorithm
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 20:14:46 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Anthony Hsu <erwaman@m...> wrote: > Hi, I am currently learning the CLL algorithms from Masayuki Akimoto's website, and the algorithm on the right on this page doesn't seem to work for me: http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm > Could somebody please help me out? Thank you. R2 D L' B L D' R2 U' F' U' F seems to do it. A lot of errors for one algorithm... Mike
1707. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: CLL algorithm
From: Anthony Hsu <erwaman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 16:29:56 -0400

Thanks again! I just got the chance to use the correct algorithm on my very next 2x2x2 solve. Anthony ----- Original Message ----- From: mike_go_uk To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Monday, September 05, 2005 4:14 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: CLL algorithm --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Anthony Hsu <erwaman@m...> wrote: > Hi, I am currently learning the CLL algorithms from Masayuki Akimoto's website, and the algorithm on the right on this page doesn't seem to work for me: http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm > Could somebody please help me out? Thank you. R2 D L' B L D' R2 U' F' U' F seems to do it. A lot of errors for one algorithm... Mike [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1709. Re: CLL algorithm
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 05 Sep 2005 22:12:08 -0000

yes that is the corrected version both me and Akimoto have been using this alg for several years, though I am faster with the inverse (both are needed in a more advanced CLL/ELL system) The reason why it appears wrong is probably because we both (I think, correct me if I'm wrong) execute it with LL on D, and so typing it out he must have accidently mirrored some of the turns instead of rotating them x2. It's done faster when LL is on D I think. I do it this way: FD'F'D'R2'U'LBL'UR2' Definately not one of my fastest CLL cases, but this is how I've been doing it: F (with right index downward) 4 quick progessions D' (with right thumb and middle finger) F' (with right thumb) D' (with right middle finger) R2' (sweep with many fingers on right hand) U' (right thumb) (rDr'U) (a quick trigger) R2' (sweep with many fingers on right hand) Thought I do it entirely as rapid progression of my right fingers, some might use their left index for U' turns, and I think I might have at some point changed to that and then reverted back (due to lack of practice). [I say rapid progression of turns because it's not something I would catergorize as a triggerable alg.] Hope that sheds some light on the mysterious land of CLL. -Doug (finally caught up on all the posts in the last month) --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Anthony Hsu > <erwaman@m...> wrote: > > Hi, I am currently learning the CLL algorithms from Masayuki > Akimoto's website, and the algorithm on the right on this page doesn't > seem to work for me: http://rokumentai.akimoto3.com/GRSM-e3.htm > > Could somebody please help me out? Thank you. > > R2 D L' B L D' R2 U' F' U' F > > seems to do it. A lot of errors for one algorithm... > > Mike
1710. how can you be nice to the magic and still go fast?
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 00:30:15 -0000

I swear my hands have a mind of their own. I've been trying to solve
my magic a bit slower and more carefully to avoid breaking strings so
much, and lo and behold today I broke two strings at the SAME time! ;-)

My hands just aren't that coordinated or something lol :-)

Chris




1711. First sub-30 average!
From: "Chris Parlette" <mdcube@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 02:01:18 -0000

Hey guys,

So I got my first ever sub-30 average last night before going to
sleep. It was amazing! I was looking ahead so much better than I
normally do, and I'm not sure if it was because I was more tired than
usual or not.

I first solved a cube without any moves in front of me in May of 2002
(I have the exact date written somewhere), so this sub-30 average has
taken me over 3 years to accomplish. Hopefully I'll get some free
time in the next few months to work on cubing, so my quest to sub-20
doesn't take as long as this did!

Just thought I'd share :)

-Chris Parlette




1712. Re: [Speed cubing group] First sub-30 average!
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 6 Sep 2005 08:36:07 +0530

Congrats man. But watch ur back, im catching up fast :) My latest avg is 43.49 Sachin. On 9/6/05, Chris Parlette <mdcube@...> wrote: > Hey guys, > > So I got my first ever sub-30 average last night before going to > sleep. It was amazing! I was looking ahead so much better than I > normally do, and I'm not sure if it was because I was more tired than > usual or not. > > I first solved a cube without any moves in front of me in May of 2002 > (I have the exact date written somewhere), so this sub-30 average has > taken me over 3 years to accomplish. Hopefully I'll get some free > time in the next few months to work on cubing, so my quest to sub-20 > doesn't take as long as this did! > > Just thought I'd share :) > > -Chris Parlette > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1713. Understanding Algorithms
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>

Date: Tue, 6 Sep 2005 01:16:11 -0300

Hey all,

What is meant by not only memorizing algorithms (such as Fridrich's 41 OLL algs) but instead 'Understanding' how they work? I've seen this a few times in posts. Not quite sure if I understand the true definition.


Thanks Dwayne

1715. Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 05:10:30 -0000

I think most cubers don't understand the algorithms they use but just memorize them and execute them accordingly. But if you spend enough time thinking about an algorithm, then one may gain insite into how they actaully work, why they do what they do. Most algs we use are quite complicated and can't be disected into small parts that are understandable. Here is an example of one of the simplest PLL that I'm sure most ppl understand. The so-called "Allan" maneuver (old slice/non-2-gen version of the 3-edge cycle): R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 It can be understood as the sequence S' U2 S U2 conjugated with R2 U (or "conjugated by" in some literature). And it becomes the final alg with some cancellations. By conjugation I mean: if A=(R2 U) and B=(S' U2 S U2) then the final alg is A * B * A^(-1) after a bit of cancellation. Now the B in this case is easy enough to understand. B here is in fact in itself a commutator, and as we know from Group Theory, commutators tend to fix many indicies in subgroups of (finite) symmetric groups. A commutator is something of the form x*y*x^(-1)*y^(-1). It is easy to see why this reduces to the identity in commutative algebras (Abelian groups) and "does nothing". In "not-so-commutative groups" it is something that tends to be "close" to "doing nothing". A bit of trivia that even we as cubers typically don't know: Although there are 12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 possible positionsm, it is really 901083404981813616 after modding out by rotational isomorphisms. (can be shown by the Plya-Burnside lemma) The group is the semi-direct product of the orientation aspect of the cube and the permutation aspect. The orientations are isomorphic to the commutative group (Z_2)^11 "cross" (Z_3)^7. The permutation group is isomorphic to (A_8 cross A_12) semi-direct product with Z_2. (I have this memorized since I'm a math major and get asked this question A LOT.) To learn more about these more abstract idiosyncrasies of the cube check out http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/groups.htm . -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@n...> wrote: > Hey all, > > What is meant by not only memorizing algorithms (such as Fridrich's 41 OLL algs) but instead 'Understanding' how they work? I've seen this a few times in posts. Not quite sure if I understand the true definition. > > > Thanks Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1716. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 5 Sep 2005 22:13:04 -0700

There are two ways of thinking about it. I for one learned the Fridrich method very early into my cubing careerabout 6 weeks after I first learned how to solve the cube. I didn't think the look at what the F2L algorithms did and so I executed the algorithms blindly. I knew if there was a case and I did a certain algorithm, I would get the result I wanted. Blind execution is the key for fast times. Understanding how the algorithms work can enhance what you can do to the cube, but being able to react to cases on a cube is necessary for very fast times. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Sep 5, 2005, at 10:08 PM, d_funny007 wrote: > I think most cubers don't understand the algorithms they use but just > memorize them and execute them accordingly. > > But if you spend enough time thinking about an algorithm, then one may > gain insite into how they actaully work, why they do what they do. > > Most algs we use are quite complicated and can't be disected into > small parts that are understandable. > > Here is an example of one of the simplest PLL that I'm sure most ppl > understand. The so-called "Allan" maneuver (old slice/non-2-gen > version of the 3-edge cycle): > > R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 > > It can be understood as the sequence S' U2 S U2 conjugated with R2 U > (or "conjugated with" in some literature). And it becomes the final > alg with some cancellations. > > By conjugation I mean: if A=(R2 U) and B=(S' U2 S U2) then the final > alg is A * B * A^(-1) after a bit of cancellation. > > Now the B in this case is easy enough to understand. B here is in fact > in itself a commutator, and as we know from Group Theory, commutators > tend to fix many indicies in subgroups of (finite) symmetric groups. > > A commutator is something of the form x*y*x^(-1)*y^(-1). It is easy to > see why this reduces to the identity in commutative algebras (Abelian > groups) and "does nothing". In "not-so-commutative groups" it is > something that tends to be "close" to "doing nothing". > > A bit of trivia that even we as cubers typically don't know: > > Although there are 12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 possible positionsm, it is really > 901083404981813616 after modding out by rotational isomorphisms. (can > be shown by the Plya-Burnside lemma) > > The group is the semi-direct product of the orientation aspect of the > cube and the permutation aspect. The orientations are isomorphic to > the commutative group (Z_2)^11 "cross" (Z_3)^7. The permutation group > is isomorphic to (A_8 cross A_12) semi-direct product with Z_2. > (I have this memorized since I'm a math major and get asked this > question A LOT.) > > To learn more about these more abstract idiosyncrasies of the cube > check out http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/groups.htm . > > > -Doug > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > <ddollard@n...> wrote: >> Hey all, >> >> What is meant by not only memorizing algorithms (such as > Fridrich's 41 OLL algs) but instead 'Understanding' how they work? > I've seen this a few times in posts. 1717. [Speed cubing group] Re: Public cubing
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 06:43:00 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "FD-Rubik" <fdrubik@f...> wrote: > I'm mostly cubing in the metro, in Paris. This is the place > where I make my best times. I was in Paris a few weeks ago, too. My girlfriend and I both cubed on the metro several times. However, neither of us did very well. Besides the fact that we were worried about missing our stops, there was the element of the noise, the bumpy ride, and the glaring. These added up to some pretty terrible solves. The glaring bothered me the most. I cube in public everywhere in America, and it doesn't bother me nearly as much. Paris just frightened me, apparently. I still solve best when cubing in my room or with people I am very comfortable with. My average at the Chicago tournament was about 15 seconds slower than my average average at the time. I blame lack of sleep and nerves, but I'm fairly certain it was just nerves. Oh well. I suppose I'll see in November... -Mike Bennett

know what was the prinspection time for the Clock.

15 seconds.

I'm done. :-)

1721. [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 08:40:19 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Blind execution is the key for fast times. Understanding how the > algorithms work can enhance what you can do to the cube, but being able > to react to cases on a cube is necessary for very fast times. Too true. I devised a high proportion of the sequences I use... I slow right down in a number of cases where the method of construction is still obvious to me -- conjugates where there was little or no cancellation of turns, and where there are several cases that differ only in the short "conjugating" sequence. Hard to know what to do about it, apart from finding alternative -- preferably "incomprehensible" ;) -- sequences. Mike

1723. Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 09:02:40 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > A bit of trivia that even we as cubers typically don't know: > > Although there are 12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 possible positionsm, it is > really > 901083404981813616 after modding out by rotational isomorphisms. (can > be shown by the Plya-Burnside lemma) If in addition you regard a position as being equivalent to its inverse (give or take a rotation or reflection), the number is reduced to 450541810590509978, which can also be obtained using Burside's lemma. The details are at http://cubezzz.homelinux.org/drupal/?q=node/view/22 Mike
1724. [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 09:03:24 -0000

If one memorizes the algorithms well enough, they would know it well enough to execute it one-handed. I know that for me, after spending so much time on algs... forgetting an alg and having to re-learn it repeatedly over the years, I can easily call out an alg letter-by-letter without touching the cube if I see a certain case for about 1/2 of my algs. I remember Ron was saying how he know's his algs so well that he doesn't get "one-handed amnesia" (as ChrisH calles it) as much as most of us do. So I don't think understanding algs would help with one-handed times either unfortunately. It's all down to practicing the same alg over and over one-handed until you can do most of your algs one-handed (nearly) as fluidly as with two hands. I just wanted to explain for people that haven't heard about how back in the old days before we could so readily plug cases into something like ACube, how cubist used to discover new algs for their systems. The use of commutators was something that JessicaF fondly remembers I'm sure (I think that's where I first read about it from). In fact I am currently up at 4:44am "understanding" various ZBF2L algs I have been learning. (After lying awake in bed for an hr... and realizing that today is going to be the first day of classes here.) Now, I believe that understanding algs is unavoidable as a cuber continues to learn new algs. This past few months I have begun to gain significant insight into the algs I use more so than ever before. It defiantely doesn't help my times of course; actually, it might have even hurt them, lol. After a certain point algs just "make sense". I'm talking about when a person learns hundreds of algs; probably around 2-3 times as many algs as in the basic Fridrich system (and now thanks the great devotion of cubers nowadays, messily even). Unless one has some super-human (long-term) memory going on, I don't see how to maintain all that information without realizing/understanding what's really going on amongst the algs... how they inter-relate to each other. I look at a new ZBLL and execute it a few times and think to myself how it's the first part of alg A (some irreducible alg I know) combined with the last part of alg B (another simple alg I already know). And this is how I remember it... and learning new algs just builds on top of older algs. For a lot of the simple algs I know, I understand how they work and so it is reasonable how combining one alg with another would behave. And after a while the pace of absorbing more algs becomes faster. A lot of us are very amazing and impressed with how many algs some of the cubers have learned I'm sure. But consider this. Isn't it now many times easier for them to learn one new alg in a given amount of time than for a cuber that only knows say the algs of the basic Fridrich system alone? Learning *and understanding* new algs is so fun! Right now I'm drawing a bunch of arrows on my ZBF2L diagram depicting how one cae reduces down to another after only a few turns (typically 3). (Imagine the sq-1 shapes diagram on Jaap's site, lol.) -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > Sadly I think I agree with this - with the proviso that I think it really > helps to solve one-handed if you understand the algorithms better. > > Duncan > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Tyson Mao" <tmao@i...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Tuesday, September 06, 2005 6:13 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding Algorithms > > > There are two ways of thinking about it. 1725. [Speed cubing group] Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 09:11:24 -0000

I'm pretty sure he does 2 at a time through out all solves... unless of course there is some special cases he encounters. He has tried doing it many ways and find this to be best for his style. I'm sure it would be differenet for differnt people, but it never hurts to learn new methodology even if you don't end up using it. (Well, remember a WC is comming up though... so scratch the word never, lol.) Personally I do 6-4-2 a lot or even better get 5 in some way first and then the last 7 at once. Somestimes I get lucky and do 7 at once first. I know how to take care of many of the special cases that force some cubers to be "stuck", so for me it's pretty safe. Where I lack is finding pieces, and that really slows down my times. But until my recognition gets to a certain point where doing 2 at a time is faster than the 6-4-2 or 6-3-3 I am used to, I see no reason to stop. Besides doing a 6 if FUN! Then again I'm sick and preverse.... I slow down to use ZB stuff on my big cubes solves. I fell like it takes me so much longer to make a turn on the larger cubes that it is worth saving turns this way. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > Chris (Hardwick): > > Contratulations to your insane times on 4*4*4. 1726. Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 09:25:05 -0000

Whow... excellent read, I recommend it to all the math inclined out there. Combinatorics on the Cube! I assume you wrote it right? I'm only half-way through it, I'll have to finish it tommorow though. Curious though, was this research for any academic purpose, it sounds like the writer is a fellow math person. Just goes to show you, there's a lot of undiscovered math beind the cube still (that article was submitted mid-June of this year). Hopefully enough uncharted territory in the cube for a thesis topic in the future :). Eh... and if not, there's always the tried and true functional analysis... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > A bit of trivia that even we as cubers typically don't know: > > > > Although there are 12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 possible positionsm, it is > > really > > 901083404981813616 after modding out by rotational isomorphisms. 1727. Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 09:43:18 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I assume you wrote it right? It was a joint effort with Herbert Kociemba. > Curious though, was this research for any academic purpose, it > sounds like the writer is a fellow math person. I'm a solid-state physicist, so the only connection with "real" work was noticing that the concept of "magnetic symmetry" of crystals could also be applied to the Cube. Glad you find it interesting. :) Mike
1728. Re: Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 6 Sep 2005 08:48:31 -0300

Hey all, No Idea what you're talking about, but thanks for taking the time to explain it. Guess I'll just be like most cubers who only memorizes and execute the algorithms Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 05:08:28 -0000 From: d_funny007 Subject: Re: Understanding Algorithms I think most cubers don't understand the algorithms they use but just memorize them and execute them accordingly. But if you spend enough time thinking about an algorithm, then one may gain insite into how they actaully work, why they do what they do. Most algs we use are quite complicated and can't be disected into small parts that are understandable. Here is an example of one of the simplest PLL that I'm sure most ppl understand. The so-called "Allan" maneuver (old slice/non-2-gen version of the 3-edge cycle): R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 It can be understood as the sequence S' U2 S U2 conjugated with R2 U (or "conjugated with" in some literature). And it becomes the final alg with some cancellations. By conjugation I mean: if A=(R2 U) and B=(S' U2 S U2) then the final alg is A * B * A^(-1) after a bit of cancellation. Now the B in this case is easy enough to understand. B here is in fact in itself a commutator, and as we know from Group Theory, commutators tend to fix many indicies in subgroups of (finite) symmetric groups. A commutator is something of the form x*y*x^(-1)*y^(-1). It is easy to see why this reduces to the identity in commutative algebras (Abelian groups) and "does nothing". In "not-so-commutative groups" it is something that tends to be "close" to "doing nothing". A bit of trivia that even we as cubers typically don't know: Although there are 12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 possible positionsm, it is really 901083404981813616 after modding out by rotational isomorphisms. (can be shown by the Plya-Burnside lemma) The group is the semi-direct product of the orientation aspect of the cube and the permutation aspect. The orientations are isomorphic to the commutative group (Z_2)^11 "cross" (Z_3)^7. The permutation group is isomorphic to (A_8 cross A_12) semi-direct product with Z_2. (I have this memorized since I'm a math major and get asked this question A LOT.) To learn more about these more abstract idiosyncrasies of the cube check out http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/groups.htm . -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@n...> wrote: > Hey all, > > What is meant by not only memorizing algorithms (such as Fridrich's 41 OLL algs) but instead 'Understanding' how they work? I've seen this a few times in posts. Not quite sure if I understand the true definition. > > > Thanks Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] ________________________________________________________________________ ________________________________________________________________________ [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
1729. Re: Understanding Algorithms
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 12:56:41 -0000

Some algorithms are pretty basic and can be broken down into small simple steps. Understanding simple algs can help you learn them better and also helps you learn more of them. If you notice why some algs work, you can come up with more of them for similar cases. For example, a lot of OLL algs involve taking out a pair, flipping stuff, and putting the pair back differently in the same spot. Some of them hide a bunch of pieces, flip stuff, and then put the pieces back. I think this is what is meant by "understanding" algorithms. At least, it is how I interpret it. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@n...> wrote: > Hey all, > > No Idea what you're talking about, but thanks for taking the time to explain it. Guess I'll just be like most cubers who only memorizes and execute the algorithms > > Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 05:08:28 -0000 > From: d_funny007 > Subject: Re: Understanding Algorithms > > I think most cubers don't understand the algorithms they use but just > memorize them and execute them accordingly. > > But if you spend enough time thinking about an algorithm, then one may > gain insite into how they actaully work, why they do what they do. > > Most algs we use are quite complicated and can't be disected into > small parts that are understandable. > > Here is an example of one of the simplest PLL that I'm sure most ppl > understand. The so-called "Allan" maneuver (old slice/non-2-gen > version of the 3-edge cycle): > > R2 U F B' R2 F' B U R2 > > It can be understood as the sequence S' U2 S U2 conjugated with R2 U > (or "conjugated with" in some literature). And it becomes the final > alg with some cancellations. > > By conjugation I mean: if A=(R2 U) and B=(S' U2 S U2) then the final > alg is A * B * A^(-1) after a bit of cancellation. > > Now the B in this case is easy enough to understand. B here is in fact > in itself a commutator, and as we know from Group Theory, commutators > tend to fix many indicies in subgroups of (finite) symmetric groups. > > A commutator is something of the form x*y*x^(-1)*y^(-1). It is easy to > see why this reduces to the identity in commutative algebras (Abelian > groups) and "does nothing". In "not-so-commutative groups" it is > something that tends to be "close" to "doing nothing". > > A bit of trivia that even we as cubers typically don't know: > > Although there are 12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 possible positionsm, it is really > 901083404981813616 after modding out by rotational isomorphisms. (can > be shown by the Plya-Burnside lemma) > > The group is the semi-direct product of the orientation aspect of the > cube and the permutation aspect. The orientations are isomorphic to > the commutative group (Z_2)^11 "cross" (Z_3)^7. The permutation group > is isomorphic to (A_8 cross A_12) semi-direct product with Z_2. > (I have this memorized since I'm a math major and get asked this > question A LOT.) > > To learn more about these more abstract idiosyncrasies of the cube > check out http://www.geocities.com/jaapsch/puzzles/groups.htm . > > > -Doug > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > <ddollard@n...> wrote: > > Hey all, > > > > What is meant by not only memorizing algorithms (such as > Fridrich's 41 OLL algs) but instead 'Understanding' how they work? > I've seen this a few times in posts. Not quite sure if I understand > the true definition. > > > > > > Thanks Dwayne > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > ________________________________________________________________________ > ________________________________________________________________________ > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1732. you've been cubing too much if... (yes, again...)
From: Franois Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 16:30:28 +0200

You've definitely been cubing too much if you can calculate
12!*8!*2^11*3^7/2 in your head in less than a second and give an exact
answer...
And if you know why.
Franois

1737. Re: V, R, and G permutations- anyone's favorite?....
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 17:51:19 -0000

Definately not a PLL expert. But since you asked. I would say U, Z, T, V, Y in that order. Oh and Bo's crazy H is also nifty, but I do it much slower and it defiantely slows down my times, then again so does a Z-Perm lock up but that is rare. The mirrored J I can do pretty fast (though I tend to call it an L-Perm for obvious reasons). -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > Hey everyone, > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html has the letters for the permutations. > > I was curious, are any of these anyone's FAVORITE? 1738. Re: V, R, and G permutations- anyone's favorite?....
From: "qwerty1110" <qwerty1110@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 18:22:54 -0000

Why, V and R are very much so my favorite algorithms (R then V) Followed by Y and N. If you do V with the right cube rotations, then it becomes almost the same thing twice in a row (doing that just looks impressive) I do R differently than most people. If you look through the list of all 1211 POLL the guy gives about 12 different algs for each of the PLL. If you hate an alg, check it out. Y is just fun if you hold onto the right face for the first couple of R2. N is one of those where you do the same thing twice. It's pretty fun to do. R - RU' R'U' RURD R'U'RD'R'U2R'U' V - R'UR'd'y2 R'UR'U'R2y' U'R'URU Y - R2U'R2U'R2U FUF' R2FU'F' N - x RUR'DR2U'RD' UR'DR2U'RD' Fox --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Definately not a PLL expert. > > But since you asked. I would say U, Z, T, V, Y in that order. Oh and > Bo's crazy H is also nifty, but I do it much slower and it > defiantely slows down my times, then again so does a Z-Perm lock up > but that is rare. The mirrored J I can do pretty fast (though I tend > to call it an L-Perm for obvious reasons). > > > -Doug > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Brent Morgan > <brentmorganmaster@y...> wrote: > > > > Hey everyone, > > http://www.ws.binghamton.edu/fridrich/Mike/permute.html has > the letters for the permutations. > > > > I was curious, are any of these anyone's FAVORITE? 1739. Re: V, R, and G permutations- anyone's favorite?....
From: "Bob Burton" <bob@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 18:39:19 -0000

Permutations in order of preference to get in a solve along with my approximate times for the alg (assuming I don't lock up): (I will ignore mirrors and consider only my fastest side if there is a mirror) H (1.1 sec) <1 sec on perfect full-speed execution A (1.2 sec) U (1.3 sec) T (1.5 sec) R (1.6 sec) J (1.7 sec) Y (1.8 sec) Z (1.8 sec) E (1.8 sec) V (1.9 sec) G (1.9 sec) F (1.9 sec) but I mess up this one a lot. :( N (2.5 sec) The algs I use are of course on my website (though I don't list all of the edge-cycles I use yet and sometimes I use mirrors of algs on there or something). ~ Bob
1740. Re: [Speed cubing group] V, R, and G permutations- anyone's favorite?....
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 6 Sep 2005 18:47:21 +0000 (GMT)

Hi, the R is (R' U2) (R U2') (R' F R U R' U') (R' F' R2 U') (mirror just swap R for L) Y -> F (R U' R' U') (R U R' U') (R U R' U') (R' F R F') and G is different for each of the four cases... I don't know the times, 'cause I don't have a stackmat timer, and my cube is not that good... Brent Morgan <brentmorganmaster@...> escreveu: Hey Pedro, Can you elaborate on this? As in, how fast you can perform the R,G, and Y algs, and which algs you use?
