From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 6 Sep 2005 20:57:44 +0200

Except the H, U and A, I can't perform any of them under 2 seconds
(most over 3 seconds).

I wish I knew a super ZB system that has a full OLL-PLL algorithms.
(wich doesn't require to have the top-cross oriented).

But that looks like a damn lot of algorithms lol.

Maybe I'll write those one day, it'll be known as the VDP system.
(I'll tell you when I'll start :P)

But for know, I have to work on those 21+57 algorithms to solve the LL
under 5 seconds....


1742. New PBs
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 20:55:56 -0000

Ok...today was the first day back at school...and after a summer of
mainly cubing and seeing few of my fellow classmates, of course, I was
obligated to do some solves for them. This morning on the school bus
a kid was like...Can I scramble your 4x4??? I was like sure...go
ahead...Then he was like...how fast can you do it??? And i was
like...usually below 5 mintues...and I got a PB of 3:41.xx which is
better than my previous of 3:58.07...then at school I did a bunch of
solves...and then at lunch I went over to the Loblaws(a grocery store
where they sell really good hot food...And I ran into some schoolmates
and they were like...rumours are floating around you can solve a
rubik's cube...and I was like...yah...so I did some solves for
them...then the workers at Loblaws were like...can you do that???So I
got one of them to scramble it...and she challenged me...If you can do
it under 2 minutes (I am and average of approx. 60 solver...so I took
the challenge...Got 58.xx...lol free food...I'll take it...then on the
bus ride home after volleyball practice I was riding the bus and
scrambled all the cubes I had with me...i finally put together my
black DIY with arched centers, and my dad glued the center caps on and
i lubed it...then left it to dry about 24 hours...and my first solve i
got a PB of 40.89...(ex-PB of 43.30)...then I did a 4x4 solve and got
a PB of 3:28.65...which I thought was cool...I didn't get any parity
errors and I did centers in 32 seconds...edges in about 1 minute 40
seconds and whatever else time for the 3x3 part...I was happy for
today...I'll shut up now... :)

Craig




1743. Re: [Speed cubing group] V, R, and G permutations- anyone's favorite?....
From: "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 21:08:54 -0000

The R perm is my favorite. I use the same alg Pedro gave. My fastest
execution of this alg is 1.60, but it's usually under 2 unless it
locks up. It's not my fastest PLL, but it's my favorite because it's
so much fun to perform. :)

The V perm isn't so bad. I used to hate it until I practiced doing
the rotation smoothly. My fastest for this alg is 2.12.

(R' U R' U') y x2 (R' U R' U') x' (R2 U') (R' U R U)

Some of the G perms are okay. I think they're all about 2.5 for me.
I use Lars Vandenbergh's algs for all 4 of these.

-Jason

1745. Re: [Speed cubing group] V, R, and G permutations- anyone's favorite?....
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 6 Sep 2005 18:22:45 -0300 (ART)

Hmm, an interesting alg...I do R U' R U F D' F D F2 R F R' F' R' maybe I'll change... Jason Baum <speedrunningcuber@...> escreveu: The R perm is my favorite. I use the same alg Pedro gave. My fastest execution of this alg is 1.60, but it's usually under 2 unless it locks up. It's not my fastest PLL, but it's my favorite because it's so much fun to perform. :) The V perm isn't so bad. I used to hate it until I practiced doing the rotation smoothly. My fastest for this alg is 2.12. (R' U R' U') y x2 (R' U R' U') x' (R2 U') (R' U R U) Some of the G perms are okay. I think they're all about 2.5 for me. I use Lars Vandenbergh's algs for all 4 of these. -Jason SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1746. First steps towards sub-60 on the 4x4x4
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 00:29:21 -0000

Hey everyone,

I'm very happy as now I am 100% convinced that sub-60 is possible
for an average of 10 on the 4x4x4.

Today I did an average and got two sub-60 parity times, with the OLL
parity (the 15 move to fix one!).

63.92 (55.04) 66.58 65.54 62.02 67.21 67.78 56.47 (76.89) 70.04
61.86 57.52 = 63.89

Both the 56.47 and the 57.52 were with the OLL parity, and I was
still able to end with a sub-60 time.

I've noticed that even though the 3x3x3 step is the most important,
since it is after all the entire purpose of solving with centers
first, that my fastest solves are when I really concentrate and
blaze through the edges step.

I think I am getting faster at my centers, but I know for a fact
that I don't average as fast as Stefan Pochmann and his average for
the 4x4 centers on speedcubing.com. So I think I still need to
improve my centers too.

Anyway what I am trying to say is that even with a slower centers
step, and a not the fastest 3x3x3 no-inspection step, I think sub-60
is possible.

So I think this barrier is only in our heads, and that soon a LOT of
people will break it. You don't need perfect steps to do it, just
concentration and practice.

Let's get past this stupid barrier and see what the limits are for
the 4x4x4!

Chris





1747. Re: First steps towards sub-60 on the 4x4x4
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 01:32:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > I think I am getting faster at my centers, but I know for a fact > that I don't average as fast as Stefan Pochmann and his average for > the 4x4 centers on speedcubing.com. Just remember that A) it's only my record average and real average is more like 15-16 and B) Olivier is faster so next time you should mention him instead of me :-) Did you measure center solving recently? Cheers! Stefan
1748. Good cubing day
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 02:01:34 -0000

Hey, folks,
I just want to share with you my good cubing day...
today I broke my best average for 3x3x3 and made 31.88 at the morning.
Then, at night, I had my first sucessful BLD solve. I was very happy
when I opened my eyes and the cube was solved :). The time was
8:49.49...well, it's not a great time, but I'm sure I can improve.

Leyan, Macky, Tyson, Stefan, watch your back, I'll pass all of
you....hehe :)

Pedro




1749. 4x4x4 math question
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 02:11:05 -0000

Hey everyone,

I remember a while back Lars Vandenbergh did an analysis of all the
possible cross solves for the 3x3x3 (or at least I think it was Lars)
and found that no case takes more than 8 moves.

I was wondering how can I go about doing the same type of analysis for
solving the first two opposite centers of a 4x4x4?

I'd like to know the maximum number of moves it takes to solve two
opposite centers (I don't care about any other pieces), and also maybe
an average # too.

I guess my question is how exactly should I approach this problem?

Chris





1750. Re: [Speed cubing group] Good cubing day
From: Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 7 Sep 2005 09:32:03 +0530

Congrats pedro. For your avg and blindfolded too. The first BLD solve is always great. I almost jumped from my bed after i got it:) Anyway good luck with beatig all those u mentioned:) Sachin. On 9/7/05, pedrosino1 <pedrosino1@...> wrote: > Hey, folks, > I just want to share with you my good cubing day... > today I broke my best average for 3x3x3 and made 31.88 at the morning. > Then, at night, I had my first sucessful BLD solve. I was very happy > when I opened my eyes and the cube was solved :). The time was > 8:49.49...well, it's not a great time, but I'm sure I can improve. > > Leyan, Macky, Tyson, Stefan, watch your back, I'll pass all of > you....hehe :) > > Pedro > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
1751. Re: 4x4x4 math question
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 04:19:45 -0000

This problem doesn't sound too difficult for a computer to run a brute force search for. Make a structure that only stores the center sticker colors and manipulates them accordingly; the key is to exploit as many of the cube symmetries as possible. As an experienced 4x4 solver yourself, you could probably provide a very reliable "branch and bound" for it. I must refine it to two different questions here: 1. Suppose we specify the opposite sides to be solved first. 2. We don't specify this and take the best possible opposite center pair. In the second question we would certainly get a smaller number (eh... or equal I guess). Oh and a third (dumber) question is if we specify one color *then* it's opposite. But this would create much bigger numbers, though I'm sure still better than humans who do not use any optimizations for symmutaneously achiving progrress on both sides. *Even I* can write a very quick and dirty program to give the answer to question 1 (if I had the time). Just to indicate how routine something like that would be for CS ppl. Now question 2 at first sight seems (at least to me) to be highly non-trivial, though I would assume to still be attainable using todays processor speeds. The more interesting number would be the answer to question 2, and the success of the program (running in reasonable time) I would think is totally reliant on exploiting cube symmetries. *By number I really mean numbers, since the program really would generate something like a chart for the number of positions at each "distance" to the identity. And though you would think there would be multiple identities, you would start by fixing one center as the piece that "never moves"... i.e. since doing (R) is some how the same as doing (Llr') for our purposes, it would suffice to have the mappings: <L,r,R,B,f,F,u,d,D> and fix the center piece on ULB quadrant that points up. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I remember a while back Lars Vandenbergh did an analysis of all the > possible cross solves for the 3x3x3 (or at least I think it was Lars) > and found that no case takes more than 8 moves. > > I was wondering how can I go about doing the same type of analysis for > solving the first two opposite centers of a 4x4x4? > > I'd like to know the maximum number of moves it takes to solve two > opposite centers (I don't care about any other pieces), and also maybe > an average # too. > > I guess my question is how exactly should I approach this problem? > > Chris
1752. Re: First steps towards sub-60 on the 4x4x4
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 04:37:01 -0000

Good job Chris! keep up the good work. So is ZB helping as much as you thought it would for 4x4 solves? -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, cmhardw <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Hey everyone, > > I'm very happy as now I am 100% convinced that sub-60 is possible > for an average of 10 on the 4x4x4. > > Today I did an average and got two sub-60 parity times, with the OLL > parity (the 15 move to fix one!). > > 63.92 (55.04) 66.58 65.54 62.02 67.21 67.78 56.47 (76.89) 70.04 > 61.86 57.52 = 63.89 > > Both the 56.47 and the 57.52 were with the OLL parity, and I was > still able to end with a sub-60 time. > > I've noticed that even though the 3x3x3 step is the most important, > since it is after all the entire purpose of solving with centers > first, that my fastest solves are when I really concentrate and > blaze through the edges step. > > I think I am getting faster at my centers, but I know for a fact > that I don't average as fast as Stefan Pochmann and his average for > the 4x4 centers on speedcubing.com. So I think I still need to > improve my centers too. > > Anyway what I am trying to say is that even with a slower centers > step, and a not the fastest 3x3x3 no-inspection step, I think sub- 60 > is possible. > > So I think this barrier is only in our heads, and that soon a LOT of > people will break it. You don't need perfect steps to do it, just > concentration and practice. > > Let's get past this stupid barrier and see what the limits are for > the 4x4x4! > > Chris
1753. Re: improving your cube
From: "skatcat3103" <skatcat31@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 04:39:32 -0000

The levels mean how easy it is to turn the sides... 1= stock cube, 2= sides are modarately easy to turn but wont turn unless 90% of the slots(area in between cubies) is aligned, 3= easy to turn and cubies will turn at 65-75% slot alignment, 4=cubies will turn at anything above 50%... and teh tutorial includes sanding and filing, which are completely legal for preparing a cube for the world tournament. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > A tutorial-like guide about how to prepare a speedcube is always > welcome :-) > > But what on earth are those levels u talk about. I never heard about > those before. Are u simply grading the suitability of a cube for > speeding from 1 to 4? If so how do you do that? > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "skatcat3103" > <skatcat31@h...> wrote: > > ive found a way to make store bought rubiks cubes almost at the last > > cube level.... its the 3rd out of 4 cube levels (how easy it is to > > turn > > the cube) using a file... i could create a guide detailing how to do > > it > > and post it as a file... but its recomended for level 2 cubes as it > > wont do much for level 1 cubes as the center axis cubes isnt worn > > into > > the corret shape that i would be happy to show also... but it might > > take awhile for me to create and post (im not on much). should i or > > shouldnt i?

1755. Broke my first 5x5 center.
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 05:05:09 -0000

Well looks like I just broke my first 5x5 center, not sure when it
happened, it stuck around for a while but I had noticed there was one
loose x-center piece somewhere...

This is what happens when I try to break the 3:30 barrier...

I'm sure it'll happen a few more times to come.

Luckily, there is now cubesmith.


Curious how often do other 5x5 cubers break pieces (and which pieces)?


-Doug (temped to take it from my new 5x5)

1758. Re: Broke my first 5x5 center.
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 08:56:00 -0000

Hey! It will always be the centers located between the middle center and a corner-piece that will break. I have never heard of centers between the middle center and a middle edge breaking. Of course this might happen, but never heard of it. If u are serious about 5x5x5 cubing you better have a spare cube u can take pieces from. One extra cube is 24 of those centers that are likely to break ;-) This should last a few yrs. By that time u probably need to retire ur current cube anyway :-o Have fun! -Per >--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > Well looks like I just broke my first 5x5 center, not sure when it > happened, it stuck around for a while but I had noticed there was one > loose x-center piece somewhere... > > This is what happens when I try to break the 3:30 barrier... > > I'm sure it'll happen a few more times to come. > > Luckily, there is now cubesmith. > > > Curious how often do other 5x5 cubers break pieces (and which pieces)? > > > -Doug (temped to take it from my new 5x5)

1760. Canadians Going to the RUBIK'S Games Championships?
From: "David Weinstein" <DAVIDW@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 7 Sep 2005 10:05:10 -0400

Hello all: I am David Weinstein, and am heading up the Canadian PR initiative to promote the 25th Anniversary of the Cube, and the upcoming World Championships. As part of our promotion of the Championships, we are looking for Cube Enthusiasts who would be willing to demo their skills with the Canadian media (on TV Shows; with print journalists & photographers; and even with radio hosts). Ideally we'd like to have Cubists from the following Canadian centers: 1. Halifax, NS 2. Montreal, QC 3. Ottawa, ON 4. Toronto, ON 5. London, ON 6. Winnipeg. MB 7. Regina/Saskatoon, SK 8. Edmonton. AB 9. Calgary, AB 10. Vancouver, BC 11. Other communities in BC If you can please reply and confirm your willingness to be profiled as a "local participant going the the championships" we will do our very best to secure some interviews for you, and ensure you are briefed prior to your interviews. Please let me be clear on one point: We are not asking you to be a spokesperson for the Cube - rather we'd like you to share your enthusiasm and cubing skills with the media - who will in turn profile you as a local resident who is going off the the Championships to represent your city/province/ and our country. Typically these interviews happen in-studio (TV / Radio); in-person - meeting with either a TV/Radio or Print journalist at a coffee shop or wherever is mutually convenient; or over the phone. If you are interested in being profiled please reply to this email and let me know the following: 1. Who you are (Name) 2. Your phone and email address 3. What Canadian city you live in (or near) 4. Your experience level 5. Your area of cube expertise 6. and any confines that we might have to take into consideration to schedule your interviews We look forward to hearing from you, and making you famous in your community and across Canada! Standing by and best regards, David Weinstein Media Relations Director Strategic Objectives Inc. (416) 366-7735 ext 231 Please visit our web site at www.strategicobjectives.com <http://www.strategicobjectives.com/> A member of Pinnacle Worldwide This email is privileged and may contain confidential information intended only for the person or entity to which it is addressed. Any review, distribution, copying or disclosure by persons or entities other than the intended recipient is strictly prohibited. If you have received this email in error, please notify the sender by telephone or email. Return the original transmission to the sender by email without making a copy and delete the material from all computers. Ce courriel s'addresse uniquement aux rcipiendaires viss et peut contenir de l'information confidentielle ou des documents l'usage unique des personnes qui il s'adresse. Toute lecture, distribution ou copie du contenu de ce message par des tiers autres que les rcipiendaires viss est strictement interdite. Veuillez retourner le message original par courriel l'metteur sans en faire copie et supprimez immdiatement ce matriel de tous les ordinateurs. [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

1764. Re: New PBs
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 21:29:02 -0000

I just got a new PB myself a moment ago! Breaking the 3:30 barrier with a time of 3:28.42 (on the 5x5). I'm so happy :). -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > Ok...today was the first day back at school...and after a summer of > mainly cubing and seeing few of my fellow classmates, of course, I was > obligated to do some solves for them. This morning on the school bus > a kid was like...Can I scramble your 4x4??? I was like sure...go > ahead...Then he was like...how fast can you do it??? And i was > like...usually below 5 mintues...and I got a PB of 3:41.xx which is > better than my previous of 3:58.07...then at school I did a bunch of > solves...and then at lunch I went over to the Loblaws(a grocery store > where they sell really good hot food...And I ran into some schoolmates > and they were like...rumours are floating around you can solve a > rubik's cube...and I was like...yah...so I did some solves for > them...then the workers at Loblaws were like...can you do that??? So I > got one of them to scramble it...and she challenged me...If you can do > it under 2 minutes (I am and average of approx. 60 solver...so I took > the challenge...Got 58.xx...lol free food...I'll take it...then on the > bus ride home after volleyball practice I was riding the bus and > scrambled all the cubes I had with me...i finally put together my > black DIY with arched centers, and my dad glued the center caps on and > i lubed it...then left it to dry about 24 hours...and my first solve i > got a PB of 40.89...(ex-PB of 43.30)...then I did a 4x4 solve and got > a PB of 3:28.65...which I thought was cool...I didn't get any parity > errors and I did centers in 32 seconds...edges in about 1 minute 40 > seconds and whatever else time for the 3x3 part...I was happy for > today...I'll shut up now... :) > > Craig

1766. Another FUN Day
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 22:22:53 -0000

Well, second day of school...more stories...

Don't worry I won't post a story everyday...just the days something
fun/interesting happens...

Well, it all started out with my Chiropractor appointment, who I show
a different puzzle to every time I go...And today I Showed him the
Clock, he finds the puzzles semi-interesting, if he isn't busy moving
from patient to patient...

Then I went to school...duh...and I did a few random solves...nothing
special...and then I got my locker :p Nothin Special again...and I owe
the school $65...:(...anyways...At lunch I went to the cafeteria to
catch up with an old friend, and I whipped out all my cubes...I did a
whack load of solves...and before I knew it this kid came over and
picked up one of my 4x4x4s and was like...Can I borrow this...and I
was like NO...I had never seen the kid before...then I looked up and
there was a group of about 6 kids sitting there watching me
solve...they came over and sat down around me and watched me solve a
LOT...My hands were kinda shaky...but it didn't really affect my
solves...These people were like...you're my new hero...you should
solve on stage in front of the whole school...and I was
like...haha...NO!!!lol...I would do it...but...I dunno, I will
probably tell my principal I am going, cuz everyone will know by then
and she'll probably make a big deal about it...and I don't find that
many people notice cubing on buses...cuz on my way home I was on the
bus, but no one noticed...

I'll Shut Up now...no new PBs...cept the one last night on my
4x4...3:25.84

Craig

Any review, distribution, copying or disclosure by persons or entities other than the intended recipient is strictly prohibited. 1769. Re: Another FUN Day
From: "Andreas Renberg" <rubikssites@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 22:48:29 -0000

See my comment below --> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@h...> wrote: > Well, second day of school...more stories... > > Don't worry I won't post a story everyday...just the days something > fun/interesting happens... > > Well, it all started out with my Chiropractor appointment, who I show > a different puzzle to every time I go...And today I Showed him the > Clock, he finds the puzzles semi-interesting, if he isn't busy moving > from patient to patient... > > Then I went to school...duh...and I did a few random solves...nothing > special...and then I got my locker :p Nothin Special again...and I owe > the school $65...:(...anyways...At lunch I went to the cafeteria to > catch up with an old friend, and I whipped out all my cubes...I did a > whack load of solves...and before I knew it this kid came over and > picked up one of my 4x4x4s and was like...Can I borrow this...and I > was like NO...I had never seen the kid before...then I looked up and > there was a group of about 6 kids sitting there watching me > solve...they came over and sat down around me and watched me solve a > LOT...My hands were kinda shaky...but it didn't really affect my > solves...These people were like...you're my new hero...you should > solve on stage in front of the whole school...and I was > like...haha...NO!!!lol...I would do it...but...I dunno, I will > probably tell my principal I am going, cuz everyone will know by then > and she'll probably make a big deal about it...and I don't find that > many people notice cubing on buses...cuz on my way home I was on the > bus, but no one noticed... I know. i have similar experiences. I suppose everyone is tired or just want to get home so bad that they dont care... Which is too bad, because at first the teachers think the cube is cool, but after a while they get mad at me for even bringing the cube into the classroom... so basically the only times to cube are at lunch, on the bus, and at PE (i havent made that teacher mad yet ;) > I'll Shut Up now...no new PBs...cept the one last night on my > 4x4...3:25.84 > > Craig

1773. Willing to prepare a cube for $?....
From: "Brent Morgan" <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 02:37:23 -0000

Is *_ANYONE_* willing to make a cube deal? As in, $ (could be a lot
of $) for a really good cube... Seriously I cannot make my own cubes,
I just don't know how to get them how I want it. I've recently talked
to Sunil, Tyson, Doug Li about this and I guess everyone is just too
busy or something to set one up for me. Anyone interested? Let me
know.
-Brent M.

1776. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Another FUN Day
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 2005 09:19:31 +0200

Cubing in front of non-cubers is always funny at the beginning,
anbd then depending on the people, it can be very fun or very boring

The worst people are the ones that either tell you to stop because of
the noise, either they are like : you are stupid, I can do it faster
than you.

Have fun at your school with your new followers (disciples ?). :D

1778. Thought i'll share...
From: "melchan78" <melchan78@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 07:59:31 -0000

Hi guys,

I'm a big cube fan from Malaysia. I'm so happy today coz I got my
first ever sub-30 average (29.89s), a year after joining this
speedcubing group. I use the Fridrich F2L and a 3-look LL. Many thanks
to all of you who posted tips, algorithms and other great stuff here,
which helped me a great deal.

Thought i'll share,
Meng

1782. Re: SV: [Speed cubing group] Orange stickerz....
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 09:56:05 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Terje Kristensen" <terje.kristensen@w...> wrote: > Weird because on my cube the orange stickers is almost indestructible, > the white is pretty good and all the other colors have been replaced. > This is one of ton's studio cubes. The orange seems to be of a different > material than the others, and are very solid. I've found the same thing: these are the only stickers that haven't chipped on my Studio cube (though the orange darkened after exposure to strong sunlight). However, on other puzzles (not only Rubik's) I've had problems with the orange stickers -- either poor adhesion or rapid wear. There must be a good reason for it... Mike

1785. Re: New PBs
From: "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 10:35:22 -0000

I'm practicing for Swedish Open on Saturday and broke two records. 2*2*2 - average with 6,63 abdd 2:47 on the 5*5*5. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I just got a new PB myself a moment ago! > > Breaking the 3:30 barrier with a time of 3:28.42 (on the 5x5). I'm > so happy :). > > > -Doug > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > Ok...today was the first day back at school...and after a summer of > > mainly cubing and seeing few of my fellow classmates, of course, I > was > > obligated to do some solves for them. This morning on the school > bus > > a kid was like...Can I scramble your 4x4??? I was like sure...go > > ahead...Then he was like...how fast can you do it??? And i was > > like...usually below 5 mintues...and I got a PB of 3:41.xx which is > > better than my previous of 3:58.07...then at school I did a bunch > of > > solves...and then at lunch I went over to the Loblaws(a grocery > store > > where they sell really good hot food...And I ran into some > schoolmates > > and they were like...rumours are floating around you can solve a > > rubik's cube...and I was like...yah...so I did some solves for > > them...then the workers at Loblaws were like...can you do that??? > So I > > got one of them to scramble it...and she challenged me...If you > can do > > it under 2 minutes (I am and average of approx. 60 solver...so I > took > > the challenge...Got 58.xx...lol free food...I'll take it...then on > the > > bus ride home after volleyball practice I was riding the bus and > > scrambled all the cubes I had with me...i finally put together my > > black DIY with arched centers, and my dad glued the center caps on > and > > i lubed it...then left it to dry about 24 hours...and my first > solve i > > got a PB of 40.89...(ex-PB of 43.30)...then I did a 4x4 solve and > got > > a PB of 3:28.65...which I thought was cool...I didn't get any > parity > > errors and I did centers in 32 seconds...edges in about 1 minute 40 > > seconds and whatever else time for the 3x3 part...I was happy for > > today...I'll shut up now... :) > > > > Craig

1791. Re: Canadians Going to the RUBIK'S Games Championships?
From: "davehj999" <davej@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 11:43:43 -0000

Dear All. I can also verify that David is the PR guru for Canada, it was David and his team that managed to get the fantastic coverage in Toronto. Looking forward to November and off to Sweden for the competition this weekend. Will take some photos. Dave (yet another one!) Seven Towns. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "David Weinstein" <DAVIDW@s...> wrote: > > Hello all: > > I am David Weinstein, and am heading up the Canadian PR initiative to promote the 25th Anniversary of the Cube, and the upcoming World Championships. > > As part of our promotion of the Championships, we are looking for Cube Enthusiasts who would be willing to demo their skills with the Canadian media (on TV Shows; with print journalists & photographers; and even with radio hosts). > > Ideally we'd like to have Cubists from the following Canadian centers: > > > 1. Halifax, NS > 2. Montreal, QC > 3. Ottawa, ON > 4. Toronto, ON > 5. London, ON > 6. Winnipeg. MB > 7. Regina/Saskatoon, SK > 8. Edmonton. AB > 9. Calgary, AB > 10. Vancouver, BC > 11. John Louis Gunnar Krig <gunkr520@...> wrote: I'm practicing for Swedish Open on Saturday and broke two records. 2*2*2 - average with 6,63 abdd 2:47 on the 5*5*5. /Gunnar --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, d_funny007 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > I just got a new PB myself a moment ago! > > Breaking the 3:30 barrier with a time of 3:28.42 (on the 5x5). I'm > so happy :). > > > -Doug > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Craig Bouchard" > <logitewty@h...> wrote: > > Ok...today was the first day back at school...and after a summer of > > mainly cubing and seeing few of my fellow classmates, of course, I > was > > obligated to do some solves for them. This morning on the school > bus > > a kid was like...Can I scramble your 4x4??? I was like sure...go > > ahead...Then he was like...how fast can you do it??? And i was > > like...usually below 5 mintues...and I got a PB of 3:41.xx which is > > better than my previous of 3:58.07...then at school I did a bunch > of > > solves...and then at lunch I went over to the Loblaws(a grocery > store > > where they sell really good hot food...And I ran into some > schoolmates > > and they were like...rumours are floating around you can solve a > > rubik's cube...and I was like...yah...so I did some solves for > > them...then the workers at Loblaws were like...can you do that??? > So I > > got one of them to scramble it...and she challenged me...If you > can do > > it under 2 minutes (I am and average of approx. 60 solver...so I > took > > the challenge...Got 58.xx...lol free food...I'll take it...then on > the > > bus ride home after volleyball practice I was riding the bus and > > scrambled all the cubes I had with me...i finally put together my > > black DIY with arched centers, and my dad glued the center caps on > and > > i lubed it...then left it to dry about 24 hours...and my first > solve i > > got a PB of 40.89...(ex-PB of 43.30)...then I did a 4x4 solve and > got > > a PB of 3:28.65...which I thought was cool...I didn't get any > parity > > errors and I did centers in 32 seconds...edges in about 1 minute 40 > > seconds and whatever else time for the 3x3 part...I was happy for > > today...I'll shut up now... :) > > > > Craig --------------------------------- YAHOO! 1797. RE: [Speed cubing group] Canadians Going to the RUBIK'S Games Championships?
From: "David Weinstein" <DAVIDW@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 2005 10:12:19 -0400

Excellent. Thanks for your reply, David -----Original Message----- From: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Peter Douthwright Sent: Wednesday, September 07, 2005 6:42 PM To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Canadians Going to the RUBIK'S Games Championships? I am in Toronto and am VERY willing to promote -peedcubing to my fellow canadians. Peter Douthwright 416-901-3732(leave a mesage if I am not at home) ----- Original Message ----- From: David Weinstein To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Wednesday, September 07, 2005 10:05 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Canadians Going to the RUBIK'S Games Championships? Hello all: I am David Weinstein, and am heading up the Canadian PR initiative to promote the 25th Anniversary of the Cube, and the upcoming World Championships. As part of our promotion of the Championships, we are looking for Cube Enthusiasts who would be willing to demo their skills with the Canadian media (on TV Shows; with print journalists & photographers; and even with radio hosts). Ideally we'd like to have Cubists from the following Canadian centers: 1. Halifax, NS 2. Montreal, QC 3. Ottawa, ON 4. Toronto, ON 5. London, ON 6. Winnipeg. MB 7. Regina/Saskatoon, SK 8. Edmonton. AB 9. Calgary, AB 10. Vancouver, BC 11. Other communities in BC If you can please reply and confirm your willingness to be profiled as a "local participant going the the championships" we will do our very best to secure some interviews for you, and ensure you are briefed prior to your interviews. Please let me be clear on one point: We are not asking you to be a spokesperson for the Cube - rather we'd like you to share your enthusiasm and cubing skills with the media - who will in turn profile you as a local resident who is going off the the Championships to represent your city/province/ and our country. Typically these interviews happen in-studio (TV / Radio); in-person - meeting with either a TV/Radio or Print journalist at a coffee shop or wherever is mutually convenient; or over the phone. If you are interested in being profiled please reply to this email and let me know the following: 1. Who you are (Name) 2. Your phone and email address 3. What Canadian city you live in (or near) 4. Your experience level 5. Your area of cube expertise 6. and any confines that we might have to take into consideration to schedule your interviews We look forward to hearing from you, and making you famous in your community and across Canada! Standing by and best regards, David Weinstein Media Relations Director Strategic Objectives Inc. (416) 366-7735 ext 231 Please visit our web site at www.strategicobjectives.com <http://www.strategicobjectives.com/> A member of Pinnacle Worldwide This email is privileged and may contain confidential information intended only for the person or entity to which it is addressed. Any review, distribution, copying or disclosure by persons or entities other than the intended recipient is strictly prohibited. If you have received this email in error, please notify the sender by telephone or email. Return the original transmission to the sender by email without making a copy and delete the material from all computers. Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 17:17:35 -0000

and QTM -- heck, I hope he doesn't prefer SQTM), but got a screen
saying that my prayer would be reviewed by a moderator shortly.

A *moderator*. What's that then -- some measly saint? Some acned
seraph?

I am bitterly disappointed. God doesn't even read his own e-mail...

Mike




1801. Cube song help
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 19:37:12 -0000

Hey guys,
I just had my backup hard drive tank and I lost a ton of stuff (none
of it important). One of the things I'm now looking for is a catchy
little song about the cube. I've only ever heard of 3 songs
specifically about the cube, and I can only remember the name and
singer of one:

Baron Knights - "Mr. Rubik"

Luckily, I remember a lot of lyrics from the other two, so I'll post
em and see if anyone else can tell me who sang them or where to find them.

The first I stumbled across on the internet one day and goes something
like:

I've never peeled off the stickers,
Taken apart the pieces,
Or purchased any books with the solution.
But I'm gonna get that bottom line
If it takes all my time,
Cause I don't want to add to next year's resolutions.
Whether by skill or by luck,
There's no choice but to mix it back up.

Where will I be when old Rubik's stops challenging me.

It's longer than that and maybe not in the right order, but you get
the jist. Anyway, it was actually a catchy melody and I really liked
it! So any help finding it would be greatly appreciated.

The last song I first heard during Comedy Central's "Premium Blend" a
few years back. I'm pretty sure he was the last performer to go on.
It was more silly (like the Baron Knights song) but still not bad.
Anyway, here's what I remember of it:

Hello operator can you get me Hungry?
I've got to talk to Erno Rubik 'bout this problem you see.
...
(chorus)
Rubik's cube, it's driving me crazy!
I'm about to peal the stickers off
'Cause I'm too stupid and lazy.

Sorry, that was a loooong time ago that I heard that so I don't
remember very much of it.

At any rate, those are the only cube songs I know about (though lots
actually mention the cube without being about it!) So if you guys
have any more or know which these are, I'd appreciate it!

Thanks!
Daniel

1804. Waterman Method
From: "Dwayne" <ddollard@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 2005 18:04:05 -0300

Hey all,

Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. Is this like a what came first question: Chicken/Egg? Is it worth learning... (Do many people practice this method?). Let's have a show of hands!! Any info would be greatly appreciated.

BTW almost sub-30 (30.4 Ave)
Thanks
Dwayne

1805. Re: [Speed cubing group] Waterman Method
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 2005 14:09:41 -0700

There aren't any resources for this mysterious "Waterman" method. I
have no idea who Mark Waterman is and the only thing I know about his
method is that it has something to do with corner's first but it
doesn't seem there is anything on the internet to teach these things.

Can someone direct me to the "Waterman" method? I am relatively new to
cubing so as far as I know, it's just a myth... kinda like Loch Ness
and the Yeti. These legendary things but why should I believe it if I
haven't seen it?

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

1806. Re: [Speed cubing group] Orange stickerz....
From: "Andreas Renberg" <rubikssites@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 21:13:10 -0000

Yeah, i have a 4x4 not verry used that i lended out to a friend, and when it came back 2 of the orange pices are instead white, but since it was scrambled i didnt notice, so while solving it i couldnt find a pice, so i scolded my friend and got mad at him because i thought he had swapped the stickers, ooops... :) there is a thin layer on the orange sticker pice that peels off to easily, the whole sticker doesnt peel.... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > I dont have orange stickers on my cube. But i do have two white faces :) > > > > > > On 9/8/05, Beer, Bram de <bbeer@g...> wrote: > > About 2 months ago this was already noticed... If you have any problems ask me and ill send you it... Andreas rubikssites@... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > Hey guys, > I just had my backup hard drive tank and I lost a ton of stuff (none > of it important). One of the things I'm now looking for is a catchy > little song about the cube. I've only ever heard of 3 songs > specifically about the cube, and I can only remember the name and > singer of one: > > Baron Knights - "Mr. Rubik" > > Luckily, I remember a lot of lyrics from the other two, so I'll post > em and see if anyone else can tell me who sang them or where to find them. > > The first I stumbled across on the internet one day and goes something > like: > > I've never peeled off the stickers, > Taken apart the pieces, > Or purchased any books with the solution. > But I'm gonna get that bottom line > If it takes all my time, > Cause I don't want to add to next year's resolutions. > Whether by skill or by luck, > There's no choice but to mix it back up. > > Where will I be when old Rubik's stops challenging me. > > It's longer than that and maybe not in the right order, but you get > the jist. Anyway, it was actually a catchy melody and I really liked > it! So any help finding it would be greatly appreciated. > > The last song I first heard during Comedy Central's "Premium Blend" a > few years back. I'm pretty sure he was the last performer to go on. > It was more silly (like the Baron Knights song) but still not bad. > Anyway, here's what I remember of it: > > Hello operator can you get me Hungry? > I've got to talk to Erno Rubik 'bout this problem you see. > ... > (chorus) > Rubik's cube, it's driving me crazy! > I'm about to peal the stickers off > 'Cause I'm too stupid and lazy. > > Sorry, that was a loooong time ago that I heard that so I don't > remember very much of it. > > At any rate, those are the only cube songs I know about (though lots > actually mention the cube without being about it!) So if you guys > have any more or know which these are, I'd appreciate it! > > Thanks! > Daniel

i have found somethings on watermans method this is the only stuff i've found that i've remotely able to understand there is a downloadable section at the bottom with a complete book, if anyone makes heads or tails out of it and want to do some website work to turn this into something understandable, i'd be game on helping out --- Tyson Mao <tmao@...> wrote: > There aren't any resources for this mysterious > "Waterman" method. I > have no idea who Mark Waterman is and the only thing > I know about his > method is that it has something to do with corner's > first but it > doesn't seem there is anything on the internet to > teach these things. > > Can someone direct me to the "Waterman" method? I > am relatively new to > cubing so as far as I know, it's just a myth... > kinda like Loch Ness > and the Yeti. These legendary things but why should > I believe it if I > haven't seen it? > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Sep 8, 2005, at 2:04 PM, Dwayne wrote: > > > Hey all, > > > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when > all I seem to hear > > about is that the Waterman method is the most > efficient. 1811. Re: Waterman Method
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 21:34:42 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > There aren't any resources for this mysterious "Waterman" method. I > have no idea who Mark Waterman is and the only thing I know about his > method is that it has something to do with corner's first but it > doesn't seem there is anything on the internet to teach these things. > > Can someone direct me to the "Waterman" method? I am relatively new to > cubing so as far as I know, it's just a myth... kinda like Loch Ness > and the Yeti. These legendary things but why should I believe it if I > haven't seen it? Loch Ness isn't a myth. Here's a picture of it: http://www.scotland-flavour.co.uk/highlands_pictures/highlands_loch_ness_0136.jpg It's almost 1000 feet deep and is 24 miles long so it could hardly be described as a myth. I've been there before. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Sep 8, 2005, at 2:04 PM, Dwayne wrote: > > > Hey all, > > > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear > > about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. Is this like > > a what came first question: Chicken/Egg? Is it worth learning... (Do > > many people practice this method?). Let's have a show of hands!! Any > > info would be greatly appreciated. > > > > BTW almost sub-30 (30.4 Ave) > > Thanks > > Dwayne > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1812. Re: [Speed cubing group] Waterman Method link
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 21:45:30 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Clancy Cochran <perscription_death@y...> wrote: > duh forgot to paste the link :p > > http://rubikscube.info/waterman/index.html An interesting quote from this site: "We tried to do 41 cubes in less then 15 minutes, we nearly succeeded! In this period I met Anneke Treep and entered CFF (Cubism For Fun, the Dutch cube association). I did contests with Guus Razoux-Schultz at his home, and won most times. We practised together very often, we learned each others method. We even did contests, using each others method, and became as fast as 40 seconds!" 40 seconds was obviously a time to get excited about (even if it was a different method would they be so happy if they were much faster using their own methods) so a very good time for 41 cubes would be 41*40 seconds = 1640 seconds which is 27 minutes 20 seconds. Could it be that they tried to solve 41 cubes between them (i.e. about 20.5 cubes each)? That would then be 13 minutes 40 (on a very good time) so allowing for less good times and tiredness setting in 15 minutes could be still a good time. Or could it be that 40 seconds with a different method seemed extraordinary (in which case, what time would be realistic from their own methods)? It doesn't seem to add up to me.
1813. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Waterman Method
From: Franois Sechet <frsechet@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 00:30:01 +0200

I'm pretty sure he meant the monster that's supposed to live in there. You know, the thing that's greenish-brownish, that throws boats to the ground, only comes out when it's foggy and most importantly, is between 50 and 300 feet long depending on the witness and the quantity of guiness left in the glass in front of him. And it IS a myth. No monster in there. GameOfDeath2 a crit : > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: > > There aren't any resources for this mysterious "Waterman" method. I > > have no idea who Mark Waterman is and the only thing I know about his > > method is that it has something to do with corner's first but it > > doesn't seem there is anything on the internet to teach these things. > > > > Can someone direct me to the "Waterman" method? I am relatively new to > > cubing so as far as I know, it's just a myth... kinda like Loch Ness > > and the Yeti. These legendary things but why should I believe it if I > > haven't seen it? > > Loch Ness isn't a myth. Here's a picture of it: > > http://www.scotland-flavour.co.uk/highlands_pictures/highlands_loch_ness_0136.jpg > > It's almost 1000 feet deep and is 24 miles long so it could hardly be > described as a myth. > I've been there before. > > > > > Tyson Mao > > MSC #631 > > California Institute of Technology > > > > On Sep 8, 2005, at 2:04 PM, Dwayne wrote: > > > > > Hey all, > > > > > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear > > > about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. Is this like > > > a what came first question: Chicken/Egg? Is it worth learning... (Do > > > many people practice this method?). Let's have a show of hands!! Any > > > info would be greatly appreciated. > > > > > > BTW almost sub-30 (30.4 Ave) > > > Thanks > > > Dwayne > > > > > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=irjrM9wdJDBnytECiSfUCw> > Free puzzle inlay games > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=5IEF0wvHk31uvuXI6ReWEw> > Educational game and puzzle > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=37T2K_4zOte4R94IVKMFNQ> > > Word puzzle game > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Word+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=3DsIilZKH4dSS_WgIx9QRg> > Kid puzzle game > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Kid+puzzle+game&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=2-DgzSlkRkTyIak1hdhkgQ> > Puzzle games > <http://groups.yahoo.com/gads?t=ms&k=Puzzle+games&w1=Jigsaw+puzzle+game&w2=Free+puzzle+inlay+games&w3=Educational+game+and+puzzle&w4=Word+puzzle+game&w5=Kid+puzzle+game&w6=Puzzle+games&c=6&s=147&.sig=EJHY58oeC85Up2uB7KhBMA> > > > > ------------------------------------------------------------------------ > YAHOO! Rubik's Cube is Driving me Crazy!" by Crazy Davis. Crazy Davis is the
alter ego of Eric Drysdale who write's for Comedy Central's "The Daily
Show" -- a fantastic show IMHO.

I could have a copy of the song and if I could post it to the group.

1816. Re: [Speed cubing group] Waterman Method link
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>

Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 22:46:33 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > Could it be that they tried to solve 41 cubes between them (i.e. about 20.5 cubes each)? The booklet explicitly says Mark averaged 18 seconds. But first I was wondering the same as you ;-) Cheers! Stefan
1817. Re: [Speed cubing group] Waterman Method
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 2005 23:50:33 +0100

There are lots of other methods out there both discovered and undiscovered.
I'm an old cuber which means I'm biased towards those who find there own way
:) Waterman exists. Fridrich is fantastically clever and has been refined
by so many people it probably is the best full method for becoming a top
speedcuber but that doesn't mean it always will be. Go out and find your
own way!

Duncan




1818. Re: Waterman Method
From: "Brent Morgan" <brentmorganmaster@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Sep 2005 22:54:17 -0000

The Waterman Method is not "mysterious" at all, and there are sources
of it online. Josef Jelinek made a site that explicitly demonstrates
the method in full detail and recently had Waterman's permission to
have it fully published on the www.rubiks.info site. A few people I
know in here are learning/use it (Josef himself, Mike Atkinson...).
Not sure if some of them gave it up or not, but I think it has
something to do with (or a variation of) David Allen's method back in
wc2003. Might wanna check the forum database for this stuff... :)
-Brent Morgan

1823. Re: Cube song help - found them all!
From: "Daniel Hayes" <swedishlf@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 06:20:28 -0000

OK, sorry to spam the boards guys but I this was driving me crazy.
Last post on the subject, I promise! I've been searching all day and
finally found out every thing I need to know.

Song 1 - You folks were kind enough to point me to a download of "Mr.
Rubik" By The Barron Knights. That was the easy one!

Song 2 - After much searching, the secret lies in post number 2715 of
our very own group. The song is "Rubik's Cube" by the Amateur Lovers
off the 1997 album Virgin White Lies. I posted it on www.putfile.com
, which I've never used before so let me know if it works:
http://media.putfile.com/RubiksCube26 It's a fantastic song, and
there were many responses to the original post about it. Odd that
none of us remembered them.

Song 3 - "This Rubik's Cube is Driving me Crazy!" - Eric Drysdale
Originally aired on Comedy Central's Premium Blend episode 307 and (I
think) can be found on Comic Remix episode 116. I'll have to keep an
eye out on the comedy central tv listings, and see if Mr. Drysdale
responds to my request. I'd like to have a copy of it.

Other songs I found during the search:
"Your Cat Can do the Cube" - Ronnie Allen & the Missing Pieces from
The Dr. Demento Show #82-41 - 10/10/82

"I can't do The Cube" - Ronnie Allen & the Missing Pieces

"The Cube" - Bob Jenkins

"Cubic Refugee" - Stevens & Grdnic (not a typo) from The Dr. Demento
Show #82-22 - May 30, 1982

I have been unable to find copies of any of these yet, though I do
have partial lyrics for some.

Thanks for the help, and I'm happy I can finally sleep!

-Daniel

1825. RE: [Speed cubing group] Orange stickerz....
From: "Beer, Bram de" <bbeer@...>

Easiest way to solve the whitening orange stickers is just to take them off. Then you have black instead of orange, which works fine for me... -----Oorspronkelijk bericht----- Van: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com [mailto:speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com]Namens Andreas Renberg Verzonden: donderdag 8 september 2005 23:13 Aan: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Onderwerp: Re: [Speed cubing group] Orange stickerz.... Yeah, i have a 4x4 not verry used that i lended out to a friend, and when it came back 2 of the orange pices are instead white, but since it was scrambled i didnt notice, so while solving it i couldnt find a pice, so i scolded my friend and got mad at him because i thought he had swapped the stickers, ooops... :) there is a thin layer on the orange sticker pice that peels off to easily, the whole sticker doesnt peel.... --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Sachin Shirwalkar <sachinss@g...> wrote: > I dont have orange stickers on my cube. 1827. 4x4 Methods/Limits
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 08:22:22 -0000

With November rapidly approaching and in light of the recent
achievments of some of the elite, I have some questions about what the
possible limits of 4x4ing are.

I know most of the top cubers feel that sub-60 is realistically
achievable. I'm curious what they feel the fastest possible average
will be.

I'm also curious about the current average move counts of the faster
solvers out there for centers first, but also for other systems. I've
come up with an edges first method that works great for me, and I'm
curious how it compares.

With the method I use, a good solve without the hard parity generally
runs about 130 moves. With the hard parity it's about 140. A good
solve without either parity is around 120 to 125. Now, my times with
this are still pretty high (2 min. on average), but that works out to
a little over 1 move per second. I suspect the top solvers are moving
at twice this speed.

Because it's edges first, there are a lot of slice moves. Probably
many more than a centers first method. This will perhaps make it
slower overall than centers first, but I wonder how much. This method
affords excellent look ahead, but is that enough to offset the
possible extra moves and more slice turns?

Currently, I'm averaging something like 49-50 seconds for the two
1x3x4 blocks on L and R, around 40-41 for the U layer corners and the
edge pairing and placement, and 34-35 for the centers. I'm 100%
certain these times could be much lower with more effort. I think
more specialized algorithms would help for both the centers stage and
for edge pairing. I also think I could benefit from learning more
algs for the two centers I begin with. It often takes me 10 or more
seconds for the first two centers alone. As I understand it, that's
only a little less than it takes some people to solve all 6.

Another area I think could stand some improvement is the final centers
stage. I'm left with 4 centers in the M slice. I really only use a
few cases to solve everything. Once I get the hang of solving 3
cycles, though, it should go much faster. I can't seem to find the
alg anywhere that swaps 3 opposite center cubies, though. I know
someone mentioned it in a post on here, but I can't find it.

Based on how efficient my solving currently is, improvement to sub-30
for the first step, 25-30 for the second, and sub-25 for the third
should be easily attainable. This still comes out to 80-85 seconds,
but that's a far cry from my 150 pb with centers first. I know that
if someone were to put as much effort into this method as some people
are putting into centers first, this could be taken much farther than
I am, but I suppose laziness strikes again...

Anyway, I guess this wraps up my late night ramble. Thanks for
reading if you made it this far. ;) Happy (big) cubing.

-Mike Bennett




1828. Re: a comp in colorado?
From: turtleparadise <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 08:32:58 -0000

I'm in Honolulu. I too feel marooned with no other cubers or competition around. I would love to start a Honolulu cube club that meets once every 3 months for competition and sharing of ideas. But atlas... people here are more interested in surfing and hula. Being 13 is a good thing and not a problem! Those were the good ol' days for many other reasons. When I was in junior high I knew only one other kid that could solve the cube. When I was in high school, I was the only cubist. :( Aloha! --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "rubikorkow" <calcdude@h...> wrote: > Hey, im dying for a competetion, but the problem is, im 13, and i live > in colorado. So I was thinkning of organizing a competition here. But > i was wondering if anyone would be interested in actually coming. > Colorado Springs to be exact.
1829. Re: Waterman Method
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 09:20:09 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@n...> wrote: > Hey all, > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. Is this like a what came first question: Chicken/Egg? Is it worth learning... (Do many people practice this method?). Let's have a show of hands!! Any info would be greatly appreciated. You can be sub-15 with a method like Waterman's. I think nobody knows all the sequences described in this method. Gilles.
1830. Re: Orange stickerz... born again, again

at

despite my forgetting to use the keyword "Amen". You will have to
click on the cherubs a few times if you want to find it.

The owner of the site appears to be a Sudoku fanatic and a programmer.
Perhaps that helps explain his tolerance... I am unsure how or when God
will make His reply, as He is said to move in mysterious ways. But I
am full of Hope.

1831. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 Methods/Limits
From: "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 9 Sep 2005 11:44:37 +0100

I havent checked this out but it seems to me that the number of seconds to be really world class to solve a cube is around about (maybe a bit less than!) the number of cubies in that cube. That would mean under 20 seconds for 3x3x3, 56 seconds for 4x4x4 and 1 minute 32 seconds for 5x5x5. Just a rule of thumb and I dont actually know what good times for 5x5x5 are - I suspect that they aren't quite that fast - yet! Anyway one cubie per second solving sounds like a reasonable goal. Maybe it gives us a target for the 6x6x6 too. Duncan ----- Original Message ----- From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...> To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Friday, September 09, 2005 9:22 AM Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 Methods/Limits > With November rapidly approaching and in light of the recent > achievments of some of the elite, I have some questions about what the > possible limits of 4x4ing are. > > I know most of the top cubers feel that sub-60 is realistically > achievable. I'm curious what they feel the fastest possible average > will be. > > I'm also curious about the current average move counts of the faster > solvers out there for centers first, but also for other systems. I've > come up with an edges first method that works great for me, and I'm > curious how it compares. > > With the method I use, a good solve without the hard parity generally > runs about 130 moves. With the hard parity it's about 140. A good > solve without either parity is around 120 to 125. Now, my times with > this are still pretty high (2 min. on average), but that works out to > a little over 1 move per second. I suspect the top solvers are moving > at twice this speed. > > Because it's edges first, there are a lot of slice moves. Probably > many more than a centers first method. This will perhaps make it > slower overall than centers first, but I wonder how much. This method > affords excellent look ahead, but is that enough to offset the > possible extra moves and more slice turns? > > Currently, I'm averaging something like 49-50 seconds for the two > 1x3x4 blocks on L and R, around 40-41 for the U layer corners and the > edge pairing and placement, and 34-35 for the centers. I'm 100% > certain these times could be much lower with more effort. I think > more specialized algorithms would help for both the centers stage and > for edge pairing. I also think I could benefit from learning more > algs for the two centers I begin with. It often takes me 10 or more > seconds for the first two centers alone. As I understand it, that's > only a little less than it takes some people to solve all 6. > > Another area I think could stand some improvement is the final centers > stage. I'm left with 4 centers in the M slice. I really only use a > few cases to solve everything. Once I get the hang of solving 3 > cycles, though, it should go much faster. I can't seem to find the > alg anywhere that swaps 3 opposite center cubies, though. I know > someone mentioned it in a post on here, but I can't find it. > > Based on how efficient my solving currently is, improvement to sub-30 > for the first step, 25-30 for the second, and sub-25 for the third > should be easily attainable. This still comes out to 80-85 seconds, > but that's a far cry from my 150 pb with centers first. I know that > if someone were to put as much effort into this method as some people > are putting into centers first, this could be taken much farther than > I am, but I suppose laziness strikes again... > > Anyway, I guess this wraps up my late night ramble. Thanks for > reading if you made it this far. ;) Happy (big) cubing. > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > >
1832. Re : Waterman Method
From: "Nathan Moreau" <nathan.m@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 13:10:30 -0000

>You can be sub-15 with a method like Waterman's.
>I think nobody knows all the sequences described in this method.

>Gilles.


Complete ZB is easier to learn :)
Start with "Solving L" step is slow, compare to F2L (averaging 8-9 for
F2L = averaging ... 4-5 for L?).
If someone really wants to learn something like Waterman, learning
Gilles' method !





1833. Re: Waterman Method
From: "Josef Jelinek" <josef.jelinek@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 13:16:04 -0000

Hey Gilles, I am nobody according to your opinion? :-) Well, I know all the algs of the method, however, I know just optimal ones (in UMR group, generated by ACube); the original method contains some algs that are longer (all found 'manually' by Marc, Daan, and some others). The point is that unlike Fridrich and similar methods, the sequences can be learned by understanding what is to be accomplished. Knowing background of the last step of the Gilles's method may help in this. I still have to improve a lot (I average low 20s now - even without fingertricks...). I agree with Gilles, that you can get 15s with this or similar method. I saw video of Marc doing 42 cubes bellow 17min with many mistakes and some pops and obviously crap stiff cubes. He used absolutely NO fingetricks and M, M', M2 doing always like r'R, rR', and r2R2... Josef --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@n...> > wrote: > > Hey all, > > > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear > about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. Is this like a > what came first question: Chicken/Egg? Is it worth learning... (Do many > people practice this method?). Let's have a show of hands!! Any info > would be greatly appreciated. > > > You can be sub-15 with a method like Waterman's. > I think nobody knows all the sequences described in this method. > > Gilles.

Marc Waterman > is the fastest i saw until now but he lost interest in he cube. He > became a farmer on reform products." > > just wondering what is a farmer on reform products? > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" > <ddollard@n...> wrote: > > Hey all, > > > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear > about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. 1835. Re: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 Methods/Limits
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 13:27:05 -0000

Hi! I have been thinking about this for a while without posting about it. My cage method for 4x4x4 requires about 145-150 moves. And i have achieved averages of about 70 secs and lower for that. So that's slight above 2 moves/sec. The way i see it there are 2 aspects to how fast u can solve a twisty puzzle. One is og course the solution length. And the other is turning speed. Im a firm believer that eventually it's the method with higher turning speed that will be the best. In order to achieve high turning speed 2 things are required. Good lookahead and predictability of where cubies will end up after an algorithm (sequence of moves). Good lookahead leads to shorter delays between successive algorithms. Moving only a few pieces by each algorithm makes it easier to track cubies and hence makes it easier to prepare for next sequence of moves. I have strong doubts it will be possible to solve 1 cubie/sec for larger cubes than 5x5x5. Even for 5x5x5 im not really close to that on average. There is too large "search space" as the puzzles go larger (have more parts/cubies). Maybe others have an opinion about this ?? Have fun !! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Duncan Dicks" <duncan@d...> wrote: > I havent checked this out but it seems to me that the number of seconds to > be really world class to solve a cube is around about (maybe a bit less > than!) the number of cubies in that cube. That would mean under 20 seconds > for 3x3x3, 56 seconds for 4x4x4 and 1 minute 32 seconds for 5x5x5. Just a > rule of thumb and I dont actually know what good times for 5x5x5 are - I > suspect that they aren't quite that fast - yet! Anyway one cubie per second > solving sounds like a reasonable goal. Maybe it gives us a target for the > 6x6x6 too. > > Duncan > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@h...> > To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Friday, September 09, 2005 9:22 AM > Subject: [Speed cubing group] 4x4 Methods/Limits > > > > With November rapidly approaching and in light of the recent > > achievments of some of the elite, I have some questions about what the > > possible limits of 4x4ing are. > > > > I know most of the top cubers feel that sub-60 is realistically > > achievable. I'm curious what they feel the fastest possible average > > will be. > > > > I'm also curious about the current average move counts of the faster > > solvers out there for centers first, but also for other systems. I've > > come up with an edges first method that works great for me, and I'm > > curious how it compares. > > > > With the method I use, a good solve without the hard parity generally > > runs about 130 moves. With the hard parity it's about 140. A good > > solve without either parity is around 120 to 125. Now, my times with > > this are still pretty high (2 min. on average), but that works out to > > a little over 1 move per second. I suspect the top solvers are moving > > at twice this speed. > > > > Because it's edges first, there are a lot of slice moves. Probably > > many more than a centers first method. This will perhaps make it > > slower overall than centers first, but I wonder how much. This method > > affords excellent look ahead, but is that enough to offset the > > possible extra moves and more slice turns? > > > > Currently, I'm averaging something like 49-50 seconds for the two > > 1x3x4 blocks on L and R, around 40-41 for the U layer corners and the > > edge pairing and placement, and 34-35 for the centers. I'm 100% > > certain these times could be much lower with more effort. I think > > more specialized algorithms would help for both the centers stage and > > for edge pairing. I also think I could benefit from learning more > > algs for the two centers I begin with. It often takes me 10 or more > > seconds for the first two centers alone. As I understand it, that's > > only a little less than it takes some people to solve all 6. > > > > Another area I think could stand some improvement is the final centers > > stage. I'm left with 4 centers in the M slice. I really only use a > > few cases to solve everything. Once I get the hang of solving 3 > > cycles, though, it should go much faster. I can't seem to find the > > alg anywhere that swaps 3 opposite center cubies, though. I know > > someone mentioned it in a post on here, but I can't find it. > > > > Based on how efficient my solving currently is, improvement to sub-30 > > for the first step, 25-30 for the second, and sub-25 for the third > > should be easily attainable. This still comes out to 80-85 seconds, > > but that's a far cry from my 150 pb with centers first. I know that > > if someone were to put as much effort into this method as some people > > are putting into centers first, this could be taken much farther than > > I am, but I suppose laziness strikes again... > > > > Anyway, I guess this wraps up my late night ramble. Thanks for > > reading if you made it this far. ;) Happy (big) cubing. > > > > -Mike Bennett > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
1836. Re: Re : Waterman Method
From: "Josef Jelinek" <josef.jelinek@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 13:52:08 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Nathan Moreau" <nathan.m@n...> wrote: > >You can be sub-15 with a method like Waterman's. > >I think nobody knows all the sequences described in this method. > > >Gilles. > > > Complete ZB is easier to learn :) That smiley shows that you - obviously - cannot be serious here... :) > Start with "Solving L" step is slow, compare to F2L (averaging 8-9 for > F2L = averaging ... 4-5 for L?). Fast Fridrich cubers do ~32 turns for F2L (corrent me if I am wrong). 8-9s is 3.5-4 turns/s. I average 16 turns for one layer (always the same color). Marc averaged about 6-7s for one face... After solving remaining corners (2-3s), you can be still bellow 10s and you are left with two steps and the last easy middle edge permutation which is around 22 turns total... > If someone really wants to learn something like Waterman, learning > Gilles' method ! Yes, it may be better for someone... Everyone can find the best-fitting method for himself (maybe even herself? :-)). Josef

<tomiante@...>, David Mills <davidomills@...>, Chris Morris <camjmm@...>, Janna Morris <janna200121@...>, Mike Noll <MNoll45854@...>, Kimberly O'Planick <koplan@...>, Melanie Ohtan <melohtan@...>, Danielle Paredes <dparedes01@...>, Krista Paterson <goodgirl782001@...>, Frances Perkins <plantcityhome@...>, PhiSigmaPi <PSP-TALK@...>, Tamojit Ray <tamojitray@...>, Jeremy Reed <extreme_30@...>, Bryan Rogomentick <brogomen@...>, Autumn Ross <ajsmiley@...>, Nikolaus Rotzinger <laxgoalie17@...>, Joseph Roybal <bananarepub1ic@...>, Amy S <coffee_bean15@...>, Andrea Scott <ars773s@...>, Lucas Shiver <lucasshiver@...>, Rubix Speed Solving <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, Christopher Stueve <chs139s@...>, Fred Toothman <toothman3@...>, Erin Waldron <ewaldron@...>, Brittany Warren <bwarren@...>, Nicole Winters <nicole_winters@...>
Date: Fri, 9 Sep 2005 08:19:54 -0700 (PDT)

I just thought that I would pass this along to those
who may be interested.

Want to know how to solve the cube? Already know how
to solve? Just want to watch (and be amazed)? Please
feel free to join them no matter your skill level.
Gather tips from some of the best speedcubers in the
world. Some of the attendees are 5x5 unofficial world
record holder Frank Morris, sub-20 solver Chris Hunt
and many local cubers (range of solve times 30 secs to
a min) and many other local people. Get information
on the recent Cal-Tech Dallas Tournament, the upcoming
World Championships in Orlando and much more. Prizes
are supplied by 7 Towns and the competition is
sponsored by the Idaho Speedcubing Club.

For more information on cubing (and speedcubing)
please see the following links
isconline.tk
www.speedcubing.com

Please pass this along to friends, family, coworkers
that may be interested or who can cube themselves.

"Hope you have the time of your life" - GD
Christy (Crispy)




______________________________________________________
Click here to donate to the Hurricane Katrina relief effort.
http://store.yahoo.com/redcross-donate3/

1845. Re: Waterman Method
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 16:32:31 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Dwayne" <ddollard@n...> wrote: > Hey all, > > Why is Fridrich the most popular method when all I seem to hear about is that the Waterman method is the most efficient. Is this like a what came first question: Chicken/Egg? Is it worth learning... (Do many people practice this method?). Let's have a show of hands!! Any info would be greatly appreciated. > > BTW almost sub-30 (30.4 Ave) > Thanks > Dwayne > > [Non-text portions of this message have been removed] Hi Dwayne, I think that the Fridrich method was the first method to be posted online which could produce times near 20 seconds, and enthusiastic cubers like Chris and Ron helped make it popular, and developed it more. Cheers, David J
1846. Your own method and algs
From: "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 16:40:42 -0000

Is there anyone here who uses their own method and uses only their own
algorithms? Or is everyone here using other's methods and algorithms?

What percentage of the algorithms you use that you didn't learn from
others, but developed yourself?

David J

1849. Re: Your own method and algs
From: mike_go_uk <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 18:58:26 -0000

Hi David, --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Is there anyone here who uses their own method and uses only their own > algorithms? Or is everyone here using other's methods and algorithms? I don't really count as a speedcuber, but I use my own LBL method, with 3-look LL. Mostly my own simple algs. > What percentage of the algorithms you use that you didn't learn from > others, but developed yourself? Sorry, I can't quote a percentage: there is more than one way to do the counting, and I use some simple conjugates of a couple of the algs -- I wouldn't know how many times to count those! But of the ones I /didn't/ work out myself: 1 sequence was from Singmaster's Notes... possibly 2 (it's too long ago to be sure now) 1 came from Helmstetter's tables (but I should be using more) 4 were computed using ACube (but I've only learnt 3 -- the fourth covers a fairly rare case) And yes, I'm lazy. :) Mike
1850. PB in Super Mario Bros
From: "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@...>

I know this is not really the best place to post this but I'm so happy
with this that I want to share it with you :

I have a NES console at home with the wonderful game Super Mario Bros
(1) and I just managed a very good PB of 7 minutes and 37 seconds to
finish it.

I'm not really sure sub7 minutes is possible but I'll try it.

Do you know if a there is some sort of SpeedMarioBrossing sport or
anything ? :P

Now, let's get back to serious stuff : the cube. :P

Thanks,
Gilles.
