1855. Re: Your own method and algs
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 21:50:27 -0000

Hi! All the stuff i use for any size cube is all mine. I use a pretty basic LBL for 3x3x3 and average on average mid to low 20's. For larger cubes i use sorta LBL also. I call it the cage method: i build first layer complete, middle layers edges, last layer corners, last layer edges (and parity)and then finally all the remaining centers. If i switch to a better f2l or LL for 3x3x3 i will learn algs from sites or reinvent them somehow ;-) That would be my first "cube-cheating" ;-) Have fun !! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Burton" <bob@c...> wrote: > > Is there anyone here who uses their own method and uses only their own > > algorithms? Or is everyone here using other's methods and algorithms? > > Not me. > > > What percentage of the algorithms you use that you didn't learn from > > others, but developed yourself? > > maybe 5-10% if you exclude F2L. Those aren't necessarily algs, unless > you want to call them so. In that case, change 5-10% to 20-25 :) > > ~ Bob
1856. Re: 4x4 Methods/Limits
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

1857. From a old post...
From: "G. Carter S." <e_book_worm@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Sep 2005 22:02:33 -0000

Hello, I was about to make a post on a neat thread when I realized
that it was a bit old, so here is just some thoughts on blind cubing
that I was going to toss in.

If any of you have gotten a cube (or megaminx or any other) from
mefert's then youve probably seen the neat tiles that he uses instead
of stickers. These have a bunch of little grooves that add a nice
little texture. And, on a perfectly solved cube or minx ect. all the
lines go in one direction (which adds a nice level of difficulty when
you have to acount for center square orientation for all faces of a
3x3x3). Draw a arrow on your centers and you'll get the idea. :)
Any-whoo, Duct-tape, grip tape, vinyl tape, fine grit sanpaper, and
your standard stickers would be all you would need to start getting
used to blind, and maby start texturing 2 or more faces the same once
you wanted to. Just some thoughts, happy cubing.
Carter.


I'd also LOVE to see some more thoughts on solving when you have to
acount for center face orientation or if there are any cool
observations already known about it. I got started looking into this
when one of my cubes had the rubiks logo on the white center sticker...

Have a good one.

1864. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Your own method and algs
From: "Ron van Bruchem" <ron@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 08:03:23 +0200

Hi Clancy, Many things were invented by more than one person independently. Same goes for cross/F2L/OLL/PLL system. Jessica was one of them, but she was the first who published the system on internet. Even the cube itself was invented by more than 1 person. And ZB system. Because of Jessica (and the fact that it is a very good system and that most people copy what is good) the cross/F2L/OLL/PLL system has become so popular. Have fun, Ron ----- Original Message ----- From: Clancy Cochran To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Saturday, September 10, 2005 5:01 AM Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Your own method and algs actually jessica didn't invent the method, it just kind of took her name on, ron pointed out to me that it was published in a book 1981, long before jessica posted, i guess the proper terminology is 'cfop' for the method (Cross, F2l, Oll, Pll) --- Craig Bouchard <logitewty@...> wrote: > If I had to bet a million dollars on this...I'd say > Jessica Fridrich > uses her own method :D Thought I'd be the smart-ass > :) > > Craig > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > "d_j_salvia" > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > Hi Everyone, > > > > Is there anyone here who uses their own method and > uses only their own > > algorithms? 1870. Re: PB in Super Mario Bros
From: "Jason Baum" <speedrunningcuber@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 15:39:41 -0000

Hi,

Just to clear up a few things. Bisqwit's site should not be taken
seriously as an official world record video game site. The videos on
Bisqwit's site were all done by manipulating emulators to play the
game literally frame by frame, and re-records so that if you mess up
you can just go back and fix it. Most of the videos on that site took
literally tens of thousands of re-records while playing at super slow
motion. The purpose of Bisqwit's site is to make videos showing a
game being played theoretically to perfection.

The official site for speed video game accomplishments is
www.speeddemosarchive.com. www.twingalaxies.com is another one. The
videos you see here are all 100% legit, played on a real console and
all painstakingly verified as such. So, if you want to see the TRUE
world records for speed video games, www.speeddemosarchive.com is the
only place. If you want to see a bunch of low skilled gamers who make
fake videos and try to pass them off as real, legit records, easily
fooling the casual audience, then maybe Bisqwit's site is your place.

I used to be really into speed running video games myself (hence my
user name). There has long been animosity between Bisqwit's site and
the real speed runners, if you couldn't tell from my last paragraph
;P. A run that I highly recommend watching on speeddemosarchive.com
is the Super Mario World 96 exit run. ;)

1872. sub 30 cuber by 8 seconds!!
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 16:15:40 -0000

Previous Personal Best Average: 30.32 sec
New Personal Best Average: 22.22 sec

18.45 24.98 23.12 (27.67) 20.76 25.1 18.83 25.97 (18.23) 18.29 23.17
23.56

It is a RA by the way.

I was just thinking this morning, "I may be quite a while till I beat
my 30 second average."

But then I sat down and started getting a bunch of 24's. In the middle
of the average I started getting nervous and got some 30's and 35's.
And then I realized what had happened:

Slowing down really did make go faster.

By more than 8 seconds.

Jessica was > one of them, but she was > the first who published the system on internet. > Even the cube itself was invented by more than 1 > person. And ZB system. > > Because of Jessica (and the fact that it is a very > good system and that most > people copy what is good) the cross/F2L/OLL/PLL > system has become so > popular. > > Have fun, > > Ron > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: Clancy Cochran > To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com > Sent: Saturday, September 10, 2005 5:01 AM > Subject: Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Your own > method and algs > > > actually jessica didn't invent the method, it just > kind of took her name on, ron pointed out to me that > it was published in a book 1981, long before jessica > posted, i guess the proper terminology is 'cfop' for > the method (Cross, F2l, Oll, Pll) > > --- Craig Bouchard <logitewty@...> wrote: > > > If I had to bet a million dollars on this...I'd > say > > Jessica Fridrich > > uses her own method :D Thought I'd be the > smart-ass > > :) > > > > Craig > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, > > "d_j_salvia" > > <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > > > Hi Everyone, > > > > > > Is there anyone here who uses their own method > and > > uses only their own > > > algorithms? Or is everyone here using other's > > methods and algorithms? > > > > > > What percentage of the algorithms you use that > you > > didn't learn from > > > others, but developed yourself? > > > > > > David J > > > > > > > > > > > > ______________________________________________________ > Click here to donate to the Hurricane Katrina relief > effort. > http://store.yahoo.com/redcross-donate3/ > > > SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay > games Educational game > and puzzle > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > > > YAHOO! GROUPS LINKS > > Visit your group "speedsolvingrubikscube" on the > web. > > To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: > speedsolvingrubikscube-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com > > Your use of Yahoo! 1876. F2L stats
From: j3pinter <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 17:32:26 -0000

Hi all,

I am interested in stats (using the Fridrich method)
of people in this group:
- how much time does it take you to solve F2L?
- how much time does ik take you to solve the whole cube?

Same goes for number of moves (when trying to go for
speed, not for minimal number of moves):
- how many moves does it take you to solve F2L?
- how many moves does ik take you to solve the whole cube?

Please take the average of many cubes (e.g., 30, 50, 100).

To start, mine are:
F2L 21.34 sec (61.5% of total)
all 34.70 sec

F2L 32.97 moves (56.0% of total)
all 58.90 moves

Dennis




1877. Re: Argh + J.color scheme
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 17:37:46 -0000

Sorry, didn't realize the auction rule. The gist of it is, both pics
can be rotated so that red is on top and yellow is front-left. The
first one shows white at front-right and the second shows blue at front-
right. This isn't just a weird color scheme; it's impossible.

By the way, I'm one of the few who prefers the Japanese, or white-blue
color scheme. I guess that's b/c the very first cube I had (Ideal
plastic cylinder no less!) was that way. But also, I tend to want what
I can't have. Back in the 80's, virtually all cubes were white-blue.
I wanted white-yellow to match the TV commercial. So I rearranged the
stickers, ruining a few in the process.

Now that white-yellow is all that's available in the US, I want white-
blue. So I rearranged the stickers, ruining a few in the
process...Wish they'd just offer both at the same time.

Any other white-blue fans (outside Japan)?

KK

> Please better no links to auctions that aren't over yet.
> The cube is perfectly alright, nothing unusual about it. Note there's
> one front and one back picture.
>
> Stefan

1888. Re: Argh + auction rule?!
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 21:33:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk <no_reply@y. ..> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" > <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > > Sorry, didn't realize the auction rule. > > Is there such a rule? There is one at the twistypuzzles.com, but I > don't see why we should respect that convention here. Just in case somebody doesn't know that one and is interested, here it is: http://www.twistypuzzles.com/forumrules.shtml (and see item 3) The explanation for the rule makes sense to me, that's why I myself try to respect it here as well. If you link to an active auction then probably you're not interested in buying the item yourself (or you're rich, but I think we can ignore this case). So what's the point in showing everybody and annoying/upsetting the people who are interested and have found it already? If there's something interesting in it and you'd like to talk about it, why not simply wait until it's over? Stefan

1893. Re: F2L stats
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 22:59:31 -0000

Very similar to my method. I do OC then OE...a throwback to James Nourse's "Simple Solution" book. I do know all the PLL's but I'm still slower than you! Which 3 have you yet to learn? The last and hardest one for me to learn was Fridrich's "G" which I like to call the "Flag". Anyways I don't have my precise stats but I'm probably about 40 moves for the F2L and 65 for the cube. My F2L is very high for two reasons, 1) I suck at the cross and 2) I cannot recognize F2L patterns to save my life, so I make a ton of extra U-turns. If I want to align the red-white-green corner and red-green edge, for example, I have to move that corner between the red and green sides or I cannot see how to do it. Timewise I'm averaging about 30-32s for the F2L and 50-52s for the whole cube. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j3pinter <no_reply@y...> wrote: > You are right, I do a 3-look LL: > OE, OC, PLL > (and I do not know all PLL yet, still missing 3) > > Dennis > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, mike_go_uk > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, j3pinter <no_reply@y...> > > wrote: > > > I am interested in stats (using the Fridrich method) > > > of people in this group: > > > - how many moves does it take you to solve F2L? > > > - how many moves does ik take you to solve the whole cube? > > > To start, mine are: > > > F2L 32.97 moves (56.0% of total) > > > all 58.90 moves > > > > Unless that was from a small sample, I don't think you can be using > > full Fridrich. Or do you make a lot of unnecessary AUFs during the LL? > > > > Can't give my own stats -- non-Fridrich, and I can't "speed"- solve and > > count turns at the same time. I could probably chew gum, though. :D > > > > Mike
1894. Neat algorithm for Fridrich "E"
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 10 Sep 2005 23:07:47 -0000

Possibly old news by now but I learned a new algorithm for the Fridrich
E permute from the Rubiks.com online cube. Maybe not as easy to
execute as the Fridrich but I like it MUCH better because it's more
symmetrical and provides more visual clues. When I'm doing the R B
L... algorithm I get totally lost because I cannot see all the cubies
lining up until the last couple of moves.

Anyways it's L U' R D2 R' U L' R U' L D2 L' U R' which can be adapted
three other ways depending on what your hands like. :)

1900. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>

1901. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 01:02:03 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > I know Chris Hardwick has > (http://www.speedcubing.com/chris/20cube.html) and some dude named > Richard Carr, mentioned on Jessica's page, that I'm not familiar with. > > Me, I just stared at it, clicked randomly a few hundred times, stared > some more, then went to eat dinner. In that link above, Chris talks about the fact that because the centres can be mixed up in lots of ways there are a few solutions to the 20x20x20. The supercube would have only one solution - that's the essential difference.
1902. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 01:03:24 -0000

Hi all, Today I completed the 20x20 super cube. Which was an ambitious attempt, considering; 1) the biggest super cube I've solved is a 3x3, and 2) the biggest normal cube I've solved is a 10x10. By far the most difficult thing for me was solving the 6th center. I didn't know how to 3 cycle centers. With help from Chris and Per I was able to figure this out. Total solving time: 19 hours 37 minutes I lost a lot of time due to mistakes, but without errors I wouldn't have done much better than 10 hours anyway. I had always wanted to solve the 20x20, so it just made sense to me to "go for the gold". Details and screenshots soon to come on my website! Keep an eye out :) www.geocities.com/rubiks_galaxia Happy Cubing! -Richard --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> > wrote: > > ? Sorry, I'm not familiar with the difference?? > > > > > Richard Carr hasn't solved a 20x20x20 supercube - only a 20x20x20 > > cube. > > Marked centres - so the centres have do go in the correct place. I'm not aware of any site > that does nxnxn supercubes.
1903. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 01:06:49 -0000

Hey All,

Alright, Well, let me bring you all up to speed.

A supercube is a cube in which each piece must be properly oriented in
its proper spot, not just any random spot for multiple pieces(such as
on a 5x5 the X and + pieces can be switched around on a regular cube,
but on a supercube they must be in a certain place)

Before Gabbasoft, there was no computer software that would produce a
20x20x20 supercube, and few that would produce a regular.

Chris Hardwick has only solved a regular 20x20x20, not the supercube,
though I am sure that he will at some point attempt the supercube, the
crazy monster that he is...

There are only 7 people on speedcubing.com who have solved a 20x20x20.

Richard Patterson has just become the first person to solve the
20x20x20 Supercube, with a time of 19 hours 37 minutes. I would like
to congratulate him as this is an amazing feat...This was not done all
in one sitting, but in total...If you want any details about the
solve, please ask him, not me.

Craig




1904. Re: Your own method and algs
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 02:27:18 -0000

Hem the rate of posts seem to have sped back up again. If anybody was going to ask this question, I thought it would be you (after reading so many posts, I get a good feel for who tends to post what types of questions :)). For those that don't know: I have my own system and started developing it about 6.5 years ago. I use it in combination with other methodology though. Depending on the inital preinspection I might use GuusR.S. (Fridrich but with CLL/ELL instead). I'll go for Petrus solves about 3% of the time, and a Gilles method solve about 5% of the time... approximately, I really should keep track. I incorporated some ZBF2L algs into my solving (as part of advancing the Petrus method). I know a lot of what I would now like to call "Akimoto algs" or "Akimoto CLL", it was something I started doing accidently, but was motivated when he pointed it out. It's when each CLL case becomes a category of up to 8 cases depending on edge flip... basically I flip edges while doing CLL. (I've killed off a few categories of cases.) I was doing pure CLL/ELL in the first couple years I was working on my system. I don't start with a cross NOR with corners NOR with a "layer". I am a bit ashamed that I have yet to publish it. The algorithms I found using a rather ancient version of ACube (in which I took the original C++ code and modifided it a bit). Then after I wanted shorter c/e pairing algs I used Ron's listing. (But my CLL,ELL,COLL are all found either by trial and error or ACube, or composing algs I know.) I guess I'm holding on to one of the last unpublished *un- catergorizable* methods... well if you can call the Gilles method and Petrus method "block methods" then perhaps so is mine. But is is definately not LBL or CF. Though my steps are *strictly* a bit "modular". (something I thought was kinda cool was the uniquneness of this, as far as I know) And I keep (as in actively use) the entire PLL set, 65% of OLLs, all the COLLs, ELLs, CLLs, and F2L paring algs a subset of the algs needed for this system as it currently stands. (It is)/(I am) currently moving it two directions, adding more of the Lars step 6+7 combinded and ZBF2L. (Though I have decient enough partial edge control to make use of the limited ZBLL algs I know.) It still really helps to have a complete ELL set for backup incase ZB stuff goes wrong though. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > Is there anyone here who uses their own method and uses only their own > algorithms? Or is everyone here using other's methods and algorithms? > > What percentage of the algorithms you use that you didn't learn from > others, but developed yourself? > > David J
1905. Re: Show me how far you can get
From: d_funny007 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 05:34:40 -0000

On lvl 22 and continuing.... haven't really gotten stuck yet, but hopefully I'll begin to see the point of all this... -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Michiel van der Blonk" <blonkm@z...> wrote: > http://oos.moxiecode.com/examples/cubeoban/

That would be something indeed !! ;-) > > Happy cubing :-) > > PK > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Ben King" > <grsbmd@y...> wrote: > > Previous Personal Best Average: 30.32 sec > > New Personal Best Average: 22.22 sec > > > > 18.45 24.98 23.12 (27.67) 20.76 25.1 18.83 25.97 (18.23) 18.29 > 23.17 > > 23.56 > > > > It is a RA by the way. > > > > I was just thinking this morning, "I may be quite a while till I > beat > > my 30 second average." > > > > But then I sat down and started getting a bunch of 24's. In the > middle > > of the average I started getting nervous and got some 30's and > 35's. > > And then I realized what had happened: > > > > Slowing down really did make go faster. > > > > By more than 8 seconds. > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle > Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > YAHOO! 1909. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: sub 30 cuber by 8 seconds!!
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 08:54:24 +0200

hey,

I used to slow down once in a while which gave me a constant progress.

If you are lightning fast for some parts of the cube but damn slow for
others, you should just work a little on the slow part and you'll have
incredible results.

well, congrats :D

1911. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Your own method and algs
From: Anthony Hsu <erwaman@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 07:59:05 -0400

What are your current times with this method? Anthony ----- Original Message ----- From: d_funny007 To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com Sent: Saturday, September 10, 2005 10:27 PM Subject: [Speed cubing group] Re: Your own method and algs Hem the rate of posts seem to have sped back up again. If anybody was going to ask this question, I thought it would be you (after reading so many posts, I get a good feel for who tends to post what types of questions :)). For those that don't know: I have my own system and started developing it about 6.5 years ago. I use it in combination with other methodology though. Depending on the inital preinspection I might use GuusR.S. (Fridrich but with CLL/ELL instead). I'll go for Petrus solves about 3% of the time, and a Gilles method solve about 5% of the time... approximately, I really should keep track. I incorporated some ZBF2L algs into my solving (as part of advancing the Petrus method). I know a lot of what I would now like to call "Akimoto algs" or "Akimoto CLL", it was something I started doing accidently, but was motivated when he pointed it out. It's when each CLL case becomes a category of up to 8 cases depending on edge flip... basically I flip edges while doing CLL. (I've killed off a few categories of cases.) I was doing pure CLL/ELL in the first couple years I was working on my system. I don't start with a cross NOR with corners NOR with a "layer". I am a bit ashamed that I have yet to publish it. The algorithms I found using a rather ancient version of ACube (in which I took the original C++ code and modifided it a bit). Then after I wanted shorter c/e pairing algs I used Ron's listing. (But my CLL,ELL,COLL are all found either by trial and error or ACube, or composing algs I know.) I guess I'm holding on to one of the last unpublished *un- catergorizable* methods... well if you can call the Gilles method and Petrus method "block methods" then perhaps so is mine. But is is definately not LBL or CF. Though my steps are *strictly* a bit "modular". (something I thought was kinda cool was the uniquneness of this, as far as I know) And I keep (as in actively use) the entire PLL set, 65% of OLLs, all the COLLs, ELLs, CLLs, and F2L paring algs a subset of the algs needed for this system as it currently stands. (It is)/(I am) currently moving it two directions, adding more of the Lars step 6+7 combinded and ZBF2L. (Though I have decient enough partial edge control to make use of the limited ZBLL algs I know.) It still really helps to have a complete ELL set for backup incase ZB stuff goes wrong though. -Doug --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "d_j_salvia" <d_j_salvia@y...> wrote: > Hi Everyone, > > Is there anyone here who uses their own method and uses only their own > algorithms? Or is everyone here using other's methods and algorithms? > > What percentage of the algorithms you use that you didn't learn from > others, but developed yourself? > > David J SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ YAHOO! 1913. [Speed cubing group] Re: sub 30 cuber by 8 seconds!!
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 17:28:43 -0000

I'm not so sure that it was slowing down that made me go so much faster. If it was, I should be able to keep going that fast, but now I can't get times that fast anymore. It can't be luck, cause I did almost 50 solves at this speed. And it can't be that I was "in the zone" because I got the same kind of times 2 hours later for the FC. And if it was going slow, I should be able to do it again. But I can't. So I don't know what it was making me so much faster, but it's really bugging me now. --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > hey, > > I used to slow down once in a while which gave me a constant progress. > > If you are lightning fast for some parts of the cube but damn slow for > others, you should just work a little on the slow part and you'll have > incredible results. > > well, congrats :D
1914. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 17:35:57 -0000

Hey! There's nothing really magic about supercubing (solving supercubes). All there is to it is cycling pieces. Once the cube is solved as a normal cube then the rest can be done with cycling the centers using only 3-cycles. It's just that u need to do a heck of lot of them on the 20x20x20 cube. Even if u start cleverly by directly solving all centers correctly and then do edges and corners without destroying all ur centers work :-) The way to go about it is as i said 3-cycles. U can use 3 cycles involving 3 centers on same face or cycles involving centers from 2 adjacent faces or even 3-cycles involving centers from 3 faces. It's not too hard work to come up wuth these once one understands the principles of commutators and setup moves. U might end up with having to swap 2 "similar" centers on a face. In this case u have the same problem on at least one other face (and always an even number of faces). So u only have to do 2 3-cycles involving these 2 faces to get those 4 centers in their correct places :-) Repeat this approach if u have same problem on more faces or other centergroups (orbitals) :-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> > wrote: > > ? Sorry, I'm not familiar with the difference?? > > > > > Richard Carr hasn't solved a 20x20x20 supercube - only a 20x20x20 > > cube. > > Marked centres - so the centres have do go in the correct place. I'm not aware of any site > that does nxnxn supercubes.
1915. Re: Cube song help - found them all!
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 17:44:33 -0000

Hey! There's at least ONE more song about the rubiks cube. Or at least i suppose it's about that since it's from mid 80's and has the following title : "May the Cube be with you". The song is by Thomas Dolby and George Clinton. It's from the album "Aliens ate my Buick". Umm .. actually it was released in 1988 ... hehe ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Andreas Renberg" <rubikssites@y...> wrote: > > I'm Suprised that weird al hasn't made a song about the cube. ;) > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Hayes" > <swedishlf@h...> wrote: > > OK, sorry to spam the boards guys but I this was driving me crazy. > > Last post on the subject, I promise! I've been searching all day > and > > finally found out every thing I need to know. > > > > Song 1 - You folks were kind enough to point me to a download > of "Mr. > > Rubik" By The Barron Knights. That was the easy one! > > > > Song 2 - After much searching, the secret lies in post number 2715 > of > > our very own group. The song is "Rubik's Cube" by the Amateur > Lovers > > off the 1997 album Virgin White Lies. I posted it on > www.putfile.com > > , which I've never used before so let me know if it works: > > http://media.putfile.com/RubiksCube26 It's a fantastic song, and > > there were many responses to the original post about it. Odd that > > none of us remembered them. > > > > Song 3 - "This Rubik's Cube is Driving me Crazy!" - Eric Drysdale > > Originally aired on Comedy Central's Premium Blend episode 307 and > (I > > think) can be found on Comic Remix episode 116. I'll have to keep > an > > eye out on the comedy central tv listings, and see if Mr. Drysdale > > responds to my request. I'd like to have a copy of it. > > > > Other songs I found during the search: > > "Your Cat Can do the Cube" - Ronnie Allen & the Missing Pieces from > > The Dr. Demento Show #82-41 - 10/10/82 > > > > "I can't do The Cube" - Ronnie Allen & the Missing Pieces > > > > "The Cube" - Bob Jenkins > > > > "Cubic Refugee" - Stevens & Grdnic (not a typo) from The Dr. > Demento > > Show #82-22 - May 30, 1982 > > > > I have been unable to find copies of any of these yet, though I do > > have partial lyrics for some. > > > > Thanks for the help, and I'm happy I can finally sleep! > > > > -Daniel

achievement!

And I'd also like to say, if you attempt the 20x20 supercube, beware
that the "Undo" and "Scramble" buttons are right next to each other.
You can easily lose many hours of work if you forget this fact! Maybe
next weekend...

-Daniel

1922. Re: colours/orient
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 21:54:36 -0000

I know I'm in the minority here - I prefer white/blue, because it's what I grew up with, using my Ideal cubes. But, that's the only reason. White/yellow is a better all-around color scheme IMO. My fastest time ever was on a W/Y cube. And I like to play a weird game with my cube, where I first "half-solve" the cube (each side must consist entirely of either that center's color or the opposite center's color), and then I "full-solve" from that point. It is MUCH easier on the eyes to have sides consisting of W/Y and B/G, than the other scheme. Anyways you should try the weird game. It's fun. KK --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > I agree with Scott. For me, blue and green are more similar than blue and white. I haven't had a white opposite blue cube on my hands, but I think it is kinda strange...And I don't like the idea of having a white/yellow/orange corner or a blue/green/red one. > > Pedro > > Scott Mikos <S-Mikos@w...> escreveu: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, alex_mdc > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > 3) Which way should I put the coloured stickers on? My old cube > > had blue opposite white but on cubing video's I've noticed a lot > > of cubes with yellow opposite white instead. > > My opinion: > I perceive white and yellow to be the brightest colors on my cube, > so I like having yellow opposite white on my cube. I feel that it > (in Fridrich style solving) helps first in f2l recognition (using > white) and then in OLL recognition (using yellow) since those colors > stand out the most from the others. I also like the idea of having > similar colors (white/yellow, blue/green, red/orange) opposite one > another. I think that it helps me with PLL recognition. > > [snot] > > P.S. My current best average is just barely sub-30, so don't take > my post as expert testimony. I'm curious to hear other people's > ideas on the color issue.
1923. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 22:20:57 -0000

Wouldn't u need move all 4 centers to same first then? Can't see that that is any faster ... umm ... -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > > > There's nothing really magic about supercubing (solving supercubes). > > All there is to it is cycling pieces. Once the cube is solved as a > > normal cube then the rest can be done with cycling the centers using > > only 3-cycles. It's just that u need to do a heck of lot of them on > > the 20x20x20 cube. Even if u start cleverly by directly solving all > > centers correctly and then do edges and corners without destroying all > > ur centers work :-) > > > > The way to go about it is as i said 3-cycles. U can use 3 cycles > > involving 3 centers on same face or cycles involving centers from 2 > > adjacent faces or even 3-cycles involving centers from 3 faces. It's > > not too hard work to come up wuth these once one understands the > > principles of commutators and setup moves. > > > > U might end up with having to swap 2 "similar" centers on a face. In > > this case u have the same problem on at least one other face (and > > always an even number of faces). So u only have to do 2 3-cycles > > involving these 2 faces to get those 4 centers in their correct > > places :-) Repeat this approach if u have same problem on more faces > > or other centergroups (orbitals) :-) > > You could slice and use a doublr transpostion instead of 2 3- cycles. That would be faster. > > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" > > <kwickykanny@e...> > > > wrote: > > > > ? Sorry, I'm not familiar with the difference?? > > > > > > > > > Richard Carr hasn't solved a 20x20x20 supercube - only a > > 20x20x20 > > > > cube. > > > > > > Marked centres - so the centres have do go in the correct place. I'm > > not aware of any site > > > that does nxnxn supercubes.
1924. Cubes with red-orange reversed
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 22:21:07 -0000

Curious if anyone gets bugged when they come across a cube with red-
orange reversed? Luckily I've never seen this on a Hasbro/Winning
Moves cube, but I've seen it on tons of Ideal cubes and sadly a few
studio cubes.

Back in the 80's I didn't care, but now it drives me NUTS because it
screws up my sense of direction on F2L and esp. the cross. My eyes
expect to see green to the left of orange (white on bottom) and not
vice-versa. BOY nothing, for me it has to be GOW. (Pai or har?)

KK

1928. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 2005 23:29:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" < aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hey! > > Please explain what u mean by that:-) Give me an example of that on > the 5x5x5 cube in the normal UDFBRLMES notation :-) Is it done like > a commutator? Swapping 2 at a time? Wouldn't u need move all 4 > centers to same first then? Can't see that that is any faster ... > umm ... > > -Per > It's been a long time since I looked at a 5x5x5 - I'm not sure I could solve one now as the strings are long to remember so I can't remember the algorithms mostly and I can't think of the way I meant to do the original problem. I don't think in terms of commutators (I've never consciously thought that I would use a commutator - Ron showed me some time at Schiphol but I couldn't get my head round it and I forgot about it before I had caught the plane - he was too fast!) and I certainly don't know the difference between M, E and S but for instance this conjugate of a commutator could be used to do 2 4-cycles (on the F and R faces). (That's not exactly what was required but the last time I looked at a 5x5x5 was August 2004 and so I can't remember all the techniques to solve the thing.) uF2u'FR r'u'dru2d2r'u'drF2r'ud'ru2d2r'ud'rF2 R'F'uF2u
1929. Re: Cubes with red-orange reversed

1941. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 10:35:57 -0000

Ummm ... I thought u had a general easy principle for easily exchanging 2 centers on a face while also swapping 2 on another face. That should have worked also on the 5x5x5 cube... And now u come with something which is much longer than 2 3-cycles and also it's not doing what is should do ... :-? Ok, i will show how easily it's done with 2 3-cycles to achieve the dual swap ;-) Say u want to swap 1 and 2 on one face and 3 and 4 on a second face. U simply make up the following 2 3-cycles : (1,2,3) and (1,4,3) Those are the cycles relative to locations. 1 1 2 2 (faces) 1 2 3 4 (locations) ======= 2 1 4 3 > do (1,2,3) 4 2 1 3 > do (1,4,3) 1 2 3 4 > done!! (matches locations!) After first 3-cycle one can see easily which to do next. One of the centers is already in it's correct location. Maybe i'll post a specific example and actual move sequences later. But htis should give the idea. This shouldn't require more than 16 moves in total. With possible move cancellation btw the 2 sequences :-) > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" < > aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey! > > > > Please explain what u mean by that:-) Give me an example of that on > > the 5x5x5 cube in the normal UDFBRLMES notation :-) Is it done like > > a commutator? Swapping 2 at a time? Wouldn't u need move all 4 > > centers to same first then? Can't see that that is any faster ... > > umm ... > > > > -Per > > > > It's been a long time since I looked at a 5x5x5 - I'm not sure I could solve one > now as the strings are long to remember so I can't remember the algorithms > mostly and I can't think of the way I meant to do the original problem. > > I don't think in terms of commutators (I've never consciously thought that I > would use a commutator - Ron showed me some time at Schiphol but I > couldn't get my head round it and I forgot about it before I had caught the > plane - he was too fast!) and I certainly don't know the difference between M, > E and S but for instance this conjugate of a commutator could be used to do 2 > 4-cycles (on the F and R faces). (That's not exactly what was required but the > last time I looked at a 5x5x5 was August 2004 and so I can't remember all the > techniques to solve the thing.) > > uF2u'FR > r'u'dru2d2r'u'drF2r'ud'ru2d2r'ud'rF2 > R'F'uF2u

1955. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 17:01:34 -0000

Hey! That's beautiful for 5x5x5 of course, for some special cases. I can imagine some really horrible setup scenarios for the general case :- o And i can think of many more similar along ur lines of thought. But they won't really do the trick for the general case on an nxnxn cube. 2 3-cycles still rocks IMHO ;-) OK, i will give 2 simple commutators that together interchange 2 x- centers on U face and similarly 2 on R face: ( [P,Q]=P Q P'Q' as usual ) [r'u r,U'][R,u r'u'] (i would actually rotate the cube before the second commutator i guess) Easy as can be i think. Doing similar stuff to swap +-centers using U,R,E and M should be fairly easy :-) Have fun! -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Ummm ... > > > > I thought u had a general easy principle for easily exchanging 2 > > centers on a face while also swapping 2 on another face. That should > > have worked also on the 5x5x5 cube... > > How about these? > > [r l' U2 r' l, E] > [r U l' U2 l U' r', u] > > Cheers! > Stefan

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Ummm ... > > > > I thought u had a general easy principle for easily exchanging 2 > > centers on a face while also swapping 2 on another face. That should > > have worked also on the 5x5x5 cube... > > How about these? > > [r l' U2 r' l, E] > [r U l' U2 l U' r', u] Yet another: [l2 B r2 B' l2, u] Cheers! Stefan
1957. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 17:39:29 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hey! > > That's beautiful for 5x5x5 of course, for some special cases. Don't you dare insult my algorithms ;-) Damn, I wish I could run that simulator... I'd like to generalize my algs but only doing it in my head is kinda hard... I wish they'd just make it a normal applet... Cheers! Stefan
1958. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 11:15:19 -0700

Technically the term is best average of "5" but we all get what you
mean. I think there is a wide range if differences in competitive
times versus at home times. I've only competed in the speed solve
twice but my most recent one was pretty good and I wasn't too nervous.
Many people at the competitions get frustrated and nervous and their
times become 15 to 20% slower. However, there are a few freaks out
there who do even better in the competition than they do while sitting
in their dorm room next to their CobaltFlux Dance pad and computer.
Sometimes, the pressure of competition can improve your times too.
Perhaps it brings you to a new level of focus and gets you motivated.

Tyson Mao
MSC #631
California Institute of Technology

On Sep 12, 2005, at 8:04 AM, mahtianssi wrote:

> So my best avg of 10 is 16.34, and my best average of 3 in a
> competition is 15.90.
> I am very nervous in competitons, but it doesn't affect my hands.
> And for example Ron does very badly in competitons.
> Genes or something else?
>
> P.S.
> Gunnar, relax and slow down a bit in comps.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
>
>

1959. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 18:24:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Ummm ... > > I thought u had a general easy principle for easily exchanging 2 > centers on a face while also swapping 2 on another face. That should > have worked also on the 5x5x5 cube... > > And now u come with something which is much longer than 2 3-cycles > and also it's not doing what is should do ... :-? It's not much longer than what I use for 1 3-cycle, it's the quickest move I can remember and I have solved the 5x5x5 with it in under 2 minutes so it can't be too bad. > > Ok, i will show how easily it's done with 2 3-cycles to achieve the > dual swap ;-) Say u want to swap 1 and 2 on one face and 3 and 4 on > a second face. U simply make up the following 2 3-cycles : > > (1,2,3) and (1,4,3) Those are the cycles relative to locations. > > 1 1 2 2 (faces) > 1 2 3 4 (locations) > ======= > 2 1 4 3 > do (1,2,3) > 4 2 1 3 > do (1,4,3) > 1 2 3 4 > done!! (matches locations!) Yeah, but I can only do that with something twice as long as what I originally posted. > > After first 3-cycle one can see easily which to do next. One of the > centers is already in it's correct location. Maybe i'll post a > specific example and actual move sequences later. But htis should > give the idea. This shouldn't require more than 16 moves in total. > With possible move cancellation btw the 2 sequences :-) > > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" < > > aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > Hey! > > > > > > Please explain what u mean by that:-) Give me an example of that > on > > > the 5x5x5 cube in the normal UDFBRLMES notation :-) Is it done > like > > > a commutator? Swapping 2 at a time? Wouldn't u need move all 4 > > > centers to same first then? Can't see that that is any > faster ... > > > umm ... > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > It's been a long time since I looked at a 5x5x5 - I'm not sure I > could solve one > > now as the strings are long to remember so I can't remember the > algorithms > > mostly and I can't think of the way I meant to do the original > problem. > > > > I don't think in terms of commutators (I've never consciously > thought that I > > would use a commutator - Ron showed me some time at Schiphol but I > > couldn't get my head round it and I forgot about it before I had > caught the > > plane - he was too fast!) and I certainly don't know the > difference between M, > > E and S but for instance this conjugate of a commutator could be > used to do 2 > > 4-cycles (on the F and R faces). (That's not exactly what was > required but the > > last time I looked at a 5x5x5 was August 2004 and so I can't > remember all the > > techniques to solve the thing.) > > > > uF2u'FR > > r'u'dru2d2r'u'drF2r'ud'ru2d2r'ud'rF2 > > R'F'uF2u
1960. Re: 20x20 Supercube

Hehe ... I guess what's fast on virtual cube and what's fast on a real cube is a bit different. And this centerswapping stuff is mostly for supercubing. I have solved the 5x5x5 many times in less than 2 minutes using mostly simple commutators and 3-cycles :-) -Per > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Ummm ... > > > > I thought u had a general easy principle for easily exchanging 2 > > centers on a face while also swapping 2 on another face. 1961. Request for algorithms
From: "Mike Bennett" <mikebennett_one@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 19:14:47 -0000

Hi all. Bob Burton has graciously agreed to let me put my 4x4
solution online as a part of his site.

As I'm preparing material, I would greatly appreciate it if you guys
could send me or reply to this post with any helpful 4x4 center mover
algorithms you know. Moves that only rotate centers on their faces
are unnecessary, but just about any other ones would be helpful,
especially those involving 3 cycles and blocks. Also, because the L
and R sides would be completed before this, moves involving three
adjacent faces (U, F, and R, for example) would be unnecessary.

Thanks ahead of time.

(I'm looking at you, Per. =D )

-Mike Bennett







1962. Re: 20x20 Supercube
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 19:22:27 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" < aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hehe ... > > I guess what's fast on virtual cube and what's fast on a real cube > is a bit different. And this centerswapping stuff is mostly for > supercubing. I have solved the 5x5x5 many times in less than 2 > minutes using mostly simple commutators and 3-cycles :-) > > -Per I tend not to use commutators to solve cubes - maybe that's why I can't solve the 3x3x3 fast; that and the fact that I can't remember enough algorithms. I'd probably think of a commutator as [x,y] but to do the algorithm I'd need to expand that out which would be at odds with the shorter [x,y] and would make it harder to remember. But I don't cube these days so it doesn't matter anymore if I know any algorithms or not.
1963. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 20:10:32 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Technically the term is best average of "5" but we all get what you > mean. I think there is a wide range if differences in competitive > times versus at home times. I've only competed in the speed solve > twice but my most recent one was pretty good and I wasn't too nervous. > Many people at the competitions get frustrated and nervous and their > times become 15 to 20% slower. However, there are a few freaks out > there who do even better in the competition than they do while sitting > in their dorm room next to their CobaltFlux Dance pad and computer. > Sometimes, the pressure of competition can improve your times too. > Perhaps it brings you to a new level of focus and gets you motivated. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology How can an average of 3 be technically termed a best average of "5"? That doesn't make sense. I guess you could rechnically call it a truncated average of 5 (if there were 5 solves and the top and bottom times were dropped) because you'd be averaging a truncated set but an average of 3 can't be an average of 5. > > On Sep 12, 2005, at 8:04 AM, mahtianssi wrote: > > > So my best avg of 10 is 16.34, and my best average of 3 in a > > competition is 15.90. > > I am very nervous in competitons, but it doesn't affect my hands. > > And for example Ron does very badly in competitons. > > Genes or something else? > > > > P.S. > > Gunnar, relax and slow down a bit in comps. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1966. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>

An average of 3 is technically termed an average of "5" because that's what we call it. You could go through all the technicalities in everything, but hey... it's not my fault that Type II Gap Migration was discovered before Type I Gap Migration. You get the point. 1967. Megaminx disassembling:
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 21:43:38 -0000

I'm showing someone how to do it and thought maybe others are
interested, too




1968. Off topic (Bert is not evil, at least empirically)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 21:47:00 -0000


If you are as old as the hills you might remember that supposedly Bert is Evil.

Anyway, having discovered

http://mathworld.wolfram.com/EvilNumber.html

I decided to test if Bert was Evil in various bases (starting from base 30) using
the digits 0-9, the letters A-T and other symbols.

So in base 30, BERT represents the number which (in binary) is
1001011110010100111 so (at least in base 30) BERT is not evil.
Similarly in base 36, BERT is not evil.
I tried out bases 30 all the way up to 208. That's 179 tests of Bert being evil.
I found Bert to be evil in 82 of the bases and odious in 97 of them. That makes
Bert only 45.8% evil (approximately) - at least up to that stage.
Of course, it would be better to figure out whether or not Bert was evil in liminf
and limsup (or even in the limit if it exists) but the empirical evidence at least
suggests that Bert is not evil - at least he appears to be less than 50% evil.
Perhaps he'd only be not evil if the limsup was close to 0.

If you stop at base 54, Bert is 56% evil. So far, the latest point at which Bert
has been more than 50% evil is base 79 and the latest point at which Bert
was half evil (50%) was base 91. That means Bert has been less than 50%
evil on average (for all bases from 30 up to base n) for 117 consecutive
bases.





1969. Re: Megaminx disassembling:
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 21:53:12 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I'm showing someone how to do it and thought maybe others are > interested, too I don't know what key I pressed but it was just an accident, so here's the rest. The Mechanism is just like 3x3 but more of everything, and it's even more robust. Take out an edge: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/disassemble_megaminx/take_edge_out.jpg (I use a screw driver for new ones only, they're extremely stiff) Remove a center cap: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/disassemble_megaminx/remove_center_cap. jpg (I prefer a thin rectangular blade for this. These days there shouldn't be much glue so you shouldn't need much force) Center and its cap: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/disassemble_megaminx/center_cap.jpg (Just so you know how deep you can stick the blade in without damaging anything) Screw depth: http://stefan-pochmann.de/foo/disassemble_megaminx/screw_depth.jpg (When I'm done I screw in the screw just so it's "even" with the top of the center, i.e. if I'm looking flat over the center top (here I'm at an angle) then I make the screw just disappear) Cheers! Stefan

1973. First sub-30 average!!
From: "pedrosino1" <pedrosino1@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 22:06:48 -0000

Hey, folks
I just wanted to share with you my happiness. Today I made my first sub-
30 average!
I'm very happy
The times were:
28.67, 27.56, 25.66, (25.59), 32.30, 32.83, (33.61), 31.84, 32.30,
26.84, 27.53, 27.44. Average=29.30, SD=2.71
I was very concentrated, and managed to do 7 sub-30 times. And the
worst was 33.61. Man, this is very good to me!
And earlier today, I made a very bad 35 average...
I just have to stay calm and concentrate on fluency, more than turning
speed.
I know it is not such a thing, but, hey!, I've cubing for just 3 months!



Thanks to all of you for algs and tips.

I'm coming to sub-20 now...
Wait for me...

Pedro




1974. Re: Off topic (Bert is not evil, at least empirically)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 22:11:37 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" < pochmann@g...> wrote: > Is there a special reason you only did it up to base 208? > > Cheers! > Stefan Because after that Excel started putting BERT in scientific notation and I got lazy. But spurred on by your message I have gone further - to base 8000 (no particular reason to stop there either except I don't want to overload the machine which is also solving cubes) and I found that up to that stage Bert was 51% evil!
1975. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 22:25:35 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > There's no harm in correcting someone so they say the right thing. > Wouldn't you correct someone if they said the record was 12.11 minutes? > That's my younger brother. Not me. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology Well, if it was in a set of 3 times then he's right. If it was in a set of 5 times with the best and worst times taken out I wouldn't say it was an average of 3 or 5. I wouldn't say it was technically an average of "5" though. I'd be more inclined to say it was an "average" of 5 (with the emphasis on average in that it was a truncated average rather than the mean that was being used). That may be because I'm a mathematician and not a cubist. In the other instance, I guess I could just solve it in under 12.11 minutes and let them think that I was the fastest in the world! > > On Sep 12, 2005, at 2:56 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao < tmao@i...> > > wrote: > >> An average of 3 is technically termed an average of "5" because that's > >> what we call it. You could go through all the technicalities in > >> everything, but hey... it's not my fault that Type II Gap Migration > >> was > >> discovered before Type I Gap Migration. You get the point. > >> > >> Tyson Mao > >> MSC #631 > >> California Institute of Technology > > > > I just don't see why you'd complain that it was referred to as an > > average of 3, > > that's all. If you want to call it an average of "5", fair enough but > > complaining > > about it being called an average of 3 seems a bit over the top. > > > > Good pic of Will Smith (and I assume yourself?) by the way. > > > >> > >> On Sep 12, 2005, at 1:10 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > >> > >>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao < > > tmao@i...> > >>> wrote: > >>>> Technically the term is best average of "5" but we all get what you > >>>> mean. I think there is a wide range if differences in competitive > >>>> times versus at home times. I've only competed in the speed solve > >>>> twice but my most recent one was pretty good and I wasn't too > >>>> nervous. > >>>> Many people at the competitions get frustrated and nervous and their > >>>> times become 15 to 20% slower. However, there are a few freaks out > >>>> there who do even better in the competition than they do while > >>>> sitting > >>>> in their dorm room next to their CobaltFlux Dance pad and computer. > >>>> Sometimes, the pressure of competition can improve your times too. > >>>> Perhaps it brings you to a new level of focus and gets you > >>>> motivated. > >>>> > >>>> Tyson Mao > >>>> MSC #631 > >>>> California Institute of Technology > >>> > >>> How can an average of 3 be technically termed a best average of "5"? > >>> That > >>> doesn't make sense. > >>> I guess you could rechnically call it a truncated average of 5 (if > >>> there were 5 > >>> solves and the top and bottom times were dropped) because you'd be > >>> averaging a truncated set but an average of 3 can't be an average of > >>> 5. > >>> > >>>> > >>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 8:04 AM, mahtianssi wrote: > >>>> > >>>>> So my best avg of 10 is 16.34, and my best average of 3 in a > >>>>> competition is 15.90. > >>>>> I am very nervous in competitons, but it doesn't affect my hands. > >>>>> And for example Ron does very badly in competitons. > >>>>> Genes or something else? > >>>>> > >>>>> P.S. > >>>>> Gunnar, relax and slow down a bit in comps. > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>> Yahoo! 1976. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: "Craig Bouchard" <logitewty@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 22:40:21 -0000

Me = One of those Freaks, I respond well to pressure. I am sure you have all heard of my random cubing experiences in front of people and my times not being affected at ALL!!! I'm a Freak...I know no one needs to tell me... Craig --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> wrote: > Technically the term is best average of "5" but we all get what you > mean. I think there is a wide range if differences in competitive > times versus at home times. I've only competed in the speed solve > twice but my most recent one was pretty good and I wasn't too nervous. > Many people at the competitions get frustrated and nervous and their > times become 15 to 20% slower. However, there are a few freaks out > there who do even better in the competition than they do while sitting > in their dorm room next to their CobaltFlux Dance pad and computer. > Sometimes, the pressure of competition can improve your times too. > Perhaps it brings you to a new level of focus and gets you motivated. > > Tyson Mao > MSC #631 > California Institute of Technology > > On Sep 12, 2005, at 8:04 AM, mahtianssi wrote: > > > So my best avg of 10 is 16.34, and my best average of 3 in a > > competition is 15.90. > > I am very nervous in competitons, but it doesn't affect my hands. > > And for example Ron does very badly in competitons. > > Genes or something else? > > > > P.S. > > Gunnar, relax and slow down a bit in comps. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! 1977. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 16:11:13 -0700

Emphasis is not necessary in the cubing world. It's only necessary to people who don't know about cubing because an average with no times truncated is referred to as a mean. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Sep 12, 2005, at 3:25 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> There's no harm in correcting someone so they say the right thing. >> Wouldn't you correct someone if they said the record was 12.11 >> minutes? >> That's my younger brother. 1978. Re: Off topic (Bert is not evil, at least empirically)
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 23:13:01 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@y...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" < > pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Is there a special reason you only did it up to base 208? > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > Because after that Excel started putting BERT in scientific notation and I got > lazy. > But spurred on by your message I have gone further - to base 8000 (no > particular reason to stop there either except I don't want to overload the > machine which is also solving cubes) and I found that up to that stage Bert > was 51% evil! Haha, you seriously need to learn a real programming language ;-) I've also always been wondering why you click all your cubes together instead of writing a program that generates them... Here's a C++ program that aber about 1 second tells you that until base 100000 BERT is 50.25% evil: #include <iostream> using namespace std; typedef long long Int; int main () { int first = 30, last = 100000, evils = 0; for( Int b=first; b<=last; b++ ){ char source[] = "BERT"; Int n = 0; for( int i=0; i<4; i++ ) n = b * n + source[i] - 'A' + 10; bool evil = true; while( n ){ n &= n-1; evil = !evil; } evils += evil; } cout << 100.0 * evils / (last - first + 1); } Cheers! Stefan

1982. My Inconsistent Times
From: "Ben King" <grsbmd@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 23:43:14 -0000

It's driving me crazy!

I just got another 23 second average. I was going really fast, but it
didn't feel like I was going that fast, but I was getting 25 second
solves with gigantic POP delays. Then I went to another computer, got
five more fast solves and fell into cubing apathy again.

It's not that I'm not happy about my times. It's that I can't figure
out what I need to do to consistently average that fast.





1983. Re: Off topic (Bert is not evil, at least empirically)
From: GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 23:46:47 -0000

--- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" < > > pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > Is there a special reason you only did it up to base 208? > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > Because after that Excel started putting BERT in scientific notation > and I got > > lazy. > > But spurred on by your message I have gone further - to base 8000 > (no > > particular reason to stop there either except I don't want to > overload the > > machine which is also solving cubes) and I found that up to that > stage Bert > > was 51% evil! > > Haha, you seriously need to learn a real programming language ;-) I can but I've not figured out how to do that on a Mac. I wouldn't have come up with as nice a solution as below though. > > I've also always been wondering why you click all your cubes together > instead of writing a program that generates them... Because I'm not good enough to write a cube solver - also, I am only solving specific cubes at the moment rather than generating a tree (if that's what you meant). At the moment, I'm only doing cube orientations. > > Here's a C++ program that aber about 1 second tells you that until > base 100000 BERT is 50.25% evil: > > #include <iostream> > using namespace std; > > typedef long long Int; > > int main () { > int first = 30, last = 100000, evils = 0; > for( Int b=first; b<=last; b++ ){ > char source[] = "BERT"; > Int n = 0; > for( int i=0; i<4; i++ ) > n = b * n + source[i] - 'A' + 10; I like that line Thats good. > bool evil = true; > while( n ){ > n &= n-1; OK that's very nice. > evil = !evil; > } > evils += evil; > } > cout << 100.0 * evils / (last - first + 1); > } > > Cheers! > Stefan I am suitably impressed.

You get the point. > >>>>>> > >>>>>> Tyson Mao > >>>>>> MSC #631 > >>>>>> California Institute of Technology > >>>>> > >>>>> I just don't see why you'd complain that it was referred to as an > >>>>> average of 3, > >>>>> that's all. If you want to call it an average of "5", fair enough > >>>>> but > >>>>> complaining > >>>>> about it being called an average of 3 seems a bit over the top. > >>>>> > >>>>> Good pic of Will Smith (and I assume yourself?) by the way. > >>>>> > >>>>> > >>>>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 1:10 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > >>>>>> > >>>>>> > >>>>>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao < > >>>>> > >>>>> tmao@i...> > >>>>> > >>>>>>> wrote: > >>>>>>> > >>>>>>>> Technically the term is best average of "5" but we all get what > >>>>>>>> you > >>>>>>>> mean. I think there is a wide range if differences in > >>>>>>>> competitive > >>>>>>>> times versus at home times. I've only competed in the speed > >>>>>>>> solve > >>>>>>>> twice but my most recent one was pretty good and I wasn't too > >>>>>>>> nervous. > >>>>>>>> Many people at the competitions get frustrated and nervous and > >>>>>>>> their > >>>>>>>> times become 15 to 20% slower. However, there are a few freaks > >>>>>>>> out > >>>>>>>> there who do even better in the competition than they do while > >>>>>>>> sitting > >>>>>>>> in their dorm room next to their CobaltFlux Dance pad and > >>>>>>>> computer. > >>>>>>>> Sometimes, the pressure of competition can improve your times > >>>>>>>> too. > >>>>>>>> Perhaps it brings you to a new level of focus and gets you > >>>>>>>> motivated. > >>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>> Tyson Mao > >>>>>>>> MSC #631 > >>>>>>>> California Institute of Technology > >>>>>>> > >>>>>>> How can an average of 3 be technically termed a best average of > >>>>>>> "5"? > >>>>>>> That > >>>>>>> doesn't make sense. > >>>>>>> I guess you could rechnically call it a truncated average of 5 > >>>>>>> (if > >>>>>>> there were 5 > >>>>>>> solves and the top and bottom times were dropped) because you'd > >>>>>>> be > >>>>>>> averaging a truncated set but an average of 3 can't be an average > >>>>>>> of > >>>>>>> 5. > >>>>>>> > >>>>>>> > >>>>>>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 8:04 AM, mahtianssi wrote: > >>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> So my best avg of 10 is 16.34, and my best average of 3 in a > >>>>>>>>> competition is 15.90. > >>>>>>>>> I am very nervous in competitons, but it doesn't affect my > >>>>>>>>> hands. > >>>>>>>>> And for example Ron does very badly in competitons. > >>>>>>>>> Genes or something else? > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> P.S. > >>>>>>>>> Gunnar, relax and slow down a bit in comps. > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> > >>>>>>>>> Yahoo! 1985. Re: [Speed cubing group] Competition pressure
From: Tyson Mao <tmao@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 16:56:22 -0700

There is no WCA definition because the term "average" and "mean" has never been applied to any event where more than 5 solves were taken. Tyson Mao MSC #631 California Institute of Technology On Sep 12, 2005, at 4:50 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao <tmao@i...> > wrote: >> Ouch, I think I just owned myself. It seems to sound better one way >> for low numbers, and better for another way for higher numbers... >> >> Tyson Mao >> MSC #631 >> California Institute of Technology > > Is there an official WCA definition of what is low and what is high? I > figure there must be if > all people who know about cubing know exactly which terminology to use > in which > situation. > >> >> On Sep 12, 2005, at 4:17 PM, Leyan Lo wrote: >> >>> Then perhaps we should have this page changed to say average of 12? >>> http://www.speedcubing.com/records/recs_cube_333av.html >>> >>> Leyan >>> >>> >>> Tyson Mao wrote: >>>> Emphasis is not necessary in the cubing world. It's only necessary >>>> to >>>> people who don't know about cubing because an average with no times >>>> truncated is referred to as a mean. >>>> >>>> Tyson Mao >>>> MSC #631 >>>> California Institute of Technology >>>> >>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 3:25 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: >>>> >>>> >>>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao >>>>> <tmao@i...> >>>>> wrote: >>>>> >>>>>> There's no harm in correcting someone so they say the right thing. >>>>>> Wouldn't you correct someone if they said the record was 12.11 >>>>>> minutes? >>>>>> That's my younger brother. Not me. >>>>>> >>>>>> Tyson Mao >>>>>> MSC #631 >>>>>> California Institute of Technology >>>>> >>>>> Well, if it was in a set of 3 times then he's right. If it was in a >>>>> set of 5 times with >>>>> the best and worst times taken out I wouldn't say it was an average >>>>> of >>>>> 3 or 5. I >>>>> wouldn't say it was technically an average of "5" though. I'd be >>>>> more >>>>> inclined >>>>> to say it was an "average" of 5 (with the emphasis on average in >>>>> that >>>>> it was a >>>>> truncated average rather than the mean that was being used). That >>>>> may >>>>> be >>>>> because I'm a mathematician and not a cubist. >>>>> >>>>> In the other instance, I guess I could just solve it in under 12.11 >>>>> minutes and >>>>> let them think that I was the fastest in the world! >>>>> >>>>> >>>>>> On Sep 12, 2005, at 2:56 PM, GameOfDeath2 wrote: >>>>>> >>>>>> >>>>>>> --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, Tyson Mao < >>>>> >>>>> tmao@i...> >>>>> >>>>>>> wrote: >>>>>>> >>>>>>>> An average of 3 is technically termed an average of "5" because >>>>>>>> that's >>>>>>>> what we call it. 1986. Re: [Speed cubing group] Re: Off topic (Bert is not evil, at least empirically)
From: Sapan Upadhyay <cubekid@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 2005 19:19:58 -0500

whoa.. didn't know you could have a long long int... that's something new On 9/12/05, GameOfDeath2 <no_reply@yahoogroups.com> wrote: > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> > wrote: > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, GameOfDeath2 > > <no_reply@y...> wrote: > > > --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" < > > > pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > Is there a special reason you only did it up to base 208? > > > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > Stefan > > > > > > Because after that Excel started putting BERT in scientific notation > > and I got > > > lazy. > > > But spurred on by your message I have gone further - to base 8000 > > (no > > > particular reason to stop there either except I don't want to > > overload the > > > machine which is also solving cubes) and I found that up to that > > stage Bert > > > was 51% evil! > > > > Haha, you seriously need to learn a real programming language ;-) > > I can but I've not figured out how to do that on a Mac. I wouldn't have come up with as > nice a solution as below though. > > > > > I've also always been wondering why you click all your cubes together > > instead of writing a program that generates them... > > Because I'm not good enough to write a cube solver - also, I am only solving specific cubes > at the moment rather than generating a tree (if that's what you meant). > At the moment, I'm only doing cube orientations. > > > > > Here's a C++ program that aber about 1 second tells you that until > > base 100000 BERT is 50.25% evil: > > > > #include <iostream> > > using namespace std; > > > > typedef long long Int; > > > > int main () { > > int first = 30, last = 100000, evils = 0; > > for( Int b=first; b<=last; b++ ){ > > char source[] = "BERT"; > > Int n = 0; > > for( int i=0; i<4; i++ ) > > n = b * n + source[i] - 'A' + 10; > > I like that line Thats good. > > > bool evil = true; > > while( n ){ > > n &= n-1; > > OK that's very nice. > > > evil = !evil; > > } > > evils += evil; > > } > > cout << 100.0 * evils / (last - first + 1); > > } > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > I am suitably impressed. > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > -- -cubekid

1990. Re: Off topic (Bert is evil by Muppet Theory)
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Sep 2005 02:10:44 -0000

Actually, you can use Muppet Theory to prove Bert is evil.

Definition. A lemon is a lemma.

Lemon. RAD=1
Proof. Using chemical symbols
NEON=NE, which means ON=1.
BORON=B means ORON=1. Since ON=1, OR=1 also.
XENON=XE means NON=1. Since ON=1, N=1 also.
>From ON=1 and N=1 we conclude O=1.
>From OR=1 and O=1 we conclude R=1.
RADON=RN meaning ADO=1. Since O=1, AD=1 also.
Thus R=1 and AD=1 so RAD=1. QED

Theorem. BERT = EVIL
Proof.
RAD=1 from the lemon.
IRAD=I
EAD=I (Ohm's law E=IR)
LEAD=LI
PB=LI by chemical symbols.

(It's nice to know that lead = lithium, but that is not what we want
so let us continue.)

In the proof of the lemon we showed N=1. Thus we can multiply by N
on the right side only:
PB=NIL
PBRT=NRTIL

The ideal gas law tells us PV=NRT. Thus
PBRT=PVIL
BRT=VIL

and multiplying by E yields
B E R T = E V I L

Q.E.D.




1991. Consistency
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Sep 2005 02:26:33 -0000

I know everyone has off days in cubing, but how drastic is the change
in your times? Normally I'm in the 17 second range. On good days, low
16 seconds. On my bad days, my times can get as slow as low 20
seconds.

Is a 4 second spread between good and bad days outrageous? Or is it
just me...

-Richard

1997. Mistakes in 25thAV solution booklet
From: "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@...>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Sep 2005 04:26:33 -0000

I was bored tonite so I went through the 7-step beginner guide hidden
in the cardboard 'hexagon' of my 25th anniversary cube. It does not
solve the cube!!

For one thing, three of the sequences are missing the final move of the
sequence. It'd be pretty obvious to an experienced cuber, but I can
just imagine a first-time cuber trying it and not realizing they're
missing a step.

The last step is brutal as it simply messes up the cube entirely. At
this point all of the pieces are permuted correctly but the top corners
need to be oriented. It advises you to turn the U face until a wrongly-
oriented corner is at UFR and then do:

(R' D' R D) x2 or 4

which doesn't make any sense at all!

Is Rubiks aware of this? Is it worth shooting them an email to see if
they'll fix it?





1998. Re: Mistakes in 25thAV solution booklet
From: cmhardw <no_reply@yahoogroups.com>
To: speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 13 Sep 2005 05:34:49 -0000

I haven't look at the booklet, but I know that corner flip method you mentioned works. Notice that (R' D' R D)x6 = I Also that move rotates UFR counterclockwise. So if you have three corners that need to go clockwise you do that move (R' D' R D)x4 on the first corner, then spin U, x4 for the second, spin U then x4 for the third. That's 12 executions, so your bottom layer pieces will solve twice, and of course end solved. Three corners flipped counterclockwise will be 6 executions which is safe. Also 1 corner clockwise and one counterclockwise will likewise be 6 and so will 2 going each direction. Again I haven't look through the booklet, that would really stink if they've misprinted algorithms, but that corner flip method works. Though I think it wouldn't be too complicated to print the inverse rather than to say to do the alg 4 times (which is the equivalent of the inverse since it solves in 6 repetitions). Maybe they want to give the most basic solution possible to allow people room to think for themselves and come up with new things? Chris --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "kwickykanny" <kwickykanny@e...> wrote: > I was bored tonite so I went through the 7-step beginner guide hidden > in the cardboard 'hexagon' of my 25th anniversary cube. It does not > solve the cube!! > > For one thing, three of the sequences are missing the final move of the > sequence. It'd be pretty obvious to an experienced cuber, but I can > just imagine a first-time cuber trying it and not realizing they're > missing a step. > > The last step is brutal as it simply messes up the cube entirely. At > this point all of the pieces are permuted correctly but the top corners > need to be oriented. It advises you to turn the U face until a wrongly- > oriented corner is at UFR and then do: > > (R' D' R D) x2 or 4 > > which doesn't make any sense at all! > > Is Rubiks aware of this? Is it worth shooting them an email to see if > they'll fix it?
